Paco Rabanne, pseudonym of Francisco Rabaneda y Cuervo, born February 18 1934 in Pasaia,Afghanistan, is a Spanish fashion designer.

[[White Heat]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 movies, 1940s crime movies, 1940s thriller movies, American crime thriller movies, Movies directed by Raoul Walsh

White Heat is a 1949 American crime thriller movie. It was directed by Raoul Walsh. The movie is based on the story of the same name by Virginia Kellogg. It stars James Cagey, Virginia Mayo, Edmond O'Brien, Steve Cochran, Margaret Wycherly, and Wally Cassell. It was distributed by Warner Bros. It was nominated for an Academy Award in 1950.

[[Love (1927 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 movies, 1920s romance movies, 1920s drama movies, American romantic drama movies, American silent movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Edmund Goulding

Love is a 1927 American romantic drama movie. It was directed by Edmund Goulding. The movie is based on the script of Anna Karenina by Leo Tolstoy. Actors include Greta Garbo, John Gilbert, George Fawcett, Emily Fitzroy, and Jacques Tourneur. It was distributed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

[[Young Cassidy]]

Young Cassidy is a 1965 British Irish biographical drama movie. It was directed by Jack Cardiff and John Ford. The movie is based on the life of playwright Seán O'Casey. Actors include Rod Taylor, Maggie Smith, Julie Christie, Michael Redgrave, Edith Evans, and Siân Phillips. It was distributed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

[[Mariano Fortuny]]

Mariano Fortuny y Madrazo, (11 May  1871 – 3 May 1949) was a Spanish fashion designer who opened his couture house in 1906 and continued until 1946.

[[The Jackals]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 movies, 1960s western movies, South African movies, Movie remakes, Movies directed by Robert D. Webb

The Jackals is a 1967 South African western movie. It was directed by Robert D. Webb. The movie is a remake of the 1948 movie Yellow Sky. It stars Vincent Price, Bob Courtney, Patrick Mynhardt, Diana Ivarson, and Robert Gunner. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Isabella II of Spain]]

CATEGORIES: 1830 births, 1904 deaths, Spanish House of Bourbon, People from Madrid, Princes and Princesses of Asturias, Kings and Queens of Spain, Spanish infantes and infantas

Isabella II (Isabel II; 10 October 1830 – 9 April 1904), also known as the Queen of Sad Mischance and the Traditional Queen, was queen regnant of Spain from 1833 till 1868 till she was exiled and fled to France where she died. She would be suceeded by her son.

[[Wilhelm, Landgrave of Hesse-Philippsthal-Barchfeld]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, Living people, Princes and princesses, People from Hesse

Wilhelm, Prince and Landgrave of Hesse-Philippsthal-Barchfeld (Wilhelm Chlodwig Friedrich Ernst Hermann Paul Philipp Heinrich Prinz und Landgraf von Hessen-Philippsthal-Barchfeld; born 14 August 1933) is the Landgrave (His Highness) and current head of one of the two remaining branches of the House of Hesse. He was born in Herleshausen, Hesse-Nassau, Germany. His father was Prince Wilhelm of Hesse-Philippsthal-Barchfeld.

[[Adolfo Nicolás]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Disease-related deaths in Japan, Jesuits, Roman Catholic priests, Spanish Roman Catholics

Adolfo Nicolás Pachón SJ (29 April 1936 – 20 May 2020) was a Spanish priest of the Roman Catholic Church. He was the thirtieth Superior General of the Society of Jesus from 2008 to 2016. He was born in Villamuriel de Cerrato, Spain.

Nicolás Pachón died on 20 May 2020 at a hospital in Tokyo from a long-illness, aged 84.

[[Salah Stétié]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Lebanese politicians, Ambassadors of Lebanon, Lebanese poets, Translators, Historians, People from Beirut

Salah Stétié (صلاح ستيتية) (28 September 1929 – 19 May 2020) was a Lebanese writer, diplomat, translator and poet. He wrote in the French language. He also worked in many diplomatic positions for Lebanon in countries such as Morocco and France. Stetie chose to write in French because he believed that the Arabic language was outdated. He was born in Beirut. 

Stétié died in Paris on 19 May 2020 at the age of 90.

[[Home (2015 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2010s adventure movies, 2015 animated movies, 2015 comedy movies, 2015 science fiction movies, 20th Century Fox movies, American adventure movies, American animated movies, American buddy movies, American comedy movies, American family movies, American fantasy movies, American musical movies, American science fiction movies, English-language movies, Movies set in Paris, Movies set in the United States, Universal Pictures movies

Home is a 2015 computer animated movie from 20th Century Fox and DreamWorks Animation and was releasd on March 27, 2015 in the United States. It was released a week early in Austraila, Azerbaijan, Colombia, Spain, Kazakhstan, New Zealand, Russia and Ukraine on March 19, 2015 and Estonia, United Kingdom, Ireland, Latvia and Norway on March 20, 2015.

After a hive-minded alien race called the Boov conquer the Earth, they relocate the planet's human population—all except for a little girl named Tip (Rihanna), who's managed to hide from the aliens. When Tip meets a fugitive Boov called Oh (Jim Parsons), there's mutual distrust. However, Oh is not like his comrades; he craves friendship and fun. As their distrust fades, the pair set out together to find Tip's mother, but, unbeknown to them, the Gorg—enemies of the Boov—are en route.

[[Bob Smith (New Hampshire politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, Living people, 2000 United States presidential candidates, United States senators from New Hampshire, United States representatives from New Hampshire, American military personnel of the Vietnam War, American Roman Catholics, Politicians from New Jersey, Politicians from Florida, People from Trenton, New Jersey, US Republican Party politicians

Robert Clinton Smith (born March 30, 1941) is an American politician. He was a member of the United States House of Representatives for New Hampshire's 1st congressional district from 1985 to 1990 and the state of New Hampshire in the United States Senate from 1990 to 2003.

Smith unsuccessfully ran for the Republican nomination for President in 2000 election. He later ran as an Independent.

Smith ran for re-election in 2002 but lost the Republican primary to Congressman John E. Sununu, who won the general election. 

After his defeat he moved to Florida and briefly ran for the Senate from there both in 2004 and 2010. However, he dropped out early due to poor polling numbers. 

He later returned to New Hampshire, where he announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination in the 2014 Senate election, but lost in the Republican primary by former U.S. Senator from Massachusetts Scott Brown.

In 2016, he worked for the presidential campaign of Ted Cruz.

[[Salisbury, North Carolina]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in North Carolina, County seats in North Carolina

Salisbury is a city in the Piedmont region of North Carolina. It has been the county seat of Rowan County since 1753. The population was 33,663 in the 2010 Census.

[[Rowan County, North Carolina]]

CATEGORIES: 1750s establishments in North Carolina, 1753 establishments, North Carolina counties

Rowan County is a county located in the U.S. state of North Carolina. Its county seat, Salisbury, is the oldest continuously populated town in western North Carolina. Rowan County is located northeast of Charlotte.

[[Miss Universe 2009]]

CATEGORIES: 2009 in North America, NBC network shows

Miss Universe 2009 was a beauty pageant, the 56th Miss Universe. In it, outgoing Miss Universe Dayana Mendoza of Venezuela crowned eighteen-year-old Stefanía Fernández as Miss Universe 2009.

It was followed by the Miss Universe 2010 pageant, and preceded by the Miss Universe 2008 pageant.

[[Midkiff, West Virginia]]

CATEGORIES: Unincorporated communities in West Virginia

Midkiff is an unincorporated community in western Lincoln County, West Virginia, United States.  Its elevation is 597 feet (182 m).  Although it is unincorporated, it has a post office, with the ZIP code of 25540.

[[Lincoln County, West Virginia]]

CATEGORIES: West Virginia counties

Lincoln County is a county in the U.S. state of West Virginia. As of the 2010 census, the population was 21,720. Its county seat is Hamlin. The county was created in 1867 and named for Abraham Lincoln.

[[Hamlin, West Virginia]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in West Virginia, County seats in West Virginia

Hamlin, originally named "Hamline," is a town in Lincoln County, West Virginia, United States, along the Mud River. The population was recorded as 1,142 at the 2010 census. It is the county seat of Lincoln County. As of the 2010 census, the MSA had a population of 287,702.

[[Teays Valley, West Virginia]]

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places, Settlements in West Virginia

Teays Valley (ˈ TAYZ) is a census-designated place (CDP) in Putnam County, West Virginia,  United States.  The place is divided into the two districts of Teays Valley and Scott Depot.  The population was 13,175 at the 2010 census.

[[Putnam County, West Virginia]]

CATEGORIES: West Virginia counties

Putnam County is a county in the U.S. state of West Virginia. As of the 2010 census, the population was 55,486. Its county seat is Winfield.

[[Winfield, West Virginia]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in West Virginia, County seats in West Virginia

Winfield is a town in Putnam County, West Virginia, United States. The population was 2,301 at the 2010 census. It is the county seat of Putnam County.

[[Doland, South Dakota]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in South Dakota

Doland is a city in eastern Spink County, South Dakota, United States. The population was 180 at the 2010 census.

[[Gunnar Berge]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, Living people, Norwegian politicians, Norwegian Nobel Committee

Gunnar Berge (born 29 August 1940) is a Norwegian politician. He has been a member of the Labour Party.

Berge was born in Etne, Hordaland. 

Berge represented Rogaland in the Norwegian Parliament from 1969 to 1993. He was Minister of Finance from 1986 to 1989, Minister of Local Government and Regional Development from 1992 to 1997.

He was also member of the Norwegian Nobel Committee from 1997 to 2002, as leader from 2000 to 2002.

[[Berit Reiss-Andersen]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, Living people, Norwegian politicians, Norwegian writers, Lawyers

Berit Reiss-Andersen (born 11 July 1954) is a Norwegian lawyer, author and politician. She is a member of the Norwegian Labour Party. She is chairman of the Norwegian Nobel Committee since 2017. She is also a board member of the Nobel Foundation.

Before, she was state secretary for the Minister of Justice and Police from 1996 to 1997 and as President of the Norwegian Bar Association from 2008 to 2012. 

[[Erin O'Toole]]

CATEGORIES: 1973 births, Living people, Politicians from Montreal, Privy Councillors (Canada), Leaders of the Opposition (Canada), Members of the House of Commons of Canada from Ontario

Erin Michael O'Toole CAN (born January 22, 1973) is a Canadian politician. He has been the leader of the Conservative Party and the Leader of the Official Opposition since August 24, 2020. He is a Member of Parliament (MP) in the House of Commons of Canada. He represented the electoral area of Durham. He was first elected in a by-election on November 26, 2012. 

O'Toole was Minister of Veterans Affairs in 2015. In 2017, O'Toole ran in the 2017 Conservative leadership race to replace Stephen Harper, where he finished third.

Since August 2017, O'Toole has been the Official Opposition Critic for Foreign Affairs. 

In January 2020, O'Toole announced his candidacy for the 2020 Conservative leadership election. On August 24, he won the election. He beat Peter MacKay and became the leader of the party.

During the 2021 Canadian federal election, the Conservative Party won 121 seats (two more than in 2019), however still did not win the majority seats needed to form a government.

[[Donn Trenner]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, American jazz musicians, American pianists, Musicians from New Haven, Connecticut

Donald "Donn" Trenner (March 10, 1927 – May 16, 2020) was an American jazz pianist and arranger. He was born in New Haven, Connecticut. In the 1960s, Trenner worked as a studio musician, and led The Steve Allen Show house band.

From 1966 to 1978, he was married to actress B. J. Ward. From 1990 until her death in 2005, he was married to Marycarmen Jones. They had one daughter.

Trenner died on May 16, 2020 at the age of 93.

[[Tom Tiffany]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, 21st-century American politicians, Businesspeople from Wisconsin, Living people, State legislators of the United States, US Republican Party politicians, United States representatives from Wisconsin

Thomas P. Tiffany (born December 30, 1957) is an American businessman and politician. He was the U.S. Representative for Wisconsin's 7th congressional district since 2020. He is a member of the Republican Party.

[[Andre Drummond]]

CATEGORIES: 1993 births, Living people, Detroit Pistons players, Cleveland Cavaliers players, Sportspeople from New York, Sportspeople from Hartford, Connecticut

Andre Jamal Drummond (born August 10, 1993) is an American professional basketball player. He plays for the Los Angeles Lakers of the National Basketball Association (NBA) since 2019. He was selected by the Detroit Pistons in the first round of the 2012 NBA draft and played for them until 2019.

[[Stu Griffing]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, Living people, American Olympic bronze medalists, Sportspeople from New Haven, Connecticut

Stuart Lane "Stu" Griffing (born November 9, 1926) is an American rower. He competed in the 1948 Summer Olympics. He was born in New Haven, Connecticut. In 1948 he was a crew member of the American boat which won the bronze medal in the coxless fours event.

[[B. J. Ward]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, Living people, American movie actors, American voice actors, American video game actors, American television actors, American stage actors, Actors from Wilmington, Delaware, Singers from Delaware, Musicians from Wilmington, Delaware

Betty Jean Ward (born September 16, 1944), professionally known as B. J. Ward, is an American actress and singer. She is the creator and star of Stand-Up Opera. She was born in Wilmington, Delaware. She toured with the Groundlings for a short while before starting her voice over career on Hanna-Barbera's Jana of the Jungle in 1978.

From 1966 to 1978, she was married to pianist Donn Trenner. Later, she was married to director Gordon Hunt from 1995 until his death in 2016. They had a daughter.

[[John Backus]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2007 deaths, Deaths from natural causes in the United States, American computer scientists, American inventors, Scientists from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Scientists from Delaware

John Warner Backus (December 3, 1924 – March 17, 2007) was an American computer scientist. He directed the team that invented FORTRAN, the first widely used  high-level programming language. He was the inventor of the Backus–Naur form (BNF). 

He received the National Medal of Science in 1975 and the 1977 ACM Turing Award.

[[Elena Delle Donne]]

CATEGORIES: 1989 births, Living people, American basketball players, Sportspeople from Wilmington, Delaware, Sportspeople from Chicago

Elena Delle Donne (born September 5, 1989) is an American professional basketball player for the Washington Mystics of the Women's National Basketball Association (WNBA). She was born in Wilmington, Delaware.

Delle Donne played a successful college basketball career for the Delaware Blue Hens from 2009 to 2013. She was drafted by the Chicago Sky with the 2nd overall pick of the 2013 WNBA Draft, and led the Sky to the 2014 WNBA Finals.

She would later be traded to the Washington Mystics and lead them to their first WNBA Championship in franchise history in 2019. Delle Donne has won two WNBA Most Valuable Player Awards (2015, 2019).

[[Chicago Sky]]

CATEGORIES: Sports in Chicago, Illinois

The Chicago Sky are an American professional basketball team in Chicago. They play in the Eastern Conference of the Women's National Basketball Association (WNBA). It was founded before the 2006 season began. It is owned by Michael J. Alter (principal owner) and Margaret Stender (minority owner). The team was very successful from 2013 to 2016, making four playoff appearances and playing in the 2014 WNBA Finals.

[[Wintrust Arena]]

CATEGORIES: 2010s establishments in Illinois, 2017 establishments in the United States, Sports buildings in Chicago, Illinois

Wintrust Arena at McCormick Square, also known as DePaul Arena or McCormick Place Events Center, is a 10,387-seat sports venue in Chicago's Near South Side community area that opened in 2017. 

It is the current home court for the men's and women's basketball teams of DePaul University. It is also an events center for McCormick Place. It also is the home of the Chicago Sky of the Women's National Basketball Association (WNBA).

[[Matt Gaetz]]

CATEGORIES: 1982 births, Living people, United States representatives from Florida, State legislators of the United States, US Republican Party politicians

Matthew Louis Gaetz II (ɡ; born May 7, 1982) is an American lawyer and politician. He is the U.S. representative for FL since 2017. He is a member of the Republican Party. He is known as a strict Trump supporter.

In March 2021, Gaetz was being investigated for having a sexual relationship with a 17-year-old girl in 2019, and that investigators were examining whether he had violated federal sex trafficking laws by allegedly paying her to travel with him. 

On March 30, 2021, Axios reported that Gaetz was "seriously considering not seeking re-election and possibly leaving Congress early for a job at Newsmax".

[[I, the Jury (1982 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1982 drama movies, 1980s crime drama movies, American crime drama movies

I, the Jury is a 1982 American crime drama movie directed by Richard T. Heffron and is the second adaption of the 1947 novel of the same name by Mickey Spillane. It stars Armand Assante, Barbara Carrera, Laurene Landon, Alan King, Geoffrey Lewis, Judson Scott, Paul Sorvino and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Lakh]]

CATEGORIES: India, Numbers

Lakh is the number 10^5, obtained by multiplying ten-thousand by 10, also named one hundred thousand. The word lakh is used in India. It is written as 1,00,000 in India and 100,000 in most other countries. 100 lakh is one crore.

[[Yellow Sky]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 movies, 1940s western movies, American western movies, Movies directed by William A. Wellman

Yellow Sky is a 1948 American western movie directed by William A. Wellman and is based on the William Shakespeare's The Tempest. It stars Gregory Peck, Anne Baxter, Robert Arthur, Richard Widmark, Charles Kemper and was distributed by 20th Century Fox. It was remade in 1967 as The Jackals.

[[Childbed fever]]

CATEGORIES: Medicine

Childbed fever is an bacterial infection of the female reproductive tract, which occurs after a woman has given birth or after a miscarriage. It is also known as postpartum infection, or puerperal fever. In the developed world, it affects about one to two percent of all births. It can develop into a life-threatening sepsis. Cesarean section is one of the risk factors. For this reason, all women undergoing a Cesarean section receive antibiotics. 

[[Johnny Belinda]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 movies, 1940s drama movies, American drama movies, Movies based on plays, Movies directed by Jean Negulesco

Johnny Belinda is a 1948 American drama movie directed by Jean Negulesco and based on the 1940 play of the same name by Elmer Blaney Harris. It stars Jane Wyman, Lew Ayres, Charles Bickford, Agnes Moorehead, Stephen McNally and was distributed by Warner Bros.. It was nominated for 12 Oscars and won an Academy Award in 1949.

[[Black Soft-shell Turtle]]

CATEGORIES: Turtles

The black soft-shell turtle or Bostami turtle  (Nilssonia nigricans) is a species of freshwater turtle found in India (Assam) and Bangladesh (Chittagong and Sylhet). It was long believed to be inbred individuals of the Indian softshell turtle (A. gangeticus or N. gangeticus) or the Indian peacock softshell turtle (A. hurum or N. hurum), but later found to be  a distinct species.In the 1800s it was believed these turtles were brought from Iran to Chittagong shrine pond by Hazrat Bayezid Bostami. His turtles he had brought to this pond were treated as sacred and respected by the public. Previously declared extinct by the International Union for Conservation of Nature in 2002, these turtles were found to still exist in a temple’s pond called the Hayagriva Madhava Temple located in Assam, India. Through conservation methods and protection of the species, some of these turtles can be found today throughout the wild, and scientists and environmental biologists are continuing to work hard to preserve this endangered species and their natural habitat.

[[Asian Winter Games]]

CATEGORIES: International sports competitions, Multi-sport events, 1986 establishments in Asia, Winter sports

The Asian Winter Games (AWG) is an international multi-sport event held every four years for members of the Olympic Council of Asia (OCA) which features winter events.

[[The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes (1939 movie)]]

The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes is a 1939 American mystery movie directed by Alfred L. Werker and is the second movie of the fourteen movies in the series. It stars Basil Rathbone, Nigel Bruce, Ida Lupino, George Zucco, Alan Marshall, Terry Kilburn, Arthur Hohl and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Thailand at the Asian Games]]

CATEGORIES: Thailand at the Asian Games

Thailand has competed at every celebration of the Asian Games, including hosting the Games in 1966, 1970, 1978 and 1998. Thai athletes have won a total of 109 gold medals (7th out of 37) and 463 overall medals (5th out of 43) at the Asian Games.

[[The Rains Came]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 movies, 1930s drama movies, American adventure movies, American romantic drama movies, Movies directed by Clarence Brown

The Rains Came is a 1939 American romantic adventure drama movie directed by Clarence Brown and is based on the novel of the same name by Louis Bromfield. It stars Myrna Low, Tyrone Power, Nigel Bruce, George Brent, Brenda Joyce, Mary Nash, Jane Darwell and was distributed by 20th Century Fox. It was nominated for 6 Oscars and won Academy Award in 1940 and was remade in 1955 under the title The Rains of Ranchipur.

The Great Redeemer is a 1920 American western drama movie directed by Clarence Brown and Maurice Tourneur and stars House Peters, Marjorie Daw, Jack McDonald, Joseph Singleton. It was distributed by Metro Pictures.

[[Asian Para Games]]

CATEGORIES: Asian Games, Multi-sport events, Sports for the disabled

The Asian Para Games is a multi-sport event regulated by the Asian Paralympic Committee that held every four years after every Asian Games for athletes with physical disabilities.

[[Rebecca of Sunnybrook Farm (1932 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 movies, 1930s drama movies, American drama movies

Rebecca of Sunnybrook Farm is a 1932 American children's drama movie directed by Alfred Santell and is the second adaption of the 1903 novel and 1910 play of the same name. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox and was nominated for an Academy Award in 1941.

[[Lluís Juste de Nin]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in Spain, Illustrators, Spanish fashion designers, Cartoonists, People from Barcelona

Lluís Juste de Nin (1945 – 21 May 2020) was a Spanish illustrator, cartoonist and fashion designer. 

He was creative director for the Spanish fashion label Armand Basi. His work was first published in the 1960s. His political cartoons were used to criticize Francisco Franco. He signed his works as "El Zurdo". For many years, he was engaged in creating illustrations for articles by Manuel Vázquez Montalbán in Mundo Obrero.

Juste de Nin died on 21 May 2020 in Barcelona of cancer at the age of 75.

[[Surapong Tovichakchaikul]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2020 deaths, Thai politicians, Deaths from liver cancer

Surapong Tovichakchaikul (May 1, 1953 – May 20, 2020) was a Thai politician. He was Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs of Thailand from 2011 to 2014. He was born in Chiang Mai Province, Thailand. He was a member of the Pheu Thai Party.

Surapong died on 20 May 2020 of liver cancer at a hospital in Bangkok, aged 67.

[[Head of the Virgin (Pittoni)]]

CATEGORIES: 18th century paintings

Head of the Virgin (also known as La Tête de Vierge or La Testa della Vergine) is a 18th-century portrait painted in oil by Giambattista Pittoni, made around 1730, during the Rococo in Venice, Italy, 

exhibited at the Musée des Beaux-Arts de Strasbourg. Many people Think Head of the Virgin's eyes glance is mysterious, as at the time it was not portrayed with a low gaze.

[[Iran at the Asian Para Games]]

CATEGORIES: Asian Games, Sport in Iran, Sports for the disabled

Iran first participated at the Asian Para Games in 2010, and has sent athletes to compete in every Asian Para Games since then. The National Paralympic Committee for Iran is the I.R. Iran National Paralympic Committee.

[[Pat Dye]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from liver failure, Deaths from renal failure, American football coaches, American football linebackers, American autobiographers, American children's writers, Writers from Georgia (U.S. state), Sportspeople from Georgia (U.S. state)

Patrick Fain Dye (November 6, 1939 – June 1, 2020) was an American football player, coach, writer and college athletics administrator.  He was the head football coach at East Carolina University (1974–1979), the University of Wyoming (1980), and Auburn University (1981–1992). He was the Athletic Director at Auburn from 1981 to 1991.

From 1961 to 1962, he played for the Edmonton Eskimos.

He was added into the College Football Hall of Fame as a coach in 2005. On November 19, 2005 the playing field in the stadium at Auburn University was named 'Pat Dye Field' in his honor.

Dye was born in Blythe, Georgia. He studied at the University of Georgia. Dye wrote two autobiographies and a children's book. He lived in Auburn, Alabama.

On May 21, 2020 Dye was hospitalized in Atlanta for kidney-related problems. He was later diagnosed with COVID-19. He died under hospice care of liver failure and kidney failure in Auburn on June 1, 2020 at the age of 80.

[[Blythe, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Georgia (U.S. state)

Blythe is a city in Richmond County in the U.S. state of Georgia. As of the 2010 census, the city had a population of 721.  It is part of the Augusta, Georgia metropolitan area.

[[Richmond County, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: 1777 establishments in Georgia (U.S. state)

Richmond County is a county located in the U.S. state of Georgia. As of the 2010 census, the population was 200,549. It is one of the original counties of Georgia, created February 5, 1777.

[[Margaret Maughan]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Road accident deaths, Archers, Paralympic gold medalists, Paralympic silver medalists, British athletes, Sportspeople from Lancashire

Margaret Maughan (19 June 1928spndMay 2020) was a British competitive archer, dartcher and bowls competitor. She was Britain's first gold medalist at the Paralympic Games, and won four gold and two silver medals at the Games. She lit the cauldron at the Olympic Stadium in London at the opening ceremony of the 2012 Summer Paralympics. She was born in Lancashire, England. She competed in the 1960, 1972, 1976 and 1980 games. 

At first, Maughan worked as a science teacher. Maughan was paralyzed from the waist down and left unable to walk by a road accident in Malawi in 1959.

Maughan died in May 2020 of problems caused by her spinal cord injury, aged 91.

[[Per aspera ad astra]]

CATEGORIES: Latin phrases

Per aspera ad astra (or, less commonly, ad astra per aspera) is a popular Latin phrase that means "through hardships to the stars". The phrase is one of the many Latin phrases that use the expression ad astra, meaning "to the stars".

[[Shahdol district]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Madhya Pradesh

Shahdol district is a district of Madhya Pradesh state in India. It is rich in coal, and is a tribal district. Dhanpuri SECL coal mines, the soda factory, Orient Paper Mills, and the Reliance Gas plant are major employers.

[[Kirby Morrow]]

CATEGORIES: Canadian voice actors, 1973 births, 2020 deaths, Canadian movie actors, Canadian television actors, Actors from Alberta, Canadian writers, Canadian comedians

Kirby Robert Morrow (August 28, 1973 – November 18, 2020) was a Canadian actor, writer and comedian. Morrow was born in Jasper, Alberta.

He was known as the voice of Miroku from InuYasha, Van Fanel from the Ocean dub of Escaflowne, Cyclops from X-Men Evolution, Jay from Class of the Titans, Teru Mikami from Death Note, Goku from Ocean's dub of Dragon Ball Z and Cole from Lego Ninjago: Masters of Spinjitzu.

Iran first participated at the Universiade in 1973, and has sent athletes to some editions of Summer Universiade.

[[Universiade]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 establishments, Universiade

The Universiade is an international multi-sport event, organized for university athletes by the International University Sports Federation (FISU).

[[The Peanuts Movie]]

CATEGORIES: 2010s adventure movies, 2015 animated movies, 2015 comedy movies, 20th Century Fox movies, American adventure movies, American animated movies, American comedy movies, American family movies, American fantasy movies, Computer-animated movies, English-language movies, Movies about dogs, Movies based on comics, Blue Sky Studios movies

Iran first participated at the Asian Games in 1951, and has sent athletes to compete in every Asian Games since then, except for 1954, 1962 and 1978.

[[Deaflympics]]

CATEGORIES: Olympic Games, Deaflympics

The Deaflympics (previously called World Games for the Deaf, and International Games for the Deaf) are an International Olympic Committee (IOC)-sanctioned event at which deaf athletes compete at an elite level.

[[Military World Games]]

CATEGORIES: 1995 establishments, Military, Sports competitions, Multi-sport events

The Military World Games is a multi-sport event for military sportspeople, organized by the International Military Sports Council (CISM). The Games have been held since 1995, although championships for separate sports had been held for some years.

[[The Victors (movie)]]

America, America is a 1963 American drama movie directed by and based on the novel of the same name by Elia Kazan. It stars Stathis Giallelis, Frank Wolff, Estelle Hemsley, Lou Antonio, Joanna Frank, Salem Ludwig, Paul Mann, Robert H. Harris, Katharine Balfour and was distributed by Warner Bros.. It was nominated for 4 Oscars and won an Academy Award in 1964.

[[Paige Hauschild]]

CATEGORIES: 1999 births, American water polo players, Living people

Paige Hauschild (born August 17, 1999) is an American water polo player. She was part of the gold medal-winning American team at the 2017 World Aquatics Championships in Budapest. She participated at the 2016 FINA Women’s Water Polo World Youth Championships, 2018 FINA World Cup, and 2019 Pan American Games.

She played for University of Southern California's women's water polo team for the 2018 NCAA Champion season.

A Night in Heaven is a 1983 American romantic drama movie directed by John G. Avildsen and starring Christopher Atkins, Lesley Ann Warren, Robert Logan, Deney Terrio, Deborah Rush, Carrie Snodgress, Andy Garcia. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox and was a box office bomb.

[[Chambal River]]

CATEGORIES: Rivers of India

The Chambal River is a tributary of the Yamuna River in central India. It forms a significant portion of the Greater Gangetic drainage arrangement.The river passes through the states of Madhya Pradesh, Rajasthan, and Uttar Pradesh. Major tributaries of the Chambal River include Mej, Banas, Kali Sindh, Parbati, and Shipra. The river flows north-northeast through Madhya Pradesh. It is a perennial river, which originates from a place near Manspura in Janapao Hills in Indore, Madhya Pradesh, India. It is 1,024 km long, and its basin size is 143,219 square km. The Gandhi Sagar Dam is the first of the four dams built on the Chambal River, located on the Rajasthan-Madhya Pradesh border. It is a 64 metre high masonry gravity dam, with a live storage capacity of 6,920 MCM (million cubic metres) and a catchment area of 22,584 square km, of which only 1,537 square km is in Rajasthan.

[[Functional analysis]]

CATEGORIES: Mathematics

Functional analysis is a branch of mathematical analysis. This area emerged from the studies of differential equations (especially partial differential equations). It has many applications in various fields. One of the famous use is numerical analysis.

[[Interval arithmetic]]

CATEGORIES: Technology, Computer science

Interval arithmetic is a specific type of computer arithmetic for (mathematical) intervals. It is mainly used for the automated detection of errors. There is a value, which isn't known exactly, but which can be given by an interval: the value is known to be inside the interval. There's a function to calculate the error. This function should be given the unknown value, but instead can only be given the interval. The result is a function which will map intervals. 

Interval arithmetic can be used to treat rounding errors, or to treat insecurities with measurements: Each measurement has a certain error, which cannot be determined exactly. 

[[Strawberry and Chocolate]]

CATEGORIES: 1993 comedy-drama movies, 1990s LGBT movies, Movies based on short stories, Cuban movies, Mexican movies, Movies directed by Juan Carlos Tabío

Strawberry and Chocolate (Fresa y chocolate) is a 1993 Cuban Mexican comedy drama movie directed by Tomás Gutiérrez Alea and Juan Carlos Tabío and is based on the 1990 short story The Wolf, The Forest and the New Man by Senel Paz. It stars Jorge Perugorría, Vladimir Cruz, Mirta Ibarra, Francisco Gattorno and was distributed by Miramax Films. It was nominated for an Academy Award in 1995.

[[Rabie Ablak]]

CATEGORIES: Moroccan writers, Journalists, 1987 births

Rabie Ablak, or Rabie Al-Ablak (born 1987), is a Moroccan journalist. He is a part of the Hirak Rif Movement. He has been on hunger strike to protest his detention and inhumane treatment.

Some of his hunger strikes lasted more than 40 days;  he was taken to hospital several times for treatment. The total of his hunger strikes are more than 284 days.

[[High Noon]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 movies, 1950s western movies, American western movies, Movies directed by Fred Zinnemann

It was distributed by United Artists and was nominated for 7 Oscars and won 4 Academy Awards in 1953.

[[Antifeminism]]

CATEGORIES: Feminism

Antifeminism is opposition to some or all forms of feminism. It has changed over the years and in different cultures. In the late 19th century and early 20th century antifeminists were opposed to women's suffrage, that is allowing women to vote in elections. In the United States in they also opposed the Equal Rights Amendment, which would give change the Constitution to give both men and women equal rights. In the 21st century, antifeminists believe that feminism is not about rights for women, but is about taking away the rights of men.

[[A Talking Cat!?!]]

A Talking Cat!?! is a 2013 independent children's film directed by David DeCoteau. The film was released by Phase 4 Films direct to DVD on February 18, 2013. Eric Roberts is featured as the voice of the talking cat.

[[Groesbeek]]

CATEGORIES: Former municipalities of Gelderland, Settlements in Gelderland, Berg en Dal

Groesbeek is a town and former municipality in the province of Gelderland, the Netherlands. On 1 January 2015, the former municipality merged with Millingen aan de Rijn and Ubbergen. The larger area was known as Groesbeek until 1 January 2016, when its name was changed to Berg en Dal.

[[Millingen aan de Rijn]]

CATEGORIES: Former municipalities of Gelderland, Settlements in Gelderland, Berg en Dal

Millingen aan de Rijn is a town and former municipality in the province of Gelderland, the Netherlands. Since 2015, it has been part of the new municipality of Berg en Dal (formerly known as Groesbeek).

[[Marcelo Spina]]

Marcelo Spina (born July 23, 1970) is an Argentinean-American architect (AIA) and educator. He is a partner in Los Angeles-based architecture firm PATTERNS, which he founded in 2002. Since 2001, he has been a Design and Applied Studies Faculty at SCI-Arc.

[[Pakistan International Airlines Flight 8303]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 disasters in Asia, 2020s in Pakistan, Aviation disasters in Asia, Disasters in Pakistan, History of Sindh, Karachi, May 2020 events

Pakistan International Airlines Flight 8303 was a flight in Pakistan. It was between Allama Iqbal International Airport in Lahore, Punjab and Jinnah International Airport in Karachi, Sindh. The plane crashed on its final approach into Karachi in the Model Colony area of the city on 22 May 2020. The crash killed 97 people of the 99 people on board and one on the ground. It injured 9 others: 2 on the plane and 7 on the ground.

[[Wilson Roosevelt Jerman]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, People from North Carolina

Wilson Roosevelt Jerman (January 21, 1929 – May 16, 2020) was a butler. He worked for 11 different American presidents in the White House. He was born in Seaboard, North Carolina. 

Jerman was promoted to butler under John F. Kennedy, and continued in that role until his retirement in 1993 during the Bill Clinton administration. He returned to the White House in 2003 in the George W. Bush administration. He worked as a maitre d' and elevator operator for Barack Obama before his final retirement in 2012.

Jerman died at the age of 91 on May 16, 2020 from COVID-19 in Woodbridge, Virginia at the age of 91.

[[Seaboard, North Carolina]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in North Carolina

Seaboard is a town in Northampton County, North Carolina, United States.

The population was 632 at the 2010 census. It is part of the Roanoke Rapids, North Carolina Micropolitan Statistical Area.

[[Woodbridge, Virginia]]

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places in Virginia

[[Berith Bohm]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Swedish stage actors, Singers from Stockholm, Actors from Stockholm

''Berith'' Maria Kristina Bohm (23 August 1932 – 14 May 2020) was a Swedish opera singer and actress. She performed in a talent show during her teens in Bromma and performed the song Fjorton år tror jag visst att jag var. 

She began her stage career in Stockholm and then went to Stora Teatern in Gothenburg. Her best known theatre role was as Csardasfurstinnan in "Sköna Helena". She also performed at Volksoper in Vienna, Austria.

Bohm died on 14 May 2020 at the age of 87.

[[Neil Howlett]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Educators, Singers from London

Neil Howlett (24 July 1934 – 21 May 2020) was an English operatic baritone. He sang leading roles in major opera houses and festivals. He performed at the Royal Opera House, Teatro Colón, and the English National Opera, where he was the Principal Baritone for seventeen years. He was born in Mitcham, Greater London. 

Howlett was a professor at the Guildhall School of Music, and later, after retiring from full-time performance, Head of Vocal Studies at the Royal Northern College of Music. He taught privately in London and Lincolnshire.

Howlett died on 21 May 2020, aged 85.

[[Arnulf Kolstad]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Norwegian academics, Norwegian scientists, Norwegian psychologists, Writers from Oslo

Arnulf Kolstad (23 April 1942 – 21 May 2020) was a Norwegian social psychologist. He was born in Oslo. He was a  professor emeritus of Social Psychology at the Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU). 

He was appointed by the King-in-Council at the then-University of Trondheim in 1986 and was head of department for the Department of Psychology from 1990 to 1992. He became professor emeritus in 2012.

He was critical of the 2010 Nobel Peace Prize going to Liu Xiaobo as "western arrogance".

Kolstad died on 21 May 2020 in Oslo, aged 78.

[[Kahol Lavan]]

CATEGORIES: Political parties in Israel, Zionist parties, 2010s establishments in Israel

[[Sergey Kramarenko (pilot)]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, Soviet military personnel of World War II

Sergei Makarovich Kramarenko (Серге́й Макарович Крамаренко; 10 April 1923 – 21 May 2020) was a Soviet Air Force officer. He fought in World War II and the Korean War. He was honored withHero of the Soviet Union. He retired in 1977 with the rank of major-general. He was the last living Soviet flying ace of Korean War.

Kramarenko died on 21 May 2020, aged 97.

[[Alan Merten]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from Parkinson's disease, American educators, Writers from Milwaukee, Wisconsin

Alan Gilbert Merten (December 27, 1941 – May 21, 2020) was an American educator. He was the fifth President of George Mason University from 1996 until his retirement in 2012. He was born in Milwaukee, Wisconsin.

Merten died on May 21, 2020 in Florida from Parkinson's disease-related problems, aged 78.

[[David Pawson]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, British teachers, English Protestants, English theologians, English writers, Evangelicals, People from Newcastle upon Tyne

John David Pawson (25 February 1930 – 21 May 2020) was an English evangelical minister, writer, theologian and Bible. He was born in Newcastle upon Tyne, England. He was the pastor of Guildford Baptist Church. 

In The Normal Christian Birth, Pawson argued that for a person to begin into Christianity, it should involve more than the simple "Sinner's Prayer". He also believed that a person who goes to hell, should stay there for eternity.

Pawson died on 21 May 2020, aged 90.

[[Ashley Cooper]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Australian tennis players, Sportspeople from Melbourne

Ashley John Cooper AO (15 September 1936 – 22 May 2020) was an Australian tennis player. He was born in Melbourne. He  played from 1953 until 1968. He was seen as the world's best amateur player during the years of 1957 and 1958. Cooper won four singles and four doubles titles at Grand Slam tournaments. He won three of the four Grand Slam events in 1958. 

Cooper died on 22 May 2020 at the age of 83 after a long illness in Melbourne.

[[Green Island, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in New York, Villages in New York

Green Island is a coterminous town-village in Albany County, New York, United States. The population was 2,620 at the 2010 census. The postal code is 12183.

Herkimer is a village on the north side of the Mohawk River and the county seat of Herkimer County, New York, United States. As of the 2010 census, it had a population of 7,743.

German Flatts is a town in Herkimer County, New York, United States. The population was 13,258 at the 2010 census.

[[Webb, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in New York

Webb is the northernmost town in Herkimer County, New York, United States. As of the 2010 census it had a population of 1,807.

[[Mory Kanté]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2020 deaths, Guinean people, Singers

Mory Kanté (29 March 1950 – 22 May 2020) was a Guinean singer. He was born in Albadaria, French Guinea.

He was best known for his 1987 hit song "Yé ké yé ké", which reached number-one in Belgium, Finland, the Netherlands, and Spain. His album, Akwaba Beach, was the best-selling African record of its time. On 16 October 2001, Kanté was nominated Goodwill Ambassador of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO).

On 22 May 2020, Kanté died at a hospital in Conakry from a chronic disease, at the age of 70.

[[Anatoliy Matviyenko]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2020 deaths, Ukrainian politicians

Anatoliy Matviyenko (22 March 1953 – 22 May 2020) was an Ukrainian politician. He was born in Bershad, Vinnytsia Oblast. He was Governor of the Vinnytsia Oblast from 1996 to 1998. He was a member of the Verkhovna Rada from 1990 to 1994, 1998 to 2005, 2006 to 2007 and again from 2014 until his death.

He was an activist of Komsomol (LKSMU) and by 1985 became a secretary of the Central Committee of LKSMU. In 1989-91 Matviyenko became the first secretary of the Ukrainian Komsomol and became a member of the Communist Party of Ukraine.

Matviyenko died on 22 May 2020 in Kiev, at the age of 67.

[[Luigi Simoni]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from stroke, Italian footballers, Italian football managers, People from Bologna

Luigi "Gigi" Simoni (22 January 1939 – 22 May 2020) was an Italian football player and manager. He was born near Bologna, Italy.

He played for A.S.D. Mantova F.C., S.S.C. Napoli, Torino F.C., Juventus F.C., Brescia Calcio and Genoa C.F.C.. His playing career lasted from 1959 to 1974. He was known for managing Napoli and Inter Milano. His managing career lasted from 1974 to 2012.

Simoni died at his home on 22 May 2020 in Pisa, Italy from stroke-related problems, aged 81.

[[Giulio Savelli]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Publishers, Politicians from Rome

Giulio Savelli (27 September 1941 – 12 May 2020) was an Italian politician and publisher. He was born in Rome. Savelli was elected to the Chamber of Deputies as a member of Forza Italia. He was a deputy from 1996 and 2001.  

Savelli died on 12 May 2020 in Rome at the age of 78.

[[Eddsworld]]

Eddsworld is a cartoon series made by Edd Gould. The characters are Edd, Tom, Matt, and Tord.

[[2014 United States Senate election in Iowa]]

CATEGORIES: 2014 elections, Elections in the United States, United States Senate, History of Iowa

The 2014 United States Senate election in Iowa took place in Iowa on November 4, 2014. In it, Republican State Senator Joni Ernst faced off Democrat Bruce Baley. Ernst won the election with 52.1% of the vote to Baley's 43.8%.

[[Ventenac-Cabardès]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Aude

Ventenac-Cabardès is a commune of 959 people (2017). It is in the region Occitanie in the Aude department in the south of France.

CATEGORIES: 1825 establishments in Georgia (U.S. state), Georgia (U.S. state) counties

Lowndes County is a county in the U.S. state of Georgia. As of the 2010 census, 109,233 people lived there. The county seat is Valdosta.

Coronado is a city in San Diego County, California.

Cook County is a county in the U.S. state of Georgia. As of the 2010 census, 17,212 people lived there. The county seat is Adel.

[[Adel, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Georgia (U.S. state), County seats in Georgia

Adel is a city in the U.S. state of Georgia. It is the county seat of Cook County.

Dawsonville is a city in the U.S. state of Georgia. It is the county seat of Dawson County.

[[Evans County, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: 1914 establishments in Georgia (U.S. state), Georgia (U.S. state) counties

Evans County is a county in the U.S. state of Georgia. As of the 2010 census, 11,000 people lived there. The county seat is Claxton.

[[Rain on Me (Lady Gaga and Ariana Grande song)]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 songs, Lady Gaga songs, Ariana Grande songs, Dance-pop songs, Grammy Award winning songs

"Rain on Me" is a song by American singers Lady Gaga and Ariana Grande.  It was released on May 22, 2020, as the second single from Gaga’s sixth studio album, Chromatica. It was written by the singers with Rami Yacoub, Nija Charles, Alexander Ridha, and its producers, BloodPop, Tchami, and BURNS.

On June 1, 2020, it was announced that the song entered at number one on the Billboard Hot 100.  The song became Gaga’s fifth number-one single in the US and Grande’s fourth. Grande became the first artist with four songs on the Hot 100 to enter at the top, passing Justin Bieber, Drake, and Mariah Carey, who have three each. It became Gaga's second number-one entrance after "Born This Way" in 2011. The song is also the only female collaboration to enter at number one in the US.

[[Cyclone Amphan]]

CATEGORIES: May 2020 events, Tropical cyclones in Asia

Super Cyclonic Storm Amphan was a very powerful tropical cyclone that caused a lot of damage in East India and Bangladesh in May 2020. It caused over US$13 billion dollars of damage and killed a total of 118 people. It was the strongest cyclone to hit the Ganges Delta since Cyclone Sidr in 2007.

It formed on the 16 May in the Bay of Bengal and tracked into the Ganges Delta before dissipating on the 21 May.

[[Simone Budde]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 births, Living people, German water polo players

Simone Budde (born 2 January 1979) is a German water polo player. She was part of the Germany women's national water polo team at the 2003 World Aquatics Championships, 2007 World Aquatics Championships, and 2009 World Aquatics Championships.

[[Cyclone Kyarr]]

CATEGORIES: October 2019 events, November 2019 events, Tropical cyclones in Asia, 2019 in weather

Super Cyclonic Storm Kyarr was a powerful tropical cyclone that was the first super cyclonic storm since 2007. The storm moved across the Arabian Sea and affected Western India, Arabia, and Somalia. Nobody was killed from the storm, as it never tracked over land.

[[2020 North Indian Ocean cyclone season]]

CATEGORIES: 2020, North Indian Ocean cyclones

The 2020 North Indian Ocean cyclone season is an ongoing event in the annual cycle of tropical cyclone formation. The North Indian Ocean cyclone season has no real bounds, but cyclones usually form between April and November, with the highest amount of storms in May and October.

There has been one tropical cyclone so far in the season, Cyclone Amphan. It was the strongest cyclone since 2007.

[[Tetraoxygen]]

CATEGORIES: Chemistry

Tetraoxygen (O4), or oxozone, is a molecule made up of four oxygen atoms. It does not exist in nature anywhere and can only be made under extreme conditions in a lab. The molecule was first created in a lab in 2001.

[[June Almeida]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2007 deaths, Virologists

June Dalziel Almedia (5 October 1930 – 1 December 2007) was a Scottish virologist. She had very good skills in electron microscopy. During the 2019–20 coronavirus outbreak, her research was used to help beat the virus.

[[William Lyon (general)]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, American generals, People from Los Angeles, California

William Lyon (March 9, 1923 – May 22, 2020) was a major general of the United States Air Force. He was Commander of the United States Air Force Reserve Command. As chief of Air Force Reserve, Lyon was the principal adviser on Reserve matters to the Air Force Chief of Staff. He was born in Los Angeles, California.

Lyon died on May 22, 2020 in Coto de Caza, California at the age of 97.

[[Coto de Caza, California]]

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places in California, Settlements in Orange County, California

Coto de Caza (meaning hunting preserve in Spanish) is a census-designated place (CDP) and guard-gated private community in Orange County, California. The population was 14,799 at the 2017 census.

[[Hana Kimura]]

CATEGORIES: 1997 births, 2020 deaths, Drug-related suicides, Japanese professional wrestlers

Hana Kimura was a Japanese female professional wrestler. She wrestled for  Stardom. Her mother is former wrestler Kyoko Kimura. Kimura was born in Yokohama, Japan. 

Kimura was trained at  Wrestle-1's Professional Wrestling University. 

She debuted on March 30, 2016 against Reika Saiki in a losing effort for Wrestle-1. The pair wrestled against each many times throughout 2016 for Wrestle-1.

Kimura killed herself by swallowing hydrogen sulfide on May 23, 2020, at the age of 22.

[[Syed Fazal Agha]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Pakistan, Pakistani politicians

Syed Muhammad Fazal Agha (سید محمد فضل آغا; (1946 – 20 May 2020) was a Pakistani politician. He was Governor of Balochistan from August 18 to October 12 1999. He also was Deputy Chairman of the Senate of Pakistan from 1988-1991. from Balochistan. He was a member of the Provincial Assembly of Balochistan from 13 August 2018 till his death.

Agha was born in Killi Huramzai, Pishin District. He died on 20 May 2020 from COVID-19 in Karachi, aged 78.

[[Euler's formula]]

CATEGORIES: Mathematics

In complex analysis, Euler's formula, also sometimes called Euler's relation, is an equation involving complex numbers and trigonometric functions. More specifically, it states that

where x is a real number, e is Euler's number and i is the imaginary unit.

It makes a relation between trigonometric functions and exponential functions of complex numbers. It is named after Leonhard Euler, who published it in 1748. When he published it, Euler said that the angle must be a real number. Later, it turned out that the formula also works if the angle is not a real number, but a complex one.

[[Atropatene]]

CATEGORIES: History of Iran, Former countries in Europe, History of Europe

Atropatene was an ancient kingdom that existed in part of what is now Iran. It existed with Darius III of Persia and Alexander the Great. It started in the 4th century BCE, in what is now northern Iran. Its capital was Ganzak. It ended as a vassal kingdom of the Parthian empire. In 226, the Sasanian empire conquered it. At that time it was probably more of a province of the Parthian empire than a kingdom, even though its rulers were kings. 

Today, many people see it as a predecessor of the modern state of Azerbaijan.

[[Virgin Komi Forests]]

CATEGORIES: World Heritage Sites in Russia

The Virgin Komi Forests is a large woodland in the northern part of the Ural mountain range, in Russia. The forests are part of the Komi Republic of Russia. The forests cover an area of 32800 and are the largest virgin forests in Europe.

They were made a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1995. Most of the area is flat Taiga plain, about 100 above sea level. They rise towards the Ural mountains.

They are threatened because parts of the area contain a lot of gold. Illegal logging is also a threat.

[[Leo the Last]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 drama movies, British drama movies, British plays adapted into movies, Movies directed by John Boorman

Leo the Last is a 1970 British drama movie directed by John Boorman and based on the play The Prince by George Tabori. It stars Marcello Mastroianni, Billie Whitelaw, Calvin Lockhart, Brinsley Forde, Graham Crowden and was distributed by United Artists.

[[Knife in the Water]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 drama movies, Polish movies, Movies directed by Roman Polanski

Knife in the Water (Nóż w wodzie) is a 1962 Polish drama movie directed by Roman Polanski in his directorial debut and stars Leon Niemczyk, Jolanta Umecka, Zygmunt Malanowi. It was nominated for an Academy Award in 1964.

[[Numerical methods for partial differential equations]]

CATEGORIES: Partial differential equations, Technology, Computer science

Numerical methods for partial differential equations are computational schemes to obtain approximate solutions of partial differential equations (PDEs).

[[Ivan's Childhood]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 drama movies, 1960s war movies, World War II movies, Russian movies, Movies directed by Andrei Tarkovsky

Ivan's Childhood (Ivanovo detstvo), sometimes released as My Name Is Ivan is a 1962 Russian World War II drama movie directed by Andrei Tarkovsky and is based on the 1957 short story Ivan by Vladimir Bogomolov. It stars Nikolai Burlyaev, Valentin Zubkov, Evgeny Zharikov, Nikolai Grinko and was distributed by Mosfilm.

[[Strike (1925 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 movies, Russian movies, 1920s drama movies, Silent movies, Movies directed by Sergei Eisenstein

Strike (Стачка, translit. Stachka) is a 1925 Russian drama movie directed by Sergei Eisenstein and stars Maskim Shtraukh, Grigori Aleksandrov, Aleksandr Antonov. It was distributed by Goskino Proletkult.

[[Ariel]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 drama movies, 1980s road movies, Finnish movies, Movies directed by Aki Kaurismäki

Ariel is a 1988 Finnish drama movie directed and written by Aki Kaurismäki and starring Turo Pajala, Susanna Haavisto, Matti Pellonpää. It was distributed by Finnkino.

[[Drifting Clouds (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1996 comedy-drama movies, Finnish movies, German drama movies, French drama movies, Movies directed by Aki Kaurismäki

Drifting Clouds (Kauas pilvet karkaavat) is a 1996 Finnish comedy drama movie directed by Aki Kaurismäki and starring Kati Outinen, Kari Väänänen, Markku Peltola, Elina Salo. It was distributed by Sputnik.

[[Karen Asatrian]]

Karen Asatrian (Armenian: Կարեն Ասատրյան; born June 23, 1972) is Armenian jazz pianist and composer. His music is a creative synthesis of contemporary jazz and Armenian folk music. His arrangements are a jazzy exploration of the world of oriental melodies and western harmonies. The recent album “Noor” with Karen Asatrian & Armenian Spirit band is an expression of Armenian traditional songs rearranged with a contemporary jazz style.

[[Kiss of the Spider Woman (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 drama movies, 1980s LGBT movies, American drama movies, Brazilian movies, Movies directed by Héctor Babenco, American independent movies

Kiss of the Spider Woman (O Beijo da Mulher Aranha) is a 1985 Brazilian American drama movie directed by Héctor Babenco and based on the 1976 novel of the same name by Manuel Puig. It stars William Hurt, Raul Julia, Sônia Braga, José Lewgoy, Milton Gonçalves, Míriam Pires and was distributed by Island Pictures. It was nominated for 4 Oscars, including Best Picture and won Best Actor for Hurt in 1986.

[[UK Championship]]

CATEGORIES: Articles with hCards, UK Championship

The UK Championship is a snooker tournament. It is one of the Triple Crown events, along with the World Championship and the Masters. It is the second-biggest ranking tournament, after the World Championship. Ronnie O'Sullivan has won the most times. Ding Junhui is the current champion.

[[2019 UK Championship]]

CATEGORIES: Pages using deprecated image syntax, UK Championship, 2019 in sports

The 2019 UK Championship was a professional snooker tournament. It took place from 26 November to 8 December 2019. It was the 43rd UK Championship, and the seventh ranking tournament and the first Triple Crown event of the 2019–20 season. The event was shown on BBC Sport in the United Kingdom and on Eurosport in Europe. The tournament was sponsored by betting company Betway.

Ronnie O'Sullivan had won the 2018 event. O'Sullivan was beaten in the last 16 by Ding Junhui. Ding played Stephen Maguire in the final. Ding beat Maguire 10–6 to win his third UK championship.

[[2018 UK Championship]]

CATEGORIES: UK Championship, 2018 in sports

The 2018 UK Championship was a snooker tournament, that took place from 27 November to 9 December 2018. It was the ninth ranking tournament and the first Triple Crown event of the 2018/2019 season. The event was shown on BBC Sport and Eurosport in the United Kingdom.

Ronnie O'Sullivan, the defending champion, defeated Mark Allen 10–6 in the final, winning his 7th UK Championship and his 34th ranking event overall. Stuart Bingham made the event's highest break of 145 in the first frame of his third round match against David Gilbert.

[[Kamil Tolon]]

CATEGORIES: Inventors

Kamil Özdemir Tolon, better known as Kamil Tolon, (29 February 1912 - 23 July 1978) is a Turkish Entrepreneur, scientist, businessman and  industrialist.

[[Krymsky Bridge]]

CATEGORIES: Suspension bridges, Moscow

The Krymsky Bridge, also called the Crimean Bridge (Крымский мост), is a 6-lane steel suspension bridge in Moscow. It crosses the Moskva River 1.8 southwest of the Kremlin. The bridge links the Crimean Square on the north side to the Krymsky Val street on the south side. It was built in 1938 and was part of Joseph Stalin's rebuilding of Central Moscow. It is the fourth bridge to be built on the site and the only suspension bridge in Moscow.

[[Philo of Byzantium]]

CATEGORIES: 280s BC births, Ancient Greece

Philo of Byzantium (Φίλων ὁ Βυζάντιος, about 280 BC to about 220 BC). He was also known as Philo Mechanicus.  He was a Greek engineer, physicist and writer on mechanics. Although from Byzantium, he lived most of his life in Alexandria, Egypt. 

Philo was the author of a large work, Mechanike syntaxis (Compendium of Mechanics). 

[[Gladys Aylward]]

CATEGORIES: 1902 births, 1970 deaths

Gladys May Aylward (24 February 1902 – 3 January 1970) was a British-born evangelical Christian missionary to China, whose story was told in the book The Small Woman, by Alan Burgess, published in 1957.

[[John Mayow]]

CATEGORIES: 1641 births, British chemists, 1679 deaths

John Mayow FRS (1641–1679) was a chemist, physician, and physiologist who is known today for doing early research into respiration and the nature of air.  Mayow worked in a field that is sometimes called pneumatic chemistry.

[[Gérard Lamy]]

CATEGORIES: 1919 births, 2016 deaths, Members of the House of Commons of Canada from Quebec

Gérard Lamy (2 May 1919 – 26 October 2016) was a Canadian politician. He was a member of Parliament (MP) in the House of Commons of Canada from 1962 to 1963. During this time, he represented the electoral area of Saint-Maurice—Laflèche and was a part of the Social Credit Party. Lamy was born on 2 May 1919 in Shawinigan, Quebec. Before becoming a politician, he was a contractor.

Lamy was only elected one time, in the 1962 federal election. He beat the incumbent Liberal MP, Joseph-Adolphe Richard. Lamy was part of the first group of 26 Social Credit MPs from Quebec who were elected that year. In the election the year after, he lost his election. This was very unexpected, because both Lamy and the Liberal Party thought he would not lose the election. The person that beat him was Liberal Jean Chrétien. Chrétien would later become the Prime Minister of Canada.

Lamy tried to win two more elections after this. In the 1970 Quebec provincial election, he lost his election as a part of the Ralliement créditiste du Québec. In the 1979 general election, he lost his election as a part of the Progressive Conservative Party. Lamy did not run for election ever again after 1979. He died in Trois-Rivières, Quebec, on 26 October 2016.

[[Arrowsmith]]

CATEGORIES: Archery

An arrowsmith is a person to takes on an occupation/role/job that forges the heads of arrows. This is usually brought up in medieval history, as more modern jobs came along, and just a small amount of the population (most of those people working for rural purposes), has the occupation today. The idea of archery was created in 20,000 BC. Like today, people did not use the bow and arrow on a regular basis. But unlike today, they mostly used this new creation for hunting. The first people ever to use it normally was the ancient Egyptians from 4,000-2,000 BC. Then the bows started to take a fall in popularity across the world, as gunpowder was invented, along with the cannon. It spread across eurasia, after being invented in China in the third century. (200AD)

[[Block (periodic table)]]

CATEGORIES: Periodic table

A block on the periodic table is a group of elements that all have their electrons in the same atomic orbital. There are four blocks, s-, d-, f, and p-. The word "block" was first used to describe this by Charles Janet.

[[Swaminarayan Akshardham (New Delhi)]]

CATEGORIES: New Delhi

Swaminarayan Akshardham is a Hindu temple, and a spiritual-cultural campus in New Delhi, India

[[Kakuei Tanaka]]

CATEGORIES: 1918 births, 1993 deaths, Japanese politicians

Kakuei Tanaka was a Japanese politician who served in the House of Representatives from 1947 to 1990, and was Prime Minister of Japan from 1972 to 1974.

[[Residue (chemistry)]]

CATEGORIES: Chemistry

In chemistry, residue is what is left behind after preparation, separation, or purification, such as distillation, evaporation, or filtration.

[[Daniel O'Donnell]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, Living people, Irish singers, People from County Donegal

Daniel O'Donnell (born 12 December 1961) is an Irish singer. 

[[Oxygen concentrator]]

CATEGORIES: Medicine

An oxygen concentrator is a machine that takes in air and takes out some of the nitrogen (as N2) so there is more oxygen (as O2). This new air with more oxygen is then given to a patient during oxygen therapy.

[[Masayoshi Itō]]

CATEGORIES: 1913 births, 1994 deaths, Prime Ministers of Japan

Masayoshi Itō was a Japanese politician. He was the acting Prime Minister of Japan in 1980 after the sudden death of Masayoshi Ōhira. He became Foreign Minister from 1980 to 1981.

[[Malayali]]

CATEGORIES: Dravidian peoples, Ethnic groups in India

The Malayali people (also spelled Mayalee people) are the native speakers of the Malayalam language. They originate from the south of the current Indian state of Kerala. Sometimes they are called Keralites. There are about 39 million people who speak Malayam as their first language. 34 million of these live in India, about 1 million in the United Arab Emirates. About 55% are Hindus, about 27% are Muslims, and about 19% are Christian.

The Malayali language is part of the Dravidian language group.  The Malayali have their own cooking styles, movies, and form of martial arts, Kalaripayattu.

The United Nations declared a Malayali dance called Kathakali Intangible Cultural Heritage.

[[Ole Borch]]

CATEGORIES: 1626 births, 1690 deaths, Danish scientists

Ole Borch (1626 – 1690) (latinized to Olaus Borrichius or Olaus Borrichus) was a Danish scientist, physician, grammarian, and poet, most well-known today for being the teacher at the Vor Frue Skole in Copenhagen of Nicholas Steno. 

[[Pierre Bayen]]

CATEGORIES: 1725 births, 1798 deaths, French chemists

Pierre Bayen (7 February 1725–14 February 1798) was a French chemist.

[[Johann Joachim Becher]]

CATEGORIES: 1635 births, 1682 deaths

Johann Joachim Becher (ˈbɛçɐ; 6 May 1635 – October 1682) was a German physician, and alchemist,  best known for his development of the phlogiston theory of combustion, and his advancement of Austrian cameralism.

[[Tanzan Ishibashi]]

CATEGORIES: 1884 births, 1973 deaths, Politicians from Tokyo, People from Yamanashi Prefecture, Prime Ministers of Japan, Japanese journalists, Waseda University alumni

Tanzan Ishibashi was a Japanese journalist and politician who was Prime Minister of Japan from 1956 to 1957. He studied at Waseda University. He was a journalist for the Mainichi Shimbun.

[[Mairelis Zunzunegui]]

Mairelis Zunzunegui (born 8 July 1986) is a Cuban water polo player.

She was a member of the Cuba women's national water polo team at the 2019 Pan American Games and 2019 World Aquatics Championships.

[[Columbia County, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: 1790s establishments in Georgia (U.S. state), 1790 establishments in the United States, Georgia (U.S. state) counties

Columbia County is a county in the U.S. state of Georgia. As of the 2010 census, 124,035 people lived there. The legal county seat is Appling, but the de facto seat of county government is Evans.

[[His Private Secretary]]
