[[Richard Herd]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from colorectal cancer, Cancer deaths in Los Angeles, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, Actors from Boston, Massachusetts

Richard Herd, Jr. (September 26, 1932 – May 26, 2020) was an American actor. He was born in Boston, Massachusetts. He was known for playing Mr. Wilhelm on Seinfeld. He also played James W. McCord, Jr. in the 1976 political thriller All the President's Men.

Herd died of colorectal cancer-related problems in Los Angeles on May 26, 2020 at the age of 87.

[[Mirage (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1960s mystery movies, 1965 thriller movies, American mystery movies, American thriller movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Edward Dmytryk

Mirage is a 1965 American mystery thriller movie directed by Edward Dmytryk and based on the 1952 novel Fallen Angel by Howard Fast. It stars Gregory Peck, Diane Baker, Walter Matthau, Kevin McCarthy, Jack Weston, Leif Erickson, Walter Abel, George Kennedy, Hari Rhodes and was distributed by Universal Pictures.

[[How to Murder Your Wife]]

CATEGORIES: 1965 comedy movies, American black comedy movies, Movies directed by Richard Quine

How to Murder Your Wife is a 1965 American black comedy movie directed by Richard Quine and starring Jack Lemmon, Virna Lisi, Terry-Thomas, Claire Trevor, Eddie Mayehoff, Jack Albertson. It was distributed by United Artists.

[[Solo Sunny]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 drama movies, 1980s musical movies, German drama movies

Solo Sunny is a 1980 East German musical drama movie directed by Konrad Wolf and Wolfgang Kohlhaase. It stars Renate Krößner, Alexander Lang, Fred Düren, Klaus Händel, Olaf Mierau.

[[Once Is Never]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 comedy movies, German comedy movies

Once Is Never (Einmal ist keinmal) is a 1955 East German comedy movie directed by Konrad Wolf and starring Horst Drinda, Brigitte Krause, Paul Schulz-Wernburg, Hillmar Thate, Johannes Arpe. It was distributed by VEB Progess Film.

[[Squad Car]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 drama movies, 1960s crime drama movies, American crime drama movies

Squad Car is a 1960 American crime drama movie directed by Ed Leftwich and stars Paul Bryar, Vici Raaf, Don Marlowe. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Anne-Élisabeth Blateau]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 births, French actors

Anne Elizabeth Blateau  (born July 28 , 1976 in Paris) is a French actress and playwright.

[[Aeacus]]

CATEGORIES: Greek gods and goddesses

Aeacus was a mythological king of the island of Aegina in the Saronic Gulf. Aeacus was the son of Zeus and Aegina. When Aeacus died, he became one of the three judges in Hades.

[[Senlis]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Oise, Subprefectures in France

Senlis (sɑ̃lis) is a commune in the northern French department of Oise.

The monarchs of the early French dynasties lived in Senlis. It is known for the Chantilly forest nearby. It is also known for its Gothic cathedral and other historical monuments. 

The people that live here are called "Senlisiens" and "Senlisiennes".

[[June A. Willenz]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, American civil rights activists, American political writers, American feminist writers, Writers from New York City

June Adele Willenz (née Friedenberg; December 17, 1924 – May 3, 2020) was an American military veterans activist and writer. Willenz was born in New York City.

She was an  Executive Director of the American Veterans Committee (AVC). She was the author of Women Veterans: America's Forgotten Heroines (Continuum, 1983). Willenz also help build the Women in Military Service for America Memorial at Arlington National Cemetery. She was added into the Maryland Women's Hall of Fame in 2011.

Willenz died on May 3, 2020 in Bethesda, Maryland of a heart attack, aged 95.

[[Anthony Bailey (author)]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United Kingdom, British historians, Writers from Hampshire

Anthony Bailey (5 January 1933 – 13 May 2020) was a British writer and art historian.

In 1955, he emigrated to New York City and became a staff writer at The New Yorker magazine for over 30 years. He wrote twenty-three books, including biographies of artists J. M. W. Turner, John Constable, and two books on Rembrandt.

He lived on Mersea Island, near Colchester, Essex. He died on 13 May 2020 of COVID-19, aged 87. 

[[Julitta Münch]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, 2020 deaths, German journalists, German television presenters, People from Düsseldorf

Julitta Münch (25 July 1959 – 21 May 2020) was a German presenter and journalist. She was born in Düsseldorf, Germany. In 1992, she and Jürgen Drensek became the first presenters of the ARD-Morgenmagazin, which she presented until 1994. 

From 1995, she worked at WDR 5, where she presented Morgenecho and Neugier genügt. From 1997 to the end of 2010, Münch took over the radio broadcast program Hallo Ü-Wagen at WDR 5.

Münch died on 21 May 2020 in Lohmar, Germany, aged 60.

[[André Cartier]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in Canada, Canadian movie actors, Canadian television actors, Canadian voice actors, Canadian stage actors, Actors from Quebec, Writers from Quebec

André Cartier (24 December 1945 – 22 May 2020) was a Canadian actor. He was known for playing André in the children's series Passe-Partout. Cartier was born in Montreal, Quebec. He also starred in Sol et Gobelet, Bound for Glory, Les Oraliens and La bonne aventure.

Cartier died on 22 May 2020 in Dunham, Quebec of cancer at the age of 74.

[[José Roberto Figueroa]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cardiac arrest, Honduran footballers

José Roberto Figueroa Padilla, also known as Macho, (15 December 1959 – 24 May 2020) was a Honduran footballer. He played as a forward, in Honduras for F.C. Motagua, C.D.S. Vida and in Spain for Real Murcia and Hércules CF. He also represented Honduras at the 1982 FIFA World Cup.

Figueroa was born in Olanchito, Honduras. He died on 24 May 2020 in San Francisco, California of cardiac arrest, aged 60.

[[Ricardo Barreda]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cardiopulmonary arrest, Deaths from Alzheimer's disease, People convicted of assault, People convicted of murder, People from Buenos Aires

Ricardo Alberto Barreda (16 June 1936 – 25 May 2020) was an Argentine convicted mass murderer and former dentist. He was born in La Plata, Argentina. In 1992, he murdered his wife, two daughters and his mother-in-law. In 1995, he was sentenced to life imprisonment. He was granted house arrest in 2011, but was soon put back in jail after raping someone in Buenos Aires. 

Barreda died of cardiopulmonary arrest caused by Alzheimer's disease on 25 May 2020 in Buenos Aires, aged 83.

[[Francis Dufour]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Politicians from Quebec

Francis Dufour (March 28, 1929 – May 25, 2020) was a Canadian politician. He was the member for Jonquière in the National Assembly of Quebec from 1985 to 1996. He was a member of the Parti Québécois from 1985 until 1996. Dufour was born in Jonquière, Quebec. 

Dufour died on May 25, 2020 in Jonquière at the age of 91.

[[Summer Bishil]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 births, American child actors, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, Living people, Actors from Pasadena, California

Summer Yasmine Bishil (born July 17, 1988) is an American actress. She became well known for her roles as Jasira in the 2007 movie Towelhead and as Taslima in the 2009 movie Crossing Over. She is also known for her role as Margo Hanson on the Syfy fantasy drama series The Magicians.

Bishil was born in Pasadena, California. 

[[İsmail Hakkı Karadayı]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from multiple organ failure, Turkish politicians, Turkish military people, Generals

İsmail Hakkı Karadayı (1932 – 26 May 2020) was a Turkish general and politician. He became the 20th Commander of the Turkish Armed Forces on 30 August 1993. Between 1994 and 1998, he was the 22nd Chief of the Turkish General Staff. He was born in Çankırı, Turkey.

On 13 April 2018, a Turkish court sentenced him to life imprisonment for his role in the 1997 Turkish military memorandum.

Karadayı died on 26 May 2020 in Istanbul of multiple organ failure, aged 87–88.

[[Grand Lisboa]]

CATEGORIES: Buildings and structures in China

Grand Lisboa (新葡京) is a 47-floor, 261 hotel in Sé, Macau, China. It is owned by Sociedade de Turismo e Diversões de Macau and designed by Hong Kong architects Dennis Lau and Ng Chun Man. 

Its casino and restaurants were opened on February 11, 2007, while the hotel was opened in December 2008. The casino offers 800 gaming tables and 1,000 slot machines. The hotel has 430 hotel rooms and suites. The Grand Lisboa is the tallest building in Macau.

The casino is the first in Macau to offer Texas hold 'em poker ring games. It was also the first to offer craps, though several other casinos in Macau now offer the game.

In 2017 it was reported that the Grand Lisboa had the lowest revenue and profits during 2016. It was owned by businessman Stanley Ho.

[[Stanley Ho]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from renal failure, Chinese philanthropists, Chinese businesspeople

Stanley Ho Hung-sun GBM GLM GBS GML OBE (Chinese:何鴻燊, 25 November 1921 – 26 May 2020) was a Hong Kong-Macau billionaire businessman, and philanthropist. He was the founder and chairman of SJM Holdings. It owned nineteen casinos in Macau including the Grand Lisboa.

Ho had been nicknamed Godfather and King of Gambling. He was an important person on the Macau gambling industry for 75 years.

Ho was also the founder and chairman of Shun Tak Holdings, through which he owned many  businesses including entertainment, tourism, shipping, real estate, banking, and air transport. It was said that his businesses employ almost one-fourth of the workforce of Macau.

Ho died on 26 May 2020 at a hospital in Hong Kong of kidney failure, aged 98.

[[Vladimir Lopukhin]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Russia, Soviet politicians, Russian politicians, Economists, People from Moscow

Vladimir Mikhailovich Lopukhin (23 May 1952 – 26 May 2020) was a Soviet-born Russian politician and economist. He was born in Moscow. He worked for the Institute of World Economy and International Relations. He was the Minister of Energy from 10 November 1991 to 30 May 1992. 

Lopukhin died on 26 May 2020 in Moscow of COVID-19, three days after his 68th birthday.

[[Christian Mbulu]]

CATEGORIES: 1996 births, 2020 deaths, Black British sportspeople, English footballers, Sportspeople from London

Christian Mbulu (6 August 1996snd26 May 2020) was an English professional footballer. He played as a defender. Mbulu was born in Newham, England. 

He played for Brentwood Town F.C. from 2013 to 2015. From 2015 to 2018, he played for Millwall F.C.. From 2019 to 2020, he played for Crewe Alexandra F.C.. In 2020, he played for Morecambe F.C..

Mbulu died on 26 May 2020 at his home in Cottam, Lancashire, aged 23.

[[Li Ka-shing]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, Living people, Chinese philanthropists, Chinese businesspeople

Sir Li Ka-shing (born 13 June 1928) is a Hong Kong businessman, investor, and philanthropist. As of June 2019, Li is the 30th richest person in the world. He has a wealth of US$29.4 billion.

He is the senior advisor for CK Hutchison Holdings and CK Asset Holdings, after he retired from the Chairman of the Board in May 2018; through it, he is the world's leading port investor, developer, and operator of the largest health and beauty retailer in Asia and Europe.

[[Lee Shau-kee]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, Living people, Chinese businesspeople, Chinese philanthropists

Lee Shau-kee GBM (李; born 20 February 1928) is a Hong Kong businessman, investor, and philanthropist. He is well known real estate tycoon and majority owner of Henderson Land Development. In 2019, aged 91, Lee retired as chairman and managing director of the company.

His personal wealth is said to be $31.5 billion, making him the second wealthiest man in Hong Kong, and the 27th richest in the world

[[Sab Shimono]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American stage actors, Japanese movie actors, Japanese television actors, Japanese stage actors, Japanese voice actors, Gay men, LGBT actors, LGBT people from California, Actors from Sacramento, California

Saburo Shimono (born July 31, 1937) is a Japanese–American actor. He began his career on stage on Broadway. His best known roles were in Mame, Lovely Ladies, Kind Gentlemen, and Pacific Overtures. 

He has appeared in many movies and television shows in character roles, including Midway, Gung Ho, Presumed Innocent, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles III, The Shadow, Samurai Jack, and Southland Tales. He also voiced Monk Gyatso / Master Yu in Avatar: The Last Airbender.

Shimono was born in Sacramento, California. He is openly gay.

[[John Noble]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, Living people, Australian movie actors, Australian television actors, Australian stage actors, Australian voice actors, Actors from South Australia

John Noble (born 20 August 1948) is an Australian actor and theatre director. He was born in Port Pirie, South Australia.

He is best known for his roles as Dr. Walter Bishop in the US Fox science fiction television series Fringe and Henry Parrish in the Fox action-horror series Sleepy Hollow. His best known movie role was as  Denethor in Peter Jackson's The Lord of the Rings trilogy. 

He also provided the voice of the DC Comics supervillain Scarecrow in the 2015 video game Batman: Arkham Knight.

In 2015, he joined the main cast of the television series Elementary as Sherlock Holmes's father. He was also cast as a doctor in the Australian TV series All Saints. 

In 2012, Noble was diagnosed with osteoporosis.

[[Bob Lynn]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Disease-related deaths in California, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Los Angeles, California, Politicians from Alaska, People from Anchorage, Alaska, US Republican Party politicians

Bob Lynn (February 23, 1933 – May 25, 2020) was an American politician. He was a Republican member of the Alaska House of Representatives, representing the 31st district from 2003 to 2013 and the 26th district from 2013 to 2017. He was born in Los Angeles.

He was Chair of the State Affairs Committee, was Vice-Chair of the Judiciary Committee, and was a member of the Transportation Committee and Joint Armed Forces Committees.  He also was on the Labor & Workforce Development, Military & Veterans' Affairs, and Public Safety Finance Subcommittees, for the 28th Legislature. 

Lynn died on May 25, 2020 in California from a long-illness, aged 87.

[[Murder of George Floyd]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 in the United States, History of Minneapolis, Minnesota, May 2020 events, Police misconduct, Black Lives Matter, Racially-motivated violence in the United States

Derek Chauvin, a white police officer, murdered George Floyd, a 46 year old African-American man, during an arrest on May 25, 2020 in Minneapolis, Minnesota. The murder started the George Floyd protests against racism in the United States and in other countries.

George Floyd was a 46 year old African-American man from Houston, Texas. Chauvin, a police officer of the Minneapolis Police Department, killed Floyd while he was under arrest for using counterfeit cash. Chauvin put his knee on Floyd's neck for nearly nine minutes while Floyd was gasping for breath. Witnesses said Floyd told the officers, "I can't breathe" many times before he lost consciousness. This happened in the Powderhorn area of Minneapolis. 

The event was recorded on many mobile phones. Four officers involved were fired the next day. The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced a federal civil rights investigation into the incident.

In late May, after days of protests, the officer who killed Floyd, Derek Chauvin, was charged with third-degree murder and manslaughter. The charge was later changed to second-degree murder. The three other officers were charged on June 3 with aiding and abetting second-degree murder, meaning they are charged with helping Chauvin kill Floyd.

Chauvin's trial began on March 9, 2021. On April 20, 2021, a jury found Chauvin guilty. On June 25, Chauvin was given a sentence of 22 years and six months in prison.

[[George Floyd]]

CATEGORIES: 1973 births, 2020 deaths, American burglars, American rap musicians from North Carolina, American robbers, American thieves, Criminals from Texas, Deaths from asphyxiation, Murdered African-American people, People convicted of drug offenses, People from North Carolina, Singers from Houston, Texas, Singers from North Carolina, American manslaughter victims

his death

George Perry Floyd Jr. (October 14, 1973 - May 25, 2020) was an African American man  who was murdered by a white police officer, Derek Chauvin, who knelt on Floyd's neck for almost 8 minutes7:46 not 8:46 Many people were sad and angry about his death, which led to many protests in order to stop violence and racism against Black people.

George Floyd was born in North Carolina. He grew up in Houston, Texas. He played football and basketball throughout high school and college. He held several jobs, and he was also a hip hop artist and a mentor in his religious community. Between 1997 and 2005, he was convicted of eight crimes; in 2009, he accepted a plea bargain for a 2007 armed robbery, serving four years in prison. In 2014, he moved to Minneapolis, finding work as a truck driver and a bouncer. In 2020, he lost his security job during the COVID-19 pandemic.

[[Pashupati Sharma]]

CATEGORIES: Folk singers, Living people, Nepalese musicians, Nepalese singers, 1982 births

Pashupati Sharma is a Nepalese folk singer born on 31 October 1982 in Putalibazar Municipality Ward Number 3 of Syangja District, Nepal. Sharma moved to Kathmandu on 2003 for his further studies, as he was interested in singing he started singing in Saptakoshi Dohori Sanjh (a duet folk singing club) and released his first official song on 2003. Sharma has already sung more than 1000 songs during his career. His songs revolves around patriotism, love and satire One of his latest satire song Lutna Sake Lut was recently forced to remove from YouTube.

[[Taft, California]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in California, Settlements in Kern County, California

Taft (formerly Moron, Moro, and Siding Number Two) is a city in the edge of the San Joaquin Valley, in Kern County, California. Taft is located 32 west-southwest of Bakersfield. The population was 9,327 at the 2010 census. According to the United States Census Bureau, the city has a total area of 15.1.

It was named for President William H. Taft in 1909.

[[Liesbeth Migchelsen]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cancer, Dutch football managers, Dutch footballers, Sportspeople from Gelderland

Liesbeth Migchelsen (11 March 1971 – 27 May 2020) was a Dutch footballer. She represented the Netherlands women's national team 95 times between 1990 and 2008. Micgchelsen played in Germany for FFC Heike Rheine and in The Netherlands for S.V. Fortuna Wormerveer and AZ Alkmaar. She coached Australian W-League team Canberra United FC from 2013 to 2014.

Migchelsen was born in Harderwijk, Netherlands. She died on 27 May 2020 of cancer, aged 49.

[[Elizabeth Hubbard]]

CATEGORIES: Emmy Award winning actors, 1933 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, Actors from New York City

Elizabeth Hubbard (born December 22, 1933) is an American actress. She is best known for her role as Dr. Althea Davis on The Doctors (1964-69, 1970-78, 1981-82) and powerful businesswoman Lucinda Walsh on As the World Turns (1984-2010). 

She also played roles on The Edge of Night, One Life to Live, and Guiding Light. 

[[Judith Guest]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, Living people, American novelists, American screenwriters, Writers from Detroit, Michigan

Judith Guest (born March 29, 1936) is an American novelist and screenwriter. She was born in Detroit, Michigan. She is the great-niece of Poet Laureate Edgar Guest (1881–1959). She is a winner of the Janet Heidinger Kafka Prize.

Guest's first book, Ordinary People was published in 1976. The 1980 movie version, Ordinary People won the Academy Award for Best Picture.

Guest co-authored the mystery Killing Time in St. Cloud (1988) with novelist Rebecca Hill. Guest's most recent book, The Tarnished Eye (2004).

[[Mariclare Costello]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, People from Peoria, Illinois, Living people, American television actors, American movie actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, American educators, Actors from Los Angeles, California, Actors from Illinois

Mariclare Costello (born February 3, 1936) is an American actress and educator. She is a lifetime member of The Actors Studio. Her best known roles were as Rosemary Hunter Fordwick on the television series The Waltons, from 1972 to 1977. 

In 1977, after her role on The Waltons, she played Maggie Fitzpatrick on the short-lived drama show The Fitzpatricks.

Costello was born in Peoria, Illinois. From 1977 until his death in 2013, she was married to actor Allan Arbus. She is an acting professor at Loyola Marymount University in Los Angeles.

[[Grand Haven, Michigan]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Michigan, County seats in Michigan

Grand Haven is a city in the U.S. state of Michigan and the county seat of Ottawa County. As of the 2010 census, Grand Haven had a population of 10,412. It is part of the Grand Rapids Metropolitan Area.

[[Grand Haven Charter Township, Michigan]]

CATEGORIES: Townships in Michigan

Grand Haven Charter Township is a charter township of Ottawa County in the U.S. state of Michigan.  The population was 15,178 at the 2010 census. The Grand Haven Township is located immediately south of Grand Haven.

[[The Disappearance of Finbar]]

CATEGORIES: 1996 drama movies, 1996 mystery movies, Irish movies, Swedish movies

The Disappearance of Finbar is a 1996 Irish Swedish mystery drama movie directed by Sue Clayton and starring Jonathan Rhys Meyers, Colin Farrell, Lorraine Pilkington. It was distributed by Channel 4 Films.

[[Mool mantar]]

CATEGORIES: Sikhism

The Mool Mantar (also spelled Mul Mantar) is the opening verse of the Guru Granth Sahib, the Sikh holy book. The verse is repeated many times throughout the book.

[[Kate Garraway]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 births

Kathryn Mary Garraway (born 4 May 1967) is an English broadcaster and journalist. In the 1990s, Garraway was a journalist for ITV News Central and later a co-presenter of ITV News Meridian. From 2000 to 2010, she has co-presented GMTV. Currently, Garraway is the presenter of Mid Mornings with Kate Garraway on Smooth Radio and newsreader (on Thursdays) and co-anchor (on Fridays) of the ITV Breakfast programme Good Morning Britain.

[[The Morning After (1986 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1980s mystery movies, 1986 thriller movies, American mystery movies, American thriller movies, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Sidney Lumet

The Morning After is a 1986 American mystery thriller movie directed by Sidney Lumet and starring Jane Fonda in her Oscar nominated role, Jeff Bridges, Raul Julia, Kathy Bates, Diane Salinger, Kathleen Wilhoite. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Cofresh]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 establishments in the United Kingdom, Manufacturing, Food companies of the United Kingdom, Leicester

Cofresh Snack Foods is a company that makes savoury snacks. It is based in Leicester, United Kingdom. The company earns £28 million a year.

Cofresh was started in 1974 by an Indian family who moved from Kenya to Leicester, and used their fish and chip shop to make snacks, such as Bombay Mix. 

[[Kama (river)]]

CATEGORIES: Rivers of Russia

The Kama (Ка́ма, ˈkamə; Чулман/Çulman'; Udmurt: Кам) is a river in Russia. It is 1805 long and is a large tributary of the Volga river. It is one of the biggest tributaries of the river.

Koto Matsudaira was a Japanese diplomat from Tokyo who was an Ambassador to the United Nations from 1957 to 1961.

[[Siilinjärvi carbonatite]]

CATEGORIES: Finland, Geology

The Siilinjärvi carbonatite complex is in Central Finland near to Kuopio. It is named after the village it is next to, Siilinjärvi. It is a carbonatite mine. The complex is about 16 long. The place was discovered in 1950 by the Geological Survey of Finland. They began mining it in 1958. It is the second-largest carbonatite complex in Finland. The Sokli mine is the biggest.

[[Gilles Grondin]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2005 deaths, Cancer deaths in Canada, Members of the House of Commons of Canada from Quebec, Canadian mayors

Gilles Grondin (3 February 1943 – 18 July 2005) was a Canadian politician. He was the mayor of Shawinigan-Sud, Quebec from 1977 to 1985. He was also a member of Parliament (MP) in the House of Commons of Canada from 1986 to 1988. He represented the electoral area of Saint-Maurice. During this time, he was a part of the Liberal Party.

As a politician, he was the mayor of Shawinigan-Sud for two terms. He did not try to get elected for a third time. Instead, he was elected in a by-election in 1986 to replace Jean Chrétien. This was for the federal House of Commons. In the 1988 federal election, he did not run for re-election. He was replaced by Denis Pronovost, who was a part of the Progressive Conservative Party.

Grondin died in 2005. He had cancer for a very long time.

[[Crew Dragon Demo-2]]

CATEGORIES: May 2020 events

SpaceX Demo-2 (also referred to as SpaceX Demonstration Mission 2, or Demo-2) is the first crewed test flight of the Crew Dragon spacecraft, from the company SpaceX. It launched on 30 May 2020 at 19:22:45 UTC (3:22:45 PM EDT). It is heading to the International Space Station.

It was originally scheduled for 27 May 2020 at 20:33:33 UTC (4:33:33 PM EDT), but was stopped 16 minutes before take-off due to bad weather.

Demo-2 is the first crewed orbital spaceflight launched from the United States since the final Space Shuttle mission, STS-135, in 2011, on which Douglas G. Hurley was the pilot.

Hurley is be spacecraft commander on Crew Dragon Demo-2, joined by Robert L. Behnken as joint operations commander.

Crew Dragon Demo-2 is also the first two-person orbital spaceflight launched from the United States since STS-4 in 1982.

[[SpaceX Dragon 2]]

CATEGORIES: Spacecraft

SpaceX Dragon 2 is a class of reusable spacecraft created by American aerospace manufacturer SpaceX as the replacement to the Dragon 1 cargo spacecraft. 

The spacecraft launches atop a Falcon 9 Block 5 rocket and returns to Earth via an ocean splashdown. The spacecraft can dock itself to the ISS instead of being berthed.  

It has two versions; Crew Dragon, a human-rated capsule capable of carrying up to seven astronauts, and Cargo Dragon, an updated replacement for the original Dragon spacecraft.

Crew Dragon is equipped with an integrated launch escape system in a set of four side thruster pods with two SuperDraco engines each. The spacecraft features redesigned solar arrays.

[[Oleh Hornykiewicz]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, Austrian scientists, Polish scientists, Biochemists, Wolf Prize winners

Oleh Hornykiewicz (17 November 1926 – 26 May 2020) was a Polish-born Austrian Wolf Prize-winning biochemist. Hornykiewicz was born in Sykhiw (a district of Lviv), then in Poland (now Ukraine). 

He was chairman of the Institute of Biochemical Pharmacology at the University of Vienna for twenty years. In 1967, he began a long career with the University of Toronto in Canada and, in 1992, he was named professor emeritus at that institution.

He discovered that Parkinson's disease was due to dopamine deficiency in the brain. He also played a key role in the development of L-dopa as a therapy for the disorder.

Hornykiewicz died on 26 May 2020, aged 93.

[[Biff Pocoroba]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2020 deaths, Atlanta Braves players, Sportspeople from California, Businesspeople from California, People from Burbank, California

Biff Benedict Pocoroba (July 25, 1953 – May 24, 2020) was a Major League Baseball catcher who also played a few games at third base. He was born in Burbank, California. He played for the Atlanta Braves from 1975 to 1984. In 1978, he made the National League All-Star team. He retired at the age of 30.

In retirement, Pocoroba was known for creating a business where he made his own sausages.

Pocoroba died on May 24, 2020 at the age of 66.

[[Early County, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: 1818 establishments in Georgia (U.S. state), Georgia (U.S. state) counties

Early County is a county in the U.S. state of Georgia. As of the 2010 census, 11,008 people lived there. The county seat is Blakely.

[[Fannin County, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: 1854 establishments in Georgia (U.S. state), Georgia (U.S. state) counties

Fannin County is a county in the U.S. state of Georgia. As of the 2010 census, 23,682 people lived there. The county seat is Blue Ridge. The county was created on January 21, 1854.

Chahar Mahaal and Bakhtiari Province (استان چهارمحال و بختیاری, Ostān-e Chahār-Mahāl-o Bakhtiyārī ) is one of the 31 provinces of Iran. Its capital is Shahr-e Kord.

[[Daisies (song)]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 songs, Katy Perry songs

"Daisies" is a song by American singer Katy Perry. It was released on May 15, 2020.  Perry wrote the song with Jonathan Bellion, Jacob Kasher Hindlin, Jordan K. Johnson, Stefan Johnson, and Michael Pollack.  The song was produced by The Monsters & the Strangerz.

The song entered the Billboard Hot 100 at number 40.

[[Qizha]]

CATEGORIES: Middle Eastern foods, Cakes

Qizha (in Arabic:  قزحة, like: Kiz-ha) is a Syrian and Palestinian semolina cake. It is made from Semolina flour flavored with crushed Nigella seeds.

Rachael Finch (born July 8, 1988) is an Australian television host, model and beauty pageant titleholder. She finished 4th in Miss Universe 2009 pageant.

[[Al Mokawloon Al Arab SC]]

CATEGORIES: 1970s establishments in Egypt, 1973 establishments in Africa, Football clubs, Egypt

Al Mokawloon Al Arab Sporting Club is an Egyptian football club. Liverpool star Mohamed Salah started his career there.

[[The Carey Treatment]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 crime movies, 1970s mystery movies, American mystery movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Blake Edwards

The Carey Treatment is a 1972 mystery movie directed by Blake Edwards and based on the 1968 novel A Case of Need by Michael Crichton. It stars James Coburn, Jennifer O'Neill, Pat Hingle, Elizabeth Allen, John Fink, James Hong, Jennifer Edwards and was distributed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

[[The Prodigal]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 drama movies, American drama movies, Movies directed by Richard Thorpe

The Prodigal is a 1955 American drama movie directed by Richard Thorpe and starring Lana Turner, Edmund Purdom, Louis Calhern, Audrey Dalton, Neville Brand, Walter Hampden, Cecil Kellaway, Joseph Wiseman. It was distributed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

[[Dark Command]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 movies, 1940s western movies, American western movies, Movies directed by Raoul Walsh

Dark Command is a 1940 American western movie directed by Raoul Walsh and based on the novel by W. R. Burnett. It stars John Wayne, Claire Trevor, Walter Pidgeon, Roy Rogers, George "Gabby" Hayes, Porter Hall, Marjorie Main and was distributed by Republic Pictures. It was nominated for 2 Academy Awards in 1941.

The movie was nominated for two Academy Awards for Best Original Score and Best Art Direction by John Victor Mackay.

[[The Life of General Villa]]

CATEGORIES: 1914 movies, 1910s drama movies, American action movies, American drama movies, American silent movies, Movies directed by Raoul Walsh, Movies directed by Christy Cabanne

The Life of General Villa is a 1914 American action drama movie directed by Christy Cabanne and starring Pancho Villa, Raoul Walsh, Teddy Sampson, Irene Hunt, Walter Long. It is lost movie.

[[Kevin Lloyd]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 1998 deaths, British actors

Kevin Reardon Lloyd was born 28 March, 1949 in Derby and died 2 May, 1998 in Burton-on-Trent. He was a British actor best known for playing DC Alfred Tosh Lines in ITV The Bill, Harry Blackburn in Auf Wiedersen, Pet and Don Watkins in Coronation Street. He has also appeared in Britannia Hospital, Link, Don't Open till Christmas, Billy the Kid and the Green Baize Vampire, A Dirty Knight's Work. He was the older brother of ITN journalist Terry Lloyd.

[[James Langevin]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, Living people, United States representatives from Rhode Island, 20th-century American politicians, 21st-century American politicians, People from Providence, Rhode Island

James R. Langevin (born April 22, 1964) is an American politician from Rhode Island. He has represented Rhode Island's 2nd congressional district since January 2001. He is a part of the Democratic Party. He was also the Secretary of State of Rhode Island between 1995 and 2001. Langevin is the first quadriplegic to be a part of the United States Congress.

[[MATLAB]]

CATEGORIES: Technology, Computer science, Computing, Mathematics, Microsoft Windows software, Linux software

MATLAB (matrix laboratory) is a programming language made by Cleve Moler from MathWorks. It was originally made for numerical analysis (especially numerical linear algebra). But today, it is used in many areas such as:

[[Mirza Mahdi Elahi Qomshehei]]

CATEGORIES: Iranian poets, 1901 births, 1973 deaths

Mirza Mahdi Elahi Qomshehei (Persian: میرزا مهدی الهی قمشه‌ای ; Jan 1, 1901 - May 15, 1973), was an Iranian poet, translator of the Quran, and one of the grand Masters of the philosophical school of Tehran. He taught in Sepahsalar School, University of Tehran for 35 years.

[[Allen West (politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, Living people, United States representatives from Florida, American political commentators, American political writers, Politicians from Atlanta, Georgia, Politicians from Texas, Writers from Atlanta, Georgia, Writers from Florida, Writers from Texas, People from Boca Raton, Florida, US Republican Party politicians

Allen Bernard West (born February 7, 1961) is an American political commentator and politician. He was a member of the U.S. House of Representatives. A member of the Republican Party, West represented FL in the House from 2011 to 2013.

In July 2019, West announced he would be running for the chairmanship of the Republican Party of Texas in 2020. He won the election, however, resigned at Texas GOP Chair in 2021.

On May 23, 2020, West was in a motorcycle crash just outside Waco, Texas.

In July 2021, West announced his candidacy for Governor of Texas to challenge incumbent Governor Greg Abbott for the Republican nomination.

[[Jaime Harrison]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 births, Living people, Politicians from South Carolina, US Democratic Party politicians

Jaime R. Harrison (born February 5, 1976) is an American politician. He was the chair of the South Carolina Democratic Party from 2013 to 2017. He became the Democratic National Committee in January 2021.

Harrison is running for the U.S. Senate from South Carolina in the 2020 election against Republican Lindsey Graham.

[[Flovilla, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Georgia (U.S. state)

Flovilla is a city in Butts County, Georgia, United States. The population was 653 at the 2010 census.

[[Grand Rapids Charter Township, Michigan]]

CATEGORIES: Townships in Michigan

Grand Rapids Charter Township is a charter township of Kent County in the U.S. state of Michigan. The population was 16,661 at the 2010 census. 

[[Bucky Baxter]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2020 deaths, American rock guitarists, American country guitarists, Musicians from Florida

William "Bucky" Baxter (1955spndMay 25, 2020) was an American rock country guitarist.  He was known for having played in Bob Dylan's Never Ending Tour during the 1990s.  He released his only solo album, Most Likely, No Problem, in 1999. He was born in Melbourne, Florida. Baxter was a founding member of The Dukes, Earle's backing band.

Baxter also appeared on various albums by artists such as Ryan Adams, R.E.M., and Joe Henry.  In studio, Baxter played steel guitar, acoustic guitar, electric guitar, mandolin, dobro.

Baxter died on May 25, 2020, in Sanibel Island, Florida, at the age of 65.

[[Library of Birmingham]]

CATEGORIES: Libraries in the United Kingdom, Birmingham

The Library of Birmingham is a public library in Central Birmingham, England. It is in Centenary Square next to the Birmingham Repertory Theatre and Baskerville House. It opened on the 3 September 2013 and cost £8.5 million to build. It has been called the largest public library in the United Kingdom.

[[Centenary Square]]

CATEGORIES: Birmingham, Town squares

Centenary Square is a public square on Broad Street in Central Birmingham, England. Baskerville House, the Library of Birmingham, the Birmingham Repertory Theatre, and the International Convention Centre are on the outside of the square. The Hall of Memory is on the east side of the square. The Library tram stop of the West Midlands Metro is next to the square.

[[Pepper Rodgers]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Accidental deaths from falls in the United States, American football placekickers, American football quarterbacks, Sportspeople from Atlanta, Georgia

Franklin Cullen "Pepper" Rodgers (October 8, 1931 – May 14, 2020) was an American football player and coach. Rodgers was a quarterback and placekicker for Georgia Tech. He was born in Atlanta, Georgia.

As a college football player, he led the Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets to an undefeated season in 1952 and later became their head coach. He also coached for the Kansas Jayhawks and UCLA Bruins. He worked for the United States Football League (USFL) and Canadian Football League (CFL).

Rodgers died on May 14, 2020 in Reston, Virginia from problems caused by a fall, aged 88.

[[Reston, Virginia]]

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places in Virginia

Reston is a census-designated place in Fairfax County, Virginia. In 2018, Reston was ranked as the Best Place to Live in Virginia.

The U.S. Census Bureau said Reston's population to be 60,070.

[[Link (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 horror movies, British horror movies, Movies directed by Richard Franklin

Link is a 1986 British horror movie directed by Richard Franklin and starring Elisabeth Shue, Terence Stamp, Kevin Lloyd, David O'Hara, Linus Roache. It was distributed by Cannon Films.

[[Valeriy Davydenko]]

CATEGORIES: 1973 births, 2020 deaths, Assassinated people, Murders by firearm, Ukrainian politicians

Valeriy Davydenko (Валерій Миколайович Давиденко, 16 March 1973 – 23 May 2020) was a Ukrainian businessman and politician. He was born in Nosivka, Chernihiv Oblast. He was a member of the Verkhovna Rada from 2014 to 2020. He was a member of the Spade and Our Land political parties.

Davydenko was found shot dead in the bathroom of his office on 23 May 2020 in Kiev, aged 47.

[[Zdena Tominová]]

CATEGORIES: Novelists, Political writers, Writers from Prague, 1941 births, 2020 deaths

Zdena Tominová (7 February 1941 – 24 May 2020) was a Czech novelist and a dissident in the communist era of Czechoslovakia. He was born in Prague. She was a spokesperson for Charter 77. Tominová published two novels in the 1980s, Stalin's Shoe and The Coast of Bohemia.

Tominová died on 24 May 2020 in Prague, aged 79.

[[Jimmy Kirunda]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2020 deaths, Ugandan people, Footballers, Football managers, Deaths from myocardial infarction

Jimmy Kirunda (1950 – 25 May 2020) was a Ugandan international football player and international football manager for the Uganda national football team. He participated in five Africa Cup of Nations. He was manager of the national team between 1989 and 1996.

Kirunda died of a heart attack on 25 May 2020 in Kampala, Uganda at the age of 70.

[[Jörg Ohm]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, German footballers, German football managers

Jörg Ohm (14 March 1944 – 21 May 2020) was an East German football player and manager. He played in the DDR-Oberliga for both Chemie Leipzig and 1. FC Magdeburg. As a defender he won the championship four times between 1964 and 1975.

Ohm began to play football in the youth department of BSG Lokomotive Haldensleben, north of Magdeburg. In 1962 he joined the focus club of BSG Lokomotive, SC Lokomotive Leipzig, after playing four matches for the youth national team in the spring.

Ohm died on 21 May 2020, aged 76.

[[Renate Krößner]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, German movie actors, German television actors, German stage actors, German voice actors, Actors from Lower Saxony

Renate Krößner, also Renate Krössner (17 May 1945 – 25 May 2020) was a German actress. She was known for her main role in the 1980 movie Solo Sunny. From 1985, she worked in West Berlin and was known for roles in TV series such as Tatort and Einmal Bulle, immer Bulle. She was born in Osterode am Harz, Lower Saxony.

Krößner died on 25 May 2020 in Mahlow, Brandenburg at the age of 75.

[[Golestan Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Iran

Golestan Province (استان گلستان, Ostān-e Golestān) is one of the 31 provinces of Iran. Its capital is Gorgan. It is to the south of Caspian Sea.

[[Hamadan Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Iran

Hamadan Province (استان همدان) is one of the 31 provinces of Iran. Its capital is Hamadan.

[[Alborz Province]]

CATEGORIES: Establishments in Iran, 2010 establishments in Asia, Provinces of Iran

Alborz Province (استان البرز, Ostān-e Alborz ) is one of the 31 provinces of Iran. Its capital is Karaj.

Alborz Province was created by division of Tehran Province into two provinces, after the Parliamentary approval on 23 June 2010, and was introduced as 31st province of Iran.

[[Grayeagle]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 movies, 1970s western movies, American western movies

Grayeagle is a 1977 American western movie directed by Charles B. Pierce (who also stars) and stars Ben Johnson, Paul Fix, Iron Eyes Cody, Lana Wood, Jack Elam. It was distributed by American International Pictures.

[[Samson and Delilah]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 movies, Adventure movies, Austrian movies, Silent movies, Movies directed by Alexander Korda

Samson and Delilah is a 1922 Austrian historical adventure movie directed by Alexander Korda and stars María Corda, Franz Herterich, Ernst Arndt, Alfredo Boccolini, Paul Lukas. It was distributed by Rosenhügel Film Studios.

[[To Joy (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 drama movies, Swedish movies, Movies directed by Ingmar Bergman

To Joy (Till glädje) is a 1950 Swedish drama movie directed by Ingmar Bergman and stars Maj-Britt Nilsson, Stig Olin, Birger Malmsten, John Ekman, Victor Sjöström.

[[Kansas City Bomber]]

CATEGORIES: Sports movies, 1972 drama movies, American drama movies

Kansas City Bomber is a 1972 American sports drama movie directed by Jerrold Freedman and based on the story by Barry Sandler. It stars Raquel Welch, Kevin McCarthy, Norman Alden, Jodie Foster, Shelly Novack, Helena Kallianiotes, Russ Marin and was distributed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

[[The Squall]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 movies, 1920s romance movies, 1920s drama movies, American romantic drama movies, Movies based on plays, Movies directed by Alexander Korda

The Squall is a 1929 American romantic drama movie directed by Alexander Korda and based on the 1926 play of the same name by Jean Bart. It stars Richard Tucker, Alice Joy, Loretta Young, Carroll Nye, Harry Cording, Myrna Loy and was distributed by First National Pictures.

[[Hanging Up]]

CATEGORIES: 2000 comedy-drama movies, American comedy-drama movies, German drama movies

Hanging Up is a 2000 American German comedy drama movie directed by Diane Keaton (who also stars) and based on the 1995 novel of the same name by Delia Ephron. It stars Lisa Kudrow, Meg Ryan, Walter Matthau, Adam Arkin, Cloris Leachman, Myndy Crist, Charles Matthau and was distributed by Columbia Pictures.

[[Through a Glass Darkly (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 drama movies, Swedish movies, Movies directed by Ingmar Bergman

Through a Glass Darkly (As in a Mirror) is a 1961 Swedish drama movie written and directed by Ingmar Bergman. It stars Harriet Andersson, Gunnar Björnstrand, Max von Sydow and Lars Passgård.

[[Hormozgan Province]]

Hormozgan Province (استان هرمزگان, Ostān-e Hormozgān) is one of the 31 provinces of Iran. Its capital is Bandar Abbas.

[[The Legend of Bagger Vance]]

CATEGORIES: 2000 comedy-drama movies, 2000s sports movies, American comedy-drama movies, American sports movies, Movies directed by Robert Redford

The Legend of Bagger Vance is a 2000 American sports drama movie based on Steven Pressfield's 1995 novel and directed by Robert Redford. It stars Will Smith, Matt Damon, Charlize Theron, Bruce McGill and Jack Lemmon in his final film role.

[[Escuintla Department]]

Escuintla is a department in Guatemala. The capital is also named Escuintla.

Guatemala is a department in Guatemala.  The capital is Guatemala City, which is also the national capital.

Huehuetenango is a department in Guatemala. The capital is also named Huehuetenango. It is on the border with Mexico.

[[San Marcos Department]]

CATEGORIES: Departments of Guatemala

San Marcos is a department in northwestern Guatemala. The capital is the city of San Marcos. It is on the Pacific Ocean and along the western Guatemala-Mexico border.

Jalapa is a department in Guatemala. The capital is also named Jalapa.

[[Teirake Kaini Kiribati]]

CATEGORIES: National anthems, Kiribati

"Teirake Kaini Kiribati", meaning "Stand up, Kiribati", is the title of the national anthem of Kiribati, adopted in 1979 upon independence from the United Kingdom. Tamuera Ioteba Uriam wrote the lyrics (words) and composed the music of this song.

[[God Bless Fiji]]

CATEGORIES: Fiji, National anthems

"Meda Dau Doka", also known as "God Bless Fiji" in English, is the the national anthem of Fiji. It adopted in 1970 when the country got its independence from the United Kingdom.

Earlier, in 1911, American gospel writer Charles Austin Miles composed the music for the Christian hymn Dwelling in Beulah Land – the same melody that is being used for this song today.

The lyrics (words) were written by Michael Francis Alexander Prescott. The Fijian version and the English version are not translations of each other, and the English version is used much more commonly.

In 2008, it was suggested that this anthem should be sung in Fijian, English and Fiji Hindi – the country's official languages – all in one piece.

[[Mizrahi music]]

CATEGORIES: Israeli music

Mizrahi music (מוזיקה מזרחית) is a music genre in Israel that combines elements from Europe, North Africa and the Arab world, and is mainly performed by Israelis of Mizrahi descent. 

Over time fusions of Mizrahi music with other genres emerged, including oriental rock, hip hop, and pop.

[[Ofer Levi]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, Israeli singers, Israeli musicians

Ofer Levi (Hebrew: עופר לוי‎; born June 17, 1964) is an Israeli singer, composer and musician, one of the pioneers of the Mizrahi music in the Turkish and Arabic genres.

[[Forest of Dean]]

CATEGORIES: Forests, Geography of England, Geography of Gloucestershire

The Forest of Dean is an area in Gloucestershire. It is in the west of the county between the River Wye, Herefordshire, the River Severn and the city of Gloucester.

[[Andrew Baum]]

CATEGORIES: British academics, Academics of the University of Oxford

Professor Andrew Baum is a British academic. He is Professor of Practice at the Saïd Business School, University of Oxford. His research focuses mainly on property finance, development and technology, property funds and international real estate investment.

In 2019, he was given the UK PropTech Association Special Achievement Award.

[[Royal Pavilion]]

CATEGORIES: Brighton

The Royal Pavilion is a former Royal residence in the city of Brighton. Originally it was a farmhouse. It was bought by the Prince Regent who had the original building turned into a Palace. It is now a Grad I Listed building.

[[Ohio's 2nd congressional district]]

CATEGORIES: Congressional districts of Ohio

Ohio's 2nd congressional district is a district in southwest Ohio. It is currently represented by Republican Brad Wenstrup in the House of Representatives. Former representatives include Rutherford B. Hayes, who was President of the United States from 1877–1881.

Heike Beier (born 3 December 1983 Berlin) is a German volleyball player .

Mount Meron is a mountain in Israel overlooking Galilee.

Cholet is a commune. It is in the region Pays de la Loire in the Maine-et-Loire department. This is in the western part of France.

Elbert County is a county in the U.S. state of Georgia. As of the 2010 census, 20,166 people lived there. The county seat is Elberton.

Elberton is a city in the U.S. state of Georgia. It is the county seat of Elbert County.

Jutiapa Department is a department in Guatemala that borders along El Salvador and the Pacific Ocean. The capital is the city of Jutiapa. As of 2018, 488,395 people lived there.

Stroud is a town and civil parish in the county of Gloucestershire, England.

[[BT Tower (Birmingham)]]

CATEGORIES: Telecommunications, Birmingham, Buildings and structures in England

The BT Tower is a telecommunications tower in Central Birmingham, England. It is 152 tall, making it the tallest structure in the city. It used to be called the GPO Tower. It was built between 1963 and 1965.

[[Quiché Department]]

CATEGORIES: Departments of Guatemala

Quiché is a department in Guatemala. The capital is Santa Cruz del Quiché.

[[Katzelmacher]]

Katzelmacher is a 1969 West German drama movie directed by Rainer Werner Fassbinder (who also stars) and starring Hanna Schygulla, Harry Baer, Irm Hermann.

[[10 Holloway Circus]]

CATEGORIES: Skyscrapers in the United Kingdom, Birmingham

10 Holloway Circus (also called Holloway Circus Tower or Beetham Tower) is a skyscraper in Central Birmingham, England. It is 122 tall, making it the tallest building and second-tallest structure in the city. It is also the 42nd tallest building in the United Kingdom.

[[Cinderford]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Gloucestershire

Cinderford is a small town on the eastern edge of the Forest of Dean, England.

[[Absolute Beginners]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 drama movies, 1980s musical movies, British drama movies, British musical movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Julien Temple

Absolute Beginners is a 1986 British musical movie directed by Julien Temple and based on the novel of the same name by Colin MacInnes. It stars Eddie O'Connell, David Bowie, Patsy Kensit, James Fox, Paul Rhys, Edward Tudor-Pole, Ray Davies, Sade, Steven Berkoff, Peter-Hugo Daly, Sylvia Sims and was distributed by Palace Pictures.

[[Joseph Chamberlain Memorial Clock Tower]]

CATEGORIES: Buildings and structures in England, Towers in the United Kingdom, Birmingham

The Joseph Chamberlain Memorial Clock Tower (usually called Old Joe) is a clock tower in the campus of the University of Birmingham, England. It is the tallest freestanding clock tower in the world. It is either 110, 99, or 100 tall.

[[Jeeves]]

CATEGORIES: Characters in written fiction, Television characters

Jeeves is a well-known children´s book series written by British author PG Wodehouse. They star Jeeves, the genius butler of Bertie Wooster, a rich, spoiled man in his twenties. The last Jeeves book, Aunts Aren´t Gentlemen, was written in 1974. The first Jeeves book, Extricating Young Gussie, was a short story written in 1915.

[[Coleford, Gloucestershire]]

CATEGORIES: Market towns in England, Towns in Gloucestershire

Coleford is a market town in the west of the Forest of Dean, Gloucestershire.

[[Mohammad Reza Rezaei Kouchi]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 births, Iranian politicians, Iranian Muslims, Living people

Mohammad Reza Rezaei Kouchi (محمدرضا رضایی کوچی; born 23 September 1971) is an Iranian politician who represents Jahrom in the Islamic Consultative Assembly since 2008. He is the head of the civil commission of the parliament.

[[Querelle]]

CATEGORIES: 1982 drama movies, 1980s LGBT movies, French drama movies, German drama movies, Movies directed by Rainer Werner Fassbinder

Querelle is a 1982 West German–French drama movie directed by Rainer Werner Fassbinder and based on the 1947 novel by Jean Genet. It stars Brad Davis, Franco Nero, Jeanne Moreau, Laurent Malet, Axel Bauer, Roger Fritz and was distributed by Gaumont.

[[The First Day]]

The First Day (Die ersten Tage) is a 1971 Austrian drama movie directed by Herbert Holba and starring Ariane Niehoff, Olga Felber, Heinz Herki, Karlheinz Hayek.

[[Oro, Plata, Mata]]

CATEGORIES: 1982 drama movies, 1980s war movies, Filipino movies, World War II movies, Movies directed by Peque Gallaga

Oro, Plata, Mata is a 1982 Filipino World War II drama movie directed by Peque Gallaga and starring Cherie Gil, Sandy Andolong, Liza Lorena, Ronnie Lazaro, Joel Torre, Jaime Fabregas. It was distributed by ABS-CBN Corporation.

[[Tony Scannell]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Irish movie actors, Irish television actors, Freemasons, People from County Cork

Tony Scannell (14 August 1945 – 26 May 2020) was an Irish actor. He was best known for playing DS Ted Roach in The Bill and appeared in the 1980 movie Flash Gordon. He was declared bankrupt in 2002. He was a Freemason.

Scannell died on 26 May 2020 aged 74 from unknown causes.

[[Provab Technosoft]]

CATEGORIES: 2010 establishments in Asia

Provab Technosoft is an award-winning software development company. It develops next-generation travel technology solutions, custom web applications and native mobile applications for global customers. It is headquartered in Bangalore India and has a customer base in 48 countries.

[[McDonough, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: County seats in Georgia, Cities in Georgia (U.S. state)

McDonough is a city in Henry County, Georgia, United States. It is part of the Atlanta metropolitan area. Its population was 22,084 at the 2010 census. The city is the county seat of Henry County.

[[Barbara (singer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 1997 deaths, Deaths from respiratory failure, French songwriters, French pop singers, French movie actors, French television actors, Actors from Paris, Writers from Paris

Monique Andrée Serf (9 June 1930 – 24 November 1997) was a French pop singer-songwriter and actress. She took her stage name, Barbara, from her grandmother.  Her song "L'Aigle noir" sold 1 million copies in twelve hours.

In 1971, she co-starred with Jacques Brel in Franz.

Barbara, who smoked many times, died of respiratory failure.

[[M. P. Veerendra Kumar]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cardiac arrest, Indian politicians, Indian writers

M. P. Veerendra Kumar (22 July 1936 – 28 May 2020) was an Indian politician, writer and journalist. He was a Member of Parliament for Lok Sabha from 1996 to 1998 and again from 2004 to 2009. He was also a member of Rajya Sabha from 2016 to 2017 and again from 2019 to 2020. He was a member of the Loktantrik Janata Dal political party.

He was also the chairman and managing director of the Malayalam daily newspaper Mathrubhumi. 

Kumer died of cardiac arrest at a hospital in Calicut, India on 28 May 2020, aged 83.

[[Claude Goasguen]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in France, French politicians

Claude Goasguen (12 March 1945 – 28 May 2020) was a French politician. He was a member of the National Assembly for Paris from 1993 to 1995 and again from 1997 until his death in 2020. He was a member of The Republicans.

For a short time, he was Minister of Reform of the State, Decentralisation and Citizenship in 1995 under Prime Minister Alain Juppé.

Goasguen died on 28 May 2020 in Issy-les-Moulineaux, France from COVID-19, aged 75.

[[Issy-les-Moulineaux]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Hauts-de-Seine

Issy-les-Moulineaux (isi le mulino) is a commune in the southwestern suburban area of Paris, France, lying on the left bank of the river Seine. It is one of Paris' entrances and is located 6.6 from Notre-Dame Church.

[[Guy Bedos]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from Alzheimer's disease, French movie actors, French television actors, French stage actors, French comedians

Guy Bedos (15 June 1934 – 28 May 2020) was a French actor and comedian. He was born in Algiers. He was best known for his roles in Sweet and Sour, Pardon Mon Affaire, Too! and All Together. He was also famous for his left-wing political support and he had supported politicians such as François Mitterrand.

Bedos died on 28 May 2020 in Paris of problems caused by Alzheimer's disease, aged 85.

[[University of California, Merced]]

CATEGORIES: 2000s establishments in California, 2005 establishments in the United States, University of California, Merced County, California

The University of California, Merced (UC Merced) is a public research university in Merced, California. It is the newest campus of the University of California. The university has 8,847 undergraduate students and 686 graduate students.

[[Al Rex]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, American jazz musicians, American country musicians, Musicians from Pennsylvania

Albert Floyd Piccirilli (July 13, 1928 – May 25, 2020), also known by his stage name Al Rex, was an American bass player. He was known for playing with Bill Haley & His Comets. He started playing for them in 1949 and became known for "wild antics" on stage. He was born near Plymouth Township, Pennsylvania.

Rex died at his home in Norristown, Pennsylvania on May 25, 2020 at the age of 91.

[[Plymouth Township, Montgomery County, Pennsylvania]]

CATEGORIES: Townships in Pennsylvania

Plymouth Township is a township with home rule status in Montgomery County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 16,525 at the 2010 census.  

[[Henri van Zanten]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, 2020 deaths, Dutch movie actors, Dutch stage actors, Dutch artists, Dutch singers, People from Rotterdam

Henri Carel van Zanten (March 18, 1957 – May 22, 2020) was a Dutch artist. He was born in Rotterdam.

Van Zanten started working under the Stanislavski method. His mentor was the Belgian theatre reformer Jan Decorte. Van Zanten was active from 1982 as an artist, actor and director. He was known for his street art and directing many art movies. He called himself an "omni artist". His best known work was ʼuʼ.

Van Zanten died on May 22, 2020 in Berlin at the age of 63.

[[Dark Souls II]]

CATEGORIES: 2014 video games, Role-playing video games, PlayStation 3 games, PlayStation 4 games, Windows games, Xbox 360 games, Xbox One games, Video game sequels

Dark Souls 2 is an action RPG made by Hidetaka Miyazaki and FromSoftware. It is the sequel to Dark Souls. And the third sequel, titled Dark Souls III released in 2016.

[[Peter Alexander (artist)]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, American sculptors, People from Los Angeles, California, People from Santa Monica, California

Peter Alexander (February 27, 1939 – May 26, 2020) was an American artist. He was part of the Light and Space artistic movement in southern California in the 1960s. He was best known for his resin sculptures from the 1960s and 1970s. He was born in Los Angeles.

In 1980 he was awarded a fellowship from the National Endowment for the Arts.

He was a longtime friend of Christopher Isherwood.  A portrait of Alexander by Isherwood's former lover Don Bachardy has been seen at the Laguna Art Museum.

In October 2011, Craig Krull Gallery exhibited a survey of Alexander's work, including paintings and sculptures from 1970 to 2009. 

[[Irm Hermann]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, German movie actors, German television actors, German voice actors, German stage actors, People from Munich

Irmgard Hermann (4 October 1942 – 26 May 2020) was a German actress. She was born in Munich. She was known for appearing in movies directed by  Rainer Werner Fassbinder. She had lead roles in The Merchant of Four Seasons (1971) and The Bitter Tears of Petra von Kant (1972). 

Hermann died on 26 May 2020 in Berlin, aged 77. 

[[Anthony James (actor)]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in Massachusetts, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, American painters, Actors from South Carolina, People from Myrtle Beach, South Carolina

Anthony James (born James Anthony; July 22, 1942 – May 26, 2020) was an American actor. He was known for playing villain in Western movies or television series. He was born in Myrtle Beach, South Carolina. 

His movie roles include: P.J. (1968) and ...tick...tick...tick... (1970). He played one of the lynch mobsters in High Plains Drifter and appeared the horror movie Burnt Offerings (1976). He had roles in Blue Thunder (1983),  Nightmares (1983), and The Naked Gun 2½: The Smell of Fear (1991).

James died on May 26, 2020 of cancer, aged 77.

[[Federico García Vigil]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Conductors, Composers, People from Montevideo

Federico García Vigil (5 January 1941 – 27 May 2020) was a Uruguayan composer and conductor. He was the conductor of the Montevideo Philharmonic Orchestra from 1994 to 2008. He was born in Montevideo.

García Vigil died on 27 May 2020 in Montevideo, aged 79.

[[Battle of Huế]]

CATEGORIES: 20th century in Vietnam, 1968, Vietnam War, Battles involving the United States, January events, February events, March events, Tet Offensive

The Battle of Huế was a battle of the Vietnam War during the Tet Offensive. It happened between 31 January and 2 March 1968. Since Huế was part of an important route between Danang and the North Vietnam-South Vietnam border, Huế was an important target for communist Vietnamese soldiers to attack. The battle was one of the deadliest in the war. Even today, visitors to the city can see signs that the battle was fought in Huế. Some buildings that were damaged or destroyed were never fixed. Other buildings still have bullet holes left from the battle.

[[WorkPuls]]

CATEGORIES: 2015 establishments in California

Workpuls is an automated time tracking and employee monitoring software. Their offices are locations in San Francisco (California) and Belgrade (Serbia). Finances Online awarded Workpuls with a Rising Star Award in 2016, and a Great User Experience Award in 2017.

[[Vietnamese Demilitarized Zone]]

CATEGORIES: Vietnam War, 20th century in Vietnam, 1950s in Asia, 1960s in Asia, 1970s in Asia, 20th century establishments in Vietnam, 1954 establishments in Asia, 1970s disestablishments in Asia, 1975 disestablishments

The Vietnamese Demilitarized Zone was the border between North Vietnam and South Vietnam during the Vietnam War. In 1954, after the Viet Minh defeated France during the First Indochina War, France gave up control of Vietnam, but France also split Vietnam in two halves. The Vietnamese DMZ would be a place where many battles would take place during the Vietnam War. After North Vietnam defeated South Vietnam at the end of the war in 1975, the Vietnamese DMZ was no more and the two countries were united into one Vietnam in 1976.

[[Viet Minh]]

CATEGORIES: Vietnam, First Indochina War, Wars of independence

The Viet Minh (also known as Vietnamese Independence League, or Việt Nam Độc Lập Đồng Minh Hội) was an Vietnamese organization who fought for Vietnam's independence from France. 

It was founded by Pac Bo and Ho Chi Minh in 1935 or 1936. It fought against Japan during World War II with help from the United States and the Republic of China. 

After World War II ended, the Viet Minh would fight against France during the First Indochina War. The Viet Minh would win the war and Vietnam would be independent, but it would be split into two countries, North Vietnam and South Vietnam.Asia

[[Bún bò Huế]]

CATEGORIES: Vietnamese food

Bún bò Huế is a beef rice noodle dish from the city of Hue in Vietnam. The dish is best known for its balance of salty, spicy, and umami flavor.

[[The Merchant of Four Seasons]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 drama movies, German drama movies, Movies directed by Rainer Werner Fassbinder

The Merchant of Four Seasons (Händler der vier Jahreszeiten) is a 1971 West German drama movie directed by Rainer Werner Fassbinder and starring Hans Hirschmüller, Irm Hermann, Ingrid Caven, Kurt Raab, Hanna Schygulla, Klaus Löwitsch. It was distributed by Tango Film.

[[Dancing plague of 1518]]

CATEGORIES: 1518

The dancing plague (or dance epidemic) of 1518 was when a massive case of dancing mania happened in Strasbourg, Alsace (now modern-day France), in the Holy Roman Empire in July 1518. Somewhere between 50 and 400 people took to dancing for days.

The outbreak began in July 1518 when a woman began to dance randomly in a street in Strasbourg. Some sources claim that, for a short time, the plague killed around fifteen people per day; however, the sources of the city of Strasbourg at the time of the events did not mention the number of deaths, or even if there were any deaths.

[[HBO Max]]

CATEGORIES: Time Warner, Entertainment websites, HBO Max

HBO Max is an American subscription video on demand streaming service from WarnerMedia Entertainment. It is part of AT&T's WarnerMedia. The service was launched on May 27, 2020.

HBO Max is based on WarnerMedia's HBO premium TV service. It includes all of its programming. Movies and television shows made by Warner Bros., as well as companies that it owns such as CNN, Cartoon Network, TBS, and Turner Classic Movies, are in this streaming website.

[[New Albany, Ohio]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Ohio

New Albany is a city in the U.S. state of Ohio, located 15 northeast of the state capital of Columbus. Most of the city is located in Franklin County. New Albany had a population of 10,933 in 2019.

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, Living people, American billionaires, American Jews, American philanthropists, Businesspeople from Dayton, Ohio, Jewish billionaires, Jewish businesspeople, Jewish philanthropists

Leslie Herbert Wexner (born September 8, 1937) is an American billionaire businessman. He is the founder and chairman emeritus of L Brands (formerly Limited Brands). He retired in February 2020.

[[Ghislaine Maxwell]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, Living people, Jeffrey Epstein, British philanthropists, British businesspeople, Socialites

Ghislaine Maxwell (, ghee; born 25 December 1961) is a British socialite and the youngest child of publishing tycoon Robert Maxwell.

[[Robert Maxwell]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 1991 deaths, Accidental deaths by drowning, British military personnel of World War II, UK MPs 1964–1966, UK MPs 1966–1970, British businesspeople, Publishers

Ian Robert Maxwell GBR (born Ján Ludvík Hyman Binyamin Hoch; 10 June 1923 – 5 November 1991), was a British media proprietor, Member of Parliament (MP), and fraudster. He was known for his publishing companies.

After his death, huge difference in numbers in his companies' finances were revealed, including his fraudulent actions on Mirror Group pension fund.

In 1991, his body was discovered floating in the Atlantic Ocean, having fallen overboard from his yacht. He was buried in Jerusalem.

[[I Am a Tuvan]]

"I Am a Tuvan", known in the Tuvan language as Men – Tıva Men ("Мен – Тыва Мен"), is the regional anthem of the Republic of Tuva, a federal subject of Russia located in south Siberia. It was composed by Olonbayar Gantomir with words by Bayantsagaan Oohiy. It was adopted officially by the Great Khural of Tuva on 11 August 2011 replacing the previous anthem Tooruktuğ Dolgay Tañdım.

[[Male reproductive system]]

CATEGORIES: Male reproductive system

The male reproductive system is made up of a number of sex organs. It works in the process of human reproduction. Some organs are outside the body, some are in the pelvis.

The main male sex organs are the penis and the testicles, which produce semen and sperm. During sexual intercourse the penis delivers the sperm into a woman's body. The sperm can fertilize the egg cell in the woman's body. The fertilized egg will develop into a fetus, which is later born as a baby.

The matched system in woman is the female reproductive system.

[[The Bitter Tears of Petra von Kant]]

The Bitter Tears of Petra von Kant (Die bitteren Tränen der Petra von Kant) is a 1972 West German drama movie directed by Rainer Werner Fassbinder and based on his own play. It stars Margit Carstensen, Irm Hermann, Hanna Schygulla, Eva Mattes, Gisela Fackeldey and was distributed by New Yorker Films.

[[Pat Kilbane]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, Comedians from Ohio, People from Lakewood, Ohio

Patrick F. "Pat" Kilbane (born November 5, 1969) is an American actor, comedian, and screenwriter. He is best known for his three seasons as a cast member on MADtv (1997–2000), as well his memorable appearance in the 1996 "The Bizarro Jerry" episode of Seinfeld, in which he played Bizarro Kramer. Kilbane's first book, The Brain Eater's Bible: Sound Advice for the Newly Reanimated Zombie, was released on March 18, 2011. He was born in Lakewood, Ohio.

[[Barrow Wake]]

CATEGORIES: Geography of Gloucestershire

Barrow Wake is a scenic view in Gloucestershire, near Birdlip, England.

It is a beautiful area.  It has been, however, subject to reports of particular anti-social use.

Barrow Wake was as the location for the music video "Wytches" by Pagan Rock Band Inkubus Sukkubus in December 1993.

Inkubus Sukkubus also released an album titled "Barrow Wake - Tales of Witchcraft & Wonder Volume 1", The Album features the title track "Barrow Wake", which is written about Barrow Wake.

[[Quest For Fire]]

Quest For Fire (La Guerre du feu) is a 1981 Canadian French adventure movie directed by Jean-Jacques Annaud and starring Ron Perlman, Everett McGill, Rae Down Chong, Nameer El-Kadi. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox and won an Academy Award in 1983.

[[Kemp's ridley sea turtle]]

CATEGORIES: Turtles

Kemp's ridley sea turtle (Lepidochelys kempii), also called the Atlantic ridley sea turtle. is the rarest species of sea turtle and is critically endangered. 

It is one of two living species in the genus Lepidochelys (the other one being L. olivacea, the olive ridley sea turtle).

[[Oryukdo]]

CATEGORIES: Archipelagos, Islands of South Korea, Busan

Oryukdo is an archipelago that is 600 southeast of the Uam Peninsula in Busan, South Korea. It is one of the symbols of Busan. 

In the order close to the land, there are six islands: Shield Island, Pine tree Island, Suri Island, Awl Island, Oyster Island, and Lighthouse Island. In the past, Shield Island and Pine tree Island, which were connected to Haesik Island, were collectively called Usakdo Island, but in 2011, they were organized under the name of the uninhabited island.

Anan Ameri  is an American museum director and writer. She won a Palestine Book Award. The Arab Community Center for Economic and Social Services named her 2020 Arab American of the Year. In 2005, The Detroit News named her Michiganian of the Year.

Charles Wayland Bryan (1867-1945, D-NE) was a relative of Secretary of State William Jennings Bryan and was the governor of Nebraska. He was also nominated by the Democratic Party to serve as the vice-presidential nominee in 1924.

[[Bob Andras]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 1982 deaths, Privy Councillors (Canada), Members of the House of Commons of Canada from Ontario, Cancer deaths in British Columbia, Politicians from Ontario

Robert Knight "Bob" Andras CAN (21 February 1921 – 17 November 1982) was a Canadian politician. He was a Member of Parliament (MP) in the House of Commons of Canada from 1965 to 1980. He was a part of the Liberal Party during this time. He represented two electoral areas in Ontario. They were Port Arthur and Thunder Bay—Nipigon. Andras was from Lachine, Quebec. He moved to Port Arthur, Ontario to work in a car dealership.

As a politician, Andras was a part of the cabinet of Canada many different times. Most of the time, this was when Pierre Trudeau was the Prime Minister. He was Minister without Portfolio from 1968 to 1971, Minister of State for Urban Affairs from 1971 to 1972, the Minister of Status of Women from 1971 to 1974, Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs in 1972, Minister of Manpower and Immigration from 1972 to 1976, President of the Treasury Board from 1976 to 1978, and Minister of State for Economic Development from 1978 to 1979. For the 1980 federal election, he said he wouldn't try to be elected again.

One of the most important things Andras did was help the Immigration Act, 1976 become a law. This was when he was the Minister of Manpower and Immigration. The law replaced the Immigration Act of 1952. The law made sure that there was a minimum amount of immigrants Canada let in, and that immigrants would be let in without discriminating on their ethnicity, gender, or country they came from. Andras also tried to work with Jean Chrétien to help with making public policy of the First Nations people.

Andras died on 17 November 1982 in Vancouver, British Columbia. This is after he fought cancer for a year.

Stephen F. Austin High School is a high school in Sugar Land, Texas.

[[Elizabeth Fitzgerald Stemke]]
