Elizabeth Fitzgerald Stemke  (born July 15, 1980)  is an American volleyball player and coach.

She was a member of the United States women's national volleyball team. 

She participated at the 2002 Women's Volleyball World Championships and 2003 Pan-American Games.

[[Hugh Parmer]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, State legislators of the United States, American lawyers, Mayors of Fort Worth, Humanitarians, Businesspeople from Fort Worth, Texas, US Democratic Party politicians

Hugh Quay Parmer (August 3, 1939 – May 27, 2020) was an American lawyer, businessman and Democratic politician. He was a member of the Texas House of Representatives from 1963 to 1965. He was later a member of the Texas Senate from 1983 to 1991. Between 1977 to 1979, he was Mayor of Fort Worth, Texas.

Parmer died in Fort Worth on May 27, 2020 at the age of 80.

[[George Floyd protests]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 in the United States, Arson, Attacks on buildings and structures in the United States, May 2020 events, June 2020 events, July 2020 events, Riots in the United States, August 2020 events, September 2020 events, October 2020 events, Black Lives Matter

Supported by:

The George Floyd protests are ongoing protests and riots that started in the Minneapolis–Saint Paul metropolitan area, Minnesota, United States. Unrest began in Minneapolis on May 26, 2020, after the murder of George Floyd and continued into September. Floyd died while being arrested by officers of the Minneapolis Police Department (MPD) on May 25. Protests spread to many cities in the United States, and later the world.

Some of the protesters at the MPD's Third Precinct fought with law enforcement officers, who fired tear gas and rubber bullets. On May 27, one man was shot at a pawn shop and died. Witnesses recall hearing him say "George is a monkey!" Additionally, the Third Precinct's windows were smashed. A supermarket was looted, and other buildings were attacked and set on fire. At least thirteen people were killed so because of the protests, but overall, most protests were peaceful. According to a September 2020 report by the U.S. Crisis Monitor, almost 95% of all protests were nonviolent.

On May 28, Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey declared a state of emergency, and Governor of Minnesota Tim Walz called in 500 Minnesota National Guard troops. More businesses across the Twin Cities were damaged and looted. 

MPD in the Third Precinct building attempted to hold off the protesters with tear gas, but around 11:00 pm, protesters overran the building and set it on fire. It had been evacuated. 

Both Walz and Frey added curfews. U.S. President Donald Trump assured Walz of U.S. military support.

The activist group Black Lives Matter is involved in the protests, but the protests do not have one leader or one organization.

There were many attacks on journalists, both in the Twin Cities and at sister protests.

[[Yogesh (lyricist)]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, Indian writers

Yogesh Gaur, commonly credited as Yogesh, (March 19, 1943 – May 29, 2020) was an Indian writer and lyricist. He worked in Bollywood and was best known for composing the music scores for ''Anand. 

Yogesh died on May 29, 2020 in Mumbai at the age of 77.

[[Ernest W. Gibson III]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, American lawyers, American judges, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Vermont, People from Brattleboro, Vermont, US Republican Party politicians

Ernest W. Gibson III (September 23, 1927 – May 17, 2020) was an American lawyer and politician. Gibson was a member of the Vermont House of Representatives from 1961 to 1963. He was an Associate Justice of the Vermont Supreme Court from 1983 to 1997. He was a member of the Republican Party.

Gibson was born in Brattleboro, Vermont. His father was Governor Ernest W. Gibson Jr.. His grandfather was United States Senator Ernest Willard Gibson. 

Gibson died at his home in Northfield, Vermont on May 17, 2020 at the age of 92.

[[Northfield, Vermont]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Vermont

Northfield is a town in Washington County, Vermont, United States. It has the village of Northfield, where over half of the population lives. The town's total population was 6,207 at the 2010 census.

[[Northfield (village), Vermont]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Vermont

Northfield is a village in the town of Northfield in Washington County, Vermont, United States.  The population was 2,101 at the 2010 census.

[[Ernest W. Gibson Jr.]]

CATEGORIES: 1901 births, 1969 deaths, United States senators from Vermont, Governors of Vermont, American judges, American lawyers, American military personnel of World War II, People from Brattleboro, Vermont, US Republican Party politicians

Ernest William Gibson Jr. (March 6, 1901 – November 4, 1969) was an American politician, lawyer and judge. From 1940 to 1941, he was made United States Senator after the death of his father Ernest Willard Gibson. From 1947 to 1950, he was Governor of Vermont. In 1949, President Harry S. Truman made him Judge of the United States District Court for the District of Vermont.

Gibson died in Brattleboro, Vermont on November 4, 1969 at the age of 68. 

[[Ernest Willard Gibson]]

CATEGORIES: 1872 births, 1940 deaths, American lawyers, United States representatives from Vermont, United States senators from Vermont, People from Brattleboro, Vermont, US Republican Party politicians

Ernest Willard Gibson (December 29, 1872spaced ndashJune 20, 1940) was an American politician and lawyer. He was a member of the United States House of Representatives from Vermont between 1923 and 1933. He was a United States Senator from 1933 until his death in 1940. His son, Ernest W. Gibson Jr. replaced him.

[[Londonderry, Vermont]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Vermont

Londonderry is a town in Windham County, Vermont, United States. It is bounded on the north by Landgrove and Weston. The population was 1,709 in the 2000 census. Londonderry also includes the village of South Londonderry.

[[Gracia Barrios]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from lung disease, Chilean artists, People from Santiago

Gracia Barrios Rivadeneira (27 June 1927 – 28 May 2020) was a Chilean painter. She was born in Santiago de Chile. She was the winner of the 2011 National Prize for Plastic Arts. Her husband, José Balmes, was also an artist.

After the 1973 Chilean coup d'état, the artist went into exile in France along with her husband and daughter.

Her works "human activity in everyday life". Some of the themes she tackled in her paintings were war, indigence, and exile. In addition to using oil and acrylic paints, she experimented with natural elements such as earth and clay.

Barrios died on 28 May 2020 from lung disease at a hospital in Santiago, aged 92.

[[José Balmes]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2016 deaths, Deaths from pneumonia, Spanish people, Chilean artists

José Balmes Parramón (20 January 1927 – 28 August 2016) was a Spanish-born Chilean. He received Chile's National Prize for Plastic Arts in 1999. He was the husband of artist Gracia Barrios. He was born in Montesquiu, Spain. 

Balmes died on 28 August 2016 at a hospital in Santiago de Chile from pneumonia-related problems, aged 89.

[[Charlie Monttana]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Deaths from stroke, Mexican singer-songwriters, Guitarists, Philanthropists, Singers from Mexico City, Musicians from Mexico City

Carlos César Sánchez Hernández (November 6, 1961 – May 28, 2020), known professionally as Charlie Monttana, was a Mexican rock urbano musician and singer-songwriter. He was born in Mexico City. 

Sánchez began his career as a singer in Mexico City's rock urbano scene in the 1980s. After that invited by Rodolfo León "León Vago" he joined Vago. In 1987 he was invited by musician Toshiro Midori to be the vocalist of Mara. In 1989 he separated from Mara.

In 1992 Monttana launched his solo career releasing hits such as "Vaquero Rocanrolero" (Rock And Roll Cowboy), "Por Qué El Amor Apesta" ("Why Love Stinks") and "Mi Terrible Soledad" ("My Terrible Loneliness"), among others. He was also a philanthropist.

Monttana died of a heart attack caused by a heatstroke on May 28, 2020 at the age of 58.

[[Betsy Price]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, Living people, Businesspeople from Fort Worth, Texas, Mayors of Fort Worth, US Republican Party politicians

 Barbara Elizabeth Cornelius "Betsy" Price (born October 21, 1949) is an American businesswoman and politician. She has been the 44th mayor of Fort Worth, Texas since 2011.

[[Kay Granger]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, Living people, Mayors of Fort Worth, United States representatives from Texas, US Republican Party politicians

Norvell Kay Granger (Mullendore; born January 18, 1943) is an American Republican politician. She is a member of the United States House of Representatives since 1997. She was elected as Fort Worth's first female mayor in 1991.

[[Springtown, Texas]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Texas

Springtown is a town in Parker County and Wise, Texas, United States. According to the 2010 census, the population of Springtown was 2,658.

[[Ajit Jogi]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cardiac arrest, Deaths from choking, Indian politicians

Ajit Pramod Kumar Jogi (29 April 1946 spnd 29 May 2020) was an Indian politician. He was a member of the Janta Congress Chhattisgarh (INC) political party. He was born in present-day Chhattisgarh, India.

Jogi was a member of Parliament of India from 1998 to 1999 and again from 2004 to 2008. He was the first Chief Minister of Chhattisgarh from 2000 to 2003. 

Jogi died of cardiac arrest after choking on food on 29 May 2020 in Raipur, India at the age of 74.

[[Choking]]

CATEGORIES: Medical emergencies

Choking happens when breathing is made difficult. It happens when the windpipe is blocked. 

In some cases the air flow is completely blocked, in other cases some amount of air can pass to the lungs. Insufficient oxygen being delivered to the body will result in oxygen deprivation. 

Although oxygen stored in the blood and lungs can keep a person alive for several minutes after breathing stops. 

[[Sudlersville, Maryland]]

Sudlersville is a town in the far northeastern corner of Queen Anne's County, Maryland, United States. The ZIP code is 21668 and the area code is 410. The population was 497 at the 2010 census.

[[Centreville, Maryland]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Maryland

Centreville is an incorporated town in Queen Anne's County, Maryland, United States on the Delmarva Peninsula. It is the county seat of Queen Anne's County. The population was 4,285 at the 2010 census.  

[[Bob Kulick]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2020 deaths, American pop musicians, American rock guitarists, American jazz musicians, Record producers, Musicians from New York City, Businesspeople from New York City

Robert J. Kulick (January 16, 1950 – May 28, 2020) was an American rock pop jazz guitarist and record producer. He was born in New York City. He was best known for his studio work with Kiss and for his works with W.A.S.P..

Kulick died on May 28, 2020 in Las Vegas, Nevada at the age of 70.

[[Jerzy Pilch]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from Parkinson's disease, Polish journalists, Polish novelists, Columnists

Jerzy Pilch (ˈjɛʐɨ ˈpilx; 10 August 1952  – 29 May 2020) was a Polish novelist, columnist, and journalist. He was born in Wisła, Poland. In 1989, he won Kościelski Award for his debut novel Wyznania twórcy pokątnej literatury erotycznej ("Confessions of an author of illicit erotic literature"). Pilch's second novel, Spis cudzołożnic ("List of Adulteresses", 1993) was made into a movie in 1995. 

Pilch's most successful book so far is his fourth novel Pod Mocnym Aniołem ("The Mighty Angel", 2000), a satirical take on the "drinking novel" genre, which was awarded a Nike Award.

Pilch died on 29 May 2020 in Kielce, Poland of problems caused by Parkinson's disease, aged 67.

[[Without a Trace (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1983 drama movies, 1983 mystery movies, American drama movies, American mystery movies

Without a Trace is a 1983 American drama movie directed by Stanley R. Jaffe and based on the novel Still Missing by Beth Gutcheon. It stars Kate Nelligan, Judd Hirsch, David Dukes, Stockard Channing, Danny Corkill and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Alfred Kolleritsch]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Austrian journalists, Austrian poets, Philosophers

Alfred Kolleritsch (16 February 1931 – 29 May 2020) was an Austrian journalist, poet and philosopher. He was born in Eichfeld, Austria. He was the founder of the literary magazine manuscripts. He was the President of the Forum Stadtpark, a cultural center in Graz. 

Kolleritsch died on 29 May 2020 in Graz, aged 89.

[[Roosevelt Taylor]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Sportspeople from New Orleans, Louisiana, American football safeties, Chicago Bears players, San Francisco 49ers players, Washington Redskins players

Roosevelt "Rosey" Taylor (July 4, 1937spaced ndashMay 29, 2020) was an American professional football player. He was a safety. He played for the Chicago Bears, San Francisco 49ers, and Washington Redskins of the National Football League (NFL). His career lasted between 1961 to 1972.

Taylor was born in New Orleans, Louisiana. He played college football at Grambling State University. Taylor died on May 29, 2020 at the age of 82.

[[L'Argent (1983 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1983 drama movies, French drama movies, Swiss movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Robert Bresson

L'Argent (laʁ.ʒɑ̃, meaning "Money") is a 1983 French Swiss drama movie directed by Robert Bresson and is loosely based on the first part of Leo Tolstoy's novella The Forged Coupon. It stars Christian Patey, Vincent Risterucci, Caroline Lang, Sylvie Van Den Elsen and was distributed by MK2 Diffusion.

[[Blame It on Rio]]

CATEGORIES: 1984 romance movies, 1984 comedy movies, 1980s romantic comedy movies, American romantic comedy movies, Movies directed by Stanley Donen, American independent movies

Blame It on Rio is a 1984 American romantic comedy movie directed by Stanley Donen and is based on the 1977 remake of the French movie Un moment d'égarement. It stars Michael Caine, Joseph Bolonga, Michelle Johnson, Demi Moore, Valerie Harper and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Tickling game]]

CATEGORIES: Paraphilias, BDSM

Tickling games are interpersonal or social activities involving the tickling of one person by another. Some people find tickling to not only be a pleasurable experience, but also an erotic one. They may be sexually excited by being tickled or by tickling another person, some people like being tickled on their genitals, their waist, their feet, their armpits, their anus, or their breasts while others prefer to tickle and some like doing both an example of a tickle game is asking a guy to adjust your bra so it leaves him open to a tickle attack on the armpits and waist while also making him think about your boobs. Some engage in tickling games as part of a social act.

[[The Vindicator (movie)]]

The Vindicator (also known as Frankenstein '88 and known in Brazil as Roboman) is a 1986 Canadian science fiction thriller movie directed by Jean-Claude Lord and starring Richard Cox, David McIlwraith, Teri Austin, Pam Grier, Maury Chaykin. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Beverly Hills Madam]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 drama movies, American drama movies

Beverly Hills Madam (also known as Ladies of the Night) is a 1986 American television drama movie directed by Harvey Hart and starring Faye Dunaway, Melody Anderson, Donna Dixon, Terry Farrell, Louis Jourdan, Seymour Cassel. It was distributed by Orion Pictures.

[[The Light at the Edge of the World]]

The Light at the Edge of the World is a 1971 American Spanish Liechtenstein adventure movie directed by Kevin Billington and stars Yul Brynner, Kirk Douglas, Samantha Eggar, Jean-Claude Drouot, Fernando Rey, Tito García. It was distributed by National General Pictures.

[[INTLAB]]

CATEGORIES: Software, Technology, Computer science

INTLAB (INTerval LABoratory) is an interval arithmetic library using MATLAB. It is available in Windows and Linux, macOS. It was developed by S.M. Rump from Hamburg University of Technology. INTLAB was used to develop other MATLAB-based libraries such as VERSOFT and INTSOLVER,. It was also used to solve some problems in the Hundred-dollar, Hundred-digit Challenge problems.

[[Lemon Popsicle]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 comedy movies, German comedy movies, Israeli movies, Cult movies, Movies directed by Boaz Davidson

Lemon Popsicle (Israeli: Eskimo Limon, אסקימו לימון) is a 1978 Israeli West German comedy movie directed by Boaz Davidson and starring Anat Atzmon, Zachi Noy, Jonathan Sagall, Yftach Katzur. Its success led to a series of sequels and a 1982 remake The Last American Virgin.

[[Ace Eli and Rodger of the Skies]]

Ace Eli and Rodger of the Skies is a 1973 American adventure comedy movie directed by John Erman and starring Cliff Robertson, Pamela Franklin, Bernadette Peters, Rosemary Murphy,  Eric Shea. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Minneapolis Police Department]]

CATEGORIES: 19th-century establishments in Minnesota, 1867 establishments in the United States, Law enforcement agencies of the United States, Minneapolis, Minnesota

The Minneapolis Police Department (MPD) is the police department in Minneapolis, Minnesota. It was formed in 1867, making it the second-oldest police department in Minnesota. The Saint Paul Police Department is the oldest, formed in 1854. The department has four precincts with over 800 officers and 300 other employees. The department did get national attention from the murder of George Floyd.

[[Patrick van Aanholt]]

CATEGORIES: 1990 births, Living people, Association football defenders, Association football full-backs, Dutch footballers, Chelsea F.C. players, Crystal Palace F.C. players, Premier League players, People from 's-Hertogenbosch, Sportspeople from North Brabant

Patrick John Miguel van Aanholt (born 29 August 1990) is a Dutch footballer. He currently plays for Turkish club Galatasaray. He also plays for the Netherlands national football team. He is a left back (defender). He started his career at FC Den Bosch in their academy, a team for their very young players. He has also played for PSV Eindhoven, Chelsea, Coventry City, Newcastle United, Leicester City, Wigan Athletic, Vitesse, Sunderland and Crystal Palace.

[[Alphablocks]]

CATEGORIES: 2010 British television series debuts, English-language television programs, CBeebies

Alphablocks is a British children's CGI-animated TV series. It debuted on CBeebies in 25 January 2010. It is produced by Blue-Zoo Productions and Alphablocks, the studios that also produce Alphablocks. The show teaches children literacy including simple holding hands.

[[Run (cricket)]]

CATEGORIES: Cricket

There are many versions of cricket. In general, cricket uses runs for scoring. In most cases, the team with the most runs wins the game.  One run 

(known as a "single") can be scored after the bowler, who is in one batsman's ground, has thrown the ball to the batsman in the other ground. That batsman (known as the "striker") can hit the ball away from the fielders. Both the striker and the non-striker then run the length of the pitch, 22 while running to the other ground.  They will cross each other. To complete a run, both batsmen must "make their ground", meaning some part of their person or held bat touches the ground behind the crease (line) at the other end of the pitch. If the wicket in either ground is knocked off by a fielder with the ball when no batsman is in that ground, then the ball becomes dead and one of the batsmen (usually the one nearest to that ground) is run out of the game for the rest of the innings.

The batsman is given four runs if the ball rolls along the ground and hits the boundary. They are given six runs if the ball crosses the boundary while in the air and then touches the ground, similar to a home run in baseball.

When it takes longer to recover the ball, the batsmen may run several times and score many runs.

The total score is gotten by adding up all runs.

[[Hatchback]]

CATEGORIES: Automobile body styles

A hatchback is a car body style. It is useful for short journeys and for a medium amount of luggage.

[[Sofiene Chaari]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 births, 2011 deaths, Tunisian actors, People from Tunis, Tunisian television personalities

Sofiene Chaari (سفيان الشعري; born July 31, 1962 – August 22, 2011) was a Tunisian actor who is famous for his role of Sbouï in the sitcom Choufli Hal. On television, he plays in the series Mnamet Aroussia, Chez Azaïez, and Loutil. In 2005, he obtained the role of Sboui in the television series Choufli Hal, a role which made him popular with the Tunisian public. He plays there alongside Mouna Noureddine and Kamel Touati. 

He also hosts a children's program, the Sofiane show, broadcast on national television.

[[Surround sound]]

CATEGORIES: Sound

Surround sound is the name of a number of technologies for sound reproduction. At the start, sound was reproduced using a single channel (called mono), later there were two channels, left and right (called stereo). Surround sound extends this idea, by adding more channels. There are speakers that surround the listener. The speakers are grouped, and each group has its own channel.  There are different setups ranging from 2 or 3 speakers/channels in the front, and two in the back, up to a setup with 24 speakers (known as 22.2)

With surround sound,  channels are treated differently, to be able to create special sound effects. In classical theatres, surround sound is not used; they may also have different speaker with different channels, but all channels are treated the same.

[[The Man Who Loved Cat Dancing]]

CATEGORIES: 1973 movies, 1970s romance movies, American western movies, MGM movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Richard C. Sarafian

The Man Who Loved Cat Dancing is a 1973 American romantic western movie directed by Richard C. Sarafian and based on the novel of the same name by Marilyn Durham. It stars Burt Reynolds, Sarah Miles, Lee J. Cobb, Jack Warden, George Hamilton, Bo Hopkins and was distributed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

[[Audierne]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Finistère

Audierne (Gwaien) is a commune. It is found in the region Brittany in the Finistère department in the northwest of France. On 1 January 2016, Esquibien became a part of the commune of Audierne.

[[Milizac-Guipronvel]]

CATEGORIES: 2017 establishments in France, Communes in Finistère

Milizac-Guipronvel (Milizag-Gwiproñvel) is a commune. It is found in the region Brittany in the Finistère department in the northwest of France. The municipality was created on 1 January 2017 and consists of the former communes of Guipronvel (the seat) and Milizac.

[[Guipronvel]]

CATEGORIES: Former communes in Finistère

Guipronvel (Gwiproñvel) is a former commune. It is found in the region Brittany in the Finistère department in the northwest of France. On 1 January 2017, it was merged into the new commune of Milizac-Guipronvel.

[[Milizac]]

CATEGORIES: Former communes in Finistère

Milizac (Milizag) is a former commune. It is found in the region Brittany in the Finistère department in the northwest of France. On 1 January 2017, it was merged into the new commune of Milizac-Guipronvel.

CATEGORIES: Former communes in Finistère

Esquibien (An Eskevien) is a former commune. It is found in the region Brittany in the Finistère department in the northwest of France. On 1 January 2016, it became a part of the commune of Audierne.

CJJR-FM, also called 93.7 JR Country, is a country music radio station that broadcasts at 93.7 FM. The radio station is in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada.

[[Battle of Khe Sanh]]

CATEGORIES: Vietnam War, 1968, Tet Offensive, January events, February events, March events, April events, May events, June events, July events, 20th century in Vietnam, Battles involving the United States

The Battle of Khe Sanh was a battle of the Vietnam War during the Tet Offensive. The battle was fought from 21 January to 9 July 1968. Khe Sanh was an important target for communist Vietnamese soldiers to attack because it was a city near the North Vietnam-South Vietnam border and there was a US-South Vietnamese military base nearby. While the US and South Vietnamese militaries fought off communist soldiers in most of the battlezones within 2 months, the Battle of Khe Sanh lasted much longer. It was one of the longest and deadliest battles in the war.

[[Baye, Finistère]]

Baye (Bei) is a commune. It is found in the region Brittany in the Finistère department in the northwest of France.

[[Floyd County, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: 1832 establishments in Georgia (U.S. state), Georgia (U.S. state) counties

Floyd County is a county in the U.S. state of Georgia. As of the 2010 census, 96,317 people lived there. The county seat is Rome.

[[Khe Sanh]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Vietnam

Khe Sanh is a town nearby the old Vietnamese Demilitarized Zone. It was the site of the Battle of Khe Sanh, one of the longest and dealiest battles of the Vietnam War.

[[Jennifer Flynn Oldenburg]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 births, Living people, American volleyball players, American volleyball coaches

Jennifer Flynn Oldenburg (born 26 July 1978) is an American volleyball player and coach. She was a member of the United States women's national volleyball team. She played at the 2002 FIVB World Championship.

She graduated from Ohio State University. She coached for University of Illinois and Ohio State University.

[[Waterparks (band)]]

CATEGORIES: American pop rock bands, Musical groups from Texas, Musicians from Houston, Texas, 21st-century establishments in Texas, 2011 establishments in the United States

Waterparks is an American pop rock band formed in 2011 in Houston, Texas. The members of the group are Awsten Knight (lead vocalist, rhythm guitar), Geoff Wigington (lead guitar, backing vocals) and Otto Wood (drums). 

The group have released three EPs; two were released independently while the third was released under Equal Vision. They released their first full-length album, Double Dare, on November 4th, 2016 under Equal Vision, then their second, Entertainment, under the same label on January 26th, 2018. The band officially announced that they had left Equal Vision on May 23rd, 2019, and revealed that they were under Hopeless Records. Their third full-length album, Fandom, was released under Hopeless on October 11th, 2019. The group are now signed with 300 Entertainment.

[[Miral Abdelkader]]

CATEGORIES: 1983 births, Living people, Egyptian sportspeople, Volleyball players

Miral Abdelkader (born 16 November 1983) is an Egyptian volleyball player. She was a member of Egypt women's national volleyball team. She participated in the 2002 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship and 2006 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship in Japan.

On the club level, she played with Al Ahly Women's Volleyball.

[[Moncef Lazaâr]]

CATEGORIES: Tunisian actors, 1942 births, 2018 deaths, Tunisian screenwriters, People from Tunis

Moncef Lazaâr (المنصف الأزعر; born November 31, 1962 – August 22, 2011) was a Tunisian actor screenwriter. He plays in more than fifty plays, but it is especially his roles in television films which make him known to the general public in the 1990s, notably his role in Ghada by Mohamed Hadj Slimane in 1994 alongside the actors Fethi Haddaoui and Dorsaf Mamlouk, and also his role in El Hassad by Abdelkader Jerbi in 1995 with Dalila Meftahi. In 2005, he wrote the script for Chara Al Hobb directed by Hamadi Arafa.

[[Imperial City of Hue]]

CATEGORIES: Palaces, Buildings and structures in Vietnam

The Imperial City of Hue was the palace where the Nguyen emperors lived and ruled Vietnam from 1802 to 1945. It has a similar purpose to the Forbidden City in Beijing, China. Like the Forbidden City, the inner part of the Imperial City, the Forbidden Purple City, did not allow commoners to enter. The Imperial City was opened to everyone after Vietnam's last emperor, Bao Dai, stepped down from power. The Imperial City would later be a battleground in the Battle of Hue. Even today, visitors can see signs that the battle happened since many of the buildings still have bullet holes in them.

[[Thai Nguyen]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Vietnam

Thai Nguyen is a city in northern Vietnam. It is around 63 kilometers away from Hanoi by plane and 85 kilometers away by car. It is famous for growing tea. It was also the first city in Vietnam to have a steel mill. It is also a center of education in Vietnam. It is also home of the Museum of Cultures of Vietnam's Ethnic Groups.

[[People's Army of Vietnam]]

CATEGORIES: Vietnam War, North Vietnam, Communist militaries, 20th century in Vietnam

The People's Army of Vietnam (PAVN) is the military of modern-day Vietnam. It was also the military of communist North Vietnam during the First Indochina War and the Vietnam War. Non-communist fighters called it the Viet Minh during the First Indochina War and the North Vietnamese Army (NVA) during the Vietnam War. The NVA is not to be confused with the Viet Cong because the Viet Cong were South Vietnamese who fought for North Vietnam. During the Vietnam War, the NVA made a system of trails (mostly in Laos and Cambodia) called the Ho Chi Minh Trail. This was made to send NVA soldiers into South Vietnam and to give Viet Cong support to fight against non-communist soldiers.

[[Ho Chi Minh trail]]

CATEGORIES: Vietnam War

The Ho Chi Minh Trail is a system of trails made in the Vietnam War send North Vietnamese soldiers into South Vietnam and to help the Viet Cong insurgents fight against non-communist South Vietnamese soldiers. Most of the trails were in Laos and Cambodia because the United States was not allowed to enter those countries to bomb the trails. Later in the war, the United States would secretly send US soldiers to fight communist Vietnamese soldiers in Laos and Cambodia.

In early 1971, South Vietnam–with United States support–tried to disrupt the Ho Chi Minh Trail by invading Laos and launching Operation Lam Son 719, but this operation was a failure.

[[Jay Rayner]]

CATEGORIES: British journalists, 1966 births, Columnists, English television personalities, English television presenters, Living people

Jay Rayner is a British journalist and food critic.

[[Hoi An]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Vietnam

Hoi An is a city in Quang Nam Province in Vietnam. It is a popular tourist site near Danang. The old town area has been a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1999. It is a well-kept trading port that mixed native Vietnamese architecture with other types of architecture. Popular ways of traveling the nearby areas are by bicycle, motorcycle, kayak, and motorboat.

[[Ha Long Bay]]

CATEGORIES: Bays, Geography of Vietnam, World Heritage Sites in Asia

Ha Long Bay is a popular tourist site and UNESCO World Heritage Site in northeast Vietnam. The site is famous for having many karsts off the coast.

[[Water puppetry]]

CATEGORIES: Puppets, Vietnamese culture

Water puppetry (Múa rối nước) is a type of puppet theater that has been played in Vietnam since the 11th century. It takes place in a pool where the puppeteers control puppets using a bamboo pole underwater.

[[Cu Chi Tunnels]]

CATEGORIES: Tunnels, Buildings and structures in Vietnam, Vietnam War

The Cu Chi Tunnels was a tunnel system used by the Viet Cong to attack Saigon nearby during the Vietnam War. Throughout the war, Viet Cong would live in tunnels. These tunnels were often deep enough to protect Viet Cong from American bombers. Many of these tunnels were too small for most American soldiers to go into comfortably. They would often have traps that could injure or kill enemy soldiers.

[[Life (magazine)]]

CATEGORIES: American magazines, Magazines published in New York City

Life was an American magazine published weekly until 1972. It later published monthly from 1978 until 2000. During its golden age from 1936 to 1972, Life was a wide-ranging weekly general interest magazine known for the quality of its photography.

After 2000, Time Inc. continued to use the Life brand for special issues. Life returned as a weekly newspaperfrom 2004 to 2007. 

On January 30, 2012, the LIFE.com URL became a photo channel on Time.com.

[[Wolfgang Gunkel]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Rowers, German Olympic gold medalists, Sportspeople from Berlin

Wolfgang Gunkel (15 January 1948 – 20 May 2020) was an East German rower. He competed in coxed pairs together with Jörg Lucke. In this event he won the European title in 1971, the Olympic gold medal in 1972, and the world title in 1975. He was born in Berlin.

[[John Loengard]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 deaths, 1934 births, Deaths from heart failure, American photographers, American educators, People from New York City

John Borg Loengard (September 5, 1934 – May 24, 2020) was an American photographer. He worked at Life magazine from 1961, and was its picture editor from 1973 to 1987. He taught at the International Center of Photography and at The New School for Social Research. He was born in New York City.

Loengard died on May 24, 2020 in New York City of heart failure, aged 85.

[[Granville, Manche]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Manche

Granville (ɡʁɑ̃.vil; Norman: Graunville) is a commune in the Manche department and region of Normandy in north-western France. 

The town is populated by 13,021 people, who are called Granvillais.

[[Curtis Cokes]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, American boxers, Deaths from heart failure, Sportspeople from Dallas, Texas

Curtis Cokes (June 15, 1937 – May 29, 2020) was an American boxer. He was born in Dallas, Texas. Cokes was the World Welterweight Champion. In 2003, Cokes was added into the International Boxing Hall of Fame.

Cokes died on May 29, 2020 of heart failure in Dallas, aged 82.

[[Evaldo Gouveia]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, Brazilian singers, Brazilian writers, Songwriters, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil

Evaldo Gouveia de Oliveira (August 8, 1928 – May 29, 2020), better known as simply Evaldo Gouveia, was a Brazilian singer-songwriter. His works were MPB. He was born in Orós, Ceará. Gouveia released seven studio albums and many plays, most of them featuring fellow singers Adelino Moreira and Jair Amorim. 

On May 29, 2020, Gouveia died in Fortaleza, Ceará at the age 91 from COVID-19.

[[Henk Steevens]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Dutch cyclists, People from Sittard-Geleen, Sportspeople from Limburg (Netherlands)

Henk Steevens (1932, Geleen – 29 May 2020) was a Dutch cyclist. Steevens won the GP of Aken and the Grote Continental Prijs of Hannover. 

He was named together with Sjefke Janssen and Jan Nolten the “three of Elsloo”. They were all three part of the Dutch team at the 1953 Tour de France. He was part of the pre-selection for the 1954 Tour de France, but was not selected.

After his cycling career, he became team manager of “ Ovis en Driessen Stoffen”.  His brother Harry Steevens was also a cyclist.

Steevens died on 29 May 2020, aged 88.

[[Harry Steevens]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, Living people, Dutch cyclists, Dutch Olympians, Sportspeople from Limburg (Netherlands)

Henri "Harry/Harrie" Steevens (born 27 April 1945) is a retired Dutch cyclist. His career lasted from 1960 and 1972. He competed at the 1964 Summer Olympics in the individual road race and finished in 40th place. 

Two years later he won a silver medal in the team time trial at the 1966 UCI Road World Championships. He also won the Olympia's Tour (1965), Ronde van Limburg (1966) and Amstel Gold Race (1968).

His brother Henk Steevens was also a cyclist.

[[Michael Angelis]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, British movie actors, British television actors, British stage actors, British voice actors, Actors from Liverpool

Michael Angelis (18 January 1952– 30 May 2020) was a British actor. He was best known for his roles in Boys from the Black Stuff and G.B.H.. He was the narrator of the British children's television series Thomas and Friends from 1991 to 2012. He was born in Liverpool, England.

Angelis died on 30 May 2020 of a heart attack in Berkshire, aged 68.

[[Bobby Dimond]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Australian rugby league players, Sportspeople from New South Wales

Bobby Dimond (July 30, 1930 – May 30, 2020) was an Australian rugby league footballer. He played in the 1940s and 1950s and was known for his play with the national team. He was selected to play for Australia and was a member of the 1948 Kangaroo Tour. He played 20 matches on the tour and scored ten tries, but did not play in a test match. 

He was born in Dapto, New South Wales. Dimond died on May 30, 2020 in Mexico City, aged 89.

[[Thomas Pynchon]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, American essayists, American novelists, American Roman Catholics, Cornell University alumni, Living people, Writers from New York

Thomas Ruggles Pynchon Jr. (ˈ, commonly -; born May 8, 1937) is an American author. He is part of the MacArthur Fellowship and writes very complex novels with deep meanings. He writes many different types of both fiction and non-fiction. For ''Gravity's Rainbow, Pynchon won the 1973 U.S. National Book Award for Fiction

Pynchon is from Long Island, New York, and served two years in the United States Navy. He also got a degree in English from Cornell University. He published many short stories in the late-1950s and early-1960s. After this, he started writing novels. He is most famous for the novels V. (1963), The Crying of Lot 49 (1966), and Gravity's Rainbow (1973) from this time. 

[[Elsa Dorfman]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from renal failure, American photographers, People from Cambridge, Massachusetts

Elsa Dorfman (April 26, 1937 – May 30, 2020) was an American portrait photographer. She was known for her use of a large-format instant Polaroid camera. She was born in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

Dorfman's principal published work, originally published in 1974, was Elsa's Housebook - A Woman's Photojournal. She took pictures of Lawrence Ferlinghetti, Allen Ginsberg and Peter Orlovsky, Gary Snyder, Gregory Corso, and Robert Creeley. She also photographed staples of the Boston rock scene such as Jonathan Richman frontman of The Modern Lovers, and Steven Tyler of Aerosmith.

Dorfman died of kidney failure at her home in Cambridge on May 30, 2020 at the age of 83.

[[Fudan University]]

CATEGORIES: 20th century establishments in China, 1900s establishments in Asia, 1905 establishments, Buildings and structures in Shanghai, Colleges and universities in Asia

Fudan University (复旦大学) is a public research university in Shanghai, China. Most people think it is one of the best universities in China. It was founded in 1905, and was the first university in China started by the people instead of the government. Fudan is part of the C9 League of universities. The Chinese Ministry of Education calls the university a  CLass A Double First Class University. This means they think it is very good.

[[Mady Mesplé]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, French singers, People from Toulouse, Deaths from Parkinson's disease

Mady Mesplé (7 March 1931 – 30 May 2020) was a French opera singer. She was a well known coloratura soprano in France. She was born in Toulouse, France. Her career lasted from 1953 to 1985. 

[[Glen Cove, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in New York

Glen Cove is a city in Nassau County, New York, United States. It is on the North Shore of Long Island. There were 26,964 people who lived there in 2010.

[[John Nzenze]]

CATEGORIES: People from Nairobi, Deaths from surgical complications, Guitarists, 1940 births, 2020 deaths

John Amutabi Nzenze (1940 – May 30, 2020) was a Kenyan guitarist. He was born in Nairobi. He had performed the twist dance style. Some of his most popular songs were "Angelike" (released in 1961), "Julieta Rudi Tuone" and "Habari za Nairobi (Nairobi twist)".

He toured Japan, Britain and various East African countries. In 1968 he represented Kenya at All African Music Festival in Algeria, finishing third. Next year the band performed with Miles Davis in Germany.

In 1971, BBC World Service gave them a Best Band in Africa award. 

Nzenze died on May 30, 2020 at a hospital in Kakamega, Kenya from problems caused by stomach surgery, aged 80.

[[Series acceleration]]

CATEGORIES: Mathematics, Computer science

In numerical analysis, series acceleration (sometimes called as convergence improvement) is the name for algorithms that transforms slowly convergent series to rapidly convergent series.

[[Bobby Morrow]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from peripheral neuropathy, Deaths from anemia, American track and field athletes, American Olympic gold medalists, Sportspeople from Texas

Bobby Joe Morrow (October 15, 1935 – May 30, 2020) was an  American sprinter. He won three gold medals at the 1956 Summer Olympics. He was known as "the dominant sprinter of the 1950s" and "the most relaxed sprinter of all time, even more so than his hero Jesse Owens". He was born in Harlingen, Texas. 

He retired in 1958 to become a farmer and a woodworker.  He made a short comeback before the 1960 Olympic Games, but failed to qualify for the U.S. Olympic team.

Morrow died of anemia and peripheral neuropathy on May 30, 2020, at his home in San Benito, Texas, at the age of 84.

[[San Benito, Texas]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Texas

San Benito is a city in Cameron County, Texas, United States. The population was 24,250 at the 2010 census. 

[[Kate Higgins]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American video game actors, American jazz musicians, American pianists, American jazz singers, People from Charlottesville, Virginia, Actors from Virginia, Singers from Virginia, Musicians from Virginia, Actors from Alabama, Musicians from Alabama, Singers from Alabama

Katherine Davis Higgins (born August 16, 1969) is an American actress, singer, and jazz pianist. 

Higgins's major voice roles have been in English-language versions of Japanese anime, and she is best known as the voice of Sakura Haruno in Naruto and Talho Yuuki in Eureka 7. 

She has also voiced CC in Code Geass and Saber in the original Fate/stay night. 

Between 2010 and 2013, Higgins voiced Tails in the video game series Sonic the Hedgehog. 

She also voices Kate, Stinky, and Lilly in the Alpha and Omega sequels. She is the current voice of Princess Aurora since 2010.

[[Fourier series]]

CATEGORIES: Mathematical analysis

Joseph Fourier said that it is possible to use sine waves to approximate another function. This is a series in the mathematical sense. This theory can be generalized to the Fourier transform. Mathematical analysis of these functions is called Fourier analysis. 

In the 18th century, mathematicians such as Euler, Lagrange and Bernoulli already used sinusoids to approximate and model other functions. When Fourier published a work on heat, in 1822, he said that such approximations exist for any such function (that is continuous in the interval). At first, people didn't believe him, and it took almost ten years for a proof (of part of the problem) to appear.

Today, fourier series are used a lot in digital signal processing.

The Holden Commodore was a medium-sized saloon produced by Holden from 1978 to 2020.

Michael Scofield is one of the main characters in the TV series Prison Break. His part was played by Went Worth Miller.

[[Southern Comfort (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 action movies, 1980s adventure movies, 1981 thriller movies, American action thriller movies, American adventure movies, Swiss movies, American independent movies, Movies directed by Walter Hill

Southern Comfort is a 1981 American action adventure thriller movie directed by Walter Hill and starring Keith Carradine, Powers Boothe, Fred Ward, Franklyn Seales, Peter Coyote, T. K. Carter, Lewis Smith. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[List of Disney live-action remakes of animated movies]]

CATEGORIES: Disney movies

This is a list of the live-action reimaginings saga produced by Walt Disney Pictures of its animated films. This list does not include remakes of live-action/animation hybrid films (such as Mary Poppins or Pete's Dragon), animated movies or live-action movies that were produced by another studio and later reimagined into live-action films by Disney (such as The Wizard of Oz and The Nutcracker and the Four Realms), live-action films another studio made based on the same story as a Disney feature that were later acquired (such as Fox’s Ever After or Pathé‘s The Wind in the Willows/Mr. Toad’s Wild Ride), the direct to video release The Jungle Book: Mowgli’s Story, or based on animated television shows (such as Kim Possible).

[[Wild Strawberries (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 drama movies, Swedish movies, Movies directed by Ingmar Bergman, Movies about dreams

Wild Strawberries is a 1957 Swedish drama movie directed by Ingmar Bergman and stars Victor Sjöström, Bibi Andersson, Ingrid Thulin, Gunnar Björnstrand, Björn Bjelfvenstam, Max von Sydow. It was nominated for an Academy Award in 1960.

[[Bernardine (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 comedy movies, 1950s musical movies, Movies based on plays, American musical comedy movies, Movies directed by Henry Levin

Bernardine is a 1957 American musical comedy movie directed by Henry Levin and based on the play of the same name by Mary Coyle Chase. It stars Pat Boone, Terry Moore, Janet Gaynor, Dean Jagger, Dick Sargent, James Drury, Walter Abel, Russ Conway and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Georgina Pinedo]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 births, Living people, Argentine volleyball players

Georgina Soledad Pinedo (born 30 May 1981 in Buenos Aires) is an Argentine volleyball player.

She participated at the 2002 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship, 2003 Women's South American Volleyball Championship, 2009 Women's South American Volleyball Championship, 2008 Women's Pan-American Volleyball Cup, 2008 Final Four Women's Volleyball Cup, 2010 Final Four Women's Volleyball Cup, 2011 FIVB Volleyball World Grand Prix, and 2013 European Cup.

At the club level, she played for Boca Juniors and Volero Le Cannet.

[[Southern Peninsula (Iceland)]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Iceland

The Southern Peninsula (Suðurnes) is a region in the southwest of the Iceland. The population of the region was 27,829 (2020). The capital in the region is Keflavík, with a population of 15,930 (2018).

[[Capital Region (Iceland)]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Iceland

Greater Reykjavík (Höfuðborgarsvæðið, meaning "The Capital Region") is one of the eight regions of Iceland and also one of the two NUTS 3 regions. It is in the southwest of the country. The population of the region was 233,034 (2020). The capital in the region is Reykjavík, which is also the national capital. It is made up of six municipalities.

[[Todd Fisher]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, American chief executives, American cinematographers, American movie directors, American movie producers, American television directors, American television producers, Living people

Todd Emmanuel Fisher (born February 24, 1958) is an American director, cinematographer, producer and actor of television movies and documentaries. He was born in Beverly Hills. Fisher is the son of singer Eddie Fisher and actress Debbie Reynolds. Carrie Fisher was his sister. His nieces are Billie Catherine Lourd, Olivia Luna Fisher-Duddy, Skylar Grace Fisher-Duddy, True Harlow Fisher-Duddy. He wrote the book My Girls: A Lifetime with Carrie and Debbie.

[[Archosauromorph]]

CATEGORIES: Reptiles

Archosauromorpha is a clade of diapsid reptiles containing all reptiles more closely related to archosaurs than to lepidosaurs.

Lepidosaurs include tuataras, lizards, and snakes.

Archosauromorphs include turtles, crocodiles, dinosaurs and birds.

[[1938 Atlantic hurricane season]]

CATEGORIES: Atlantic hurricane seasons, 1938

The 1938 hurricane season was a normal season except for one thing. The 1938 hurricane season brought a EXTREMELY strong hurricane to Long Island, New Jersey, and even New Hampshire. It brought category 4 winds with it. It is also known as the 1938 New England Hurricane. Except for that, the 1938 hurricane season was a normal season.

[[Global Banking & Finance Review]]

CATEGORIES: 2010 establishments in the United Kingdom, Magazines of the United Kingdom

Global Banking and Finance Review is a British finance related magazine. Their office is located in the United Kingdom. It was launched in 2010 by Varun Sash. The magazine focuses on global financial trends and developments. Wanda Rich is the current editor of Global Banking and Finance Review. In 2011, it started awards program which is known as Global Banking & Finance Awards.

[[Morning Advertiser]]

CATEGORIES: Magazines of the United Kingdom

Morning Advertiser is a British trade magazine. In 2011, William Reed Business Media, bought The Publican from United Business Media and merged these two titles to The Publican's Morning Advertiser. Later, in 2016, it was renamed to the Morning Advertiser.

The magazine was first published in 1794 in London.

[[Cambridge University Press]]

CATEGORIES: University presses, Publishing companies of the United Kingdom, 1534 establishments

Cambridge University Press is the publishing wing of the University of Cambridge. King Henry VIII of England granted it the letters patent in 1534. It is also the world's oldest publishing house and the second-largest university press in the world.

Cambridge University Press has offices in 40 countries and it has published over 50,000 titles by authors from 100 different countries. They publishes academic journals, monographs, reference works, textbooks, and English language teaching and learning publications.

[[H. C. Stackpole III]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, American generals, American military personnel of the Vietnam War, People from New Haven, Connecticut

Henry Charles "Hank" Stackpole III (May 7, 1935 – May 29, 2020) was an American lieutenant general in the Marine Corps. His awards include the Silver Star, Legion of Merit, and Defense Superior Service Medal. He entered the Marine Corps in 1957. He was born in New Haven, Connecticut. 

Stackpole died in Hawaii on May 29, 2020 at the age of 85.

[[Nadine Kunz]]

She was part of the German women's national water polo team  at the 2001 Women's European Water Polo Championship, 2006 Women's European Water Polo Championship, 2007 World Aquatics Championships, and 2009 FINA Women's World Championships.

[[Yawovi Agboyibo]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, Prime Ministers of Togo, 2020 deaths

Yawovi Madji Agboyibo (31 December 1943 – 30 May 2020) was a Togolese politician. He was Prime Minister of Togo from September 2006 to December 2007. He was National President of the Action Committee for Renewal (CAR), an opposition political party, from 1991 to 2008. 

He died in Paris on 30 May 2020 after a short-illness, aged 76.

[[Michel Gauthier]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from lung cancer, Leaders of the Opposition (Canada), People from Quebec City, Politicians from Quebec, Members of the House of Commons of Canada from Quebec

Michel Gauthier (miʃɛl ɡotje; (February 18, 1950 – May 30, 2020) was a Canadian politician. He was leader of the Bloc Québécois from 1996 to 1997. He was Leader of the Opposition in the Parliament of Canada during the same time. He was a member of parliament from 1994 to 2007. 

Gauthier was born in Quebec City. He was also a member of the Conservative Party. Gauthier died on May 30, 2020 in Quebec City of lung cancer, aged 70.

[[Christo and Jeanne-Claude]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2009 deaths, 2020 deaths, Deaths from aneurysm, Deaths from natural causes in the United States, Naturalized citizens of the United States, People from Casablanca, Bulgarian people, American sculptors, American painters, Duos, Artists from New York City

Christo Vladimirov Javacheff (June 13, 1935 – May 31, 2020) and Jeanne-Claude Denat de Guillebon (June 13, 1935 – November 18, 2009) were a married couple who created environmental works of art. 

Their works include the wrapping of the Reichstag in Berlin and the Pont-Neuf bridge in Paris, the 24 artwork called Running Fence in Sonoma and Marin counties in California, and The Gates in New York City's Central Park.

Christo was born in Gabrovo, present-day Bulgaria. Jeanne-Claude was born in Casablanca, present-day Morocco. They met in Paris in 1958. In 1964, they moved to New York City where they began their joint art career. 

Their works were given credit to "Christo" only, until 1994, when the outdoor works and large indoor were credited to "Christo and Jeanne-Claude". They flew in separate planes: in case one crashed, the other could continue their work.

Jeanne-Claude died, aged 74, on November 18, 2009 in New York City, from problems caused by a brain aneurysm. Christo died on May 31, 2020, of natural causes in New York City, aged 84.

[[Theresa Klein]]

CATEGORIES: German water polo players, Living people, Year of birth missing (living people)

Theresa Klein is a German water polo player. She was part of the German women's national water polo team at the 2003 World Aquatics Championships, 2006 European Water Polo Championship, and 2007 World Aquatics Championships, 2008 Women's European Water Polo Championship, and 2009 FINA Water Polo Women's Championship.

CATEGORIES: 1979 births, Living people, German water polo players

Nina Wengst (born 20 March 1979) is a German water polo player. She was part of the German women's national water polo team at the 2005 World Aquatics Championships, 2007 World Aquatics Championships, and 2009 World Aquatics Championships.

She played for University of Southern California's women's water polo team.

[[Dan van Husen]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United Kingdom, German movie actors, German television actors, German stage actors, Actors from North Rhine-Westphalia

Dan van Husen (30 April 1945 – 31 May 2020) was a German actor. He appeared in some Hollywood movies. He was born in Gummersbach, Germany. Van Husen was known for his roles in Fellini Casanova, by Federico Fellini, in Salon Kitty by Tinto Brass and Nosferatu the Vampyre directed by Werner Herzog.

Van Husen died on 31 May 2020 in Somerset, England of COVID-19, aged 75.

[[Tinto Brass]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, Living people, Italian movie directors, Italian movie producers, Italian screenwriters, People from Milan

Giovanni "Tinto" Brass (born 26 March 1933) is an Italian movie director, producer and screenwriter. He was born in Milan, Italy.

In the 1960s and 1970s, he directed many avant-garde movies. He is known for his movies Caligula, Così fan tutte (released under the English title All Ladies Do It), Paprika, Monella (Frivolous Lola) and Trasgredire.

In April 2010, Brass was hospitalized after having an intracranial hemorrhage.

[[Evan H. Turner]]

Evan Hopkins Turner (born 1927) is an American art historian and museum director.

[[Nosferatu the Vampyre]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 horror movies, German horror movies, French horror movies, Movies directed by Werner Herzog

Nosferatu the Vampyre is a 1979 West German French horror movie directed by Werner Herzog. Its original German title is Nosferatu: Phantom der Nacht (Nosferatu: Phantom of the Night) and stars Isabelle Adjani, Bruno Ganz, Klaus Kinski, Dan van Husen, Roland Topor, Jan Groth, Walter Ladengast, Rijk de Gooyer and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

Indy Baijens (born 4 February 2001 in Zaandam) is a Dutch volleyball player for ASPTT Mulhouse and the Dutch national team.

[[Sajid–Wajid]]

CATEGORIES: Duos, Indian composers, 1970s births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in India

Sajid–Wajid was an Indian Bollywood Hindi movie music director duo made up of brothers Sajid Khan and Wajid Khan, the sons of Ustad Sharafat Ali Khan. They were born in Saharanpur, Uttar Pradesh. Their career began in 1998.

The music duo has also composed music for several movies starring Salman Khan, which include Tumko Na Bhool Paayenge (2002), Tere Naam (2003), Garv (2004), Mujhse Shaadi Karogi (2004), Partner (2007), Hello (2008), God Tussi Great Ho (2008), Wanted (2009), Main Aur Mrs Khanna, (2009), Veer (2010), Dabangg (2010), No Problem (2010) and Ek Tha Tiger (2012).

Wajid Khan died on June 1, 2020 of COVID-19, aged 43. 

[[Norman Lamm]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, American rabbis, American educators, Jewish American writers, Writers from New York City

Norman Lamm (December 19, 1927 – May 31, 2020) was an American Modern Orthodox rabbi, scholar, author and Jewish communal leader. He was the Chancellor of Yeshiva University until his retirement on July 1, 2013. He was born in New York City. 

In 1958 Lamm helped found Tradition, an academic journal of Modern Orthodox thought. He also launched the Torah U-Madda Journal.

Lamm died on May 31, 2020 in Englewood, New Jersey at the age of 92.

[[Five Days from Home]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 drama movies, 1970s crime drama movies, American crime drama movies

Five Days from Home is a 1979 American crime drama movie directed by George Peppard (who also stars) and starring Sherry Boucher, Neville Brand, Robert Donner, Ronnie Claire Edwards, Savannah Smith Boucher. It was distributed by Universal Pictures.

[[Antifa (United States)]]

CATEGORIES: Political movements

The antifa (æ), short for anti-fascist, movement in the United States is a militant left-wing, anti-fascist political activist movement. It is made up of activist groups that protest with the use of direct action instead of policy changes.

The methods include protesting, digital activism, property damage, physical violence and harassment against those who they see as fascist, racist, or on the far-right.

The movement has anti-capitalist views and support anarchism, communism, liberalism, social democracy and socialism.

It has been called a terrorist movement by President Donald Trump after the group took part in the George Floyd protests in 2020.

[[Doug Hurley]]

CATEGORIES: 1966 births, Living people, American astronauts, Engineers from New York, Scientists from New York, People from Endicott, New York

Douglas Gerald Hurley (born October 21, 1966) is an American engineer. He was a former Marine Corps pilot, and current NASA astronaut. He piloted Space Shuttle missions STS-127 (July 2009) and STS-135 (July 2011), the final flight of the Space Shuttle program. 

He launched into space for the third time as Commander of Crew Dragon Demo-2, the first crewed spaceflight from American soil since STS-135. He was also the first Marine to fly the F/A-18 E/F Super Hornet. 

[[Bob Behnken]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 births, Living people, American astronauts, Engineers from Missouri, Scientists from St. Louis, Missouri

Robert Louis Behnken (ˈ; born July 28, 1970) is a NASA astronaut, engineer, and former Chief of the Astronaut Office. Behnken was selected as an astronaut by NASA in 2000 and is a veteran of two space shuttle flights. A native of Missouri, Behnken flew STS-123 in March 2008 and STS-130 in February 2010, logging more than 708 hours in space, and more than 37 hours during six spacewalks. Behnken most recently served as Joint Operations Commander on the first crewed flight of the SpaceX Crew Dragon, the Demo-2 mission, which landed August 2, 2020. He also served as Flight Engineer on the International Space Station for Expedition 63.

[[St. Ann, Missouri]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Missouri

St. Ann is a suburb of St. Louis in north St. Louis County, Missouri, United States. The population was 13,020 at the 2010 census.

Wexford is an unincorporated community in Allegheny County, Pennsylvania, United States.

[[Pine Township, Allegheny County, Pennsylvania]]

Pine Township is a township in Allegheny County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 11,497 at the 2010 census.

Pine Township was named for the large number of pine trees.

[[Cheswold, Delaware]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Delaware

Cheswold is a town in Kent County in the U.S. state of Delaware. It is part of the Dover, Delaware Metropolitan Statistical Area. The population was 1,380 at the 2010 census.

[[Music to Be Murdered By]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 albums, Eminem albums

Music to Be Murdered By is the eleventh studio album by American rapper Eminem, released on January 17, 2020 by Aftermath Entertainment, Interscope Records and Shady Records with no prior announcement, similar to his previous album Kamikaze (2018). The album was produced by Dr. Dre, and features collaborations with Black Thought, Q-Tip, Juice Wrld, Ed Sheeran, Young M.A, Skylar Grey, Don Toliver, Anderson Paak and Royce da 5'9", among others.

Alongside the album, Eminem also released a music video for "Darkness", directed by James Larese.

[[Back from the Dead (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 horror movies, American horror movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Charles Marquis Warren

Back from the Dead is a 1957 American horror movie directed by Charles Marquis Warren and based on the 1952 novel The Other One by Catherine Turney. It stars Peggie Castle, Arthur Franz, Marsha Hunt, Don Haggerty, Marianne Stewart and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[God Is My Partner]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 drama movies, American drama movies, Movies directed by William F. Claxton

God Is My Partner is a 1957 American drama movie directed by William F. Claxton and starring Walter Brennan, John Hoyt, Marion Ross, Jesse White, Nelson Leigh, Charles Lane, Paul Cavanagh, Gloria Blondell. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Léo Major]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 2008 deaths, Canadian military personnel of World War II, Military personnel of the Korean War, People from Massachusetts

Léo Major CAN & Bar (January 23, 1921 – October 12, 2008) was a Canadian soldier. He was the only Canadian to ever get the Distinguished Conduct Medal (DCM) twice in different wars. Major got his first DCM in World War II in 1945 when he made the German army run away in the city of Zwolle; he did this by himself. He was sent to scout the city with one of his best friends, but he thought Zwolle was too beautiful for an attack, deciding instead to clear it out himself. A firefight happened in which his friend was killed, and after that, he put the commanders of each group of enemy soldiers he found at gunpoint. He did this until he could take soldier groups prisoner back at base. He did this again and again until the there were no more German soldiers in the city. He got his second DCM in 1951 during the Korean War for leading the capture of an important hill.

[[Accumoli]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Italy, Settlements in Lazio

Accumoli is a town (comune) in Central Italy. It is in the Province of Rieti in the region of Lazio.

[[Apache Warrior]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 movies, 1950s western movies, American western movies

Apache Warrior is a 1957 American western movie directed by Elmo Williams and was also known as Red Arrow, The Apache Kid and The Long Knives. It stars Keith Larsen, Jim Davis, Rodolfo Acosta, John Mijan, Damian O'Flynn, George Keymans and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Hell on Devil's Island]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 drama movies, 1950s adventure movies, American adventure movies, American drama movies, Movies set in islands

Hell on Devil's Island is a 1957 American adventure drama movie directed by Christian Nyby and starring Helmut Dantine, William Talman, Donna Martell, Jean Willes, Jay Adler, Rex Ingram. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Break in the Circle]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 drama movies, British drama movies, Movies directed by Val Guest

Break in the Circle is a 1955 British drama movie directed by Val Guest and starring Forrest Tucker, Eva Bartok, Marius Goring, Guy Middleton, Eric Pohlmann, Reginald Beckwith. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[The Sun Also Rises (1957 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 drama movies, American drama movies, Movies based on books, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Henry King

The Sun Also Rises is a 1957 American drama movie directed by Henry King and based on the novel of the same name by Ernest Hemingway. It stars Tyrone Power, Ava Gardner, Mel Ferrer, Errol Flynn, Eddie Albert, Henry Daniell, Juliette Gréco and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Derek Barton]]

CATEGORIES: British chemists

Sir Derek Harold Richard Barton (8 September 1918 – 16 March 1998) was an English organic chemist and Nobel Prize laureate.

He was born in Gravesend, Kent. His father was William Thomas and mother was Maude Henrietta Barton. He attended Gravesend Grammar School (1926–29), The King's School, Rochester (1929–32), Tonbridge School (1932–35) and Medway Technical College (1937–39). He was graduated from the Imperial College London and obtained his PhD degree in Organic Chemistry in 1942.

He was awarded the Fellow of the Royal Society and Fellowship of the Royal Society of Edinburgh.

[[Quinn Hughes]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, 1999 births, Vancouver Canucks players, Ice hockey defencemen

Quinton Hughes (born October 14, 1999) is an American ice hockey defenseman. He is currently playing for the Vancouver Canucks of the National Hockey League (NHL). The team drafted him 7th overall during the 2018 NHL Entry Draft.

After playing with the USA Hockey National Team Development Program, Hughes joined the University of Michigan for the 2017–18 season. He played two seasons with Michigan before joining the Canucks for their 2018–19 NHL season.

[[The Phantom Carriage]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 movies, Fantasy movies, 1920s horror movies, Swedish movies, Silent movies, Movies directed by Victor Sjöström

The Phantom Carriage (Körkarlen, literally "The Wagoner") is a 1921 Swedish fantasy horror movie directed by Victor Sjöström (who also stars) and based on the 1912 novel Thy Soul Shall Bear Witness! (Körkarlen) by Selma Lagerlöf. It stars Hilda Borgström, Tore Svennberg, Astrid Holm, Concordia Selander and was distributed by AB Svensk Filmindustri. It was remade in 1958.

[[Carl Gunnarsson]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 births, Living people, St. Louis Blues players, Stanley Cup champions, Toronto Maple Leafs players, Ice hockey defencemen

Carl Gunnarsson (born 9 November 1986) is a Swedish ice hockey defenceman currently playing for the St. Louis Blues of the National Hockey League (NHL). Gunnarsson was drafted by the Toronto Maple Leafs in the 2007 NHL Entry Draft. Gunnarsson won the Stanley Cup as a member of the Blues in 2019.

[[Joel Edmundson]]

CATEGORIES: 1993 births, Canadian ice hockey defencemen, Carolina Hurricanes players, Ice hockey people from Manitoba, Kamloops Blazers players, Living people, Moose Jaw Warriors players, St. Louis Blues players, Stanley Cup champions

Joel Edmundson (born June 28, 1993) is a Canadian professional ice hockey defenceman for the Carolina Hurricanes of the National Hockey League (NHL). He was drafted by the St. Louis Blues in the 2011 NHL Draft. He helped the Blues win their first Stanley Cup in the team's history in 2019. On September 24, 2019, Edmundson was traded to the Carolina Hurricanes.

[[Excalibur (movie)]]

Excalibur is 1981 American British Irish fantasy movie directed by John Boorman and starring Nigel Terry, Helen Mirren, Nicholas Clay, Cherie Lunghi, Nicol Williamson, Corin Redgrave, Patrick Stewart, Clive Swift, Liam Neeson, Gabriel Byrne. It was distributed by Warner Bros. and was nominated for an Academy Award in 1982.

[[Under the Cherry Moon]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 romance movies, 1980s musical movies, American romance movies, American musical movies

Under the Cherry Moon is a 1986 American romantic musical movie directed by Prince (who also stars) and stars Jerome Benton, Kristin Scott Thomas, Steven Berkoff, Francesca Annis. It was distributed by Warner Bros. and won 5 Razzies at the Golden Raspberry Awards in 1987.

[[Hick's law]]

CATEGORIES: Psychology

Hick's law, or the Hick–Hyman law is named after British and American psychologists William Edmund Hick and Ray Hyman. It describes the time it takes for a person to make a decision as a result of the possible choices.

Increasing the number of choices increases the decision time logarithmically. The amount of time taken to process a certain amount of bits in the Hick–Hyman law is known as the rate of gain of information.

Hick's law may support some computing menu design decisions. For example, to find a given word (e.g. the name of a command) in a randomly ordered word list (e.g. a menu). If the list is alphabetical, and the user knows the name of the command, he or she may be able to use a subdividing strategy that works in logarithmic time.

[[Danny Havoc]]

CATEGORIES: American professional wrestlers, 1986 births, 2020 deaths, Sportspeople from Iowa

Grant Berkland, better known as Danny Havoc (May 19, 1986 – May 31, 2020) was an American professional wrestler. He was born in Cylinder, Iowa. He wrestled for Game Changer Wrestling (GCW), and was best known for his work in Combat Zone Wrestling (CZW).

He announced his retirement and on September 9, 2017. Two years later, Havoc came out of retirement for Matt Tremont's H2O Wrestling at a benefit show. 

In February 2020, he returned to Game Changer Wrestling (who he had made special appearances from 2015 to 2017) for their Tokyo tour.

His death was announced on May 31, 2020 at the age of 34.

[[Mukar Cholponbayev]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2020 deaths, Kyrgyzstani people, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Kyrgyzstan

Mukar Shaltakovich Cholponbayev (Мукар Шалтакович Чолпонбаев; 29 March 1950 – 24 May 2020) was a Kyrgyzstani politician. He was born in Issyk-Kul Region, Kyrgyz SSR. From 1984 to 1991, he was Deputy Head of the Legal Department of the Supreme Council of the Kyrgyz SSR, and later promoted to Head of the Legal Department.

After the collapse of the Soviet Union, from 1991 to 1993, he was the Head of Department of Justice of Chuy Region, and Head of the Presidential Administration Department. He was Minister of Justice from 1993 to 1995. He was the Chairman of the Legislative Assembly of Kyrgyzstan from 1995 to 1996. 

He died in Bishkek on 24 May 2020 from COVID-19, aged 70.

[[John Zdechlik]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, American composers, American conductors, American educators, Musicians from Minneapolis, Minnesota, Writers from Minneapolis, Minnesota

John Zdechlik (Zuh-DECK-lik; May 2, 1937 – May 21, 2020) was an American composer, music teacher, and conductor.  Zdechlik was elected to the American Bandmasters Association in 1989. He was born in Minneapolis, Minnesota. His best known work was Chorale and Shaker Dance.

In 1970, Zdechlik began his career as a teacher at Lakewood Community College (now Century College) in White Bear Lake, Minnesota. For thirty years he was a conductor, professor, music department chair, and resident composer. He retired in 1997.

Zdechlik died on May 21, 2020 at his home in White Bear Lake, Minnesota, aged 83.

[[White Bear Lake, Minnesota]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Minnesota

White Bear Lake is a city in Ramsey County in the state of Minnesota. A small portion of the city also in Washington County. The population was 23,769 at the 2010 census. 

[[Susan Rothenberg]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, American painters, American sculptors, People from Buffalo, New York, People from New Mexico

Susan Charna Rothenberg (January 20, 1945 – May 18, 2020) was an American contemporary painter, printmaker and sculptor. She was known for her iconic images of the horse.

Rothenberg’s first solo exhibition in New York in 1975. After moving to a ranch near Galisteo, New Mexico, her paintings reflected life in the Southwestern United States.

Rothenberg died at her home in Galisteo on May 18, 2020, at age 75.

[[Galisteo, New Mexico]]

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places in New Mexico

Galisteo is a census-designated place (CDP) in Santa Fe County, New Mexico, United States. It is part of the Santa Fe, New Mexico Metropolitan Statistical Area. The population was 253 at the 2010 census.

[[Bruce Nauman]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, Living people, American sculptors, American photographers, People from Fort Wayne, Indiana

Bruce Nauman (born December 6, 1941) is an American artist. His works focused on many medias including sculpture, photography, neon, video, drawing, printmaking, and performance. He was born in Fort Wayne, Indiana.

In the 1960s, Nauman began to exhibit his work at Nick Wilder's gallery in Los Angeles and in New York at Leo Castelli in 1968 along with early solo shows at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and the Whitney Museum in 1972. His Self Portrait as a Fountain (1966) shows the artist spouting a stream of water from his mouth. 

Nauman lives near Galisteo, New Mexico. He was married to artist Susan Rothenberg from 1989 until her death in 2020.

[[Jim McDermott]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, Living people, United States representatives from Washington, Politicians from Chicago, Politicians from Seattle, Washington, US Democratic Party politicians

James Adelbert McDermott (born December 28, 1936) is an American politician. He was the U.S. Representative for WA from 1989 to 2017.  He is a member of the Democratic Party. 

He served on the House Ways and Means Committee and was a member of the House Progressive Caucus.  He was formerly the committee chairman, then in 1995, ranking minority member on the House Ethics Committee. 

On January 4, 2016, he announced his retirement.

Nancy Elizabeth Lee Johnson (born January 5, 1935) is an American politician. Johnson was a Republican member of the United States House of Representatives from 1983 to 2007.

[[Civil township]]

CATEGORIES: Subdivisions of the United States

In the United States, the term civil township is used for a form of goverment below the county level. In some places, the name town is used instead. About twenty states use the term civil township.

[[Paul Myners, Baron Myners]]

CATEGORIES: British politicians, British businesspeople

Paul Myners, Baron Myners is a British businessman and politician. He was the Financial Services Secretary in the UK's finance ministry during the Labour Government of Gordon Brown.

He also served on the Prime Minister's National Economic Council and at present sits as a crossbencher in the House of Lords. He has been working in the financial sector since 1974 and was a  chairman of the Low Pay Commission. He also served as the chairman of the Guardian Media Group which publishes The Guardian and The Observer newspapers in the United Kingdom.

[[Eye of Providence]]

CATEGORIES: Christian symbols, Freemasonry, National coats of arms, Symbols of the United States

The Eye of Providence, also known as the All-Seeing Eye of God is a symbol that is often used in a religious context. Very often, it is shown as a single human eye, surrounded by triangle and rays of light. It is often seen as a symbol for knowledge, trinity or for a god that "sees all". The most common depiction of the Eye of Providence is in the back of the United States one-dollar bill. In a Christian context, it is often inside a triangle, where the triangle represents the Trinity. Freemasons also use the symbol, there it stands for knowledge.

[[David Marsh]]

CATEGORIES: British writers, British businesspeople

David Wayne Marsh is a British financial writer and business consultant. In 2000, he was appointed as a Commander of The Most Excellent Order of the British Empire (CBE).

Colin Welch born as James Colin Ross Welch was an English journalist and writer.

[[The Secret of Convict Lake]]

[[Völuspá]]

CATEGORIES: Norse mythology

Vǫluspá is the first and best known poem of the Poetic Edda. It tells the story of the creation of the world and its coming end, related to the audience by a völva addressing Odin. It is one of the most important primary sources for the study of Norse mythology.

[[Nicolas Steno]]

CATEGORIES: 1638 births, 1686 deaths, Danish scientists, Geologists, Bishops

Nicolas Steno was a Danish scientist, a pioneer in  anatomy and geology. He became a Catholic bishop in his later years.

by 1659 he questioned the knowledge of the natural world accepted in his time. He questioned the idea that fossils grew in the ground, and the explanations of rock formation. His investigations made him one of the founders of modern stratigraphy and modern geology.

[[Sariwon]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in North Korea

Sariwŏn (sa.ɾi.wʌn) is the capital of North Hwanghae Province, North Korea. In 2008, there were 307,764 people living there.

Dearborn Heights is a city in Wayne County, Michigan, United States. As of the 2010 census, 57,774 people lived in Dearborn Heights.

[[Cyrus Cylinder]]

CATEGORIES: British Museum, Mesopotamia

The Cyrus Cylinder (Ostovane-ye Kūrosh) or Cyrus Charter (منشور  کوروش fa) is a very old clay cylinder, which is now broken into many pieces. It has writing on it in the Akkadian language in the name of Persia's Achaemenid king Cyrus the Great. It was made in the 6th century BC. It was found near the ruins of Babylon, Mesopotamia (now in Iraq) in 1879. It is currently in the British Museum in London.

Song Ha-yoon (born Kim Mi-sun on December 2, 1986) is a South Korean actress. Her first stage name was Kim Byul, but she changed it to Song Ha-yoon in 2012. She is best known for being in the drama Fight for My Way (2017).

[[Hebrew Poetry]]

CATEGORIES: Poetry

Many parts of the  Hebrew Bible are written as poetry.  One of the the main features of the Hebrew poetry is parallelism of thought. The Book of Psalms and the Book of Proverbs are almost all poetry.  Some of the Prophetic books also have poetic sections. Even the Book of Genesis includes some poems, or songs and they are sometimes called. 

[[Blue-Zoo Productions]]

CATEGORIES: 2000 establishments in the United Kingdom, British animation studios

Blue-Zoo Productions is a UK-based computer animation studio. Blue-Zoo is mainly known for producing children's TV series, advertising commercials and short films. Some of the more popular children's shows the studio has produced are Miffy and Friends, Alphablocks, Digby Dragon and Miffy's Adventures Big and Small. The company operates from a studio in Fitzrovia, London, where they have a team of over 100 artists. It later opened up a new studio, adjacent to its main studio, specializing in 2d animation.

[[Conch Republic]]

CATEGORIES: Florida Keys, History of Florida, Micronations

The Conch Republic is a micronation secession of the city of Key West, Florida, from the United States on April 23, 1982. Since then, the term "Conch Republic" has expanded to refer to "all of the Florida Keys".

While the protests that created the Conch Republic have been described by some as "tongue-in-cheek," they were caused by frustrations over real concerns. The original protest event was caused by a U.S. Border Patrol roadblock and checkpoint that was inconvenient to residence.

The Conch Republic celebrates its Independence Day every April 23 as part of a week-long festival of activities involving numerous businesses in Key West. The organization — a "Sovereign State of Mind", seeking only to bring more "Humor, Warmth and Respect" to a world in sore need of all three according to its late Secretary General, Peter Anderson — is a key tourism booster for the area.
