[[Fairchild Channel F]]

CATEGORIES: Video game consoles

The Fairchild Channel F (also known as Channel F) is a home video game console. The "F" in the name stands for "Fun". It was designed by Jerry Lawson and released in November 1976 by Fairchild Camera and Instrument in the United States for a price of 169.95 $. It is the first console that uses ROM cartridges and a microprocessor. By 1977, 250,000 Fairchild Channel F consoles were sold. The production ended in 1983.

[[Aiding and abetting]]

CATEGORIES: Law, Crime

"Aiding and abetting" is a crime. A person is guilty of aiding and abetting if they help someone else commit a crime, and then they do it. Some ways a person can aid and abet a crime are to help someone commit the crime, give someone advice on how to commit the crime, or pay them to commit the crime.

[[Bibbidi-Bobbidi-Boo]]

CATEGORIES: 1940s songs, Disney

"Bibbidi-Bobbidi-Boo" (also called "The Magic Song") is a novelty song. It was written in 1948 by Al Hoffman, Mack David, and Jerry Livingston. It was first used in the 1950 movie Cinderella. In this movie, it was sung by the actress Verna Felton. The song is about the Fairy Godmother turning a pumpkin into a carriage, which is something that happens in the story of Cinderella.

[[Montaigu-Vendée]]

CATEGORIES: 2019 establishments in France, Communes in Vendée

Montaigu-Vendée is a commune. It is found in the region Pays de la Loire in the Vendée department in the west of France.  The municipality was created on 1 January 2019 and consists of the former communes of Montaigu (the seat), Boufféré, La Guyonnière, Saint-Georges-de-Montaigu and Saint-Hilaire-de-Loulay.

[[Sèvremont]]

CATEGORIES: 2016 establishments in France, Communes in Vendée

Sèvremont is a commune. It is found in the region Pays de la Loire in the Vendée department in the west of France.  The municipality was created on 1 January 2016 and consists of the former communes of La Flocellière (the seat), Les Châtelliers-Châteaumur, La Pommeraie-sur-Sèvre and Saint-Michel-Mont-Mercure.

[[Neum]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Bosnia and Herzegovina

Neum is a village in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Around it there is about 21 of coastline which is the only access of this country to the Adriatic Sea.

CATEGORIES: 2016 establishments in France, Communes in Vendée

Doix-lès-Fontaines is a commune. It is found in the region Pays de la Loire in the Vendée department in the west of France.  The municipality was created on 1 January 2016 and consists of the former communes of Doix (the seat) and Fontaines.

[[Samsung Galaxy S6]]

CATEGORIES: Samsung mobile phones, Mobile phones released in 2010s, Mobile phones with 4K video recording

The Samsung Galaxy S6, Galaxy S6 or just GS6 is an Android-based smartphone developed, manufactured, released and marketed by Samsung Electronics. It is the successor to the Samsung Galaxy S5 and the predecessor to the Samsung Galaxy S7. It was unveiled on March 1, 2015 with the Samsung Galaxy S6 Edge and released on April 5, 2015. On August 21, 2015, the Samsung Galaxy S6 Edge+ was released.

[[RCA Studio II]]

CATEGORIES: Video game consoles

The RCA Studio II (also known as RCA Studio 2, Studio II or Studio 2) is a home video game console that was released in January 1977 by RCA. It could only display black and white graphics, similar to earlier Pong consoles.

Tennis for two (also known as Computer Tennis) is a video game from 1958. It simulates a tennis game and is one of the oldest known games in the history of computer and video games.

[[Z.P.G.]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 science fiction movies, American science fiction movies, Danish movies, Dystopian movies

Z.P.G. (short for Zero Population Growth) is a 1972 Danish–American science fiction movie directed by Michael Campus and starring Oliver Reed, Geraldine Chapman, Diane Cilento, Don Gordon. It was distributed by Paramount Pictures.

[[Santa Sangre]]

CATEGORIES: 1989 movies, 1980s horror thriller movies, Italian horror movies, Italian thriller movies, Mexican movies, Movies directed by Alejandro Jodorowsky

Santa Sangre (Holy Blood) is a 1989 Mexican–Italian horror thriller movie directed by Alejandro Jodorowsky and starring Axel Jodorowsky, Adán Jodorowsky, Blanca Guerra, Guy Stockwell, Thelma Tixou, Sergio Bustamante, Gloria Contreras.

[[The Vanishing (1988 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 movies, 1980s thriller movies, French thriller movies, Dutch movies, Movies directed by George Sluizer

The Vanishing (Spoorloos, literally: "Traceless" or "Without a Trace") is a 1988 Dutch–French thriller movie directed by George Sluizer and adapted by the novella The Golden Egg by Tim Krabbé. It stars Bernard-Pierre Donnadieu, Gene Bervoets, Johanna ter Steege, Gwen Eckhaus. It was remade in 1993.

She studied at University of Pretoria.

[[SpaceCamp]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 movies, 1980s family movies, 1980s adventure movies, American family movies, American adventure movies

SpaceCamp is a 1986 American family adventure movie directed by Harry Winer and starring Kate Capshaw, Kelly Preston, Larry B. Scott, Lea Thompson, Tate Donovan, Joaquin Phoenix, Tom Skerritt. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[The Delicious One]]

CATEGORIES: Mascots

The Delicious One, otherwise known as TDO for short, is the mascot of Wienerschnitzel. He is an anthropomorphic chili dog. Almost everybody wants to eat the Delicious One due to him being a hot dog; his famous trademark is when he runs off screaming.

[[Sunday Drive]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 comedy movies, 1980s family movies, American family movies, American comedy movies

Sunday Drive is a 1986 American television family comedy movie directed by Larry Brand and starring Tony Randall, Carrie Fisher, Audra Lindley, Ted Wass, Hillary Wolf, Norman Alden. It was distributed by Walt Disney Television.

[[Las fuerzas vivas]]

CATEGORIES: 1970s action movies, 1975 comedy movies, Mexican movies

Las fuerzas vivas ("The Living Forces") is a 1975 Mexican action comedy movie directed by Luis Alcoriza and starring Héctor Ortega, Héctor Lechuga, David Reynoso, Armando Silvestre.

[[Martin Klebba]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 births, American movie actors, American television actors, Stuntmen, People with dwarfism, Actors from Michigan, Living people, People from Troy, Michigan

Martin Klebba is an American actor with dwarfism.

[[Werner Böhm]]

CATEGORIES: German singers, German musicians, Eurovision Song Contest entrants, 1941 births, 2020 deaths

Werner Böhm, better known under his artist name  Gottlieb Wendehals (5 June 1941 – 2 June 2020) was a German singer and musician. He was born in Toruń, "Thorn" in the German-occupied Poland.

In the late 1950s, Böhm was pianist with the "Cabinet Jazzmen" in Hamburg until the early 1960s, at the time one of the most popular jazz bands in Northern Germany. From 1970 to 1971 he was a jazz pianist in Hamburg at "Jazz House", "Riverkasematten", "Logo", "Dennis Swing Club", "Cotton Club", "Remter" and in the legendary "Onkel Po". 

In 1982 he took part in the Eurovision Song Contest with the song Der Ohrwurm. He finished 11th in the second-last place. 

Böhm died in Gran Canaria, Spain on 2 June 2020 at the age of 78.

[[Fatso (1980 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 comedy movies, 1980s romantic comedy movies, American romantic comedy movies

Fatso is a 1980 American romantic comedy movie directed by Anne Bancroft (who also stars) and starring Candice Azzara, Ron Carey, Dom DeLuise, Ralph Manza, Michael Lombard. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Roberto Gervaso]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Italian journalists, Writers from Rome

Roberto Gervaso (July 9, 1937 – June 2, 2020) was an Italian writer and journalist. He won the Premio Bancarella twice: for L'Italia dei Comuni in 1967, and for Cagliostro in 1973. He was born in Rome.

Gervaso died on June 2, 2020 in Milan at the age of 82.

[[Roberto Peccei]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Italian scientists, Physicists

Roberto Daniele Peccei (petˈtʃɛi; January 6, 1942 – June 1, 2020) was an Italian theoretical particle physicist. Her works in the area of electroweak and in the interface between particle physics and physical cosmology. He was most known for formulating the Peccei–Quinn theory (with Helen Quinn).

Peccei was a Vice Chancellor for Research at the University of California, Los Angeles, a position he held between 2000 and 2010.

Peccei died on June 1, 2020 at the age of 78.

[[Helen Quinn]]

CATEGORIES: Australian scientists, American physicists, Naturalized citizens of the United States, 1943 births, Living people, Writers from Melbourne

Helen Rhoda Arnold Quinn (born 19 May 1943) is an Australian-born American particle physicist and educator. Her works to theoretical physics include the Peccei-Quinn theory which showed a corresponding symmetry of nature and works relating to particle interactions.

[[Héctor Ortega]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Mexican movie actors, Mexican television actors, Mexican voice actors, Mexican stage actors, Mexican screenwriters, Mexican movie directors, Writers from Mexico City, Actors from Mexico City

Héctor Ortega Gómez (12 January 1939 — 3 June 2020) was a Mexican actor. He was also a screenwriter and a director. He was born in Mexico City. His best known works were in Las fuerzas vivas, Santa sangre and in Lucía, Lucía.

Ortega died on 3 June 2020 in Mexico City, aged 81.

[[Marcello Abbado]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, Italian composers, Italian pianists, People from Milan

Marcello Abbado (October 7, 1926 – June 4, 2020) was an Italian composer and pianist. He was born in Milan. His works were orchestral, two ballets, many pieces for solo piano, and a number of chamber works. 

In 1989 he was awarded the Gold Medal for Meritorious Culture and Art (Medaglia d'oro ai benemeriti della cultura e dell'arte) by the Government of Italy.

Abbado died on June 4, 2020 in Stresa, Italy at the age of 93.

[[World Weightlifting Championships]]

CATEGORIES: Weightlifting competitions, World championships

The World Weightlifting Championships is an event organised by International Weightlifting Federation (IWF).

[[World championship]]

CATEGORIES: Sports terminology, World championships

A world championship is generally an international competition open to elite competitors from around the world, representing their nations, and winning such an event will be considered the highest or near highest achievement in the sport, game, or ability.

[[Olympic weightlifting]]

CATEGORIES: Weightlifting

Olympic weightlifting, or Olympic-style weightlifting, often simply referred to as weightlifting, is a sport in which the athlete attempts a maximum-weight single lift of a barbell loaded with weight plates.

[[European Weightlifting Championships]]

CATEGORIES: Weightlifting competitions, European championships

European Weightlifting Championships is an annual event organised by the European Weightlifting Federation (EWF). It has been held since 1896. A separate event for women was held from 1988 to 1997, after which both championships have been held as one event.

[[European Championship]]

CATEGORIES: European championships

A European Championship is the top level international sports competition between European athletes or sports teams representing their respective countries or professional sports clubs.

[[Asian Weightlifting Championships]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 establishments in Asia, Weightlifting competitions

The Asian Weightlifting Championships is a weightlifting championship. It was organised by the Asian Weightlifting Federation for competitors from the Asian countries. It has been held since 1969 for men and 1988 for women. In 2008, the championships provided the official qualification for Asian competitors in the 2008 Beijing Olympics.

[[Feast (2005 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2005 comedy movies, 2005 horror movies, English-language movies, American comedy movies, American horror movies, American monster movies, Comedy horror movies

Feast is a 2005 American action horror comedy movie, directed by John Gulager, produced by Michael Leahy, Joel Soisson, Larry Tanz, and Andrew Jameson, and written by Marcus Dunstan and Patrick Melton. The movie stars Balthazar Getty, Henry Rollins, Navi Rawat, Judah Friedlander, Jenny Wade, Gulager's father Clu Gulager, Josh Zuckerman, and Jason Mewes. The story revolves around a group of people gathered inside a local bar in Nevada, where they are suddenly attacked by a horde of monstrous creatures.

[[Spetters]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 drama movies, 1980s erotic movies, 1980s LGBT movies, Dutch movies, Movies directed by Paul Verhoeven

Spetters (English translation: Splashes) is a 1980 Dutch erotic drama movie directed by Paul Verhoeven and starring Hans van Tongeren, Renée Soutendijk, Jeroen Krabbé, Rutger Hauer, Kitty Courbois, Toon Agterberg, Maarten Spanjer, Marianne Boyer.

[[Raggare!]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 drama movies, 1950s adventure movies, Swedish movies

Raggare! (in the UK released as Blackjackets) is a 1959 Swedish adventure drama movie directed by Olle Hellbom and starring Inga Edwards, Christina Schollin, Hans Wahlgren, Bill Magnusson, Sven Holmberg. It was distributed by AB Europa Studios.

[[2DTV]]

CATEGORIES: 2001 British television series debuts, 2004 British television series endings, 2000s British comedy television series, Animated television series, British satirical television series, ITV television programmes, English-language television programs

2DTV is a British satirical animated television show that was broadcast on ITV in the United Kingdom from September 1993 to December 1994. There were five series and thirty-three episodes.

[[OpenCola (drink)]]

CATEGORIES: Soft drinks

OpenCola is a brand of open source cola, meaning anyone can make it, and change its recipe freely. It was started on 27 January 2001 by Opencola, a Toronto-based free software P2P company started by Grad Conn, Cory Doctorow and John Henson, to promote their open-source software concept.

[[Delaine Christien]]

CATEGORIES: 1993 births, Living people, South African water polo players, South African water polo coaches

Delaine Christien (born 26 May 1993) is a South African water polo player and coach. 

She competed for the South Africa women's national water polo team in the 2009 World Aquatics Championships, 2013 World Aquatics Championships, and 2015 World Aquatics Championships.

She coached the Madibaz women’s team.

[[Kimberly Kay]]

CATEGORIES: 1989 births, Living people, South African water polo players

Kimberly Kay (born 20 September 1989) is a South African water polo player. She competed for the South Africa women's national water polo team in the 2011 World Aquatics Championships, 2013 World Aquatics Championships, and 2015 World Aquatics Championships.

[[Ruby Versfeld]]

CATEGORIES: 1996 births, Living people, South African water polo players

Ruby Versfeld (born 17 September 1996) is a South African water polo player. She competed for the South Africa women's national water polo team in the 2015 World Aquatics Championships.

She played for California State University, Bakersfield's women's water polo team and the University of St Andrews' women's water polo team. On 11 September 2020, she was inaugurated into The Jolly Boys as an Honorary Member.

[[Sodium bisulfite]]

CATEGORIES: Sodium compounds, Sulfur compounds

Sodium bisulfite, also known as sodium hydrogen sulfate, is a chemical compound. Its chemical formula is NaHSO3. It is made of sodium and bisulfite ions. It is a white solid with an odor of sulfur dioxide. It can be made by reacting smaller amounts of sodium dioxide and sodium hydroxide or sodium bicarbonate. If too much sodium hydroxide is used, sodium disulfite is made instead.

[[Azerbaijan Technical University]]

CATEGORIES: Technical colleges and universities in Asia, Technical colleges and universities in Europe, Buildings and structures in Baku, 20th century establishments in Azerbaijan, 1950 establishments in Asia, 1950 establishments in Europe

Azerbaijan Technical University (AzTU; Azərbaycan Texniki Universiteti) is a public university, specialized in engineering, located in Baku, Azerbaijan. It was founded in 1950 by the government of the Azerbaijan Soviet Socialist Republic. The university has 9 faculties and 54 departments, around 1,100 faculty members, including 70 professors and around 6,500 students.

[[Darya Muravyeva]]

Darya Muravyeva (born 18 August 1998) is a Kazakhstani female water polo player. She competed for the Kazakhstan women's national water polo team in the 2015 World Aquatics Championships and 2019 World Aquatics Championships.

[[Aruzhan Yegemberdiyeva]]

CATEGORIES: 1995 births, Living people, Kazakhstani water polo players

Aruzhan Yegemberdiyeva (born 22 February 1995) is a Kazakhstani female water polo player. She competed for the Kazakhstan women's national water polo team in the 2015 World Aquatics Championships.

[[Kamila Zakirova]]

CATEGORIES: 1992 births, Living people, Kazakhstani water polo players

Kamila Zakirova (born 25 December 1992) is a Kazakhstani female water polo player. She competed for the Kazakhstan women's national water polo team in the 2015 World Aquatics Championships. 2017 World Aquatics Championships, and 2019 World Aquatics Championships.

[[Kotori Suzuki]]

CATEGORIES: 1996 births, Living people, Japanese water polo players

Kotori Suzuki (born 8 December 1996) is a Japanese female water polo player who participated at the 2015 World Aquatics Championships, 2017 World Aquatics Championships, and 2019 World Aquatics Championships.

[[Marina Tokumoto]]

CATEGORIES: 1996 births, Living people, Japanese water polo players

Marina Tokumoto (born 2 February 1996) is a Japanese female water polo player who participated at the 2015 World Aquatics Championships, 2017 World Aquatics Championships, and 2019 World Aquatics Championships.

[[Philips Odyssey series]]

CATEGORIES: Video game consoles

The Philips Odyssey series is a series of home video game consoles. They were marketed by Philips. The Philips Odyssey series is the successor to the Magnavox Odyssey series.

[[Misaki Noro]]

CATEGORIES: 1996 births, Living people, Japanese water polo players

Misaki Noro (born 12 April 1996) is a Japanese female water polo player who participated at the 2017 World Aquatic Championships and 2019 World Aquatic Championships.

[[Kana Hosoya]]

CATEGORIES: 1994 births, Living people, Japanese water polo players

Kana Hosoya (born 13 October 1994) is a Japanese female water polo player who participated at the 2015 World Aquatic Championships and 2017 World Aquatic Championships.

[[BSS 01]]

CATEGORIES: Video game consoles

The BSS 01 (short for Bildschirmspiel 01, German for screen game 01 or video screen game 01) is a home video game console. It was released in 1980 or 1981 only in East Germany. The console is also known as TV-Spiel or RFT TV-Spiel. RFT stands for Rundfunk- und Fernmelde-Technik. This is an East German association of companies.

[[Loving Couples (1980 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 comedy movies, 1980s romantic comedy movies, American romantic comedy movies, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Jack Smight

Loving Couples is a 1980 American romantic comedy movie directed by Jack Smight and starring Shirley MacLaine, James Coburn, Susan Sarandon, Stephen Collins, Sally Kellerman, Helena Carroll, Pat Corley, Anne Bloom. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[The Hare Census]]

CATEGORIES: 1973 comedy movies, Bulgarian movies, Satirical movies

The Hare Census (Prebroyavane na Divite Zaytsi) is a 1973 Bulgarian satirical comedy movie directed by Eduard Zahariev. It stars Itzhak Fintzi, Nikola Todev, Georgi Rusev, Todor Kolev and Evstati Stratev.

[[Auchay-sur-Vendée]]

Auchay-sur-Vendée is a commune. It is found in the region Pays de la Loire in the Vendée department in the west of France.  The municipality was created on 1 January 2017 and consists of the former communes of Auzay (the seat) and Chaix.

[[Bertrand Stern]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, German philosophers, Writers from North Rhine-Westphalia, Living people

Bertrand Stern is a German author and philosopher. He lives in Siegburg, North Rhine-Westphalia.

He wants the legalization of alternative forms of education other than attending a school (homeschooling and unschooling for example) for Germany because he thinks that schools are not suitable for everyone and that it is not okay to force people to go to places where they do not want to be.

[[Hellenic languages]]

CATEGORIES: Hellenic languages

The Hellenic languages are a branch of languages from the Indo-European language family. The main language is Greek. Many people say that Greek is the only language in the branch. Some people also say that the ancient Macedonian language is part of the branch. Others say it was simply a dialect of Greek.

[[Italic languages]]

CATEGORIES: Indo-European languages

The Italic languages are a branch of the Indo-European language family. They were first spoken in Italy. The main language was Latin, which eventually turned into the Romance languages spoken today. The Roman Empire spread Latin to much of Western Europe. Today, the main Italic languages spoken are Spanish, French, Portuguese, Italian, and Romanian. There were other branches of Italic languages besides those that came from Latin, but they are all now extinct.

[[Wario Land series]]

Wario Land is the name of a series of video games. All these games feature Wario as protagonist.

[[Write-in candidate]]

CATEGORIES: Voting, Elections

A write-in candidate is a candidate in an election whose name does not appear on the ballot, but for whom voters may vote by writing in the person's name. Write-in candidates do not win very often. Sometimes write-in votes are cast for people who cannot hold office, or they are fictional characters. Some places require write-in candidates be registered as official candidates before the election.

[[Régence]]

CATEGORIES: French nobility, House of Bourbon, House of Orléans

The Régence (ʁeʒɑ̃s, Regency)  refers to a time between 1715 and 1723, when King Louis XV was a minor and France was governed by Philippe d'Orléans, a nephew of Louis XIV o France, as Regent of the Kingdom. In French the period is also called le Régence de Philippe'Orléans.

Contemporary European rulers included Philip V of Spain, John V of Portugal, George I of Great Britain, Charles VI, Holy Roman Emperor (faither o Empress Maria Theresa) and Victor Amadeus II of Sardinia, the maternal grandfather of King Louis XV.

[[Tsakonian language]]

CATEGORIES: Hellenic languages

Tsakonian (also Tsaconian, Tzakonian or Tsakonic; Tsakonian: τσακώνικα, α τσακώνικα γρούσσα; Greek: τσακώνικα) is a Hellenic language. It is spoken in the Peloponnese peninsula in Greece and comes from Doric Greek. It is similar to Greek, but people speaking the two languages cannot talk to each other. Only a few hundred people are left who speak the language. Most of these are elderly people.

[[Doric Greek]]

CATEGORIES: Hellenic languages

Doric or Dorian (Dōrismós) was a Hellenic language. It was a dialect of Ancient Greek. It was spoken in Western Greece and some parts of Southern Italy and Sicily.

[[Unilever]]

CATEGORIES: 20th century establishments in the Netherlands, 1920s establishments in the United Kingdom, 1929 establishments in Europe, Companies listed on the London Stock Exchange, Companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange, Companies of the Netherlands, Cosmetics companies, Food companies of the United Kingdom

Unilever is a British-Dutch multinational company. It is one of the biggest producers of consumer goods worldwide.  In 2016, around 168,000 people worked for Unilever in 100 countries.  Unilever's products can be found in about 190 countries.

Unilever is among the top 5 food producers worldwide. Food is about 40% of the revenue of Unilever. Cleaning agents, beauty products and personal care products make up the remaining 60% of the revenue.

[[Essarts-en-Bocage]]

Essarts-en-Bocage is a commune. It is found in the region Pays de la Loire in the Vendée department in the west of France. The municipality was created on 1 January 2016 and consists of the former communes of Les Essarts (the seat), Boulogne, L'Oie and Sainte-Florence.

[[The Garage (1980 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 comedy movies, Russian movies, Movies directed by Eldar Ryazanov

The Garage (Гараж) is a 1980 Russian comedy movie directed by Eldar Ryazanov and starring Liya Akhedzhakova, Iya Savvina, Svetlana Nemolyayeva, Valentin Gaft, Andrey Myagkov, Georgi Burkov, Leonid Markov, Igor Kostolevsky. It was distributed by Mosfilm.

[[Vougeot]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Côte-d'Or

Vougeot is a commune in the Côte-d'Or department.

The D122 and D974 roads pass through the village.

[[Chadic languages]]

CATEGORIES: Chadic languages, Tonal languages

The Chadic languages are a branch of languages from the Afroasiatic language family. They are spoken in West Africa, mainly in the countries Nigeria, Niger, Chad, Central African Republic and Cameroon. There are around 150 Chadic languages still spoken. The most widely spoken Chadic language is Hausa.

[[Hausa language]]

CATEGORIES: West Chadic languages

Hausa (ˈ; Harshen/Halshen Hausa) is a Chadic language. It was first spoken in Southern Niger and Northern Nigeria. Now many other people in West Africa speak it. It is the most widely spoken Chadic language, with around 47 million people speaking it as a first language.

[[West Chadic languages]]

CATEGORIES: West Chadic languages

The West Chadic languages are a branch of Chadic languages. They are spoken mainly in Nigeria and Niger. The most widely spoken West Chadic language is Hausa. There are two main branches of West Chadic languages, called A and B.

[[Hausa–Gwandara languages]]

CATEGORIES: West Chadic languages

The Hausa–Gwandara (also called A.1 West Chadic) languages are a branch of West Chadic languages. The branch has just two languages, Hausa and Gwandara.

[[Gwandara language]]

CATEGORIES: West Chadic languages

Gwandara is a Chadic language. It is the closest language to Hausa. It is spoken in Northern Nigeria and has around 30,000 speakers.

[[East Chadic languages]]

CATEGORIES: East Chadic languages, Chad, Cameroon

The East Chadic languages are a branch of the Chadic languages. There are around 40 East Chadic languages still spoken. They are spoken mainly in Chad and Cameroon.

[[Masa languages]]

CATEGORIES: Chadic languages, Chad, Cameroon

The Masa languages are a branch of Chadic languages. There are fewer than 20 that are still spoken. They are spoken in Chad and Cameroon.

[[Kerlouan]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Finistère

Kerlouan (Kerlouan) is a commune. It is found in the region Brittany in the Finistère department in the northwest of France.

[[Bureau Junction, Illinois]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Illinois

Bureau Junction is a village in Illinois in the United States.

[[Noisy-le-Grand]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Seine-Saint-Denis

Noisy-le-Grand is a commune. It is found in the Seine-Saint-Denis department in France.

[[Biu–Mandara languages]]

CATEGORIES: Chadic languages, Languages of Nigeria, Chad, Cameroon

The Biu–Mandara, or Central Chadic, languages are a branch of Chadic languages. They are spoken in Nigeria, Chad, and Cameroon. The most spoken is Kamwe.

[[Kamwe language]]

CATEGORIES: Chadic languages, Languages of Nigeria, Cameroon

Kamwe (or Kamue) is a Chadic language. It is spoken in Nigeria and Cameroon. It is the most widely spoken Biu–Mandara language with around 300,000 speakers.

[[Cushitic languages]]

CATEGORIES: Cushitic languages

The Cushitic languages are a branch of the Afroasiatic language family. They are mainly spoken in the Horn of Africa and the Nile Valley. Some widely spoken Cushitic languages are Oromo, Somali, Beja, Agaw, Afar, Saho and Sidamo.

[[Beja language]]

CATEGORIES: Cushitic languages, Eritrea, Egypt, Sudan

Beja is a Cushitic language. It is spoken on the coast of the Red Sea in Sudan, Eritrea and Egypt. Around one million people speak the language. It is the only language of the North Cushitic branch still spoken.

[[Getting It Right]]

CATEGORIES: 1989 comedy-drama movies, American comedy-drama movies, British comedy-drama movies, Movies directed by Randal Kleiser

Getting It Right is a 1989 British American comedy drama movie directed by Randal Kleiser and starring Jesse Birdsall, Jane Horrocks, Helena Bonham Carter, Pat Heywood, Lynn Redgrave, John Gielgud, Peter Cook, Ian Redford, Shirley Anne Field.

[[Enciso]]

CATEGORIES: Municipalities of Colombia

Enciso is a town and municipality in the García Rovira Province, part of Santander Department in northeastern Colombia. Founded on September 9, 1773 by Juan de Enciso, the liberating campaign of Simon Bolivar passed by this municipality on 7 occasions between the years 1814 and 1821.

[[Abdelmalek Droukdel]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 births, 2020 deaths, Algerian people, Deaths by firearm, Terrorists

Abdelmalek Droukdel (عبد المالك درودكال; 20 April 1970 &ndash 3 June 2020) also known by his nom de guerre as Abu Musab Abdel Wadoud (أبو مصعب عبد الودود), was the emir leader of the Algerian Islamic militant group Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM). He was born in Meftah, Algeria. 

His death was announced on 5 June 2020 that Droukdel, and members of his inner circle, had been killed by its forces in an operation in the north of Mali two days earlier.

[[Tara Conner]]

Tara Elizabeth Conner (born December 18, 1985) is a model and beauty pageant titleholder from the state of Kentucky. She was crowned Miss USA 2006 and also participated in the Miss Universe and Miss Teen USA pageants. 

[[Bobby Locke (baseball)]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, California Angels players, Cincinnati Reds players, Cleveland Indians players, Philadelphia Phillies players, St. Louis Cardinals players, Sportspeople from Pennsylvania

Lawrence Donald "Bobby" Locke (March 3, 1934 – June 4, 2020) was an American professional baseball right-handed pitcher. He played in Major League Baseball (MLB) in all or parts of nine seasons (1959–1965; 1967–1968) for the Cleveland Indians, St. Louis Cardinals, Philadelphia Phillies, Cincinnati Reds and California Angels. He was born in Rowes Run, Pennsylvania.

Locke died on June 4, 2020 in Dunbar, Pennsylvania at the age of 86.

[[Rowes Run, Pennsylvania]]

CATEGORIES: Unincorporated communities in Pennsylvania, Census-designated places in Pennsylvania

Rowes Run is an unincorporated community and census-designated place in Redstone Township, Fayette County, Pennsylvania, United States. As of the 2010 census its population was 564. 

[[Redstone Township, Fayette County, Pennsylvania]]

CATEGORIES: Townships in Pennsylvania

Redstone Township is a township in Fayette County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 5,566 at the 2010 census. 

[[Midland, Michigan]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Michigan, County seats in Michigan

Midland is a city in the U.S. state of Michigan in the Tri-Cities region of Central Michigan. It is the county seat of Midland County. The city's population was 41,701 as of the 2019 census estimate. 

[[Midland County, Michigan]]

CATEGORIES: 1855 establishments in Michigan, Michigan counties

Midland County is a county located in the U.S. state of Michigan. As of the 2010 census, the population was 83,629. The county seat is Midland.

[[Dunbar, Pennsylvania]]

CATEGORIES: Boroughs in Pennsylvania

Dunbar is a borough in Fayette County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 1,042 at the 2010 census. 

[[Agaw languages]]

CATEGORIES: Cushitic languages, Languages of Ethiopia, Eritrea

The Agaw, or Central Cushitic, languages are a small branch of Cushitic languages. They are spoken mainly in Ethiopia. 

[[Pete Rademacher]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, American Olympic gold medalists, American boxers, Deaths from dementia, Sportspeople from Washington

Thomas Peter "Pete" Rademacher (November 20, 1928 – June 4, 2020) was an American heavyweight boxer. He was a gold medalist at the 1956 Olympics. He became the only person to challenge for the world heavyweight championship in his first professional game when he faced Floyd Patterson on August 22 1957. He was born in Tieton, Washington.

Rademacher died on June 4, 2020 at a retirement home in Sandusky, Ohio from dementia-related problems, aged 91.

[[Tieton, Washington]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Washington (U.S. state), Yakima County, Washington

Tieton (ˈ) is a city in Yakima County, Washington, United States. The population was 1,191 at the 2010 census.

[[Dullay languages]]

CATEGORIES: Dullay languages

The Dullay languages are a branch of Cushitic languages. They are spoken mainly in Ethiopia. There are four main Dullay languages that are still spoken: Ale, Tsamai, Dihina, and Dobase. The languages are similar, but speakers of the languages cannot understand each other.

[[Ale language]]

CATEGORIES: Dullay languages, Languages of Ethiopia

Ale, also called Gawwada, is a Cushitic language. It is spoken in Ethiopia.

[[Tsamai language]]

CATEGORIES: Dullay languages, Languages of Ethiopia

Tsamai is a Cushitic language. It is spoken by about 18,000 people near the Omo River in Ethiopia.

[[Bixente Serrano Izko]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Spanish politicians, Spanish historians

Rufino Vicente "Bixente" Serrano Izco (22 January 1948 – 4 June 2020) was a Spanish historian and politician. He was born in Navarre, Spain. He was a Deputy in the Cortes Generales from 8 June 2015 to 27 October 2015. He was a member of the Geroa Bai. 

In 1974, he was put in a political prisoner during the Francisco Franco dictatorship. He was freed in 1977 after an amnesty law was signed. 

Serrano Izko died on 4 June 2020 from surgical-related problems at a hospital in Pamplona, Spain at the age of 72.

[[Boris Gaganelov]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Bulgarian footballers

Boris Atanasov Gaganelov (Борис Aтанасов Гаганелов; 7 October 1941 – 5 June 2020) was a Bulgarian football player and later coach. He was born in Petrich, Bulgaria. Gaganelov made 51 appearances for the Bulgaria national football team. He represented Bulgaria at the FIFA World Cups in 1966 and 1970.

Gaganelov died on 5 June 2020 in Sofia, Bulgaria at the age of 78.

[[Dihina language]]

CATEGORIES: Dullay languages, Languages of Ethiopia

Dihina is a Cushitic language. It is very similar to Ale. Some people think they are the same language, because they are so similar. ISO gives both languages the same code, GWD.

[[Agnes Chow]]

CATEGORIES: 1996 births, Activists from Hong Kong, Chinese politicians, Protestants, Living people

Agnes Chow Ting (周庭; born 3 December 1996) is a student activist, politician in Hong Kong. She is a former member of Demosistō. She was first known to be the spokesperson of Scholarism in the Umbrella Movement but she went away after that. She was arrested in August 2019 during the 2019–20 Hong Kong protests at her home in Tai Po. On 30 June 2020, she announced on Facebook that she left Demosistō.

[[Ved Marwah]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from lung disease, Governors of Bihar, Governors of Jharkhand, Governors of Manipur, Governors of Mizoram

Ved Prakash Marwah  (15 September 1934 – 5 June 2020) was an Indian politician. He was Governor of Manipur from 1999 to 2003, Mizoram from 2000 to 2001 and Jharkhand from 2003 to 2004. He was born in Peshawar, British India.

Marwah died on 5 June 2020 from lung disease-related problems at a hospital in Goa, India at the age of 85.

[[Dobase language]]

CATEGORIES: Dullay languages, Languages of Ethiopia

Dobase is a Cushitic language. It is spoken in Southern Ethiopia. Only around 1,500 people speak the language.

[[Highland East Cushitic languages]]

CATEGORIES: Highland East Cushitic languages, Languages of Ethiopia

The Highland East Cushitic, or Sidamic, languages are a branch of Cushitic languages. They are spoken in Ethiopia. The most spoken language in the branch is Sidamo. It has around 3 million speakers.

[[Sidamo language]]

CATEGORIES: Highland East Cushitic languages, Languages of Ethiopia

Sidamo, or Sidaama, is a Cushitic language. It is spoken in Southern Ethiopia by about three million people.

[[Mikhail Kokshenov]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Russian movie actors, Russian television actors, Russian voice actors, Russian stage actors, Russian movie directors, Russian movie producers, Actors from Moscow

Mikhail Mikhailovich Kokshenov (16 September 1936 – 4 June 2020) was a Russian actor, movie director and producer. He was born in Moscow. His career lasted from 1957 to 2010. His best known roles were as Zahar in Zhenya, Zhenechka and Katyusha (1967), as Karate in The Garage (1980) and as Septa in Sportloto-82 (1982).

Kokshenov died on 4 June 2020 in Moscow from stroke-related problems, aged 83.

[[Burji language]]

CATEGORIES: Highland East Cushitic languages, Languages of Ethiopia, Kenya

Burji is a Cushitic language. It is spoken in Ethiopia and Kenya, south of Lake Chamo. Around 70,000 people speak the language.

[[Gedeo language]]

CATEGORIES: Highland East Cushitic languages, Languages of Ethiopia

Gedeo is a Cushitic language. It is spoken in Ethiopia by nearly one million people.

[[Jiří Hanák]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Czech writers, Journalists, Political activists

Jiří Hanák (27 February 1938 – 5 June 2020) was a Czech journalist and political activist. He was born in Buchlovice, Czechoslovakia. He was a member of the Communist Party. He was the editor of a Czech newspaper company titled Free word. He was one of the signers of Charter 77.

Hanák died on 5 June 2020 in Prague at the age of 82.

[[Hadiyya language]]

CATEGORIES: Highland East Cushitic languages, Languages of Ethiopia

Hadiyya is a Cushitic language. It is spoken by around 1.3 million people in Southern Ethiopia. It is very similar to the Libido language, which is spoken just north of where Hadiyya is spoken.

[[Rupert Hine]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in London, English singer-songwriters, Record producers, Singers from London, Musicians from London, Writers from London

Rupert Neville Hine (21 September 1947 – 4 June 2020) was an English musician, singer-songwriter and record producer. 

He produced albums for artists including Rush, Kevin Ayers, Tina Turner, Howard Jones, Saga, The Fixx, Bob Geldof, Thompson Twins, Stevie Nicks, Chris de Burgh, Suzanne Vega, Underworld, Duncan Sheik, Formula and Eleanor McEvoy. 

He also recorded eleven albums under the band name Thinkman, and was a member of the band Quantum Jump. He was born in London.

Hine died on 4 June 2020 in London from cancer, aged 72.

[[Libido language]]

CATEGORIES: Highland East Cushitic languages, Languages of Ethiopia

Libido is a Cushitic language. It is spoken by around 65,000 in Southern Ethiopia. It is very similar to Hadiyya, which is spoken just south of where Libido is spoken. Some people think Libido is a dialect of Hadiyya.

[[Robert Jarvik]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, American inventors, Living people, Researchers, Scientists from Michigan, Businesspeople from Michigan, Scientists from Connecticut, Businesspeople from Connecticut, People from Midland, Michigan, People from Stamford, Connecticut

Robert Koffler Jarvik, M.D. (born May 11, 1946) is an American scientist, researcher and businessman. He is known for his role in creating  the Jarvik-7 artificial heart. He was born in Midland, Michigan.

[[Kambaata language]]

CATEGORIES: Highland East Cushitic languages, Languages of Ethiopia

Kambaata is a Cushitic language. It is spoken in Southern Ethiopia by around 900,000 people.

[[James Aloysius Hickey]]

CATEGORIES: 1920 births, 2004 deaths, Deaths from pneumonia, Cardinals of the Roman Catholic Church, Writers from Michigan, Writers from Washington, D.C., People from Midland, Michigan

James Aloysius Hickey (October 11, 1920 – October 24, 2004) was an American Cardinal of the Roman Catholic Church. He was Archbishop of Washington from 1980 to 2000. He was made a Cardinal in 1988. He was born in Midland, Michigan.

Hickey died on October 24, 2004 in Washington, D.C. of pneumonia, aged 84.

[[Donald Wuerl]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, Living people, Cardinals of the Roman Catholic Church, American theologians, Writers from Seattle, Washington, Writers from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, Writers from Washington, D.C.

Donald William Wuerl (born November 12, 1940) is an American prelate of the Catholic Church. He was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.

He was Archbishop of Washington, D.C. from 2006 to 2018. He was promoted by Pope John Paul II to be Auxiliary Bishop of Seattle (1986–1987), and Bishop of Pittsburgh (1988–2006). 

He was named Archbishop of Washington by Pope Benedict XVI and made a cardinal by him in 2010. 

Wuerl was criticized for how he handled sexual abuse cases during his time in Pittsburgh in 2018. Wuerl has denied mishandling the cases. 

On October 12, 2018, Pope Francis accepted his resignation as Archbishop of Washington. He remains a member of the College of Cardinals, eligible to vote in a papal election until November 2020. Wilton Daniel Gregory will replace him.

[[Timothy M. Dolan]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, Living people, Cardinals of the Roman Catholic Church, American theologians, American Roman Catholics, Writers from St. Louis, Missouri, Writers from Milwaukee, Wisconsin, Writers from New York City

Timothy Michael Dolan (born February 6, 1950) is an American cardinal of the Catholic Church. He is the tenth and current Archbishop of New York since 2009.

Dolan was the President of the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops from 2010 to 2013.

Dolan is widely known for his conservative views. He was Archbishop of Milwaukee from 2002 to 2009 and Auxiliary Bishop of St. Louis from 2001 to 2002.

Dolan was born in St. Louis, Missouri.

[[José Horacio Gómez]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, Living people, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Mexican writers, Mexican activists, American activists, American theologians, American Roman Catholics, Writers from Denver, Colorado, Writers from San Antonio, Texas, Writers from Los Angeles, California

José Horacio Gómez (born December 26, 1951) is a Mexican-born American prelate of the Catholic Church. He was born in Monterrey, Mexico. He has been the fifth Archbishop of Los Angeles since 2011. 

He was Auxiliary Bishop of Denver from 2001 to 2004 and as Archbishop of San Antonio from 2004 to 2010.  

Gomez was Vice President of the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops. In 2019, he became President of the conference.

[[Dave Camp]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, Living people, United States representatives from Michigan, Businesspeople from Michigan, People from Midland, Michigan, US Republican Party politicians

David Lee Camp (born July 9, 1953) is an American politician. He was a member of the United States House of Representatives from 1991 to 2015. Camp represented MI since 1993, and previously served one term representing MI. He is a member of the Republican Party.

Camp was chairman of the House Committee on Ways and Means from 2011 to 2015. In March 2014, he announced that he would not run for re-election.

[[Raoul Juneja]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 births, Record producers, Musicians from Toronto, Living people

Raoul Singh Juneja (born February 1, 1980) is a Canadian music producer and columnist based in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Raoul is better known as a media expert on urban and South Asian music.  He is credited as the executive producer of A 2Pac Tribute: Dare 2 Struggle, a  tribute album dedicated to the late hip hop icon, Tupac Shakur.

[[Tuojiangosaurus]]

CATEGORIES: Dinosaurs

Tuojiangosaurus is an armoured dinosaur that lived during the upper Jurassic period approximately 150 million years ago 

Tuojiangosaurus comes from Szechuan, China. Ancient Chinese records tell of local villagers selling mythical dragon bones to make medicine. These were probably the fossils of Tuojiangosaurus.  

Tuojiangosaurus wasn't a dragon. It was a dinosaur. To protect it, it had 17 pairs of spiky plates down its back and tail. A frightening set of tail spikes completed this plant-eater's armour. 

With one deadly swing of its spiked tail Tuojiangosaurus could hurt the belly of an attacking predator. 

The Chinese province where Tuojiangosaurus was found is home to the Zigong Dinosaur Park, the first dinosaur museum in Asia.

[[Utterly Alone]]

CATEGORIES: 2004 drama movies, 2000s war movies, Lithuanian movies

Utterly Alone (Vienui vieni) is a 2004 Lithuanian drama movie directed by Jonas Vaitkus and starring Vladas Bagdonas, Saulius Balandis, Brigita Bublyte.

[[The Story of Nampoo]]

CATEGORIES: 1984 drama movies, Thai movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Euthana Mukdasanit

The Story of Nampoo (น้ำพุ) is a 1984 Thai drama movie directed by Euthana Mukdasanit and based on the novel of the same name (known in Thai as เรื่องของน้ำพุ) by Suwanni Sukhontha. It stars Rewat Buddhinan, Amphol Lumpoon, Patravadi Sritrairat.

[[The Gardener (1912 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1912 movies, 1910s drama movies, Swedish movies, Silent movies, Movies directed by Victor Sjöström

The Gardener is a 1912 Swedish drama movie directed by Victor Sjöström (who also stars) and starring Gösta Ekman, John Ekman, Mauritz Stiller, Lili Bech.

[[Attic ladder]]

CATEGORIES: Construction

An attic ladder (US) or loft ladder (UK) is a collapsible ladder which is attached with the floor of an attic and ceiling of the floor below the attic. Fire departments also use a similar attic ladders as an equipment.

[[Milton Glaser]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from stroke, Deaths from renal failure, Artists from New York City

Milton Glaser (June 26, 1929 – June 26, 2020) was an American graphic designer. His designs include the I ❤ NY logo, the psychedelic Bob Dylan poster, and the logos for DC Comics and Brooklyn Brewery. He was born in New York City.

In 1954, he co-founded New York magazine with Clay Felker. He was honored with the National Medal of the Arts award from President Barack Obama in 2009.

Glaser died of a stroke and renal failure in New York City on his 91st birthday on June 26, 2020.

[[North Carolina Central University]]

CATEGORIES: 20th-century establishments in North Carolina, 1910 establishments in the United States, Colleges and universities in North Carolina, Durham County, North Carolina

North Carolina Central University (NCCU or NC Central), a state-supported liberal arts public historically black university in Durham, North Carolina.  

It was founded by Dr. James E. Shepard with the Chautauqua movement in 1909. It was made part of the state system in 1923, when it first received state funding and was renamed as Durham State Normal School. 

It added graduate classes in arts and sciences and professional schools in law and library science in the late 1930s and 1940s.

[[Piano Piano Kid]]

CATEGORIES: 1991 drama movies, 1990s family movies, Turkish movies

Piano Piano Kid (Piano Piano Bacaksız) is a 1991 Turkish family drama movie directed by Tunç Başaran and starring Rutkay Aziz, Yaman Okay, Emin Sivas, Serap Aksoy.

[[Peggy Flanagan]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 births, Living people, State legislators of the United States, Lieutenant Governors of Minnesota, US Democratic Party politicians

Peggy Flanagan (born September 22, 1979) is an American politician. She is the 50th Lieutenant Governor of Minnesota since 2019. She was elected lieutenant governor on November 6, 2018 and is the second Native American woman to be elected to statewide executive office in U.S. history. 

She is a member of the Minnesota Democratic–Farmer–Labor Party (DFL). Flanagan represented District 46A in the Minnesota House of Representatives from 2015 to 2019. 

[[St. Louis Park, Minnesota]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Minnesota

St. Louis Park is a city in Hennepin County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 45,250 at the 2010 census.

[[Woodbury, Minnesota]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Minnesota

Woodbury is a city in Washington County, Minnesota. It is part of the Minneapolis-Saint Paul metropolitan area.  Woodbury is east of Saint Paul along Interstate 94.  The 2019 population for Woodbury was 72,828, making it the 9th most populous city in Minnesota.

[[Paynesville, Minnesota]]

Paynesville is a city in Stearns County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 2,432 at the 2010 census. It is part of the St. Cloud Metropolitan Statistical Area.

[[Foley, Minnesota]]

Foley is a city in Benton County, Minnesota, United States.The population was 2,603 at the 2010 census.  It is the county seat of Benton County.

[[Liepāja]]

Liepāja is a city in Latvia with town rights since 1625. It is on the Baltic Sea. It is the third largest city in the country, after Riga and Daugavpils.

Rēzekne is a city in Latvia with town rights since 1773.

[[Kathy Hochul]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, Living people, United States representatives from New York, Governors of New York, Lieutenant Governors of New York (state), Politicians from Buffalo, New York, US Democratic Party politicians

Kathleen Courtney Hochul (' HOH; born August 27, 1958) is an American Democratic politician. She is the 57th Governor of New York since 2021 after Andrew Cuomo's resignation. She is the first female governor of New York. She was the Lieutenant Governor of New York from 2015 until 2021.

She was the U.S. Representative for New York's 26th congressional district from June 1, 2011 to January 3, 2013.

[[Entten tentten teelikamentten]]

CATEGORIES: Literature, Children's literature, Songs, Children's songs, Finnish culture

Entten tentten teelikamentten is an old Finnish nursery rhyme.

''Entten tentten teelikamentten

''hissun kissun vaapula vissun

''eelin keelin klot

''viipula vaapula vot

Eskon saun piun paun.

''Nyt sää lähdet tästä pelistä pois, 

Puh pah pelistä pois!''

[[Mohammed Nasim]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from stroke, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Bangladesh, Bangladeshi politicians, Bangladeshi Muslims

Mohammed Nasim (2 April 1948 – 13 June 2020) was a Bangladeshi Awami League politician. Nasim was born in the Sirajganj District in Bangladesh. 

He was the Minister of Health and Family Welfare from 2014 to 2019. He was Minister of Home Affairs from 1996 to 2001. He has been a member of the Jatiya Sangsad since 2014. He was in the Jatiya Sangsad before from 1986 to 1988 and again from 1991 to 2006.

On 1 June 2020, Nasim was hospitalized in Dhaka after testing positive for COVID-19. Four days later, he suffered a cerebral hemorrhage during his treatment. On 13 June 2020, Nasim died while being treated for COVID-19 at a hospital in Dhaka.

[[Monroe County, Michigan]]

CATEGORIES: 1810s establishments in Michigan Territory, 1817 establishments in the United States, Michigan counties

Monroe County is a county in the U.S. state of Michigan.  As of the 2010 census, the population was 152,721.  The largest city and county seat is Monroe. It was named for then-President James Monroe in 1817.

[[Monroe, Michigan]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Michigan, County seats in Michigan

Monroe is the largest city and county seat of Monroe County in the U.S. state of Michigan.  Monroe had a population of 20,733 in the 2010 census. 

[[Yokota family]]

CATEGORIES: Duos, 1932 births, 2020 deaths, 1936 births, Living people, Japanese writers, Human rights activists

The Shigeru Yokota (November 14, 1932 – June 5, 2020) and wife Sakie Yokota (born February 4, 1936) were Japanese human rights activists and writers. They founded the Japanese National Association for the Rescue of Japanese Kidnapped by North Korea in 1997. It supports the victims of abductions of Japanese citizens by North Koreans in the late 1970s and early 1980s. 

The Yokotas' daughter Megumi was kidnapped in 1977 by North Korean spies. She is currently missing.

Sakie Yokota once met with President George W. Bush to talk about sanctions on North Korea and in 2013 she testified about her daughter's abduction.

On June 5, 2020, Shigeru Yokota died at age 87.

[[North Korean abductions of Japanese citizens]]

CATEGORIES: 1977, 1983, Japan, North Korea

Abductions of Japanese citizens from Japan by agents of the North Korean government took place during for six years from 1977 to 1983. 

Although only 17 Japanese (eight men and nine women) are officially recognized by the Japanese government as having been abducted, there may have been hundreds of victims. 

The North Korean government has officially admitted to kidnapping 13 Japanese citizens.

There are testimonies that many non-Japanese citizens, including eight citizens from European countries and one from the Middle East, have been abducted by North Korea.

The National Association for the Rescue of Japanese Kidnapped by North Korea or NARKN (北朝鮮に拉致された日本人を救出するための全国協議会 or simply 救う会全国協議会) was created in 1998 by the Yokota family. The purpose of NARKN is to help the families of Japanese kidnapped victims to find their loved ones.

[[Los Hermanos Cartagena]]

CATEGORIES: 1984 drama movies, Bolivian movies

Los Hermanos Cartagena (English: The Cartagena Brothers) is a 1984 Bolivian drama movie directed by Paolo Agazzi and starring Eddy Bravo, Alberto Cornejo, Oscar Cortés, Ernesto Ferrante.

[[List of universities in Baku]]

CATEGORIES: Lists of universities, Colleges and universities in Asia, Colleges and universities in Europe, Buildings and structures in Baku

This is a list of colleges and universities in Baku, Azerbaijan.

[[Jim Fryatt]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, English footballers, English football managers, Sportspeople from Hampshire, People from Southampton

Jim Fryatt (2 September 1940 – 5 June 2020) was an English footballer and manager. He played as a striker. During his playing career he was nicknamed 'Pancho'. He was born in Southampton, England. His career lasted from 1957 to 1975. 

He was known for playing with Southend United from 1960 to 1963, Bradford from 1963 to 1966, Oldham Athletic from 1970 to 1971, and for Southport from 1971 to 1974.

He also briefly played with Stockport County, Torquay United, Blackburn Rovers, and Charlton Athletic. During his final career years, he played for the North American Soccer League playing in Philadelphia, Hartford and Las Vegas.

Fryatt died on 5 June 2020 in Las Vegas, aged 79.

[[Polonia Warsaw]]

CATEGORIES: 20th century establishments in Poland, 1911 establishments in Europe, Polish football clubs, Warsaw

Polonia Warsaw (Polonia Warszawa, pɔˈlɔɲa varˈʂava) was founded on 19 November 1911. It is the oldest existing Warsaw sports club, with football, basketball, track and field and swimming teams.

[[Piotr Rocki]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from aneurysm, Polish footballers, Sportspeople from Warsaw

Piotr Rocki (January 11, 1974 – June 1, 2020) was a Polish football player. He was born in Warsaw. He played for Polonia Warsaw, Hetman Zamość, Górnik Zabrze, Odra Wodzisław Śląski and later for Dyskobolia Grodzisk Wielkopolski. His career lasted from 1990 to 2017.

Rocki died on June 1, 2020 in Bytom, Poland after suffering from an aneurysm, aged 46.

[[Conrad Worrill]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in Chicago, American civil rights activists, American educators, American television presenters, American political writers, Writers from Chicago, Writers from California, People from Pasadena, California

Conrad Worrill (August 15, 1941 – June 3, 2020) was an African-American writer, educator, activist, and talk show host for the WVON call-in program On Target. He was born in Pasadena, California. His activism was focused in Chicago.

He was involved with the Million Man March, and the National Black United Front. Worrill called on for greater independence in African-American life. He helped young people better understand the relationships between power and institutions. He was a political advisor to Chicago Mayor Harold Washington.

Worrill died on June 3, 2020 from cancer in Chicago at the age of 78.

[[Valentina Tăzlăuanu]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2020 deaths, Moldovan people, Essayists, Journalists, Civil servants, Critics

Valentina Tăzlăuanu (5 January 1950 – 3 June 2020) was a Moldovan essayist, journalist and theatre critic. She was the editor in chief of Sud-Est. She was Chief of Arts Department at Literatura şi Arta magazine from 1977 to 1990. She also was Deputy Minister of Culture from 1997 to 2000.

She was also a member of the Moldovan Writers' Union as well as member and Secretary of PEN Club Moldova.

Tăzlăuanu died on 3 June 2020 in Chișinău, Moldova at the age of 70.

[[Appomattox County, Virginia]]

CATEGORIES: 19th-century establishments in Virginia, 1845 establishments in the United States, Virginia counties

Appomattox County is a United States county near the center of the Commonwealth of Virginia.  The county is part of the Lynchburg, VA Metropolitan Statistical Area. Its county seat is the town of Appomattox.

[[Inferno (1980 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 horror movies, 1980s sequel movies, Italian horror movies, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Dario Argento, Movies set in Rome

Inferno is a 1980 Italian horror movie directed by Dario Argento and is the sequel to the 1977 movie Suspiria. It stars Irene Miracle, Leigh McCloskey, Eleonora Giorgi, Daria Nicolodi, Sacha Pitoëff, Veronica Lazar and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Patrick Duffy (British politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1920 births, Living people, British economists, British autobiographers, Former Labour MPs (UK), British military personnel of World War II, UK MPs 1959–1964, UK MPs 1964–1966, UK MPs 1970–1974, UK MPs 1974, UK MPs 1974–1979, UK MPs 1979–1983, UK MPs 1983–1987, UK MPs 1987–1992, Politicians from London, Writers from London

Sir Albert Edward Patrick Duffy (born 17 June 1920) is a British economist and Labour Party politician. He was born in London and served in World War II. 

He was a Member of Parliament for Colne Valley from 1963 to 1966 and for Sheffield Attercliffe from 1970 to 1992. He was a Minister of the Navy in the 1970s, and President of the NATO Assembly in the 1980s. Duffy was a critic of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.

[[Patrick Duffy]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American stage actors, American television personalities, American television directors, Actors from Montana, Actors from Washington, Actors from Oregon, People from Everett, Washington

Patrick Garfield Duffy (born March 17, 1949) is an American actor. He is best known for his role on the CBS primetime soap opera Dallas, where he played Bobby Ewing from 1978 to 1985 and from 1986 to 1991. Duffy returned as Bobby in a continuation of Dallas from 2012 to 2014. 

Duffy was born in Townsend, Montana. He was raised in Everett, Washington and in Eagle Point, Oregon. He studied at the University of Washington. He was married to Carlyn Rosser from 1974 until her death in 2017. They had two children.

[[Hasnain Khan]]

CATEGORIES: 1996 births, Pakistani cricketers, Living people

Hasnain Khan (born 9 January 1996) is a Pakistani first-class cricketer. He plays for Federally Administered Tribal Areas.  

[[Eagle Point, Oregon]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Oregon

Eagle Point is a city in Jackson County, Oregon, United States. The population was 8,469 at the 2010 census.

[[Stockholm University]]

CATEGORIES: 19th century establishments in Sweden, 1878 establishments in Europe, Colleges and universities in Sweden, Buildings and structures in Stockholm

Stockholm University (Stockholms universitet) is a public university in Stockholm, the capital of Sweden. It was founded as a college in 1878. It reached the university status in 1960. It had over 33,000  students in 2019. It has four different faculties, including law, humanities, social sciences, and natural sciences. It is one of the largest universities in Scandinavia. It is one of the top 100 universities in the world, according to the Academic Ranking of World Universities.

When it was granted university status in 1960, it became the fourth oldest Swedish university. Like other public universities in Sweden, its mission is teaching and research anchored in society at large.

[[Sharad Arvind Bobde]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, Living people, Chief Justices of India

Sharad Arvind Bobde (born 24 April 1956) is an Indian judge. He was the 47th Chief Justice of India from 18 November 2019 to 23 April 2021. 

He is a former Chief Justice of Madhya Pradesh High Court.

[[Om Birla]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 births, Living people, Speakers of the Lok Sabha, Indian politicians

Om Birla (born 23 November 1962) is an Indian politician. He is the 17th and current Speaker of the Lok Sabha since 2019. He has been a Member of Parliament for the Kota-Bundi constituency in Rajasthan since 2014. He is a member of the Bharatiya Janata Party.

[[Rabi Ray]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2017 deaths, Speakers of the Lok Sabha

Rabi Ray (26 November 1926 – 6 March 2017) was an Indian socialist politician. He was the Speaker of the Lok Sabha from 1989 to 1991. He joined the Socialist Party in 1948, and later became member of the Samyukta Socialist Party, the Janata Party and the Janata Dal.

[[Yuki Niizawa]]

CATEGORIES: 1997 births, Living people, Japanese water polo players

Yuki Niizawa (born 13 February 1997) is a Japanese female water polo player who participated at the 2017 Summer Universiade, 2018 Asian Games, 2017 World Aquatic Championships, and 2019 World Aquatic Championships.

[[Manohar Joshi]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, Living people, Speakers of the Lok Sabha, Mayors, People from Mumbai

Manohar Gajanan Joshi (born 2 December 1937) is an Indian politician. He is one of the key leaders of the Shiv Sena political party. He was the Chief Minister of Maharashtra from 1995 to 1999. He was also the 13th Speaker of the Lok Sabha from 2002 to 2004.

[[Paul Tudor Jones]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, Living people, American billionaires, American chief executives, American company founders, American philanthropists, Businesspeople from Tennessee, People from Memphis, Tennessee, Stockbrokers

• The Weinstein Company 2015-2017

Paul Tudor Jones II (born September 28, 1954) is an American billionaire hedge fund manager, philanthropist, and conservationist. His hedge fund, Tudor Investment Corporation, an asset management firm headquartered in Stamford, Connecticut, was founded in 1980.

He founded the Robin Hood Foundation eight years later. The organization focuses on helping reduce poverty.

His net worth is estimated to be $5.1 billion according to Forbes.

[[Ramesh Chandra Lahoti]]

Ramesh Chandra Lahoti (born 1 November 1940) is an Indian judge. He was the 35th Chief Justice of India from 1 June 2004 to 1 November 2005.

[[S. Rajendra Babu]]

CATEGORIES: Chief Justices of India, 1939 births, Living people

S. Rajendra Babu (born 1 June 1939) is an Indian judge. He was the 34th Chief Justice of India from May to June 2004. He also served as the chairperson of National Human Rights Commission of India.

[[Akari Inaba]]

[[V. N. Khare]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, Chief Justices of India, 1939 births

Vishweshwar Nath Khare (born 2 May 1939) is an Indian judge. He was the 33rd Chief Justice of India from 19 December 2002 to 2 May 2004. He was a judge of the Supreme Court of India from 21 March 1997 before he was promoted to the post of Chief Justice by President A. P. J. Abdul Kalam.

[[Kamal Narain Singh]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, Living people, Chief Justices of India

Kamal Narain Singh (born December 13, 1926) is an Indian judge. He was the 22nd Chief Justice of India from November to December 1991. He was from  Allahabad. At 17 days, his tenure as chief justice is the shortest.

[[Yaaba]]

[[Aziz Mushabber Ahmadi]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, Living people, Chief Justices of India

Aziz Mushabber Ahmadi (born 25 March 1932) is an Indian judge. He was the 26th Chief Justice of India from 1994 to 1997. After serving as a judge in the Gujarat High Court, Ahmadi was appointed judge to the Supreme Court in 1988.

He was Chancellor at the Aligarh Muslim University for two terms.

Bhupinder Nath Kirpal (B. N. Kirpal) (born 8 November 1937) is an Indian judge. He was the 31st Chief Justice of India from 6 May 2002 until his retirement on 7 November 2002.

[[Gopal Ballav Pattanaik]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, Living people, Chief Justices of India

Gopal Ballav Pattanaik (born 19 December 1937) is an Indian judge. He was the 32nd  Chief Justice of India from 8 November 2002 to 18 December 2002. He was appointed by President A. P. J. Abdul Kalam. He was born in Cuttack, now in Odisha, India.

[[Jackson County, Michigan]]

Jackson County is a county located in the U.S. state of Michigan. Its population was 160,248 as of the 2010 Census. The county seat is Jackson. It is named for U.S. President Andrew Jackson.

[[James Albert Murray]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Bishops, American Roman Catholics, People from Jackson, Michigan, People from Kalamazoo, Michigan

James Albert Murray (July 5, 1932 – June 5, 2020) was an American prelate of the Roman Catholic Church. He was Bishop of Kalamazoo from 1998 to 2009. He was born in Jackson, Michigan.

[[Bole–Tangale languages]]

The Bole–Tangale languages (also called A.2 West Chadic languages) are a branch of West Chadic languages. They are spoken in Northeastern Nigeria.

[[Salem, Ohio]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Ohio

Salem is a city in northern Columbiana County, Ohio, United States, with a small district in southern Mahoning County.  At the 2010 census, the city's population was 12,303. Salem is the principal city of the Salem, OH Micropolitan Statistical Area.

[[Boardman, Ohio]]

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places, Settlements in Ohio

Boardman is a census-designated place (CDP) in Boardman Township, Mahoning County, Ohio, United States. It is a suburb south of Youngstown.  Boardman is one of two major retail hubs in the Mahoning Valley. The population of the CDP was 35,376 at the 2010 census.

[[Angas languages]]

CATEGORIES: West Chadic languages, Languages of Nigeria

The Angas, Angas–Sura, or Central West Chadic, (A.3 West Chadic) languages are a branch of West Chadic languages. They are spoken in North Nigeria.

[[Wilhelm von Homburg]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2004 deaths, Deaths from prostate cancer, Boxers, German movie actors, German television actors, German voice actors, Professional wrestlers, German LGBT people, Bisexual people, LGBT actors, LGBT sportspeople, Actors from Hamburg, Sportspeople from Hamburg

Norbert Grupe (August 25, 1940 – March 10, 2004), better known outside Germany by his stage name Wilhelm von Homburg, was a German boxer, actor, and professional wrestler. He was known for his villainous supporting roles in many movies of the 1980s and 90s, including Vigo the Carpathian in Ghostbusters II, the henchman James in Die Hard, and Souteneur in Werner Herzog's Stroszek. He was born in Hamburg.

von Homburg died of prostate cancer at a friend's house in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico on March 10, 2004 at the age of 63.

[[Ron languages]]

CATEGORIES: West Chadic languages, Languages of Nigeria

The Ron, Ronic, or Ron–Fyer, (A.4 West Chadic) languages are a branch of West Chadic languages. They are spoken in the Plateau State of North Nigeria.

[[Yuri Kazama]]

CATEGORIES: 1996 births, Living people, Japanese water polo players

Yuri Kazama (born 3 October 1996) is a Japanese water polo player. She was part of the Japanese women's national water polo team at the 2015 World Aquatics Championships and 2019 Summer Universiade.

[[Alexander Godunov]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 1995 deaths, Deaths from hepatitis, Russian dancers, Russian movie actors, Russian television actors, Russian stage actors, Naturalized citizens of the United States, American dancers, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors

Alexander Borisovich Godunov (Russian: Александр Борисович Годунов; November 28, 1949 – May 18, 1995) was a Russian-American ballet dancer and movie actor. He was a member of the Bolshoi Ballet. He was known for his roles as Max Beissart in The Money Pit (1986) and as Karl Vreski in Die Hard (1988).

Godunov died on May 18, 1995 from hepatitis caused by alcoholism at his home in Hollywood, California at the age of 45.

[[Bade languages]]

CATEGORIES: West Chadic languages, Languages of Nigeria

The Bade (also called B.1 West Chadic) languages are a branch of West Chadic languages. They are spoken in the Borno and Jigawa States of North Nigeria. Bade is the most widely spoken Bade langauge. It is where the branch gets its name.

[[Loc-Eguiner-Saint-Thégonnec]]

CATEGORIES: Former communes in Finistère

Loc-Eguiner-Saint-Thégonnec (Logeginer-Sant-Tegoneg) is a former commune. It is found in the region Brittany in the Finistère department in the northwest of France. On 1 January 2016, it was merged into the new commune of Saint-Thégonnec Loc-Eguiner.

[[Bade language]]

CATEGORIES: West Chadic languages, Languages of Nigeria

Bade is a Chadic language. It is spoken in the Yobe and Jigawa States of Nigeria. Around 250,000 people speak Bade. The amount of people speaking Bade is going down quickly. Some people think it might go extinct.

[[Rikako Miura]]

CATEGORIES: 1989 births, Living people, Japanese water polo players

Rikako Miura (born 13 October 1989) is a Japanese female water polo player. She participated at the 2013 Summer Universiade, 2015 World Aquatics Championships, and 2019 World Aquatics Championships.

[[Warji languages]]

CATEGORIES: West Chadic languages, Languages of Nigeria

The Warji (B.2 West Chadic) languages are a branch of West Chadic languages. They are spoken in the Bauchi State of Nigeria.

[[Chaithra Rai]]

CATEGORIES: Indian television actors, Karnataka, Living people

Chaithra Rai (born March 29) is an Indian television actress. She works for Telugu and Kannada Industries. She is known for her role as Vishaka in the soap opera Radha Kalyana which was on the Zee Kannada channel in the Kannada television industry. In the Telugu Television industry, she is known for her role as Swapan in Ashta Chamma serial telecasted on Star Maa. Now she is best known for her dual role as the twin sisters Dharani and Sravani in the serial Attarintulu Akka Chellulu which currently telecasts on Zee Telugu.

[[Pieter van der Kruk]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, Living people, Dutch journalists, Dutch Olympians, People from Delft, Sportspeople from South Holland, Sports commentators, Weightlifters, Writers from South Holland

Pieter "Piet" van der Kruk (13 August 1941 – 4 June 2020) was a Dutch heavyweight weightlifter and shot putter. He won five national weightlifting titles (1964, 1965, 1967–1969) and four shot put titles (1964, 1965, 1967 and 1969). He qualified for the 1968 Summer Olympics and finished in ninth place. He was born in Delft, the Netherlands.

Kruk died on 4 June 2020 at a hospital in Delft after a short-illness, aged 78.

[[Barawa languages]]

The Barawa (B.3 West Chadic) languages are a branch of West Chadic languages. They are spoken in the Bauchi State of North Nigeria. 

[[Vincent Perez]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, Living people, French movie actors, French television actors, French movie directors, French stage actors, French photographers, Swiss movie actors, Swiss television actors, Swiss movie directors

Vincent Perez (born 10 June 1964) is a Swiss-French actor, director and photographer. He is best known for playing the title character, Ashe Corven, in The Crow: City of Angels, and for starring in Queen of the Damned, playing Marius de Romanus.

[[Audrey Daule]]

CATEGORIES: 1993 births, Living people, French water polo players

Audrey Daule (born 6 May 1993) is a French water polo player.

She was a member of the France women's national water polo team at the 2015 World Aquatics Championships, and 2017 World Aquatics Championships.

[[Pedro Ercílio Simon]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Bishops, Brazilian people

Pedro Ercílio Simon (9 September 1941 – 1 June 2020) was a Brazilian Roman Catholic archbishop. He was born in Ibiaçá, Rio Grande do Sul. He was bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Uruguaiana from 1995 to 1998. Simon then was coadjutor bishop, diocese bishop, and then archbishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Passo Fundo, Brazil from 1998 to 2012.

Simon died in Passo Fundo, Rio Grande do Sul on 1 June 2020, aged 78.

[[Passo Fundo]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Rio Grande do Sul

Passo Fundo is a municipality in the north of the southern Brazilian state of Rio Grande do Sul. It is named after its river. It's the twelfth largest city in the state. It has a population of 201,767.

[[Warji language]]

CATEGORIES: West Chadic languages, Languages of Nigeria

Warji is a Chadic language spoken in the Bauchi State, Nigeria. Many people are starting to speak Hausa instead. Warji might go extinct.

[[Constantin Xenakis]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Greek people, French painters, French sculptors, People from Cairo, Writers from Paris

Constantin Xenakis (Κωνσταντίνος Ξενάκης; 28 December 1931 – 6 June 2020) was an Egyptian-born Greek-French painter and sculptor. 

His work were written script, in particular the Hebrew alphabet, symbols and codes of everyday life such as traffic signs, chemical symbols, Egyptian hieroglyphics and letters from the Greek, Phoenician and Arabic alphabets.

He was born in Cairo. He spent his career in Paris. His work is held in the National Gallery of Greece and the Macedonian Museum of Contemporary Art.

He was made a Chevalier of the Order of Arts and Letters in 1986.

Xenakis died on 6 June 2020 at his home in Paris, aged 88.

[[Nicholas Kristof]]

CATEGORIES: Pulitzer Prize winners, 1959 births, Living people, American political commentators, American human rights activists, American columnists, CNN people, American progressives, American political writers, Writers from Oregon, Journalists from Chicago, American bloggers

Nicholas Donabet Kristof (born April 27, 1959) is an American journalist and political commentator. He is the winner of two Pulitzer Prizes. He is a regular CNN contributor and has written an op-ed column for The New York Times since November 2001.

His works focuses on human rights abuses and social injustices, such as human trafficking and the Darfur conflict.

[[Sheryl WuDunn]]

CATEGORIES: Pulitzer Prize winners, 1959 births, Living people, American political writers, American educators, American columnists, Journalists from New York City, Businesspeople from New York City

Sheryl WuDunn (born November 16, 1959) is an American business executive, Pulitzer Prize-winning writer and lecturer.

She has also been a private wealth adviser with Goldman Sachs and was a journalist and business executive for The New York Times. She is now senior managing director at Mid-Market Securities.

In 1988, she married journalist Nicholas Kristof.

[[West Semitic languages]]

CATEGORIES: Semitic languages

The West Semitic languages are a large branch of Semitic languages. It is the only branch of Semitic languages with languages still spoken. The other branch of Semitic languages was East Semitic. It is extinct. The two branches of West Semitic languages are Central and Southern. Some linguists disagree with the branches. They think that Central and Southern Semitic languages are not related and are actually separate branches of Semitic languages.

[[Abdul Malek]]

Bangladesh Awami League politician

Abdul Malek is a Bangladesh Awami League politician and the former Member of Parliament of Mymensingh-4.  He was the organizer of the Liberation War of Bangladesh.

[[Spotted-thighed frog]]

CATEGORIES: Frogs, Animals of Australia

The spotted-thighed frog or spotted-thighed tree frog (Litoria cyclorhyncha) is a tree frog from southwestern Australia.

Spotted-thighed frogs are dark green or brown with yellow spots on their backs.  They have bright yellow spots on their legs.  It looks like its relative, the motorbike frog.

By 2020, the spotted-thighed frog had moved to southern Australia, where it is an invasive specie.  Humans carried the spotted-thighed frog to southern Australia by accident.  People have seen spotted-thighed frogs in Streaky Bay, the Eyre Peninsula and at the airport in Adelaide.

Scientists say the spotted-thighed frog is dangerous to the environment because can eat many different kinds of food, even mice and other frogs.  This means it can kill the frogs that usually live in South Australia, either by eating all their food or by eating the frogs themselves.

According to ecologist Christine Taylor, "This frog is an indiscriminate eating machine that will devour just about anything it can fit into its mouth."

The Central Semitic languages are a branch of West Semitic languages. They are spoken in the Middle East and North Africa. The branch is made up of two parts, Arabic and the Northwest Semitic languages (including Hebrew and Aramaic).

[[Harvard Business School]]

CATEGORIES: Harvard University

Harvard Business School (abbv: HBS) is the graduate business school of Harvard University. It is located in Boston, Massachusetts. It is one of the top business schools in the world. It offers a wide full-time MBA program, management-related doctoral programs, and many leadership education programs.

It owns Harvard Business Publishing. The company publishes business books, leadership articles, case studies, and the monthly Harvard Business Review. It is also where the Baker Library/Bloomberg Center is.

[[Motorbike frog]]

CATEGORIES: Frogs, Animals of Australia

The motorbike frog, also called Moore's frog, western green and golden bell frog, and bull frog (Litoria moorei), is a frog from southwestern Australia.

These frogs can be up to 7.8 cm long.  They can come in different colors from brown to green and parts of their skin turn yellow if they sit in the sunlight. They have light green or light brown bellies. They have a stripe over each eyelid that goes past the ear to the top of the front leg.

They lay their eggs in bunches stuck to plants under water.  The tadpoles can be 8 cm long and are dark brown.  They grow into frogs in March and April, late summer.  Some tadpoles stay tadpoles longer, for 14 months and can grow to be 14 cm long before turning into frogs.

The tadpoles eat algae and the adults eat arthropods, such as insects, and sometimes young motorbike frogs.

Although this frog can climb trees, it mostly lives on the ground, so not all scientists call it a tree frog.

[[Hiwassee College]]

CATEGORIES: 19th-century establishments in Tennessee, 1849 establishments in the United States, 2010s disestablishments in the United States, 2019 disestablishments, Colleges and universities in Tennessee

Hiwassee College was a private liberal arts college in Madisonville, Tennessee. It was founded in 1849. The college offered both associate and bachelor's degrees. Most of its associate degree graduates went on to complete bachelor's degrees elsewhere. 

The college closed on May 10, 2019 because of financial issues.
