[[Geoffrey Burnstock]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, English biologists, Australian biologists, Scientists from London, Writers from London

Geoffrey Burnstock AUS (10 May 1929 – 2 June 2020) was an English-born Australian  neurobiologist. He was President of the Autonomic Neuroscience Centre of the UCL Medical School. He was best known for creating the term purinergic signalling, which he discovered in the 1970s. He retired in October 2017.

[[Cave-dwelling frog]]

CATEGORIES: Frogs, Animals of Australia

The cave-dwelling frog or cave frog (Litoria cavernicola) is a frog from northwestern Australia.

The cave-dwelling frog lives in caves and between large rocks in sandstone canyons in the Kimberly region.  It is green to reddish-brown in color.

The frogs lay their eggs in shallow pools of water, but scientists do not know what the tadpoles are like.

[[Catherine Keener]]

CATEGORIES: Satellite Award winners, 1959 births, Living people, Actors from Miami, Florida, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American stage actors

Catherine Ann Keener (born March 23, 1959) is an American actress. She has been twice nominated for the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress for Being John Malkovich (1999) and for her role as Harper Lee in Capote (2005).

[[Get Out]]

CATEGORIES: 2017 horror movies, African-American movies, American horror movies, American independent movies

Get Out is a 2017 American horror movie written and directed by Jordan Peele. It stars Daniel Kaluuya, Allison Williams, Lil Rel Howery, Bradley Whitford, Caleb Landry Jones, Stephen Root, and Catherine Keener. 

Get Out premiered at the Sundance Film Festival on January 23, 2017, and was theatrically released in the United States on February 24, 2017, by Universal Pictures. 

Get Out had strong positive critical reviews and was nominated for four Academy Awards. It is thought to be one of the best movies of the 2010s.

[[Us (2019 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2019 horror movies, African-American movies, American horror movies

Us is a 2019 American horror movie written and directed by Jordan Peele. It stars Lupita Nyong'o, Winston Duke, Elisabeth Moss, and Tim Heidecker. The movie is about Adelaide Wilson (Nyong'o) and her family, who are attacked by a group of mysterious people who look just like them. 

Us was released in the United States on March 22, 2019, by Universal Pictures. It had strong positive reviews.

[[Tim Heidecker]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 births, Living people, American movie actors, American voice actors, American television actors, American television directors, American television writers, American television producers, People from Allentown, Pennsylvania, Musicians from Pennsylvania, Comedians from Pennsylvania, Writers from Pennsylvania, Actors from Pennsylvania

Timothy Richard Heidecker (ˈ; born February 3, 1976) is an American comedian, writer, director, actor, and musician. He is best known as one half of the comedy duo Tim & Eric, along with Eric Wareheim. They are known for creating the television shows Tom Goes to the Mayor, Tim and Eric Awesome Show, Great Job!, and Tim & Eric's Bedtime Stories.

Heidecker was born and raised in Allentown, Pennsylvania.

[[Eric Wareheim]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 births, Living people, American movie actors, American voice actors, American television actors, American television directors, American television writers, American television producers, Musicians from Pennsylvania, Comedians from Pennsylvania, Writers from Pennsylvania, Actors from Pennsylvania

Eric Alexander Wareheim (ˈ; born April 7, 1976) is an American actor, comedian, writer, director, and musician. He is one half of the comedy duo Tim & Eric, alongside Tim Heidecker. They created the television shows Tom Goes to the Mayor, Tim and Eric Awesome Show, Great Job!, Check It Out! with Dr. Steve Brule, Tim and Eric's Bedtime Stories, and Beef House. 

He had a constant role on the Netflix series Master of None.

Wareheim was born in Audubon, Pennsylvania.

[[Audubon, Pennsylvania]]

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places in Pennsylvania

Audubon is a census-designated place (CDP) in Montgomery County, Pennsylvania, United States. It was named for naturalist John James Audubon. The population was 8,433 at the 2010 census.

[[Anatolian languages]]

CATEGORIES: Indo-European languages

The Anatolian languages were a branch of Indo-European languages. They are now extinct. They were spoken in Asia Minor (ancient Anatolia) in modern-day Turkey. There are three, or maybe four, known branches.

[[Ray Dalio]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, Living people, American billionaires, American philanthropists, Businesspeople from New York City, Harvard University alumni

Raymond Thomas Dalio (born August 8, 1949) is an American billionaire hedge fund manager, author, and philanthropist. He is the co-chief investment officer of Bridgewater Associates since the company was founded in 1985.

The firm received a US$5 million investment from the World Bank's retirement fund. It was listed as the largest hedge fund in the world in 2013.

[[Tocharian languages]]

CATEGORIES: Indo-European languages

The Tocharian languages were a branch of the Indo-European languages. They are now extinct. They were spoken on the northern side of the Tarim Basin (now in Xinjiang, China). Writing was found from around the 5th century to the 8th century AD. There were three known languages in the branch, named A, B and C.

[[FA Community Shield]]

CATEGORIES: 1908 establishments in England, Football

The Football Association Community Shield (formerly the Charity Shield) is English football's yearly match held at Wembley Stadium. It is played between the winners of the previous Premier League season and the holders of the FA Cup. If the Premier League winners also won the FA Cup, then the league second place finishers are the opponents. The fixture is recognised as a competitive super cup by the Football Association and UEFA.

[[UEFA European Under-21 Championship]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 establishments in Europe, Football

The UEFA European Under-21 Championship is a football competition that happens every two years. It is played by the European men's under-21 national teams of the member associations of UEFA.

Italy and Spain have won the trophy more times than anyone else. They have won five times each. Spain are also the current champions.

[[Norilsk]]

CATEGORIES: Siberia, Cities in Russia

Norilsk is a city in Siberia, with almost 180,000 people. It lies about 300 north of the arctic circle, and over  1500 north of Krasnoyarsk.  There are many ore deposits in the region, especially nickel and copper. Mining ore is always linked to heavy pollution of the environment. Norilsk was founded in 1935 as a site of industry, to be able to mine the ore. In 1939, the decision was taken to also build a city. Norilsk got the statute of a city in 1953.

Norilsk is the northernmost city with more than 100.000 inhabitants. It is the second largest city within the arctic circle, only Murmansk is larger. Norilsk and Yakutsk are the only large cities built in the continuous permafrost zone. This means that even in summer, the ground remains frozen.

The nickel deposits of Norilsk-Talnakh are the largest-known nickel-copper-palladium deposits in the world.  The smelting of the nickel ore is directly responsible for severe pollution, which generally comes in the form of acid rain and smog. By some estimates, one percent of global sulfur dioxide emission comes from Norilsk's nickel mines.

Norilsk is a closed city. This means that a special permit is needed to be able to travel to Norilsk. This permit is  issued both by the Russian government, and the local mining comany. Foreigners usually do not get this permit.

[[Immigration detention in the United States]]

CATEGORIES: Immigration

The United States government holds tens of thousands of immigrants in detention. The Customs and Border Protection (CBP; principally the Border Patrol) and the Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) do this. Immigrants are detained for entering into the United States illegally, when their requests for asylum are received (and before they are released into the United States by parole), and in the process of deportation and removal from the country. During Fiscal Year 2018, 396,448 people were in ICE custody: 242,778 of them were detained by CBP and 153,670 by ICE. A daily average of 42,188 immigrants (40,075 adult and 2,113 in families) were held by ICE in that year. More than twelve thousand immigrant children are in buildings that the Office of Refugee Resettlement's program for Unaccompanied Alien Children controls. Before they are moved to these other agencies, the CBP keeps immigrants at processing centers; between mid-May and mid-June 2019, it kept between 14,000 and 18,000 immigrants.

[[City College of New York]]

CATEGORIES: 1847 establishments in the United States, Colleges and universities in New York City

The City College of the City University of New York (City College of New York, or simply City College, CCNY, or City) is a public college of the City University of New York (CUNY) system in New York City. The institution was founded in 1847. It was the first free public institution of higher education in the United States. It is the oldest of CUNY's 24 institutions of higher learning. It is considered its flagship college.

[[École de management de Normandie]]

CATEGORIES: Education in France, Le Havre

École de management de Normandie is an European higher studies establishment. The school is in 5 places, in Paris, in Le Havre, in Caen, in Oxford and in Dublin. It is has been created in 1871.

EM Normandie is specialist in the fields of economics, social sciences and management.

[[Boeing 747SP]]

CATEGORIES: Boeing 747

The Boeing 747SP is a jet airliner, a variant of the Boeing 747. Compared to the original 747, the 747SP has a shortened fuselage. Because of this, it can carry fewer passengers, but is able to fly longer distances. The 747SP first flew in 1975 and entered service in 1976. A total of 45 747SPs was built until 1987.

[[Tab stop]]

CATEGORIES: Typography, Writing tools

A tab stop is a term used to describe the location the cursor stops after the tab key is pressed. Tab stops are used in word processors to enable users to align text by pressing the tab key. Below is a picture of the ruler bar in Microsoft Office with each of the left tab stops marked as bold L's. If these were right tabs, the L would be backwards. In Microsoft Word, the tab selector, also called the tab indicator, is a button to the left of the ruler that provides a variety of tab marker options.

[[Milad Tower]]

Milad Tower is a radio and television tower. It is in the northwest of Tehran, the capital of Iran. This tower is the tallest tower in Iran with a height of 435 meters. Milad Tower is the sixth tallest radio and television tower in the world. Milad Tower is the nineteenth tallest single structure in the world. This tower is the first among all radio and television towers in the world. Milad Tower is visible almost everywhere in Tehran due to its great height. So, it is considered a symbol of the capital of Iran. Some believe that engineers built the tower on the fault system of West Town.

[[Bon]]

CATEGORIES: Religion in China, Tibet

Bon, also spelled Bön, is a religion of Tibet. The modern form of Bon has its roots in the late 900s and 1000s CE, when the first Bon monasteries were started in Tibet. There are many teachings in Bon that are similar to Buddhist teachings, and so people who study Bon disagree whether it should be called a kind of Buddhism or not. Followers of Bon believe that it was founded by a teacher called Tonpa Shenrab who lived many years ago in a land called Tazig. Some people think that Tazig refers to Persia, Central Asia, or the area around Mount Kailash in western Tibet. According to Tibetans, Bon was popular in Tibet before Buddhism became the main religion of Tibet, but some non-Tibetans like Per Kvœrne say there isn't much connection between religion in Tibet before Buddhism and the living tradition of Bon. After the Chinese army sent troops to Tibet in 1959, some followers of Bon were forced to leave Tibet and many Bon monasteries and temples were shut down. Many of the followers of Bon who left Tibet started Bon centers in cities around the world. Today, most people who believe in Bon are ethnic Tibetans, but a small number of non-Tibetans have started to believe in Bon too. 

The yungdrung, or left-facing swastika, is a sacred symbol in Bon, and the living tradition of Bon is sometimes called Yungdrung Bon, meaning "eternal Bon" in Tibetan. The yungdrung, like the vajra in Tibetan Buddhism, represents eternity because it is said that the yungdrung cannot be destroyed and lasts forever. 

Tibetan Buddhists used to write many bad things about Bon, arguing that Bon had stolen most of its teachings from Buddhism, a view that people studying Bon from Europe and North America sometimes agreed with. The fourteenth Dalai Lama, who is seen as a religious leader by most Tibetans, said that Bon is as much part of Tibetan religion as Buddhism, encouraging people to treat Bon with respect. 

Followers of Bon are called Bonpos. Bonpos believe in many gods. These gods include the creator god, Sangpo Bumtri, the god of compassion Shenlha Ökar, the goddess of compassion Sherab Chamma, and the founder of Bon Tonpa Shenrab. 

[[Amorite language]]

CATEGORIES: Semitic languages, Extinct languages

Amorite was a Semitic language. It was spoken in the Bronze Age by tribes in the Near East. It is now extinct.

[[Alaba-K'abeena language]]

CATEGORIES: Highland East Cushitic languages, Languages of Ethiopia

Alaba and K'abeena are two very similar Cushitic languages. Some people think they are dialects of one another. These people call the language Alaba-K'abeena. They are spoken in Ethiopia. The languages are similar to the Kambaata language. Alaba and K'abeena are spoken by about 300,000 people.

[[Lowland East Cushitic languages]]

CATEGORIES: Cushitic languages

The Lowland East Cushitic languages are a branch of Cushitic languages spoken on the Horn of Africa. There are around 25 languages in the branch still spoken. The most spoken are the Oromo and Somali languages.

[[Used Cars]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 comedy movies, American black comedy movies, Movies directed by Robert Zemeckis

Used Cars is a 1980 American black comedy movie directed by Robert Zemeckis and starring Kurt Russell, Jack Warden, Gerrit Graham, Frank McRae, Cheryl Rixon, Alfonso Arau, Deborah Harmon, Michael McKean. It was distributed by Columbia Pictures.

[[Balkan Romance languages]]

CATEGORIES: Romance languages

The Balkan Romance languages are a branch of Eastern Romance languages spoken in the Balkans. There are four languages in the branch, Aromanian, Romanian (also called Daco-Romanian), Istro-Romanian, and Megleno-Romanian.

[[Italo-Western languages]]

CATEGORIES: Romance languages

The Italo-Western languages are the largest branch of Romance languages. They are made up of two branches, the Italo-Dalmation languages and the Western Romance languages.

[[Italo-Dalmatian languages]]

CATEGORIES: Romance languages

The Italo-Dalmatian languages are a branch of Romance languages. They are mainly spoken in Italy. Some of them used to be spoken in Croatia.

[[A Simple Story]]

A Simple Story (Une si simple histoire) is a 1970 Tunisian drama movie directed by Abdellatif Ben Ammar and starring Labiba Ben Ammar, Juliet Berto, Pia Colombo.

[[Western Romance languages]]

CATEGORIES: Romance languages

The Western Romance languages are a branch of Romance languages. The main languages in the branch are Spanish, French, and Portuguese. The branch has two parts, Gallo-Romance and Iberian Romance.

[[Fire Sale]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 comedy movies, American comedy movies

Fire Sale is a 1977 American comedy movie directed by Alan Arkin (who also stars) and based on the novel by Robert Klane. It stars Rob Reiner, Vincent Gardenia, Kay Medford, Alex Rocco, Anjanette Comer, Sid Caesar, Oliver Clark and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[World Artistic Gymnastics Championships]]

CATEGORIES: 1903 establishments

The Artistic Gymnastics World Championships are the world championships for artistic gymnastics. The games are held by the Fédération Internationale de Gymnastique (FIG). The first championships was held in 1903 for male gymnasts. Since the tenth game of the tournament, in 1934, women's events are held together with men's events.  

[[Kurt Thomas (gymnast)]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from stroke, American Olympians, American gymnasts, Sportspeople from Miami, Florida

Kurt Bilteaux Thomas (March 29, 1956 – June 5, 2020) was an American Olympic gymnast. He was born in Miami, Florida. Thomas became a member of the U.S. Olympic team at the 1976 Summer Olympics. In 1978, Thomas was the first American male gymnast to win a gold medal in floor exercise in a world championship. 

Thomas died of stroke-related problems at a hospital in Frisco, Texas on June 5, 2020 at the age of 64.

[[Christel DeHaan]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, American philanthropists, German businesspeople, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Businesspeople from Indianapolis, Indiana

Christel DeHaan (nee Stark, October 20, 1942 – June 6, 2020) was a German-born American businesswoman and philanthropist. She was the owner of Resort Condominiums International and the founder of Christel House International. DeHaan was born in Nördlingen, Germany.

DeHaan died on June 6, 2020 at her home in Indianapolis, Indiana at the age of 77.

[[Marjan (singer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Iranian actors, Iranian singers

Shahla Safi Zamir (شهلا صافی ضمیر, 1948 – 6 June 2020), better known by her stage name Marjan (مرجان), was an Iranian singer and actress. Her career lasted from 1969 to 2012. She was born in Shiraz, Iran. Her best known roles were in Morgh-e tokhm-tala, Salam Bar Eshgh and Takye bar baad.

Marjan died on 6 June 2020, aged 72.

She died due to a cardiac arrest. She spent the last years of her life in Los Angeles.

[[Jordi Mestre]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 births, 2020 deaths, Road accident deaths, Spanish movie actors, Spanish television actors, Spanish voice actors, Spanish models, People from Barcelona

Jordi Mestre Molina (14 September 1981 – 6 June 2020), best known as Jordi Mestre, was a Spanish actor and model. He became famous for  his work as reporter on the successful Spanish TV show Sé lo que hicisteis.... He was born in Esplugues de Llobregat, Province of Barcelona.

Mestre was killed in a motorcycle crash in Madrid on 6 June 2020, aged 38.

[[Cheaper by the Dozen (2003 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2003 comedy movies, American comedy movies, Movies directed by Shawn Levy, Movies based on books, Movies set in Chicago, Illinois, Movies shot in Chicago, Illinois

Cheaper by the Dozen is a 2003 American family comedy movie directed by Shawn Levy. It stars Steve Martin and Bonnie Hunt. It is a remake of the 1950 movie of the same name.

The movie was released on December 25, 2003, by 20th Century Fox and made $190.2 million worldwide. 

A sequel, Cheaper by the Dozen 2, was released in the United States on December 21, 2005. Both movies were inspired by the real life Gilbreth family and the semi-autobiographical account of their lives as written in Cheaper by the Dozen by Frank Bunker Gilbreth Jr. and his sister Ernestine Gilbreth Carey.

[[Cheaper by the Dozen 2]]

CATEGORIES: 2005 comedy movies, American comedy movies, Sequel movies, Movies set in Chicago, Illinois

Cheaper by the Dozen 2 is a 2005 American family comedy movie directed by Adam Shankman. Steve Martin, Bonnie Hunt, Hilary Duff, Piper Perabo, Alyson Stoner, and Tom Welling return to their roles from the first movie. Eugene Levy and Carmen Electra co-star.

[[Ernestine Gilbreth Carey]]

CATEGORIES: 1908 births, 2006 deaths, Deaths from natural causes in the United States, American autobiographers, American novelists, Writers from New York City

Ernestine Moller Gilbreth, Mrs. Carey (April 5, 1908 – November 4, 2006) was an American author. She was born in New York City. With her brother, Frank Bunker Gilbreth Jr., they wrote the semi-autobiographical book Cheaper by the Dozen. She also wrote Belles on Their Toes.

Carey dued on November 4, 2006 in Fresno, California at the age of 98.

[[Frank Bunker Gilbreth Jr.]]

CATEGORIES: 1911 births, 2001 deaths, American autobiographers, American novelists, Journalists from New Jersey, People from Montclair, New Jersey, People from Plainfield, New Jersey

Frank Bunker Gilbreth Jr. (March 17, 1911  – February 18, 2001) was an American journalist and author. He was born in Plainfield, New Jersey. He co-authored, with his sister Ernestine, the autobiographical bestsellers Cheaper by the Dozen and Belles on Their Toes.

Gilbreth died on February 18, 2001, aged 89, in Charleston, South Carolina. 

[[Frank Bunker Gilbreth]]

CATEGORIES: 1868 births, 1924 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Engineers from Maine, American autobiographers, Writers from Maine, Scientists from Maine, Writers from New Jersey, Scientists from New Jersey

Frank Bunker Gilbreth (July 7, 1868 – June 14, 1924) was an American engineer, consultant, and author. He was known as an early supporter of scientific management and time and motion study. He is best known as the father and main figure of Cheaper by the Dozen.

Both he and his wife Lillian Moller Gilbreth were industrial engineers. They were key figures to the study of industrial engineering.

[[Fairfield, Maine]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Maine

Fairfield is a town in Somerset County, Maine, United States. The population was 6,735 at the 2010 census.

[[Lillian Moller Gilbreth]]

CATEGORIES: 1878 births, 1972 deaths, Deaths from stroke, American psychologists, Engineers from California, American educators, Writers from Oakland, California, Scientists from Oakland, California

Lillian Evelyn Moller Gilbreth (May 24, 1878 – January 2, 1972) was an American psychologist, industrial engineer, consultant, and educator. She was known for her works with psychology to time-and-motion studies. She was called "a genius in the art of living." 

Gilbreth, one of the first female engineers to earn a Ph.D.. She and her husband, Frank Bunker Gilbreth, were experts who work to the study of industrial engineering.

Ilana Rose Glazer (born April 12, 1987) is an American comedian, director, producer, writer, and actress. She co-created and co-starred, with Abbi Jacobson, the Comedy Central series Broad City. [[Madonna and Child with Two Angels (Pittoni)]]

[[False vacuum]]

CATEGORIES: Physics

A false vacuum is an idea from theoretical physics: In quantum field theory, such a vacuum might exist for a very long time, before it changes its state. Much like with a true vacuum, a false vacuum exists where the energy is minimal. In the case of a true vacuum, this is at a global minimum of the energy function. With a false vaccum, the energy function is only at a local minimum. As is illustrated in the figure, there is a "peak" between the local minimum and the global minimum of the energy function. 

The process by which the system changes its energy state is called bubble nucleation: Somewhere in the universe, a bubble will appear, with a lower energy state inside the bubble. This bubble will then spread and change the energy state of its surroundings.

[[Ryan Prescott (actor)]]

CATEGORIES: 1989 births, Living people, English television actors, People from Merseyside

Ryan Andrew Prescott (born 21 January 1989) is an English actor. He is best known his the role as Ryan Connor on the long-running ITV soap opera Coronation Street, he began starring in the role in 2018. In 2011, Prescott played the role of Flynn Buchanan in ITV's fellow soap opera Emmerdale.

Prescott was born in Southport, England.

[[President of Estonia]]

CATEGORIES: Presidents of Estonia

The President of the Republic of Estonia (Eesti Vabariigi President) is the head of state of the Republic of Estonia. The current President is Kersti Kaljulaid, elected by Parliament on 3 October 2016.

[[Konstantin Päts]]

CATEGORIES: 1874 births, 1956 deaths, Presidents of Estonia, Prime Ministers of Estonia

Konstantin Päts (23 February – 18 January 1956) was the President of Estonia from 1938 to 1940.

[[Lennart Meri]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2006 deaths, Deaths from brain cancer, Presidents of Estonia, Estonian writers

Lennart Georg Meri (29 March 1929 – 14 March 2006) was an Estonian politician, writer, and movie director. He was the second President of Estonia from 1992 to 2001.

[[Kersti Kaljulaid]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 births, Living people, Presidents of Estonia, Current national leaders

Kersti Kaljulaid (born 30 December 1969) is an Estonian politician. She is the fifth and current President of Estonia, in office since 10 October 2016. She is the first female head of state of Estonia and the youngest ever President, age 46 at the time of her election.

[[Prime Minister of Estonia]]

CATEGORIES: Prime Ministers of Estonia

The Prime Minister of Estonia (Estonian: peaminister, literally Main Minister or Head Minister) is the head of government of the Republic of Estonia. The prime minister is nominated by the President and confirmed by the Parliament.

The current Prime Minister is Kaja Kallas of the Reform Party.

[[Andres Tarand]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, Living people, Prime Ministers of Estonia, People from Tallinn, Former MEPs

Andres Tarand (born 11 January 1940) is an Estonian politician. He was the Prime Minister of Estonia from 1994 to 1995. He was also a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) for the Social Democratic Party, part of the Party of European Socialists, between 2004 and 2009. 

[[Mart Laar]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, Living people, Prime Ministers of Estonia

Mart Laar (born 22 April 1960) is an Estonian politician and historian. He was the Prime Minister of Estonia from 1992 to 1994 and from 1999 to 2002. He is a member of the centre-right Isamaa party.

[[Jüri Ratas]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 births, Living people, Prime Ministers of Estonia, People from Tallinn

Jüri Ratas (born 2 July 1978) is an Estonian politician. He was the Prime Minister of Estonia from 2016 until 2021. He has been the Leader of the Centre Party since 2016. 

[[Somerdale, New Jersey]]

CATEGORIES: Boroughs in New Jersey

Somerdale is a borough in Camden County, New Jersey, United States. As of the 2010 United States Census, the borough's population was 5,151.

[[Mariya Shtepa]]

CATEGORIES: Ukrainian writers, 2020 deaths, 1925 births

Mariya Shtepa (Ukrainian: Марія Степанівна Штепа, 13 March 1925 — 1 June 2020) was an Ukrainian writer. She was involved in the Ukrainian War of Independence. In 1942 she became a member of the Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists.

On 22 August 2016 she was awarded the Order of Princess Olga of the III degree by the Ukrainian president President Petro Poroshenko. 

Shtepa died on 1 June 2020 in Chortkiv, Ukraine at the age of 95.

[[Andrée Champagne]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Canadian movie actors, Canadian television actors, Politicians from Quebec, Actors from Quebec

Andrée Champagne, CAN (July 17, 1939spaced ndashJune 5, 2020) was a Canadian actress and Conservative politician. She was born in Saint-Hyacinthe, Quebec. She was a member of the House of Commons from 1984 to 1993. Champagne was the Senator for Quebec from 2005 to 2014. She played Donalda in the television movie Les Belles Histoires des pays d'en haut.

Champagne died on June 5, 2020 at the age of 80.

[[Lester Ryan]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, 2020 deaths, Irish sportspeople, Road accident deaths

Lester Ryan (18 April 1959 – 6 June 2020) was an Irish sportsman. He was born in County Kilkenny. He played hurling with his local club Clara and with the Kilkenny intercounty team. Ryan won two All-Ireland Minor Hurling medals, three Leinster Senior Hurling medals and appeared in two All-Ireland finals.

Ryan was killed in a bike crash on 6 June 2020 in Gowran, Ireland at the age of 61.

[[Ramadan Shalah]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from surgical complications, Palestinian terrorists, Palestinian Muslims

Ramadan Abdullah Mohammed Shalah (1 January 1958 – 6 June 2020) was a Palestinian militant. He was the leader of Palestinian Islamic Jihad (PIJ) between 27 October 1995 and 2018. PIJ has been designated a terrorist organisation by the United States, the European Union, the United Kingdom, Japan, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and Israel. 

In 2006, he was placed on the United States FBI Most Wanted Terrorists list.

In April 2018, Shalah suffered a many strokes. He died on 6 June 2020 in Lebanon from heart surgery-related problems, aged 62.

[[Andrea Veggio]]

CATEGORIES: Italian Roman Catholics, Bishops, 1923 births, 2020 deaths

Andrea Veggio (28 August 1923 – 6 June 2020) was an Italian Prelate of Roman Catholic Church. He was born in Manerba del Garda, Italy. 

He was ordained a priest on 29 June 1947. He was appointed auxiliary bishop to the Diocese of Verona on 1 August 1983. He was ordained bishop on 8 September 1983. He retired from the diocese of Verona on 8 September 2001.

Veggio died on 6 June 2020 in Negrar, Italy at the age of 96.

[[Jean-Alphonse Turrettini]]

CATEGORIES: 1671 births, 1737 deaths, People from Geneva, Theologians

Jean-Alphonse Turrettini (August 1671 – May 1737) was a theologian from the Republic of Geneva. The son of François Turrettini, he was born at Geneva. ... Here he became pastor of the Italian congregation, and in 1697 professor of church history, and later (1705During the next forty years of his life he enjoyed great influence in Geneva as the advocate of a more liberal theology than had prevailed under the preceding generation, and it was largely through his instrumentality that the rule obliging ministers to subscribe to the Helvetic Consensus was abolished in 1706, and the Consensus itself renounced in 1725. He also wrote and labored for the promotion of union between the Reformed and Lutheran Churches, his most important work in this connection being Nubes testium pro moderato et pacifico de rebus theologicis judicio, et instituenda inter Protestantes concordia (Geneva, 1729). Besides this he wrote Cogitationes et dissertationes theologicae, on the principles of natural and revealed religion (2 vols., Geneva, 1737; in French, Traité de la vérité de la religion chrétienne) and commentaries on Thessalonians and Romans.2) of theology

[[Inherent Vice (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2014 crime movies, 2014 comedy movies, 2010s criminal comedy movies, American criminal comedy movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Paul Thomas Anderson

Inherent Vice is a 2014 American neo-noir movie based on Thomas Pynchon's 2009 novel of the same name, and written and directed by Paul Thomas Anderson. It follows a stoner hippie investigating the case related to his ex-girlfriend and her wealthy boyfriend. The cast includes Joaquin Phoenix, Josh Brolin, Owen Wilson, Katherine Waterston, Eric Roberts, Reese Witherspoon, Benicio del Toro, Jena Malone, Joanna Newsom, Jeannie Berlin, Maya Rudolph, Michael K. Williams and Martin Short. The movie had a limited theatrical release in the United States on December 12, 2014. It had mixed responses with critics liking Phoenix's performance and disliking the plot. 

[[Jeannie Berlin]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, Living people, American movie actors, American stage actors, American television actors, American voice actors, Actors from Los Angeles, California

Jeannie Berlin (born Jeannie Brette May, November 1, 1949) is an American actress and screenwriter. She was born in Los Angeles. She is known for her role in the 1972 movie The Heartbreak Kid,  for which she received Academy Award and Golden Globe nominations. 

She later played the leading role in Sheila Levine Is Dead and Living in New York (1975). She also starred in Margaret (2011), Inherent Vice (2014) and Cafe Society (2016).

[[Michael K. Williams]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 births, 2021 deaths, American stage actors, American voice actors, American movie actors, American television actors, Actors from New York City

Michael Kenneth Williams (November 22, 1966 – September 6, 2021) was an American actor. He played Omar Little on the HBO drama series The Wire and Albert "Chalky" White on the HBO series Boardwalk Empire. 

Williams died on the morning of September 6, 2021 at his New York City apartment at the age of 54. His death is being investigated as a possible drug overdose.

[[The Heartbreak Kid (1972 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 comedy movies, 1970s romance movies, American romantic comedy movies, Movies based on books

The Heartbreak Kid is a 1972 dark romantic comedy directed by Elaine May, and written by Neil Simon. It starred Charles Grodin, Jeannie Berlin, Eddie Albert, Audra Lindley, Doris Roberts and Cybill Shepherd. It is based on the short story "A Change of Plan", written by Bruce Jay Friedman.

It is #91 on AFI's 100 Years... 100 Laughs, a list of the funniest American movies ever made.

It was remade in 2007 as The Heartbreak Kid starring Ben Stiller and Malin Åkerman.

[[Audra Lindley]]

CATEGORIES: 1918 births, 1997 deaths, Deaths from leukemia, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American stage actors, Actors from Los Angeles, California

Audra Marie Lindley (September 24, 1918 – October 16, 1997) was an American actress. She was most famous for her role as landlady Helen Roper on the sitcom Three's Company and its spin-off The Ropers. She was born in Los Angeles.

From 1972 to 1979, she was married to actor James Whitmore.

Lindley died of leukemia on October 16, 1997 at a Los Angeles hospital, aged 79.

[[Jimmy O. Yang]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, 1987 births, Actors from Hong Kong, Chinese movie actors, Chinese television actors, Chinese voice actors, Naturalized citizens of the United States, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, Actors from Los Angeles, California, Comedians from Los Angeles, California

Jimmy O. Yang (歐陽萬成; born June 11, 1987) is a Hong Kong-American actor, stand-up comedian, and writer. He is best known for starring as Jian-Yang in the HBO comedy series Silicon Valley.

[[Hsu Kun-yuan]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, 2020 deaths, Suicides by jumping, Taiwanese politicians

Hsu Kun-yuan (1 May 1957 – 6 June 2020) was a Taiwanese politician. He was born in Kaohsiung, Taiwan. He was a member of the Kuomintang. He was a member of the Kaohsiung City Council from 1994 until his death. From 2010 to 2014 and again from 2018 until his death, he was Speaker of the City Council.

Hsu killed himself after jumping off his home in Kaohsiung on 6 June 2020, aged 63.

[[Lynne Carol]]

CATEGORIES: 1914 births, 1990 deaths

Joseph Caroline Gertude Mary Faith Harber (29 June 1914 – 30 June 1990), better known as Lynne Carol, was a Welsh born (but often described as English) actress.

She is best known for her primarily roles in television serieses and telemovies, as playing busybody Martha Longhurst in the soap opera Coronation Street from the second episode in 1960 until the character was killed in 1964.

[[Whiffs]]

CATEGORIES: 1975 comedy movies, 1970s crime movies, American criminal comedy movies

Whiffs is a 1975 American crime comedy movie directed by Ted Post and starring Elliott Gould, Eddie Albert, Harry Guardino, Godfrey Cambridge, Jennifer O'Neill. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox and was nominated for an Academy Award in 1976.

[[Las furias]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 drama movies, Argentine movies

Las furias is a 1960 Argentine drama movie directed by Vlasta Lah and based on the play of the same name. It stars Mecha Ortiz, Olga Zubarry, Aída Luz, Alba Múgica.

[[The Motorcycle Diaries (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2004 drama movies, 2000s biographical movies, American biographical movies, American drama movies, British biographical movies, British drama movies, Argentine movies, Brazilian movies, French drama movies, Chilean movies, German drama movies, Peruvian movies, American independent movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Walter Salles

The Motorcycle Diaries (Diarios de motocicleta) is a 2004 Argentine Brazilian Chilean American British Pervian German French biographical drama movie directed by Walter Salles and based on the novel of the same name by Che Guevara. It stars Gael García Bernal, Rodrigo de la Serna, Mercedes Morán, Jean Pierre Noher and was distributed by Focus Features. It was nominated for 2 Oscars and won an Academy Award in 2005.

[[Katy Cavanagh]]

CATEGORIES: 1973 births, Living people, Alumni of the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art, English television actors, English stage actors, English radio actors, Actors from Greater Manchester, People from Bolton

Kathryn Sarah Collins (born 12 December 1973), known professionally as Katy Cavanagh, is an English actress. She is best known for portraying the roles of Julie Carp in the long-running ITV soap opera Coronation Street from 2008 to 2015, PC Mel Draper in the BBC One drama series The Cops from 1998 to 2001, and Anita Kenrick in the ITV drama soap opera Bob & Rose in 2001. She was born in North Shields, Northumberland, but was raised in Bolton, Greater Manchester.

[[Dwarf rocket frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Frogs

The dwarf rocket frog (Litoria dorsalis) is a frog from Papua New Guinea. It lives in forests, wetlands and grasslands.

The dwarf rocket frog may have moved from Australia to New Guinea 15,000 years ago.

[[Lingala language]]

CATEGORIES: Niger-Congo languages, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Republic of the Congo

Lingala is a Bantu language spoken in the North-East of the Democratic Republic of the Congo and the North of the Republic of the Congo. It has the status of national language in those two countries.

[[96 (number)]]

CATEGORIES: Integers

Ninety-six is a number. It comes between ninety-five and ninety-seven, and is an even number. It is divisible by 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 12, 16, 24, 32, 48, and 96.

[[97 (number)]]

CATEGORIES: Integers, Prime numbers

Ninety-seven is a number. It comes between ninety-six and ninety-eight, and is an odd number. It is also a prime number.

[[98 (number)]]

CATEGORIES: Integers

Ninety-eight is a number. It comes between ninety-seven and ninety-nine, and is an even number. It is divisible by 1, 2, 7, 14, 49, and 98.

In Roman numerals, it is XCVIII.

[[99 (number)]]

CATEGORIES: Integers

Ninety-nine is a number. It comes between ninety-eight and one hundred, and is an odd number. It is divisible by 1, 3, 9, 11, 33, and 99.

[[Norilsk railway]]

CATEGORIES: Transport in Russia, Rail transport, Siberia

The Norilsk railway connects the river port of Dudinka with  the mining towns of Kayerkan, Norilsk,  and Talnach. Different ore mines and industries are also connected to the line. The line has a single track. Originally, it was done as a narrow-gauge railway (gauge: 1m); later it was re-done as a Russian standard gauge (of 1.5m). It used to be electrified, but this was removed in the 1990s. Since then it only runs freight trains.

A paved highway from Dudinka to Norilsk was built in the 1990s; since then, the Norilsk railway no longer runs passenger services.

The railway is owned by the mining company.

The line has a length of a bit over 100, in total there are over 300 of track.

[[Policja]]

CATEGORIES: Law enforcement agencies, Poland

The police force in Poland is called policja. It was created in 1990 and has about 100,000 officers. Every Polish region has its own police department, and Warsaw has a separate department, called the Capital Police Command (Komenda Stołeczna Policji). It also counts the employees of BOA/SPAP, special police units. Most of the towns and some villages in Poland also have their city guards, which provide help to the police.

The Polish Police Headquarters is located in Warsaw. Polish police schools are located in Piła, Słupsk, Katowice, and Legionowo.

Previous Polish police was called Milicja Obywatelska, it was active during the Polish Peoples Republic.

[[Sebastián Sichel]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 births, Chilean businesspeople, Chilean politicians, Chilean lawyers, People from Santiago, Living people

Sebastián Iglesias Sichel Ramírez (born 30 July 1977) is a Chilean politician and lawyer. He is current president of the Banco del Estado de Chile, the country's state bank.

He previously served as Minister of Social Development and Family and former Executive Vice President of Corfo, under the second government of Sebastián Piñera.

He studied at the Alexander Fleming Lyceum. He received his law degree from the Pontificia Universidad Católica (PUC). He also received his his master's degree in public law from the same university. He was a professor of constitutional law at the San Sebastián University from 2016 to 2018.

He is married to journalist Bárbara Encina since 2008. Together, they have three children.

[[Triangle Shirtwaist Company fire]]

On March 25, 1911 a fire broke out in the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory  which was located on floors 8, 9 and 10 of the Asch Building at 23–29 Washington Pl, Manhattan,  New York City. The fire stopped after 20 minutes but 146 workers died.

The company's owners, Max Blanck and Isaac Harris, who survived the fire by going to the building's roof when the fire started, were indicted on charges of first- and second-degree manslaughter in mid-April; the pair's trial began on December 4, 1911. Max Steuer, counsel for the defendants, managed to destroy the credibility of one of the survivors, Kate Alterman, by asking her to repeat her testimony a number of times, which she did without altering key phrases. Steuer argued to the jury that Alterman and possibly other witnesses had memorized their statements, and might even have been told what to say by the prosecutors. The prosecution charged that the owners knew the exit doors were locked at the time in question. The investigation found that the locks were intended to be locked during working hours based on the findings from the fire, but the defense stressed that the prosecution failed to prove that the owners knew that. The jury acquitted the two men of first- and second-degree manslaughter, but they were found liable of wrongful death during a subsequent civil suit in 1913 in which plaintiffs were awarded compensation in the amount of $75 per deceased victim. The insurance company paid Blanck and Harris about $60,000 more than the reported losses, or about $400 per casualty.In 1913, Blanck was once again arrested for locking the door in his factory during working hours. He was fined $20 which was the minimum amount the fine could be.

Because of the lax labor laws at the time, this tragedy paved the way for the rise of factory workers safety protections and the formation of workers Unions such as the International Ladies Garment Union.

[[Thunder and Lightning (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1970s action movies, 1977 comedy movies, American action movies, American comedy movies

Thunder and Lightning is a 1977 American action comedy movie directed by Corey Allen and starring Kate Jackson, David Carradine, Sterling Holloway, Patrick Cranshaw, Charles Napier, George Murdock, Ron Feinberg. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[The Spy Who Loved Me (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 movies, 1970s spy movies, 1970s action movies, James Bond movies, Movies with underwater settings, Movies directed by Lewis Gilbert

The Spy Who Loved Me is a 1977 British spy action movie directed by Lewis Gilbert and is the 10th movie in the James Bond franchise. It stars Roger Moore, Barbara Bach, Curd Jürgens, Bernard Lee, Geoffrey Keen, Caroline Munro, Richard Kiel, Lois Maxwell, Desmond Llewelyn, Shane Rimmer and was distributed by United Artists. It was nominated for 3 Academy Awards in 1978.

[[Clémentine Valverde]]

CATEGORIES: 1992 births, Living people, French water polo players

Clémentine Valverde (born September 23, 1992 in Longjumeau) is a French water polo player. She was selected for the France team in 2010. She participated at the 2013 Summer Universiade.

Clémentine Valverde was twice winner of the Coupe de France with the ASPTT Nancy water polo. She then joined the Olympic Nice Natation where she won the Championship.

[[Aurore Sacré]]

CATEGORIES: 1993 births, Living people, French water polo players

Aurore Sacré  (born on April 13, 1993 in Saint-Jean-d'Angély) is a French water polo player.

She competed with the French women's national water polo team at the 2014 European Women's Water Polo Championship, the 2015 Women's World Water Polo Championship, and the 2016 Women's European Water Polo Championship, 2016 FINA Women's Water Polo World League, and 2017 Women's World Water Polo Championship.

She plays at the Angers Nautic Club.

She was a member of the France women's national water polo team at the 2015 World Aquatics Championships, and 2017 World Aquatics Championships.

[[John Miller (pitcher)]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Baltimore Orioles players, Sportspeople from Baltimore, Maryland

John Ernest Miller (May 30, 1941 – June 5, 2020) was an American professional baseball player. He played in all or part of five seasons in Major League Baseball for the Baltimore Orioles between 1962 through 1967. He was born in Baltimore, Maryland.

Miller died on June 5, 2020 at the age of 79.

[[Marian Tomaszewski]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 2020 deaths, Polish military people

Marian Bronisław Tomaszewski (13 August 1922 – 5 June 2020) was a Polish scout leader. He was an officer of the 2nd Polish Corps and a tank commander in the 6th Armoured Regiment "Children of Lwów" during World War II.

After the war he spent nearly 45 years in exile in Italy and the United Kingdom. He was one of the leaders of the Polish community in Manchester.

Tomaszewski died on 5 June 2020 in Bury, England at the age of 97.

[[Reche Caldwell]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 births, 2020 deaths, American football wide receivers, Murders by firearm in the United States, New England Patriots players, San Diego Chargers players, Sportspeople from Tampa, Florida, St. Louis Rams players, Washington Redskins players

Donald Reche Caldwell Jr. ( rih or ' REE; March 28, 1979 – June 6, 2020) was an American professional football player. He was born in Tampa, Florida.

Caldwell was a wide receiver in the National Football League (NFL) for six seasons in the 2000s.  Caldwell played college football for the Florida Gators. He played professionally for the San Diego Chargers, New England Patriots and Washington Redskins of the NFL. 

Caldwell was shot and killed during a robbery in Tampa on June 6, 2020 at the age of 41.

[[Ken Riley]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, American football cornerbacks, American football quarterbacks, Cincinnati Bengals players, Sportspeople from Florida

Kenneth Jerome Riley (August 6, 1947 – June 7, 2020) was a professional American football cornerback. He was born in Bartow, Florida. Riley played his entire career for the Cincinnati Bengals, in the American Football League in 1969 and in the NFL from 1970 through 1983. In college, he played for the Florida A&M Rattlers for Florida A&M University.

Riley died on June 7, 2020 of a heart attack at the age of 72.

[[Albert S. Ruddy]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, Living people, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Canadian movie producers, Canadian television producers, American television producers, Movie producers from New York City, People from Montreal

Albert S. Ruddy (born March 28, 1930) is a Canadian-born American movie and television producer. He was born in Montreal, Quebec. In 1972, he produced The Godfather and won his first of two Oscars for Best Picture. In 1974, Ruddy produced The Longest Yard. Ruddy produced director and animator Ralph Bakshi's satirical movie Coonskin (1975).

[[Kennett, Missouri]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Missouri, County seats in Missouri

Kennett is a city in, and the county seat of, Dunklin County, Missouri, United States. The city is located 4 east of Arkansas and 20 from the Mississippi River. It has a population of 10,932 according to the 2010 Census.

[[Keegan de Lancie]]

CATEGORIES: 1984 births, Living people, American television actors, Actors from Los Angeles, California

John Keegan de Lancie (born October 31, 1984) is an American actor and the son of John de Lancie and Marnie Mosiman. He is best known for his role as Q (or Q Junior) in Star Trek: Voyager, where he played the son of Q, portrayed by his father John de Lancie in the episode "Q2." 

He also appeared in several other popular television shows such as Ally McBeal and The Drew Carey Show. Keegan has one brother named Owen de Lancie (born 1987).

[[Damnation Alley]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 movies, 1970s science fiction movies, American science fiction movies, Movies based on books, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Jack Smight, Post-apocalyptic movies

Damnation Alley is a 1977 American science fiction movie directed by Jack Smight and based on the 1969 novel of the same name by Roger Zelazny. It stars Jan-Michael Vincent, George Peppard, Dominique Sanda, Paul Winfield, Jackie Earle Haley, Murray Hamilton and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Julia (1977 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 drama movies, American drama movies, Movies based on books, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Fred Zinnemann

Julia is a 1977 American drama movie directed by Fred Zinnemann and based on the 1973 novel Pentimento by Lillian Hellman. It stars Vanessa Redgrave, Jason Robards, Jane Fonda, Hal Holbrook, Rosemary Murphy, Maximilian Schell, Meryl Streep, Lisa Pelikan and was distributed by 20th Century Fox. It was nominated for 11 Oscars and won 3 Academy Awards in 1978.

Unfaithfully Yours is a 1984 American romantic comedy movie directed by Howard Zieff and is based on the remake of the 1948 movie of the same name. It stars Dudley Moore, Nastassja Kinski, Albert Brooks, Armand Assante, Cassie Yates, Jan Triska and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

A View to a Kill is a 1985 British American spy action movie directed by John Glen and is the 14th movie in the James Bond franchise. [[Netherlands Institute for Art History]]

CATEGORIES: Libraries in Europe, The Hague, Buildings and structures in the Netherlands

The Netherlands Institute for Art History, also known as RKD, is a large institution in The Hague in The Netherlands. It is devoted to the study of art history and has a very large library. The initials RKD stand for "Rijksbureau voor Kunsthistorische Documentatie", the older Dutch name of the institute.

The Netherlands Institute for Art History opened in 1932. Three men made the biggest contribution to the Institute's collection. The first man was Cornelis Hofstede de Groot (1863–1930). He was a collector, art historian and museum curator. In his will, he left the RKD his large collection of documents. These included about 100,000 photos of Dutch paintings and drawings from the 17th century. The second man was Frits Lugt (1884-1970). He was also a collector and art historian. He gave the institute over 100,000 reproductions of paintings, 22,000 auction catalogues and thousands of books. The third man was  E.A. van Beresteyn (1876-1948), an archivist and historian. He gave the institute a lot of material on Dutch portrait painting.

The institute has a very large library of 450,000 books and around 3,000 magazines. Much of their material is digitized—very high quality pictures of book and magazine pages which are available on the internet. Many paintings and drawings are also digitized and available on the internet. The institute's website has many pages about artists with information on their life and work. Each artist has their own RKD number. The website also has a thesaurus of words used to describe art and architecture.

[[Vivaan Shah]]

[[Snoot boot]]

A snoot boot is a protective covering for the nose.  Snoot boots are used to keep the nose warm. Theyoriginated at the University of Illinois in 1961.  They were knitted by students in Busey Hall. For a while, they became popular at American universities. 

[[Hurricane Genevieve (2014)]]

CATEGORIES: July 2014 events, August 2014 events, Pacific typhoons

Hurricane Genevieve, also known as Typhoon Genevieve, was a strong and long-lived tropical cyclone that became the fourth-strongest tropical cyclone of the 2014 Pacific typhoon season. It was also the first tropical cyclone to exist in all the three North Pacific tropical cyclone basins since Dora in 1999. Genevieve formed from a tropical wave well to the south-east of Hawaii on July 25, but weakened quickly into a remnant low due to high wind shear on July 28. The system briefly reformed on July to the south of Hawaii before dissipating once again on July 31. 

Several days later, on August 2, Genevieve regenerated. Owing to better conditions for intensification, Genevieve began to rapidly intensify, reaching hurricane strength on August 6 and major hurricane strength on August 7 shortly before crossing the International Date Line into the Western Pacific basin, where Genevieve was reclassified as a typhoon by the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA).

After reaching peak intensity as a Category 5 typhoon on August 7 and 8 to the west-southwest , Genevieve began to weaken as conditions worsened. The storm rapidly weakened to severe tropical storm strength on August 10. On August 12, the JMA downgraded Genevieve to a tropical depression, and Genevieve dissipated on August 14.

[[NeXT]]

CATEGORIES: Companies based in California, Defunct companies of the United States, American technology companies

NeXT Inc. was an American computer and software company. It was created after Steve Jobs quit his job at Apple Inc.. It was a failure but it did get him back at Apple and as CEO. The Mac OS x's core was based entirely on the NeXT computer. Apple bought NeXT for $429 million. 

Steve Jobs used $12 million of his own money to make NeXT and it did pay off because he got his job back.

[[Rockhole frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Frogs

The rockhole frog, Australian cross-banded tree frog or skipping frog (Litoria meiriana) is a small frog from Australia. It lives in Western Australia and the Northern Territory.

Male adult frogs are about 2 cm long and females are 2.2 cm long.  They have webbed hind feet but their front feet are not webbed.  Some are dark brown with dark green spots and some are less clear.  Some have spots on their thighs.  Some have white spots near their eyes.

They live near permanent bodies of water and do not like puddles or vernal pools that dry up.  They live in holes in rocks and sometimes in caves or near waterfalls.  They are so light that they can skip on the surface of the water like a skipping stone.

They lay eggs in pools near the bottoms of tall rocks, 30–40 eggs at a time.

[[Castilian languages]]

CATEGORIES: Romance languages

The Castillian languages are a branch of Romance languages. They were first spoken in central Spain, and then spread to nearly all of Spain. The main language in the branch is Spanish, which has around 480 million speakers around the world. Since the colonial era, Spanish has been spoken in Latin America.

[[Iberian Romance languages]]

CATEGORIES: Romance languages

The Iberian Romance, or Ibero-Romance, languages are a branch of Romance languages. They were first spoken in Iberia. There are two branches of Iberian Romance languages, Occitano-Romance and West Iberian. The main two languages in the branch are Spanish (Castilian) and Portuguese. They came from a dialect of Vulgar Latin spoken in Iberia after the Roman Empire ended. Spanish and Portuguese spread to Latin America during the colonial era.

[[Carly Joy Wessels]]

[[West Iberian languages]]

CATEGORIES: Romance languages

The West Iberian languages are a branch of Romance languages. They were first spoken in central and western parts of Iberia. Spanish and Portuguese are the main languages in the branch. They have been spread to Latin America since the colonial era. There are five branches of West Iberian languages. They are Castilian, Galician-Portuguese, Astur-Leonese, Barranquian, and Pyrenean–Mozarabic. Until recently, all speakers of West Iberian languages could understand each other, but now the branches are too different.

[[Marcelle Manson]]

She competed for the South Africa women's national water polo team in the 2017 World Aquatics Championships.

[[Latino-Faliscan languages]]

CATEGORIES: Indo-European languages, Languages of Europe

The Latino-Faliscan languages are a large branch of Italic languages. They were first spoken in what is now Italy. It is the only branch with languages still spoken. The only branch of Latino-Faliscan languages with languages still spoken is the Romance languages, which came from Latin. Latin was spread across Europe by the Roman Empire, and Latin then split into many branches over time. There were also at least three other Latino-Faliscan languages that are now extinct.

[[Galician-Portuguese]]

CATEGORIES: Romance languages

Galician-Portuguese is a branch of Romance languages. They were first spoken in Northwestern Iberia and spread to the south. They are now spoken in all of Portugal and Northwestern Spain. The main two languages are Galician and Portuguese. All Galician-Portuguese languages were once all the same language, but have since split. Portuguese was spread to Brazil during the colonial era and it is also now spoken there.

[[Bonnie Pointer]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2020 deaths, American R&B singers, Deaths from cardiac arrest, Singers from Oakland, California

Patricia Eva "Bonnie" Pointer (July 11, 1950 – June 8, 2020) was an American singer. She is most notable for being a member of the R&B singing group The Pointer Sisters. She also had her own solo hits after leaving the group in 1977. Her disco cover of The Elgins' "Heaven Must Have Sent You" became a U.S. Top 20 pop hit in 1979. She was born in Oakland, California.

On June 8, 2020, Pointer died due to cardiac arrest in Los Angeles. She was 69.

[[Brooklyn, Pennsylvania]]

CATEGORIES: Unincorporated communities in Pennsylvania

Brooklyn is an unincorporated community in Susquehanna County, Pennsylvania, United States. The community is located along Pennsylvania Route 167 3.8 northwest of Hop Bottom. Brooklyn has a post office with ZIP code 18813, which opened on March 20, 1830.

[[Susquehanna County, Pennsylvania]]

CATEGORIES: 1810s establishments in Pennsylvania, 1812 establishments in the United States, Pennsylvania counties

Susquehanna County is a county located in the U.S. state of Pennsylvania.  As of the 2010 census, the population was 43,356. Its county seat is Montrose. The county was created on February 21, 1810, from part of Luzerne County.

[[Montrose, Pennsylvania]]

CATEGORIES: Boroughs in Pennsylvania, County seats in Pennsylvania

Montrose (pronounced mon-TROSE) is a borough in Susquehanna County, Pennsylvania, United States, 37 north by west of Scranton. The land is elevated about 1,400 feet (427 m) above sea level. It is the Susquehanna County seat.

[[Hop Bottom, Pennsylvania]]

CATEGORIES: Boroughs in Pennsylvania

Hop Bottom is a borough of Susquehanna County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 337 as of the 2010 census.

[[Jean-Michel Cadiot]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 deaths, 1952 births, French novelists, French journalists

Jean-Michel Cadiot (23 December 1952 – 1 June 2020) was a French writer and journalist.

In the 2007 French legislative election, Cadiot ran for Deputy under the UDF-MoDem ticket in Val-d'Oise's 8th constituency. He only had 3.32% of the votes in the first round. 

In 2008, he ran in the Canton of Sarcelles-Nord-Est, earning 3.48% of the vote.

Cadiot died on 1 June 2020 at the age of 67.

[[Milena Benini]]

CATEGORIES: 1966 births, 2020 deaths, Croatian writers, Translators, People from Zagreb

Milena Benini (1966 - 4 June 2020) was a Croatian science fiction writer and translator. She won the SFERA Award six times (1999, 2006, 2010, 2012, 2016, 2017). She was born Zagreb. She wrote short stories and romantic stories. 

Benini died on 4 June 2020 from an illness.

[[Frank Bey]]

CATEGORIES: American blues singers, Singers from Georgia (U.S. state), Singers from Pennsylvania, 1946 births, 2020 deaths

Frank Bey (born Frank Bass, January 17, 1946 – June 7, 2020) was an American blues singer. He changed his last name from Bass to Bey at age 27. He joined the Moorish Science Temple of America. He was born in Millen, Georgia.

By 1996, Bey returned to singing in the Philadelphia area.  In 1998, Bey's debut album, Steppin' Out, was released on MAG Records.  He released Blues in the Pocket in 2007 on Jeffhouse Records.  

Bey died on June 7, 2020, after a long illness in Glenolden, Pennsylvania at the age of 74.

Glenolden is a borough in Delaware County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 7,153 at the 2010 census.

[[Tony Dunne]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Irish footballers, Irish football managers, Sportspeople from Dublin

Anthony Peter Dunne (24 July 1941 – 8 June 2020) was an Irish footballer and manager. He appeared at left-back for Manchester United. He won 33 caps for the Republic of Ireland, playing for the national team during 1962 to 1975. He was the Irish Footballer of the Year in 1969. He was born in Dublin.

Dunne died on 8 June 2020, aged 78.

[[Estonian alphabet]]

CATEGORIES: Latin alphabet, Uralic languages

The Estonian alphabet is based on the Latin alphabet with German influence. Because of German influence, Estonian contains the letters Ä, Ö and Ü. The Estonian alphabet originally has only 23 letters. However, including letters that are used in words borrowed from other languages, it may have 27 letters or 32 letters. They are the same as in English, with the addition of four letters - Õ, Ä, Ö and Ü. These four letters are placed after W and before X in the Estonian alphabet. The letters Š and Ž also exist in Estonian, but they are only used in words borrowed from other languages. The letter Š is placed after S in the Estonian alphabet, and Z is placed after Š in Estonian. The letter Ž is placed after Z. All together the order is as follows:

A B (C) D E F G H I J K L M N O P (Q) R S Š Z Ž T U V (W) Õ Ä Ö Ü (X) (Y)

F, Š, Z and Ž are only used in words borrowed from other languages. C, Q, W, X and Y are not used in Estonian, and only occur in names from other languages.

The original Estonian alphabet consists of 23 letters in the order as it follows:

A B D E G H I J K L M N O P R S T U V Õ Ä Ö Ü

Including the letters that only occur in words borrowed from other languages, the Estonian alphabet consists of 27 letters in the order as it follows:

A B D E F G H I J K L M N O P R S Š Z Ž T U V Õ Ä Ö Ü

Including the letters that are not used in Estonian and only occur in words from other languages, the Estonian alphabet consists of 32 letters in the order as it follows:

A B C D E F G H I J K L M N O P Q R S Š Z Ž T U V W Õ Ä Ö Ü X Y 

[[Manuel Felguérez]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, Mexican painters, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Mexico

Manuel Felguérez Barra (December 12, 1928 — June 8, 2020) was a Mexican abstract artist. He was part of the Generación de la Ruptura which broke with the muralist movement of Diego Rivera and others in the mid 20th century.

[[Marion Hänsel]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 2020 deaths, Belgian movie directors, Belgian movie producers, Belgian movie actors, Belgian screenwriters, French movie directors, French movie producers, French movie actors

Marion Hänsel (12 February 1949 – 8 June 2020) was a French-born Belgian movie director, producer, actress and screenwriter. Her best known movie was Between the Devil and the Deep Blue Sea. It was entered into the 1995 Cannes Film Festival.

Hänsel died on 8 June 2020, aged 71.

[[Italian alphabet]]

CATEGORIES: Alphabet, Italy, Latin alphabet, Romance languages, Writing systems

The Italian alphabet is the same as the English alphabet, but without J, K, W, X or Y. These letters, however, still occur in words borrowed from other languages. The letter H mostly occurs after C or G in Italian. This is because in Italian, C before E or I makes a soft sound, and G before E or I makes a soft sound. To preserve the hard sound, you add an H after C or G. The Italian Alphabet is as follows:

A B C D E F G H I L M N O P Q R S T U V Z

[[Sedley Joseph]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from kidney disease, Trinidad and Tobago footballers

Sedley Joseph (4 December 1939 – 8 June 2020) was a Trinidad and Tobago footballer. His career lasted from 1965 to 1967. He played for the national team. He also played for Maple.

Joseph died on 8 June 2020 of kidney disease in Chaguanas at the age of 80.

[[Arjun Charan Sethi]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Indian politicians

Arjun Charan Sethi (18 September 1941 – June 8 2020) was an Indian politician. He was a member of the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) political party. 

In 1971, he was elected to the Lok Sabha from Bhadrak constituency in Odisha as an Indian National Congress candidate. He was re-elected to the Lok Sabha in 1980. He was re-elected in 1991, 1998, 1999, 2004 and 2009. He was the Union Minister of water resources in Atal Bihari Vajpayee led government from 2000 to 2004. 

Sethi died on June 8, 2020 in a hospital in Bhubaneswar, India at the age of 78.

[[Bedroom Mazurka]]

Bedroom Mazurka is a 1970 Danish comedy movie directed by John Hildard and starring Ole Søloft, Axel Strøbye, Birte Tove.

[[Shim Wan-koo]]

CATEGORIES: South Korean politicians, Mayors, 1938 births, 2020 deaths

Shim Wan-koo (Korean: 심완구; Hanja: 沈完求; RR: Sim Wan-gu; 1 July 1938 – 8 June 2020) was a South Korean politician. He was the first elected Mayor of Ulsan from 1997 to 2002. He was a member of the National Assembly from 1985 to 1992.

Shim died on 8 June 2020 in Seoul, aged 81.

[[Brazos River]]

CATEGORIES: Rivers of Texas

The Brazos River (Brazos River Pronunciation.oga BRAZ), called the Río de los Brazos de Dios (translated as "The River of the Arms of God") by early Spanish explorers, is the 11th-longest river in the United States at 2060. Its source is at the head of Blackwater Draw, Curry County, New Mexico to its mouth at the Gulf of Mexico with a 116,000 drainage basin. 

It is one of Texas' largest rivers.

[[Land and Sons]]

Land and Sons (Land og synir) is a 1980 Icelandic drama movie directed by Ágúst Guðmundsson and starring Sigurður Sigurjónsson, Jón Sigurbjörnsson, Jónas Tryggvason.

[[Victor Argo]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2004 deaths, American television actors, American stage actors, American movie actors, Actors from the Bronx, Cancer deaths in New York, Deaths from lung cancer

Victor Argo (November 5, 1934 − April 7, 2004) was an American actor of Puerto Rican descent. He played tough bad guys in his movies. His career went on for over 40 years.

Argo began his career as a stage actor. He performed in an off-Broadway stage play in the 1960s. He then met Yoko Ono. With her, he did a so-called "Happening" movement.

Argo's movies include Taxi Driver, The Last Temptation of Christ, Bad Lieutenant and True Romance. He also played in television shows, including Wonder Woman, Law & Order and Miami Vice.

Argo was born in The Bronx, New York City. He died from complications of lung cancer at age 69.

[[British Go Association]]

CATEGORIES: United Kingdom, 1953 establishments in Europe, 1950s establishments in the United Kingdom, Go organizations

The British Go Association (BGA) promotes and supports the game of Go in the United Kingdom. It was founded in 1953. It holds tournaments and publishes the British Go Journal. They are a national member of the European Go Federation.

[[Donald P. Bellisario]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, Living people, American screenwriters, American television directors, American television writers, Writers from Pennsylvania

Donald Paul Bellisario (born August 8, 1935) is an American television producer and screenwriter. He is known for creating and sometimes writing episodes for the TV series Magnum, P.I. (1980–1988), Tales of the Gold Monkey (1982–1983), Airwolf (1984–1987), Quantum Leap (1989–1993), JAG (1995–2005) and NCIS (since 2003).

Bellisario was born in Cokeburg, Pennsylvania. He is of Italian and Serbian ancestry. He has been married four times and has seven children.

It stars River Phoenix, Wil Wheaton, Richard Dreyfuss, Corey Feldman, Jerry O'Connell, Kiefer Sutherland, Casey Siemaszko, John Cusack, Bruce Kirby and was distributed by Columbia Pictures. It was nominated for an Academy Award in 1987.

[[Vagrich Bakhchanyan]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2009 deaths, Soviet people, Conceptual artists

Vagrich Akopovich Bakhchanyan (Ва́грич Ако́пович Бахчаня́н; Ва́грiч Ако́пович Бахчаня́н; Վահրիճ Հակոբի Բախչանյան; born May 23, 1938 in Kharkiv, Soviet Ukraine - November 12, 2009, New York City, United States) was a Soviet and American painter, nonconformist artist and writer-conceptualist of Armenian origin.

[[Epicardium]]

CATEGORIES: Animal tissues, Heart, Muscle tissue, Anatomy of the cardiovascular system

Epicardium (heart muscle) is one of the three main layers of the heart wall.   It is the outermost layer of the heart, composed of connective tissue and fat.  The connective tissue secretes a small amount of lubricating fluid into the pericardial cavity. 

In addition to the connective tissue and fat, the epicardium is lined by, on its outer surface, simple epithelial cells.

[[Bengal famine of 1943]]

CATEGORIES: 1943, Disasters in India, India, World War II

The Bengal famine of 1943 was a famine in the Bengal province of British India during World War II. Between 2.1 and 3 million people died in the famine. They died mainly of starvation, malaria, and not having the right health care. The famine caused men to sell their farms and find work somewhere else. Some joined the British Indian Army. Women and children were made homeless and starving. Many had to move to cities like Calcutta to look for help. Historians usually say that the famine was caused by policies by the British government at the time. A small amount of historians say that the famine happened naturally.

[[Green-thighed frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Frogs

The green-thighed frog (Nyctimystes brevipalmatus) is a frog from Australia. It lives near the east coast of Australia near Brisbane.

The green-thighed frog is mostly brown with black stripes from its mouth to its front legs.  Its thighs are light blue or green with black spots.

They live near temporary bodies of water that dry up for part of the year.

According to the IUCN Red List, green-thighed frogs are endangered because people cut down the forests and build roads and railroads in the places where they like to live, because of fires and pollution, and because of invasive species.

Green-thighed frogs lay eggs that float together on top of the water.  The tadpoles hatch within one day, stay tadpoles for 40 days and most become frogs before they are 100 days old.

[[Finnic languages]]

CATEGORIES: Finnic languages

The Finnic, or Balto-Finnic, languages are a branch of Uralic languages. They are spoken in Northeastern Europe around the Baltic Sea, mainly in Finland, Estonia, and Northwestern Russia. The main two languages in the branch are Estonian and Finnish.

[[Northern Finnic languages]]

CATEGORIES: Uralic languages

The Northern Finnic languages are a branch of Finnic languages. The main language of the branch is Finnish. It is the official language of Finland and the most spoken language in the country. There are four other languages in the branch: Ingrian, Karelian, Ludic, and Veps.

He was the Minister of the Interior and Public Security from 2006 to 2007.

[[Nemir Kirdar]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from dementia, People from Tehran, Businesspeople from London

Nemir A. Kirdar (1933 – 9 June 2020) was an Iraqi-British businessman and financier. He founded Investcorp, a global alternative investment. He was CEO for over 30 years until he stood down in 2015 to became Chairman until his retirement in 2017. He was born in Tehran.

Kirdar died at his home in Cap D’Antibes, France from dementia-related problems on 9 June 2020, aged 83.

[[Ödön Földessy]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Hungarian sportspeople, Olympic bronze medalists

Ödön Földessy (1 July 1929 – 9 June 2020) was a Hungarian athlete. He competed in the long jump. He was born in Békés. He competed for Hungary in the men's long jump event at the 1952 Summer Olympics, where he won the bronze medal.

Földessy died in Budapest on 9 June 2020, aged 90.

[[Klaus Berger (theologian)]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, German Christians, German theologians

Klaus Berger (25 November 1940 – 8 June 2020) was a German academic theologian. Berger was Professor of New Testament Theology at the University of Heidelberg. He was born in Hildesheim, Germany. He was known for his study and publications on the New Testament.

Berger died on 8 June 2020 in Heidelberg at the age of 79.

[[Rosemary Hollis]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2020 deaths, Political scientists, Political writers, Researchers, British educators, People from West Midlands (county)

Rosemary Hollis (1952 – 8 June 2020) was a British political scientist. She was a professor of Middle East Policy Studies at City University London until her retirement in 2018. Hollis was known for her studies and scholarship on the relations between the European Union, the United Kingdom and the United States with the Middle East. 

She was the Research Director at Chatham House (the Royal Institute of International Affairs). He was born in Dudley, West Midlands.

Hollis died on 8 June 2020.

[[Stefan Vodenicharov]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Bulgarian writers, Bulgarian politicians, Educators

Stefan M. Vodenicharov (1 September 1944 – 8 June 2020) was a Bulgarian educator and politician. He was President of the Bulgarian Academy of Sciences from 2012 to 2016. He was the Minister of Education, Youth and Science briefly in 2013.

Vodenicharov died in Sofia on 8 June 2020, aged 75.

[[Gwen Margolis]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from natural causes in the United States, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Politicians from Miami, Florida, US Democratic Party politicians

Gwen Margolis (October 4, 1934 – June 8, 2020) was an American Democratic politician. She was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. 

Margolis was a member of the Florida Senate from 1980 to 1992, 2002 to 2008, and 2010 to 2016. She was Senate President for the 1990 to 1992 term. She was a member of the Florida House of Representatives from 1974 to 1980.

Margolis died on June 8, 2020 in Miami, Florida of natural causes at the age of 85.

[[South Semitic languages]]

CATEGORIES: Semitic languages

The South Semitic languages are a branch of Semitic languages. They are mainly spoken in East Africa and Southern Arabia. Linguists do not agree on where South Semitic languages come from. Some say they came from Ethiopia, while others say Southern Arabia.  A recent study found that they probably came from Southern Arabia. There are two branches of South Semitic languages.

[[Modern South Arabian languages]]

CATEGORIES: Semitic languages

The Modern South Arabian, or Eastern South Semitic, languages are a branch of Semitic languages. They are spoken by a small number of people in Southern Arabia in the countries of Yemen and Oman, as well as Socotra Island.

[[Soqotri language]]

CATEGORIES: Semitic languages, Yemen, United Arab Emirates

Soqotri is a Semitic language. It is spoken on the island Socotra and other nearby islands, all parts of Yemen. Around 70,000 people speak the language.

[[Mehri language]]

CATEGORIES: Semitic languages, Languages of Oman, Yemen, Kuwait

Mehri, or Mahri, is a Semitic language. It is spoken by tribes in Eastern Yemen and Western Oman by around 165,000 people. It has been spoken in the area since before Arabic was brought there.

[[Shehri language]]

CATEGORIES: Semitic languages, Languages of Oman

Shehri, or Jibbali, is a Semitic languages. It is spoken by a small number of people in towns by the coast and in mountains in Oman.

[[Rhinestone (movie)]]

[[Harsusi language]]

CATEGORIES: Semitic languages, Languages of Oman

Harsusi is a Semitic language. It is spoken by fewer than 1,000 people in the deserts of South-Central Oman. It is a lot like Mehri.

[[Hobyót language]]

CATEGORIES: Semitic languages, Languages of Oman, Yemen

Hobyót is a Semitic language. It is spoken by fewer than 500 people in Eastern Yemen and Western Oman. Hobyót could go extinct soon.

[[Bathari language]]

CATEGORIES: Semitic languages

Bathari is a Semitic language. It is spoken by fewer than 100 people in Oman. It could go extinct soon. It is a lot like Mehri.

[[Joshua Then and Now (movie)]]

[[Norilsk oil spill]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 disasters, 21st century in Russia, Disasters in Europe, May 2020 events

The Norilsk oil spill was an industrial disaster near Norilsk in Russia. It began on 29 May 2020, when a fuel storage tank at Norilsk-Taimyr Energy's Thermal Power Plant No. 3 failed. It flooded local rivers with 21000 of diesel oil. Russian President Vladimir Putin called it a state of emergency in early June.
