[[Wienerschnitzel]]

CATEGORIES: American fast food restaurants, 1961 establishments in the United States

Wienerschnitzel is an American fast food chain founded in 1961 (as "Der Wienerschnitzel") that specializes in hot dogs, also known as the World's Largest Hot Dog Chain. Wienerschnitzel locations are found predominantly in California and Texas, though others are located in Arizona, Colorado, Illinois, Louisiana, New Mexico, Nevada, Utah, and Washington. Outside the 50 states, there is a store located in Guam and one in Panama.

The chain is recognizable by the A-frame style roofs of its older restaurants, similar to the original structures used by IHOP, Tastee-Freez, Nickerson Farms, and Whataburger. Structures that have been converted from Wienerschnitzels into other restaurants often retain the distinctive architecture. The chain's advertising mascot is an anthropomorphized chili dog known as The Delicious One, who runs from people who want to eat him.

Wienerschnitzel sponsors the tongue-in-cheek Wiener Nationals, the de facto national dachshund racing championship series for the United States.

[[Emma Wright]]

CATEGORIES: 1996 births, Living people, Canadian water polo players

Emma Wright (born 16 November 1996) is a Canadian water polo player.

She participated at the 2013 World Aquatics Championships, 2015 Pan American Games, 2013 World Aquatics Championships, and 2013 World Aquatics Championships.

She plays for University of California's women's water polo team.

[[Chili dog]]

CATEGORIES: American food, Sausage

Chili dog is the generic name for a hot dog served in a bun and topped with some sort of meat sauce, such as chili con carne. Often other toppings are also added, such as cheese, onions, and mustard. The style has many regional variations in the United States. Some of these have specific sauce ingredients, types of hot dogs, or types of buns. They are referred to regionally under region-specific names.

[[Crveni Krst concentration camp]]

CATEGORIES: History of Serbia, Nazi concentration camps, The Holocaust

Crveni Krst concentration camp was one of the most dreadful concentration camps in Serbia. Prisoners from different parts of Eastern Europe were taken to this concentration camp. Some sources also say that some German Jews were also in the camp as prisoners. However, as it was not such a big concentration camp. there is not a lot of information about it.

[[Body Double]]

CATEGORIES: 1984 movies, 1980s crime thriller movies, American crime thriller movies, Cult movies, Movies directed by Brian De Palma

Body Double is a 1984 American erotic crime thriller movie directed by Brian De Palma and starring Craig Wasson, Gregg Henry, Melanie Griffith, Deborah Shelton, Dennis Franz, Barbara Crampton. It was distributed by Columbia Pictures and became a cult favorite.

[[Gaġġa]]

CATEGORIES: 1970s romance movies, 1971 thriller movies, Maltese movies

Gaġġa (Cage) is a 1971 Maltan romantic thriller movie directed by Mario Azzopardi and based on the novel by Frans Sammut. It stars Charles Arrigo, Karmen Azzopardi, Tanya Baldacchino.

[[Kawasaki disease]]

CATEGORIES: Autoimmune diseases

Kawasaki disease is a syndrome of unknown cause that results in a fever and mainly affects children under 5 years of age. It is a form of vasculitis, where blood vessels become inflamed throughout the body.

The fever typically lasts for more than five days. While the cause is unknown, it may be due to an infection triggering an autoimmune response.

Boys are more commonly affected than girls. The disorder was first described in 1967 by Tomisaku Kawasaki in Japan.

[[Tomisaku Kawasaki]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2020 deaths, Japanese scientists

Tomisaku Kawasaki was a Japanese pediatrician. Kawasaki first observed the autoimmune disease now named after him as Kawasaki disease in 1960. He published a description in Japanese in 1967, and a description in English in 1974.

[[Paul Chapman (musician)]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 deaths, 1954 births, Welsh musicians, British rock guitarists, People from Cardiff

Paul William "Tonka" Chapman (9 June 1954 – 9 June 2020) was a Welsh rock guitarist. He was best known for his work in bands such as UFO and Lone Star. Chapman was well known by his nickname "Tonka". He was born in Cardiff, Wales.

In July 2006, Chapman joined the American southern rock band Gator Country, a collection of Molly Hatchet veterans.

In 2015, Chapman went out for a 10-week US tour with the Swedish/Canadian band Killer Bee and he also recorded on their album Eye In The Sky.

Chapman died on his 66th birthday on 9 June 2020.

[[Simon Henshaw]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 deaths, Ambassadors of the United States, Politicians from Massachusetts

Simon Henshaw (died June 9, 2020) was an American diplomat. He was the United States Ambassador to Guinea from 2019 until his death. 

From 2011 to 2013, he was Director of the Office of Andean Affairs, and, from 2008 to 2011, he was Deputy Chief of Mission at the United States Embassy in Tegucigalpa, Honduras.

On August 10, 2018, President Trump announced his plans to nominate Henshaw as the next United States Ambassador to Guinea. On August 16, 2018, his nomination was sent the United States Senate. On September 26, 2018, he appeared before the United States Senate Committee on Foreign Relations. On January 2, 2019, his nomination was confirmed in the Senate.

Henshaw died of a heart attack on June 9, 2020, in Guinea.

[[Kim Chang-sop]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, North Korean politicians

Kim Chang-sop (김창섭; 2 January 1946 – 9 June 2020) was a North Korean politician. He was a member of the Workers' Party of Korea. He was born in Unsan County, South Pyongan Province. He was the Vice Minister of the State Security Department from 2015 until his death.

Kim died on 9 June 2020 in Pyongyang at the age of 74.

[[Anita Linda]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2020 deaths, Filipino actors, People from Manila

Anita Linda (born Alice Buenaflor Lake; November 23, 1924 – June 10, 2020) was a Filipino actress. At the age of 74, she became the oldest actress to ever win a FAMAS Award. She was born in Pasay, Rizal. Her best known roles were in Weighed But Found Wanting, Jaguar and Temptation Island. She starred in Sta. Niña (2012), which earned her positive reviews.

In 2014, she made a comeback on television in the television drama Sana Bukas pa ang Kahapon as Lola Patchi.

Linda died on 10 June 2020 in Manila, aged 95.

[[Mayville, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in New York, County seats in New York

Mayville is a village in Chautauqua County, New York, United States. The population was 1,711 at the 2010 census. Mayville is the county seat of Chautauqua County. 

[[MrBeast]]

CATEGORIES: 1998 births, Living people, American philanthropists, American Internet celebrities, Businesspeople from North Carolina, American YouTubers

Jimmy Donaldson (born May 7, 1998), more commonly known as MrBeast, is an American YouTuber. He was born in Greenville, North Carolina. He was known for his expensive stunts and philanthropy. He has been seen as the creator of a new genre of YouTube videos that are expensive stunts.

He is also the co-creator of Team Trees, a fundraiser for the Arbor Day Foundation, which has raised over $22 million.

[[Starman (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1984 romance movies, 1980s science fiction movies, American science fiction movies, American romance movies, Movies directed by John Carpenter

Starman is a 1984 American science fiction romance movie directed by John Carpenter and starring Jeff Bridges (in his Oscar nominated role), Karen Allen, Charles Martin Smith, Richard Jaeckel, Robert Phalen. It was distributed by Columbia Pictures and was spun off into a short-lived television series in 1986.

Lenka von Koerber (born Helene Irmgard Louise von der Leyen 16 March 1888 West Prussia – July 21, 1958 Leipzig) was a German journalist and writer.

[[Angelica Ortiz]]

Angelica J. Ortiz Irizarry (born 25 January 1988) is a female water polo player from Puerto Rico. She participated at the 2007 World Aquatics Championships, 2006 Central American and Caribbean Games, and 2011 Pan American Games.

[[Richard Osman]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 births, BBC people, English television directors, English television presenters, English television producers, People from Essex, Living people

Richard Thomas Osman (born 28 November 1970) is an English television presenter, producer, director, and novelist. Since 2014, and over to the 2015 series, Armstrong also presented the BBC Two quiz shows Two Tribes, and Richard Osman's House of Games. When he and Josh Widdecombe was been the captain since 2016, and presented by Sue Perkins, Widdecombe and Osman was been the British starring of the BBC Two comedy panel game show Insert Name Here, and in 6 February and over to 15 May 2017, he presenting Channel 4's The Fake News Show.

[[Paola Medina]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 births, Living people, Water polo players, Sportspeople from Puerto Rico

Paola Medina Montero (born 1 December 1985) is a female water polo player from Puerto Rico. She participated at the 2007 World Aquatics Championships and 2019 Pan American Games.

She played for California State University, Bakersfield's women's water polo team.

[[The Sure Thing]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 comedy movies, 1985 romance movies, 1980s adventure movies, 1980s romantic comedy movies, 1980s road movies, 1980s teen comedy movies, American adventure movies, American romantic comedy movies, American road movies, American teen comedy movies, Movies directed by Rob Reiner

The Sure Thing is a 1985 American romantic adventure comedy movie directed by Rob Reiner and starring John Cusack, Daphne Zuniga, Nicollette Sheridan, Viveca Lindfors, Anthony Edwards, Tim Robbins. It was distributed by Embassy Pictures.

[[Adriana Vinas Joy]]

CATEGORIES: 1994 births, Puerto Rican volleyball players, Living people

Adriana Vinas Joy (born  1 March 1994) is a Puerto Rican female volleyball player. She is a member of the Puerto Rico women's national volleyball team.

She participated at the 2017 Volleyball World Grand Prix and 2018 Women's World Volleyball Championship. 

She played for Long Island University's women's volleyball team. 

[[Stratopause]]

CATEGORIES: Atmosphere

The stratopause is the part of the atmosphere between the stratosphere and mesosphere. In the stratosphere the temperature gets higher the higher up you go. The stratopause is where it is warmest. On Earth, the stratopause is about 50 high. The temperature is about -15.

[[Ana Sofía Jusino]]

CATEGORIES: 1994 births, Living people, Puerto Rican volleyball players

Ana Sofía Jusino (born 5 January 1994 in San Juan) is a Puerto Rican female volleyball player. She is a member of the Puerto Rico women's national volleyball team. She was part of the Puerto Rico women's national volleyball team at the 2018 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship and 2019 Pan-American Games.

She played for University of Arkansas.

[[Jonathan Dowling]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2020 deaths, Irish scientists, American physicists, Researchers, Scientists from New York, Scientists from Louisiana, People from Baton Rouge, Louisiana

Jonathan P. Dowling (3 April 1955 – 5 June 2020) was an Irish-American researcher. He was a professor in theoretical physics. He was known for his work on quantum technology, mainly focusing in quantum entanglement. He was born in Smithtown, New York.

Dowling was the co-director of the Horace Hearne Institute for Theoretical Physics and a Hearne chair in Theoretical Physics at the Department of Physics and Astronomy, both at Louisiana State University. 

He was a Fellow at the American Association for the Advancement of Science and at the American Physical Society.

Dowling died on 5 June 2020 from a short-illness, aged 65.

[[Samuel J. Randall]]

CATEGORIES: 1828 births, 1890 deaths, Deaths from colorectal cancer, United States representatives from Pennsylvania, Speakers of the United States House of Representatives, Politicians from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, US Democratic Party politicians

Samuel Jackson Randall (October 10, 1828 – April 13, 1890) was an American politician. He was the 29th Speaker of the United States House of Representatives from 1876 to 1881. He was in the U.S. House representing Pennsylvania's 1st congressional district from 1863 to 1875 and Pennsylvania's 3rd congressional district from 1875 to 1890. 

[[Alba Hernández]]

CATEGORIES: 1994 births, Living people, Puerto Rican volleyball players

Alba Hernández (born 3 October 1994 in Fajardo) is a Puerto Rican female volleyball player. She is a member of the Puerto Rico women's national volleyball team. She was part of the Puerto Rican team at the 2017 FIVB Volleyball World Grand Prix, and 2018 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship.

[[Rosita Fornés]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from emphysema, Cancer deaths in Florida, Cuban actors, American movie actors, Actors from New York City, Singers from New York City

Rosita Fornés (February 11, 1923 – June 10, 2020) was a Cuban-American singer and actress. She was born in New York City. She was known for her roles in A Dangerous Adventure (1939), Musical Romance (1941), The Flesh Commands (1948), The Desire (1948), Women of the Theatre (1951) and in The Unknown Mariachi (1953).

Fornés died of emphysema on June 10, 2020 at a hospital in Miami, Florida at the age of 97.

[[Armando Silvestre]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, Mexican movie actors, Mexican television actors, Mexican stage actors, Actors from San Diego, California

Armando Silvestre (born 6 July 1926) is a Mexican-American actor. He appeared in more than 190 movies from 1948 until 2016. He was born in San Diego, California. His best known roles were as Natchez in Geronimo (1962), Two Crows in The Scalphunters (1968), multiple roles in the television series Daniel Boone and The F.B.I..

[[María Victoria]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, Living people, Mexican singers, Mexican movie actors, Mexican comedians, Mexican television actors, Mexican stage actors

María Victoria Cervantes Cervantes (born 26 February 1933), more commonly known simply as María Victoria, is a Mexican actress, singer, and comedian. She is best known for starring as Inocencia in the Telesistema Mexicano sitcom La criada bien criada and its 1972 spin-off movie. She was born in Guadalajara, Jalisco. Her career began in 1951.

[[Gloria Mange]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, Living people, Mexican movie actors, Mexican television actors, Mexican stage actors

Gloria Mange (born 27 August 1931) is a Mexican movie actress. She was a known actress during the Golden Age of Mexican cinema. She was born in Ciudad Obregón, Sonora. Her best known roles were in Primero soy mexicano (1950), What Has That Woman Done to You? (1951), If I Were a Congressman (1952) and in The Unknown Mariachi (1953).

[[Ciudad Obregón]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Mexico, Sonora

Ciudad Obregón (sjuˈðað oβɾeˈɣon) is the second largest city in the northern Mexican state of Sonora. It is located 525 south of the state's northern border with the U.S. state of Arizona. 

[[Rosa de Castilla]]

CATEGORIES: Mexican movie actors, Mexican television actors, Mexican singers, 1931 births, Living people

María Victoria Ledesma Cuevas (born 30 May 1931), known by her stage name Rosa de Castilla (ˈrosa ðe kasˈtiʎa), is a Mexican singer and actress. She is known as one of the great folkloric leading ladies of the "golden age" of Mexican cinema. She was born in Encarnación de Díaz, Jalisco. 

Her best known roles were in Yo... el aventurero (1959), Dos corazones y un cielo (1959), and Héroe a la fuerza (1964). Her career began in 1952.

She played for University of Colorado's women's volleyball team. 

[[Ed Ames]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, American pop singers, Singers from Massachusetts, Actors from Massachusetts, People from Malden, Massachusetts

Ed Ames (born Edmund Dantes Urick; July 9, 1927) is an American pop singer and actor. He is known for playing Mingo in the television series Daniel Boone and for his pop hits of the 1960s including "My Cup Runneth Over", "Who Will Answer?" and "When the Snow Is on the Roses". 

He was also part of the popular 1950s singing group with his siblings, The Ames Brothers. He was born in Malden, Massachusetts.

[[Warwick, New York]]

Warwick is a town in the southwest part of Orange County, New York, United States. Its population was 32,065 at the 2010 census. 

The town has three villages within the town (Florida, Greenwood Lake, and Warwick).

Middletown is a city in Orange County, New York, United States. It lies in New York's Hudson Valley region. As of the 2010 United States Census, the city's population was 28,086. The zip code is 10940. Middletown falls within the Poughkeepsie–Newburgh–Middletown Metropolitan Statistical Area.

Port Jervis is a city located at the confluence of the Neversink and the Delaware rivers in western Orange County, New York, north of the Delaware Water Gap. 

Its population was 8,828 at the 2010 census.

Greenville is a town in Orange County, New York, United States. It is located along the southern county and state line. The population was 4,616 at the 2010 census.

[[Middletown, New York]]

Middletown is the name of several places located in the U.S. state of New York:

[[Florida, Montgomery County, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in New York

Florida is a town south of the Mohawk River in Montgomery County, New York, United States. The population was 2,696 in the 2010 United States Census. The town was named after the state of Florida. 

[[Mohawk River]]

CATEGORIES: Rivers of New York

The Mohawk River is a 149 river in the U.S. state of New York. It is the largest tributary of the Hudson River. The Mohawk flows into the Hudson in Cohoes, New York, a few miles north of the city of Albany. 

The river is named for the Mohawk Nation of the Iroquois Confederacy. 

[[Cohoes, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in New York

Cohoes (k kə) is an incorporated city located in the northeast corner of Albany County in the U.S. state of New York. As of the 2010 census, the city population was 16,168. In Algonquian Cohoes, means 'pine tree'.

[[Mohawk people]]

CATEGORIES: Native American people

The Mohawk people are the most easterly tribe of the Haudenosaunee, or Iroquois Confederacy. They are an Iroquoian-speaking indigenous people of North America. They had communities in northern New York State and southeastern Canada, mainly around Lake Ontario and the St Lawrence River. 

As one of the five original members of the Iroquois League, the Mohawk are known as the Keepers of the Eastern Door.

[[New York, Florida]]

CATEGORIES: Unincorporated communities in Florida

New York is an unincorporated community in Santa Rosa County, Florida, United States. The community is 17 north-northwest of Milton.

[[Navarre, Florida]]

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places in Florida, Unincorporated communities in Florida

Navarre is a census-designated place and unincorporated community in Santa Rosa County in the northwest Florida Panhandle. It has a population of 44,876, 2020 estimate.

[[Mo Cowan]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 births, Living people, United States senators from Massachusetts, American lawyers, Businesspeople from North Carolina, Politicians from North Carolina, Businesspeople from Massachusetts, US Democratic Party politicians

William Maurice “Mo” Cowan (born April 4, 1969) is an American politician and lawyer. He was a United States Senator from Massachusetts from February 1, 2013 to July 16, 2013. He is a member of the  Democratic Party. He was legal counsel and chief of staff to Governor Deval Patrick.

Patrick appointed him on as an interim Senator to replace fellow Democrat John Kerry, who resigned to become U.S. Secretary of State.

He did not want to run in the 2013 special election to complete the remainder of Kerry's term. He was replaced by fellow Democrat Ed Markey.

Cowan was the eighth African-American U.S. Senator and the second from Massachusetts after Edward Brooke.

[[River Alun, Pembrokeshire]]

CATEGORIES: Rivers of Wales

River Alun is a small river in Northwest Pembrokeshire, Wales. It flows through the very old city of St Davids.

[[Yadkinville, North Carolina]]

Yadkinville is a town in Yadkin County, North Carolina, United States. The population was 2,959 at the 2010 census. It is the county seat and largest city of Yadkin County.

[[Yadkin County, North Carolina]]

CATEGORIES: 1850s establishments in North Carolina, 1850 establishments in the United States, North Carolina counties

Yadkin County is located in the U.S. state of North Carolina. As of the 2010 census, the population was 38,406. Its county seat is Yadkinville.

Davidson County is a county located in the U.S. state of North Carolina. As of the 2010 census, the population was 162,878. Its county seat is Lexington, and its largest city is Thomasville.

[[Michael Beach]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, Actors from Boston, Massachusetts

Michael Anthony Beach (born October 30, 1963) is an American actor. He has appeared in movies Lean on Me (1989), One False Move (1992), Short Cuts (1993), Waiting to Exhale (1995), A Family Thing (1996), and Soul Food (1997). 

On television, he starred as Monte Parker in the NBC drama series Third Watch from 1999 to 2005.

[[Julymar Otero]]

CATEGORIES: 1996 births, Volleyball players

Julymar Otero (born 31 October 1996, Toa Baja, Puerto Rico) is a female volleyball player. She is a member of the Puerto Rico women's national volleyball team. [[Sarunyoo Wongkrachang]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from liver cancer, Thai actors, Thai singers, Movie directors, Movie producers, Screenwriters, Political activists, Television presenters

Sarunyoo Wongkrachang (17 October 1960 – 10 June 2020) was a Thai actor, director, screenwriter, singer, producer, activist and host. He was born in Samut Songkhram Province, Thailand. He was known for starring as Lord Jom Rajasena in Ong Bak 2 (2008) and Ong Bak 3 (2010) and as Surachi in 13 Beloved (2006). He also directed and wrote Kon Khon (2011).

Wongkrachang died on 10 June 2020 of liver cancer at a hospital in Bangkok, aged 59.

[[St Davids Cathedral]]

St Davids Cathedral is an old cathedral in St Davids, Pembrokeshire, Wales. The current building was built between the 11th and 13th centuries. Saint David is buried there, and he started the first church here in the 6th century.

[[Ian Taylor (British businessman)]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from pneumonia, Cancer deaths in London, Businesspeople from London

Ian Roper Taylor (7 February 1956 – 8 June 2020) was a British trading businessman. He was chairman and Global CEO of The Vitol Group, the world's largest independent energy trader. He was also the majority shareholder in Harris Tweed Hebrides. He was born in Croydon, London, England.

In 2016 he was reported to have asked for his name to be withdrawn from consideration for a potential knighthood in David Cameron's resignation honours list.

The Sunday Times Rich List 2017 said that Taylor's wealth was at £180m, making him the UK's 623rd richest person.

Taylor died of pneumonia caused by cancer on 8 June 2020 in London, aged 64.

[[National Library of the Czech Republic]]

CATEGORIES: 1770s establishments in Europe, 1777 establishments, National libraries in Europe, Buildings and structures in the Czech Republic, Prague

The National Library of the Czech Republic (Národní knihovna České republiky) is the central library of the Czech Republic. The main part of the library is in the Clementinum building of Prague.

[[Craig Revel Horwood]]

CATEGORIES: 1965 births, Living people, British dancers

Craig Revel Horwood (born 4 January 1965) is an Australian-British professional ballroom dancer, choreographer, conductor, singer, author, theatre director and television personality in the United Kingdom. He is a patron of the Royal Osteoporois Society. 

He is best known as a judge on the popular BBC dancing show Strictly Come Dancing, and he is the only judge to have appeared in every episode so far.

Horwood is also often seen performing Ballroom and Latin routines on Strictly Come Dancing including, in 2019 during a performance themed on the Hello, Dolly!.

[[Mood Ring (song)]]

CATEGORIES: Britney Spears songs, 2016 songs, 2020 songs

"Mood Ring" is a song by American recording artist Britney Spears.  It was included as a bonus track on the Japanese version of Spears’ 2016 album, Glory.  Spears later re-released the standard version of the album in 2020 with a new cover and included "Mood Ring" on this version, released on May 22, 2020.  It is listed as "Mood Ring (By Demand)" on the tracklist.

The song was written by DJ Mustard, Te Whiti Warbrick, Jon Asher, Melanie Fontana, Lewis Hughes, and Nicholas Audino, while DJ Mustard produced the song.

[[Periodical]]

CATEGORIES: Journalism, Magazines, Mass media, Publications

Periodical is a type of publication that is produced regularly. It is anything that comes out with regular issues and are published in series.  A daily newspaper, a weekly news magazine, a monthly journal, and an annual book series are all examples of periodicals. Some periodicals are published in ways that make them more valuable to scholars. Periodical literature is a category of serial publications that appear in a new edition on a regular schedule.

[[Ickabog]]

CATEGORIES: Children's books

The Ickabog is a fairy tale by British author J. K. Rowling. The story will be published in parts by Rowling online, before its official publication in November 2020. The Ickabog is Rowling's first children's book since Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows was published in 2007.

[[Ray Kurzweil]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, Living people, Writers from Queens, Businesspeople from New York City, American inventors, Futurists, Massachusetts Institute of Technology alumni

Raymond "Ray" Kurzweil (born February 12, 1948 in Queens, New York City) is an American author, entrepreneur, inventor, and futurist.

Kurzweil wrote seven books (five of them were national bestsellers) about topics like health, artificial intelligence (AI), transhumanism, immortality, the technological singularity, and futurism. He speaks to people and gives speeches at conferences like DEMO, SXSW, and TED. He also maintains the news website KurzweilAI.net. It has more than three million readers per year. He has a sibling, a son, Ethan Kurzweil, and a daughter, Amy Kurzweil.

Kurzweil works at Google since 2012. He is a "director of engineering".

[[Sheikh Mujibur Rahman (Bangladeshi politician)]]

CATEGORIES: Possibly living people, Bangladeshi politicians, Bangladeshi Muslims

Sheikh Mujibur Rahman is a Bangladesh Nationalist Party politician. He was elected a member of parliament from Bagerhat-1 in February 1996.

[[Prafulla Kumar Mandal]]

CATEGORIES: Bangladeshi politicians, Hindus, Possibly living people, Year of birth missing (living people)

Prafulla Kumar Mandal Bangladesh Nationalist Party politician. He was elected a member of parliament from Khulna-1 in February 1996.

[[Valeria León]]

CATEGORIES: 1995 births, Living people, Puerto Rican volleyball players

Valeria León (born 21 November 1995) is a Puerto Rican female volleyball player. She is a member of the Puerto Rico women's national volleyball team and played for Leonas de Ponce in 2018. She was part of the Puerto Rican National Team at the 2018 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship.

She played for Ohio State University's women's volleyball.

[[Edith Mukuvilani]]

CATEGORIES: 1994 births, Living people, Kenyan volleyball players

Edith Mukuvilani (born 20 July 1994) is a Kenyan volleyball player.

She is part of the Kenya women's national volleyball team. She participated in the 2010 Women's World Volleyball Championship, 2018 Women's World Volleyball Championship, and 2019 FIVB Women's World Cup. She won the gold medal at the 2019 African Games.

[[Emmaculate Chemtai]]

CATEGORIES: 1993 births, Living people, Kenyan volleyball players

Emmaculate Chemtai (born 14 October 1993) is a Kenyan volleyball player.

She is part of the Kenya women's national volleyball team. She participated in the 2018 World Championship and 2019 FIVB Women's World Cup.  

She was chosen to represent Kenya at the 2020 Summer Olympics.

[[Miami Medical]]

CATEGORIES: 2010s American drama television series, English-language television programs

Miami Medical is a medical drama television series that aired on CBS from April 2 to July 2, 2010 that follows the professional and private lives of a team of trauma surgeons. In May 2010, CBS cancelled the series after one season.

[[115th United States Congress]]

CATEGORIES: United States Congress

The 115th United States Congress was the 115th legislative cycle of the United States House of Representatives and the United States Senate. It lasted from January 3, 2017, as a result of the 2016 elections, till January 3, 2019, when the 116th Congress began. In this cycle, both the House and Senate were controlled by Republicans.

[[Lorine Chebet Kaei]]

CATEGORIES: 1999 births, Living people, Kenyan volleyball players

Lorine Chebet Kaei (born 8 October 1999) is a Kenyan volleyball player.

She is part of the Kenya women's national volleyball team. She participated in the 2018 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship. and 2019 FIVB Women's World Cup.  

[[Kristina Karapetan]]

CATEGORIES: 1992 births, Living people, Kazakhstani volleyball players

Kristina Karapetan (born 3 August 1992 in Chara, Kalarsky District) is a Kazakhstani female volleyball player. She was a member of the Kazakhstan women's national volleyball team at the 2018 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship.

She played for Irtysh Kazchrome in 2018.

[[Zhanna Syroeshkina]]

CATEGORIES: 1999 births, Living people, Kazakhstani volleyball players

Zhanna Syroeshkina (born 4 June 1999 in Ekibastuz) is a Kazakhstani female volleyball player. She was part of the Kazakhstan women's national volleyball team at the 2018 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship.

She played for VC Almaty in 2018.

[[Kristina Belova]]

CATEGORIES: 1998 births, Kazakhstani volleyball players, Living people

Kristina Belova (born 29 November 1998 in Pavlodar) is a Kazakhstani female volleyball player. She is a member of the Kazakhstan women's national volleyball team. She was part of the team at the 2018 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship, and 2018 VTV International Women's Volleyball Cup.

She played for Irtysh Kazchrome in 2018.

[[Javelin frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Frogs

The javelin frog, pygmy rocket frog or cairns tree frog (Litoria microbelos) is a small frog from northern Australia. It lives in northern and central Queensland and in Kimberly.

The frogs are less than 2 cm long, some of the smallest in Australia.  They are light brown with dark brown stripes.

They lay eggs in areas that are temporarily flooded and not in permanent bodies of water like ponds.  Adults hide in the grass or under rocks or logs.

[[Weighed But Found Wanting]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 drama movies, Filipino movies, Movies directed by Lino Brocka

Weighed But Found Wanting (Filipino: Tinimbang Ka Ngunit Kulang; also known as Human Imperfections) is a 1974 Filipino drama movie directed by Lino Brocka and starring Anita Linda, Christopher de Leon, Mario O'Hara, Lolita Rodriguez, Eddie Garcia, Hilda Koronel, Lilia Dizon.

[[Hardcore (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 drama movies, American crime drama movies, Movies directed by Paul Schrader

Hardcore is a 1979 American crime drama movie directed by Paul Schrader and starring George C. Scott, Peter Boyle, Season Hubley, Dick Sargent, Gary Graham, Leslie Ackerman. It was distributed by Columbia Pictures.

[[Audrey Wasilewski]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 births, Living people, American voice actors, American television actors, Actors from Pennsylvania

Audrey Wasilewski (born June 26, 1967) is an American actress and voice artist. She is known as the current voice of E.T.

[[International Star Registry]]

CATEGORIES: Astronomical organizations

The International Star Registry (ISR) is an organization which sells the right to unofficially name stars. It was founded in 1979 by John and Phyllis Mosele. It has published nine large volumes of the copyrighted book titled "Your Place in the Cosmos".

[[Star Name Registry]]

CATEGORIES: Astronomical organizations

The Star Name Registry (SNR) is a British organization that sells the right to unofficially name stars. Products and services are often marketed as gifts or memorials.

[[One Crazy Summer]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 comedy movies, 1986 romance movies, 1980s romantic comedy movies, American romantic comedy movies

One Crazy Summer is a 1986 American romantic comedy movie directed by Savage Steve Holland and starring Jason Bateman, Demi Moore, Bobcat Goldthwait, Curtis Armstrong, Joel Murray, William Hickey, Jeremy Piven, Taylor Negron. It was distributed by Warner Bros..

[[Hannah and Her Sisters]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 comedy-drama movies, American comedy-drama movies, Movies directed by Woody Allen, American independent movies

Hannah and Her Sisters is a 1986 American comedy drama movie directed by Woody Allen (who also stars) and starring Michael Caine, Mia Farrow, Carrie Fisher, Barbara Hershey, Lloyd Nolan, Maureen O'Sullivan, Daniel Stern, Max von Sydow, Dianne Wiest. It was distributed by Orion Pictures and was nominated for 7 Oscars and won 3 Academy Awards in 1987.

[[Hugo Boss Prize]]

CATEGORIES: 1996 establishments, Awards

The Hugo Boss Prize is an award conveyed to an artist or group of artists to recognize their works. It recognizes artists from any medium and from any parts of of the world.

It was established in 1996 and different from other art awards like the Turner Prize) because it has no restrictions on nationality or age. The prize is curatedby the Guggenheim Museum and sponsored by the Hugo Boss clothing company. It comes with a trophy and a cash award of US$100,000.

[[Thor Steinar]]

CATEGORIES: 2000s establishments in Germany, 2002 establishments in Europe, Companies of Germany, Fashion, Neo-Nazism, Brandenburg

Thor Steinar is a German clothing company. It trades as Thor Steinar Mediatex GmbH which is a subsidiary of International Brands General Trading based in Dubai. 

In Germany, it is considered that the company is closely associated to neo-Nazism by the Verfassungschutz of the state of Brandenburg. In German media, the brand is oftenly discussed in the light of this association. Wearing Thor Steinar clothes is expressly forbidden in the Bundestag, in the Landtage of Mecklenburg-Vorpommern and Saxony and in many football stadiums.

[[BioShock 2]]

CATEGORIES: Video game sequels, PlayStation 3 games, Xbox 360 games, Windows games

BioShock 2 is the sequel to the first-person shooter game BioShock. The game has some new features, but overall BioShock 2 is very similar to the first game. It takes place 8 years after BioShock. In BioShock 2, the player plays as a Big Daddy, a major enemy from the first game, called Subject Delta. Subject Delta is an early version of the Big Daddy, the Alpha Series.

[[Lance Acord]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, Living people, American cinematographers, People from California, Fresno County, California

Lancelot J. "Lance" Acord (born September 9, 1964) A.S.C. is an American cinematographer.

Acord was born in Fresno County, California. He attended Sir Francis Drake High School's School Within A School (S.W.A.S.) program and went on to study photography and filmmaking at the San Francisco Art Institute. He began his professional career with Bruce Weber and together, they made documentaries, commercials and music videos.

His latest directorial work is E.T.: A Holiday Reunion.

[[Valentino (1977 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 drama movies, 1970s LGBT movies, British drama movies, British biographical movies, American drama movies, American biographical movies, Movies directed by Ken Russell

Valentino is a 1977 American British biographical drama movie directed by Ken Russell and starring Rudolf Nureyev, Leslie Caron, Seymour Cassel, Carol Kane, Michelle Phillips, Penelope Milford. It was distributed by United Artists.

[[Tomorrow Never Comes]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 drama movies, 1970s crime drama movies, British drama movies, Canadian drama movies

Tomorrow Never Comes is a 1978 Canadian British crime drama movie directed by Peter Collinson and starring Oliver Reed, Raymond Burr, Susan George, Paul Koslo, John Ireland, Stephen McHattie, Donald Pleasence.

[[The Boys in Company C]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 drama movies, 1970s war movies, American war movies, American drama movies, Hong Kong movies, Movies directed by Sidney J. Furie

The Boys in Company C is a 1978 American Hong Kong Vietnam War drama movie directed by Sidney J. Furie and starring Stan Shaw, Andrew Stevens, Craig Wasson, Michael Lembeck, Scott Hylands, R. Lee Eremy. It was distributed by Columbia Pictures.

[[The Betsy]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 drama movies, American drama movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Daniel Petrie

The Betsy is a 1978 American drama movie directed by Daniel Petrie and based on the novel of the same name by Harold Robbins. It stars Laurence Olivier, Tommy Lee Jones, Robert Duvall, Katharine Ross, Jane Alexander, Lesley-Anne Down and was distributed by United Artists.

[[Claudia Winkleman]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 births, British television presenters, English journalists, English television presenters, English writers, Living people, People from Hampstead, People from London

Claudia Anne Irena Winkleman (born 15 January 1972) is an English television presenter, film critic, radio personality, and journalist. Between 2004 and 2010, she presented Strictly Come Dancing: It Takes Two on weeknights on BBC Two. Since 2010, she has co-presented Strictly Come Dancing's main results show on Sunday nights with Tess Daly on BBC One and since 2014 she has been co-host with Daly on the Saturday night live shows, following the departure of Sir Bruce Forsyth. She has twice been nominated for the British Academy Television Award for Best Entertainment Performance for her work on Strictly Come Dancing. 

Winkleman was also the presenter of the BBC's Film..., replacing Jonathan Ross after his move to ITV in 2010.

[[PlayerUnknown's Battlegrounds]]

CATEGORIES: 2017 video games, Android (operating system) games, IOS games, PlayStation 4 games, Windows games, Xbox One games

PlayerUnknown's Battlegrounds (PUBG) is a multiplayer battle royale game published by Tencent Games in corporation with Blue Hole company.

[[Armed and Dangerous (1986 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 comedy movies, 1986 crime movies, 1980s criminal comedy movies, American comedy movies, Movies directed by Mark L. Lester

Armed and Dangerous is a 1986 American comedy movie directed by Mark L. Lester and starring John Candy, Eugene Levy, Meg Ryan, Kenneth McMillan, Brion James, Larry Hankin, Tito Puente. It was distributed by Columbia Pictures and box office reviews were poor.

[[Casey's Shadow]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 drama movies, Family movies, American drama movies, Movies directed by Martin Ritt

Casey's Shadow is a 1978 American family drama movie directed by Martin Ritt and based on the short story by John McPhee. It stars Walter Matthau, Alexis Smith, Murray Hamilton, Robert Webber, Andrew Rubin and was distributed by Columbia Pictures.

[[Midnight Express]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 drama movies, American biographical movies, American drama movies, British biographical movies, British drama movies, Movies directed by Alan Parker, American independent movies, Movies set in Turkey, Istanbul

Midnight Express is a 1978 American British biographical drama movie directed by Alan Parker and based on the 1977 novel of the same name by Billy Hayes. It stars Brad Davis, Irene Miracle, Bo Hopkins, Paolo Bonacelli, Paul L. Smith, Randy Quaid, John Hurt and was distributed by Columbia Pictures. It was nominated for 6 Oscars and won 2 Academy Awards in 1979.

[[Goya Awards]]

CATEGORIES: Movie awards, 1980s establishments in Spain, 1987 establishments in Europe

The Goya Awards (Premios Goya) are Spain's main national annual movie awards.

The awards were created in 1987, a year after the founding of the Academy of Cinematographic Arts and Sciences. The first awards ceremony took place on March 16, 1987 in Madrid. 

The ceremony continues to take place annually at Centro de Congresos Príncipe Felipe, around the end of January/start of February, and awards are given to movies created during the year before.

[[Prime Minister of Gabon]]

CATEGORIES: Prime Ministers of Gabon

This is a list of prime ministers of Gabon since the formation of the post of Prime Minister in 1960, to the present day.

A total of eleven people have been Prime Minister.

[[Eyes of Laura Mars]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 thriller movies, 1970s mystery movies, 1970s serial killer movies, American mystery movies, American thriller movies

Eyes of Laura Mars is a 1978 American mystery thriller movie directed by Irvin Kershner and starring Faye Dunaway, Tommy Lee Jones, Brad Dourif, Raul Julia, René Auberjonois. It was distributed by Columbia Pictures.

[[Paulin Obame-Nguema]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, Living people, Prime Ministers of Gabon

Paulin Obame-Nguema (born 28 December 1934) is a Gabonese politician. He was the Prime Minister of Gabon from 2 November 1994 to 23 January 1999. He is a Deputy in the National Assembly of Gabon.

[[Jean-François Ntoutoume Emane]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, Living people, Prime Ministers of Gabon, Mayors

Jean-François Ntoutoume Emane (born 6 October 1939) is a Gabonese politician. He was Prime Minister of Gabon from 23 January 1999 to 20 January 2006. He was Mayor of Libreville, the capital, from 2008 to 2014.

[[Julien Nkoghe Bekale]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, 1958 births, Prime Ministers of Gabon

Julien Nkoghe Bekale (born 9 January 1962) is a Gabonese politician. He was the 11th Prime Minister of Gabon. In the aftermath of the 2019 Gabonese coup d'état attempt, he was made prime minister by President Ali Bongo Ondimba on 12 January 2019.

[[The Unknown Mariachi]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 comedy movies, Mexican movies

The Unknown Mariachi (El mariachi desconocido) is a 1953 Mexican comedy movie directed by Gilberto Martínez Solares and starring Germán Valdés, Rosa de Castilla, Gloria Mange, Rosita Fornés, Marcelo Chávez, Tito Novaro, Lupe Carriles.

[[Emmanuel Issoze-Ngondet]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from asthma, Prime Ministers of Gabon

Franck Emmanuel Issoze-Ngondet (2 April 1961 – 11 June 2020) was a Gabonese Democratic politician. He was the 10th Prime Minister of Gabon from 2016 until 2019. In the aftermath of the failed coup d'état attempt, President Ali Bongo Ondimba replaced him with Julien Nkoghe Bekale.

From 2012 to 2016, he was the Minister for Foreign Affairs. He was born in Makokou, Gabon.

Issoze-Ngondet died from asthma on 11 June 2020 in the Gabonese capital of Libreville, aged 59.

[[Paul Okoumba d'Okwatsegue]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, Living people, Gabonese people, Civil servants

Paul Okoumba d'Okwatsegue (born December 30, 1933) is a Gabonese politician. He was born in Franceville, Gabon. He was the Foreign Minister of Gabon from 1974 to 1976. He was later he was elected as Secretary-General of the Agency of Cultural and Technical Cooperation (ACCT) on December 16–17, 1985.

[[Paul Malékou]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, Living people, Gabonese people, Civil servants

Paul Malékou (born November 17, 1938) was the Foreign Minister of Gabon for a short time in 1968. He was born in Fougamou, Gabon. Malékou was Director-General of ASECNA from 1975 to 1983.

[[Jean Engone]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, Living people, Gabonese people, Civil servants

Jean Engone (born 1932) is a Gabonese politician. He was the Foreign Affairs Minister of Gabon for 1965 to 1967, during the Léon M'ba presidency. He was born in the capital city of Libreville.

[[Flame Top]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 drama movies, Finnish movies

Flame Top (Tulipää) is a 1980 Finnish drama movie directed by Pirjo Honkasalo and Pekka Lehto. It stars Rea Mauranen, Asko Sarkola, Esko Salminen, Matti Oravisto, Kari Franck.

[[Ain Kaalep]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from Alzheimer's disease, Estonian people, Poets, Playwrights, Translators, Estonian educators, Critics, Essayists, Editors

Ain Kaalep (4 June 1926 – 9 June 2020) was an Estonian poet, playwright, literary critic and translator. 

[[Stan London]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2020 deaths, American physicians, People from Springfield, Illinois, People from St. Louis, Missouri

Stanley London (c. 1925 – June 8, 2020) was an American doctor. He worked with St. Louis Cardinal players from 1956 until his death. He was born in Springfield, Illinois. He became the team's senior medical adviser in October 1997. London was also team physician for the St. Louis Hawks for 11 seasons.

London died on June 8, 2020 under hospice care in Ladue, Missouri at the age of 94.

[[Mr. Wrestling II]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, American professional wrestlers, 2020 deaths, Sportspeople from Atlanta, Georgia, Sportspeople from South Carolina, People from Charleston, South Carolina

John "Johnny" Francis Walker (September 10, 1934 – June 10, 2020) was an American professional wrestler, better known by the ring name Mr. Wrestling II. He was best known for his appearances with Championship Wrestling from Florida and Georgia Championship Wrestling in the 1970s and early 1980s. He was born in Charleston, South Carolina and was raised in Atlanta, Georgia.

Walker died on June 10, 2020 in Mililani, Hawaii at the age of 85.

[[Mililani, Hawaii]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Hawaii

Mililani is a city located near the center of the island of Ookinaahu in Honolulu County, Hawaiʻi, United States. 

It is made up of two census-designated places, Mililani Town, with a population of 27,629 at the 2010 census, and Mililani Mauka, with a 2010 census population of 21,039.

[[Mr. Wrestling]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2002 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, American professional wrestlers, Sportspeople from New York, Sportspeople from Michigan, People from Utica, New York

George Burrell Woodin (July 28, 1934 – November 30, 2002) was an American professional wrestler, better known by his ring names, Mr. Wrestling and Tim Woods. He was born in Utica, New York.

Woodin began his wrestling career at the age of 28 using the name "Tim Woods". He was then given the name "Mr. Wrestling" by Nebraska promotor Joe Dusek. Mr. Wrestling became a major superstar in the Georgia, Florida, Texas and Mid-Atlantic territories. He wrestled in the World Wide Wrestling Federation in the northeast.

On November 30, 2002, Woodin died from a heart attack at his home in Charlotte, North Carolina at the age of 68.

[[Steve Corino]]

CATEGORIES: 1973 births, Living people, Canadian professional wrestlers, People from Winnipeg

Steven Eugene Corino (born May 29, 1973) is a Canadian semi-retired professional wrestler. He is signed with WWE as a trainer and producer for their developmental territory NXT. 

He is best known for his time in Extreme Championship Wrestling (ECW) and Ring of Honor (ROH) under the ring name Steve Corino. He was born in Winnipeg, Manitoba.

[[Ares (wrestler)]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 births, Living people, Swiss sportspeople, Professional wrestlers

Marco Jaggi (born January 12, 1980) is a Swiss professional wrestler and wrestling trainer. He is known by his ring name Ares (or Are$). He was born in Biel/Bienne, Switzerland.

For much of his career, Jaggi teamed with Claudio Castagnoli and Marc Roudin as part of Swiss Money Holding. They were one of the top tag teams in Europe during the 2000s, the trio won titles in Germany, France, the United Kingdom and their native Switzerland.

Under the Freebird Rule, Jaggi held the IPW:UK Tag Team Championship with Castagnoli and Roudin for a record 12 months.

In 2008, he married wrestler Allison Danger. They have one daughter.

[[Jonah and the Pink Whale]]

CATEGORIES: 1995 comedy movies, Bolivian movies, Mexican movies

Jonah and the Pink Whale is a 1995 Bolivian Mexican comedy movie directed by Juan Carlos Valdivia and based on the 1987 novel by José Wolfango Montes Vannuci. It stars Dino García, María Renée Prudencio, Julieta Egurrola.

[[Allison Danger]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 births, Living people, Canadian professional wrestlers, People from Winnipeg

Cathy Allison Corino (born March 31, 1977) is a Canadian retired professional wrestler and professional wrestling manager. She is better known by her ring name, Allison Danger. She was born in Winnipeg, Manitoba. Her brother is also a professional wrestler, Mr. Wrestling III. Danger joined Ring of Honor (ROH) as the manager of the Christopher Street Connection.

Danger is heavily involved with the running of Chicago-based female independent circuit independent professional wrestling promotion Shimmer Women Athletes.

In 2008, she married wrestler Ares. They have one daughter.

[[Jas Waters]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 births, 2020 deaths, Suicides by hanging in the United States, American television writers, Journalists from Chicago, People from Evanston, Illinois

Jas Waters (October 21, 1980 – June 9, 2020), also known as Jas Fly,  was an American screenwriter and journalist. She was known for writing 18 episodes of the TV series This Is Us. She also wrote for The Breaks and Hood Adjacent with James Davis. 

Waters was a journalist in the hip hop industry, writing a digital column for Vibe Vixen in the early 2010s. 

Waters was born in Evanston, Illinois. She studied at Columbia College Chicago. She hung herself on June 9, 2020 in Los Angeles County, California at the age of 39. 

[[Sexual Dependency]]

CATEGORIES: 2003 drama movies, 2000s LGBT movies, American drama movies, Bolivian movies

Sexual Dependency (original Spanish title Dependencia sexual) is a 2003 Bolivian American drama movie directed by Rodrigo Bellott and starring Alexandra Aponte, Roberto Urbina, Jorge Antonino Saavedra, Matthew Guida.

[[Harry Glickman]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2020 deaths, American journalists, Portland Trail Blazers, Sportspeople from Portland, Oregon, Writers from Portland, Oregon, Businesspeople from Portland, Oregon

Harry Glickman (May 13, 1924 – June 10, 2020) was an American journalist, promoter, and sports executive.  He was one of the founders of the Portland Trail Blazers, and the team's president from 1987 to 1994. He was born in Portland, Oregon. He was also a sports editor for The Oregonian.

On June 10, 2020, Glickman died in Portland at the age of 96.

[[Wang Dingguo]]

CATEGORIES: 1912 births, 2020 deaths, Chinese politicians, Chinese military people, Centenarians

Wang Dingguo (王定国; 4 February 1912 – 9 June 2020) was a Chinese Red Army veteran and politician. She was the wife of Xie Juezai, president of the Supreme People's Court. She was a member of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference from 1978 to 1993. She was a member of the Communist Party of China. Wang was born in Yingshan County, Sichuan.

Wang died on 9 June 2020 in Beijing from an illness, aged 108.

[[Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference]]

CATEGORIES: Political organizations based in Asia, Politics of China

The Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC, 中国人民政治协商会议), also known as the People's PCC (人民政协, Chinese-Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference.ogg) or simply the PCC (政协), is a political organization in the People's Republic of China.  The organisation is made up of delegates from eight legally-allowed political parties and other organisations, as well as independent members. 

The CPPCC is controlled by the United Front Work Department.

[[Claudell Washington]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from prostate cancer, Cancer deaths in California, Atlanta Braves players, California Angels players, Chicago White Sox players, New York Mets players, New York Yankees players, Oakland Athletics players, Texas Rangers players, American League All-Stars, National League All-Stars, Baseball players from California, African-American baseball players, Sportspeople from Los Angeles, California, Sportspeople from Atlanta, Georgia

Claudell Washington (August 31, 1954 – June 10, 2020) was an American outfielder in Major League Baseball. He was born in Los Angeles and raised in Atlanta. He won the World Series in 1974.

Washington played for the Oakland Athletics (1974–76), Texas Rangers (1977–78), Chicago White Sox (1978–80), New York Mets (1980), Atlanta Braves (1981–86), New York Yankees (1987–88, 1990) and California Angels (1989–90). 

Washington died on June 10, 2020 from prostate cancer in San Francisco at the age of 65.

[[Basil Meeking]]

CATEGORIES: New Zealand people, Roman Catholics, Bishops, 2020 deaths, 1929 births

John Basil Meeking (19 November 1929 – 11 June 2020) was a New Zealand bishop. He was the 7th bishop of Christchurch, New Zealand from 1987 to 1995. Meeking was born in Ashburton, New Zealand.

He was made Bishop of Christchurch by Pope John Paul II on 30 March 1987 and resigned on 15 December 1995. 

Meeking died in Christchurch on 11 June 2020, aged 90.

[[Katsuhisa Hattori]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from heart failure, Japanese composers, Businesspeople from Tokyo, Record producers

Katsuhisa Hattori was a Japanese classical composer. He also wrote music for anime movies, television shows and OVAs. He was born in Tokyo.

His style was classical, although he also had works which were New Age, Jazz, etc. He was the son of Ryoichi Hattori and father of Takayuki Hattori.

He was a producer and music supervisor for many years, and had his own publishing company, Hattori Music Publishing. He was also pianist, judge and a chairman for the Tokyo music festivals.

Hattori died on June 11, 2020 in Tokyo from heart failure, aged 83.

[[Blackout Tuesday]]

CATEGORIES: June 2020 events

Blackout Tuesday was a collection of action to protest racism and police brutality. The action, originally organized within the music industry in response to the murders of George Floyd, Ahmaud Arbery, and Breonna Taylor, took place on Tuesday, June 2, 2020. 

Businesses taking part were asked to stop the releasing music and other business operations. Some outlets produced blacked out, silent or minimal programming for 8 minutes and 46 seconds, the length of time police officer Derek Chauvin stepped on Floyd's neck, killing him.

[[Eight minutes 46 seconds]]

CATEGORIES: June 2020 events

8′46″ (8 minutes and 46 seconds or 8:46) is the length of time with the killing of George Floyd, who died in police custody after police officer Derek Chauvin knelt on his neck for roughly eight minutes.

In the days after his death, and the protests that followed, that specific time span has become the focus of debates, especially around Blackout Tuesday.

The time has been specifically referenced in "die-in" protests in Minneapolis, New York, Chicago Boston, Philadelphia, Portland, Denver and other cities, where protesters lay down for 8 minutes and 46 seconds to protest police brutality.

[[Shooting of Breonna Taylor]]

CATEGORIES: March 2020 events, Police misconduct, 2020 in the United States, Louisville, Kentucky, 21st century in Kentucky, Racially-motivated violence in the United States

On March 13, 2020, Breonna Taylor, a 26-year-old African-American emergency medical technician, was shot and killed by Louisville Metro Police Department (LMPD) officers. 

That day, three police officers came to her apartment. The officers wore everyday clothing, they were not in uniform.  As they had a search warrant for drugs, there was no way of refusing them entry. Taylor's boyfriend Kenneth Walker and the officers shot at each other. When Walker was questioned, he said he believed that the officers were intruders. The LMPD officers fired over twenty shots. Taylor was shot eight times and LMPD sergeant Mattingly was injured by gunfire. 

Another police officer and an LMPD lieutenant were on the scene when the warrant was executed. No drugs were found in the apartment.

According to a lawsuit filed against the police by the Taylor family's lawyers, the officers entered the home without knocking or announcing that they were police officers.

[[Elisabeth-Anne de Massy]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, Princes and princesses of Monaco

Baroness Elizabeth-Ann de Massy Noghès (13 January 1947 – 10 June 2020) was a Monegasque aristocrat. She was the daughter of Princess Antoinette of Monaco and Alexandre-Athenase Noghès. 

[[Princess Antoinette, Baroness of Massy]]

CATEGORIES: 1920 births, 2011 deaths, Princes and princesses of Monaco

Princess Antoinette of Monaco, Baroness of Massy (Antoinette Louise Alberte Suzanne Grimaldi; 28 December 1920 – 18 March 2011), was a member of the princely family of Monaco. She was the elder sister of Prince Rainier III and aunt of Albert II, Prince of Monaco. 

Her parents were Count Pierre de Polignac and Princess Charlotte, Duchess of Valentinois.

On 18 March 2011 Princess Antoinette died at The Princess Grace Hospital Centre, aged 90.

[[Michel Lévêque]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, 1933 births, Ministers of State of Monaco, Ambassadors of France

Michel Lévêque (born 19 July 1933) is a French diplomat and politician. From 1997 to 2000 he was Minister of State of Monaco. 

He was the French ambassador to Libya (1985-1989), Morocco (1991-1993), Brazil (1993-1994) and Algeria (1995-1997).

[[Minister of State (Monaco)]]

CATEGORIES: Ministers of State of Monaco

The Minister of State is the head of government of Monaco, being appointed by the Prince or Princess of Monaco. 

During their term of office, the holder is responsible for directing the work of the Monegasque government and is in charge of foreign relations.

[[Paul Dijoud]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, Living people, Ambassadors of France, Ministers of State of Monaco

Paul Dijoud (born 25 June 1938) is a Monegasque politician. He was the 18th Minister of State of Monaco from 1994 to 1997. 

Dijoud was born in Neuilly-sur-Seine.  He was French ambassador to Colombia (1988–1991), Mexico (1992–1994) and Argentina (1997–2003). 

[[Patrick Leclercq]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, Living people, Ambassadors to France, Ministers of State of Monaco

Patrick André Leclercq (born 2 August 1938) is a Monegasque politician. He was the Minister of State of Monaco. He was chosen by Rainier III, Prince of Monaco in December 1999 to replace Michel Lévêque.

He was an Ambassador to France, Spain, Egypt (Jordan), Montreal (Canada), as well as in the Foreign Ministry.

He retired in May 2005.

[[Abdelmadjid Tebboune]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, Living people, Prime Ministers of Algeria, Current national leaders, Presidents of Algeria

Abdelmadjid Tebboune (ʿAbd al-Majīd Tabbūn; born 17 November 1945) is an Algerian politician. He is the 8th President of Algeria. He became president in December 2019. He took over the power from former President Abdelaziz Bouteflika and former Acting Head of State Abdelkader Bensalah. 

He was Prime Minister of Algeria from May 2017 to August 2017. He was also Minister of Housing from 2001 to 2002 for a year and again from 2012 to 2017 for 5 years.

[[Liamine Zéroual]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, Living people, Presidents of Algeria

Liamine Zéroual (اليمين زروال ALA-LC: al-Yamīn Zarwāl; Berber: Lyamin Ẓerwal; born 3 July 1941) is an Algerian politician. He was the sixth President of Algeria from 31 January 1994 to 27 April 1999.

[[Brian Connolly]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 1997 deaths, Deaths from liver failure, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Deaths from renal failure, Cardiovascular disease deaths in England, Drug-related accidental deaths in the United Kingdom, Musicians from Glasgow, Scottish rock singers, Scottish singer-songwriters

Brian Francis Connolly (5 October 1945 – 9 or 10 February 1997) was a Scottish singer-songwriter, musician and actor. He is best known as a member of the British glam rock band The Sweet from 1968 to 1979. As the band's lead singer, he performed hit singles such as "Little Willy" (1972), "Wig-Wam Bam" (1972), "Block Buster!" (1973), "The Ballroom Blitz" (1973), "Fox on the Run" (1975) and "Love Is Like Oxygen" (1978).

Connolly was born in Govanhill, Glasgow. His stepbrother was actor Mark McManus. He also had a son, Brian (born 1995).

Connolly was an alcoholic. On 9–10 February 1997, he died due to kidney failure, liver failure and repeated heart attacks in Slough, Berkshire, England. He was 51.

[[Abdelaziz Djerad]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, Living people, Prime Ministers of Algeria

Abdelaziz Djerad (عبد العزيز جراد; born 12 February 1954) is an Algerian politician. He was the 18th Prime Minister of Algeria from 28 December 2019 until 30 June 2021.

[[Rosa Maria Sardà]]

CATEGORIES: Goya Award winners, 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from lymphoma, Cancer deaths in Spain, Spanish movie actors, Spanish television actors, Spanish voice actors, Spanish stage actors, Comedians, Political activists, Entertainers from Barcelona

[[The Drop (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2014 crime movies, American crime movies

The Drop is a 2014 American crime movie directed by Michaël R. Roskam. It was written by Dennis Lehane and is based on his 2009 short story "Animal Rescue". It is about Bob Saginowski, a bartender who becomes involved in an investigation after the mob ran bar that he works at was robbed. It stars Tom Hardy, Noomi Rapace, James Gandolfini (his last movie role), and Matthias Schoenaerts.

The movie was produced by TSG Entertainment and Chernin Entertainment. It premiered at the 2014 Toronto International Film Festival and was released theatrically on September 12, 2014. It had positive reviews and has an 89% approval rating based on 198 votes on Rotten Tomatoes.

[[John Sayles]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American novelists, Editors, Movie directors from New York, Screenwriters from New York, Movie producers from New York, Actors from New York, People from Schenectady, New York

John Thomas Sayles (born September 28, 1950) is an American movie director, screenwriter, editor, actor, and novelist. He has twice been nominated for the Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay, for Passion Fish (1992) and Lone Star (1996). His movie Men with Guns (1997) was nominated for the Golden Globe for Best Foreign Language Film.

[[Bill Smitrovich]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American stage actors, Actors from Connecticut, People from Bridgeport, Connecticut

William Stanley Zmitrowicz Jr. (born May 16, 1947), known professionally as Bill Smitrovich, is an American actor. He was born in Bridgeport, Connecticut.

Smitrovich is known for playing many military roles. These include Independence Day (1996), Air Force One (1997), Thirteen Days (2000), Fail Safe (2000), and Eagle Eye (2008).

[[Starkville, Mississippi]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Mississippi, County seats in Mississippi

Starkville is a city in, and the county seat of, Oktibbeha County, Mississippi, United States.  Mississippi State University, the state's land-grant institution and a public flagship university, is located in Starkville. The population was 25,653 in 2019. 

[[Brian Cummings]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, Living people, Actors from South Dakota, People from Sioux Falls, South Dakota, American voice actors, Disney people

Brian Cummings (born March 4, 1948) is an American voice actor. He is known for his work on G.I. Joe: A Real American Hero, DuckTales and Beauty and the Beast.

[[Sylvester, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: County seats in Georgia, Cities in Georgia (U.S. state)

Sylvester is the county seat of Worth County, Georgia, United States. The population was 6,188 at the 2010 census.  The city is the county seat and business center of Worth County. 

[[Worth County, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: 1853 establishments in Georgia (U.S. state)

Worth County is a county located in the south central portion of the U.S. state of Georgia.

As of the 2010 census, the population was 21,679. The county seat is Sylvester.

[[Poulan, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Georgia (U.S. state)

Poulan is a city in Worth County, Georgia, United States. The population was 851 at the 2010 census.

[[Leighton, Alabama]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Alabama

Leighton is a town in Colbert County, Alabama, United States. It is part of the Florence - Muscle Shoals Metropolitan Statistical Area known as "The Shoals". At the 2010 census the population was 729. 

[[List of prime ministers of Guyana]]

CATEGORIES: Prime Ministers of Guyana

This is a list of the prime ministers of Guyana, from the creation of the office of Chief Minister of British Guiana in 1953 to the present day.

[[COVID-19 pandemic in Guyana]]

CATEGORIES: Guyana, COVID-19 pandemic by country

The COVID-19 pandemic in Guyana is part of the worldwide pandemic of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).

The virus was confirmed to have reached Guyana on 11 March 2020. The first case was a woman who travelled from New York, a 52-year-old woman suffering from other health conditions, including diabetes and hypertension. The woman died at the Georgetown Public Hospital.

[[COVID-19 pandemic in Estonia]]

CATEGORIES: Estonia, COVID-19 pandemic by country

The COVID-19 pandemic in Estonia is part of the ongoing worldwide pandemic of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). The virus was confirmed to have spread to Estonia when the first case was confirmed in Tallinn on 27 February 2020.

By 11 March, 15 people in Estonia had been diagnosed with the virus, all of them had been infected outside the country, mostly in Northern Italy. On 12 March, the first cases of locally transmitted infections emerged, and on 13 March, the Estonian government declared a state of emergency until 1 May 2020. That emergency situation was extended to May 17. As a result, all the schools and universities were closed, and all public gatherings banned, including sports and cultural events.

As of 1 September, the total number of confirmed cases in the country was 2,395 of which 2,112 had recovered and 64 had died. As of 1 October, the total number of confirmed cases in the country was 3,450 of which 2,643 had recovered and 65 had died.

By the end of 2020, the total number of confirmed cases was 27,990 of which 18,326 had recovered and 229 had died.

[[Cabell County, West Virginia]]

CATEGORIES: West Virginia counties

Cabell County is a county in the U.S. state of West Virginia. As of the 2010 census, the population was 96,319, making it West Virginia's fourth-most populous county. Its county seat is Huntington. The county was organized in 1809.

[[Wayne County, West Virginia]]

CATEGORIES: West Virginia counties

Wayne County is the westernmost county in the U.S. state of West Virginia. As of the 2010 census, the population was 42,481. Its county seat is Wayne. The county was founded in 1842.

[[Wayne, West Virginia]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in West Virginia, County seats in West Virginia

Wayne is a town in Wayne County, West Virginia, United States. The population was 1,413 at the 2010 census. It is the county seat of Wayne County.

[[Matthias Schoenaerts]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 births, Living people, Belgian movie actors, Belgian television actors, Belgian stage actors, Belgian voice actors, Belgian artists, Belgian movie producers, People from Antwerp

Matthias Schoenaerts (ˈ; ˈmɑtjɑs ˈsxunaːrts; born 8 December 1977) is a Belgian actor, movie producer, and graffiti artist. 

Schoenaerts is best known for his roles as Filip in Loft (2008), Jacky Vanmarsenille in the Oscar-nominated Bullhead (2011), Ali in the BAFTA and Golden Globe-nominee Rust and Bone (2012), Eric Deeds in The Drop (2014), Bruno von Falk in Suite Française (2015), Gabriel Oak in Far from the Madding Crowd (2015), Hans Axgil in The Danish Girl (2015) and Uncle Vanya in Red Sparrow (2018). 

He also starred as an ex-soldier suffering from PTSD in Disorder (2015), and as an inmate training a wild horse in The Mustang (2019).

[[List of women executed in the United States since 1976]]

CATEGORIES: American murderers, American people executed for murder

This is a list of women executed in the United States since 1976. Since 1976, when the Supreme Court lifted the moratorium on capital punishment in Gregg v. Georgia, sixteen women have been executed in the United States. Women represent just 1.07% of the 1,492 executions performed in the United States since 1976.

[[Samala]]

CATEGORIES: Somalia

Samala is a place in Sool, Somalia, next to Guumays. It was the first place in Somalia where the British and Darawiish fought.

[[Kraisak Choonhavan]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from tongue cancer, Thai politicians, Guitarists, People from Bangkok

Kraisak Choonhavan (ไกรศักดิ์ ชุณหะวัณ; 8 October 1947 – 11 June 2020) was a Thai politician. He was a member of the Senate for Nakhon Ratchasima Province from 2000 until 2006. He was also Deputy Leader of the Democrat Party from 2008 to 2011. He was born in Bangkok.

Choonhavan died of tongue cancer in Bangkok on 11 June 2020, aged 72.

[[Jung Ho-young]]

CATEGORIES: 2001 births, Living people, South Korean volleyball players

Jung Ho-young (Korean: 정호영; RR: Jeong Ho-yeong; born 23 August 2001) is a South Korean female professional volleyball player.

She also competed at the 2018 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship. 

[[Hans Mezger]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, German engineers, People from Stuttgart

Hans Mezger (18 November 1929 – 10 June 2020) was a German automotive engineer. He was well known for his work at Porsche. Mezger was born near Stuttgart, Baden-Württemberg. He retired in 1994.

His first project was to work on the valve train of the Fuhrmann-designed Carrera engine. Over the next 35 years he took part in the 1960s F1 programme and  had design leadership for the first Porsche 911 production.

Mezger was responsible for the Porsche-made TAG Turbo engine from the mid 1980s, which won multiple championships in Formula One in the McLaren MP4/2 chassis.

Mezger died on 10 June 2020 at the age of 90.

[[Waterville, Maine]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Maine

Waterville is a city in Kennebec County, Maine, United States. As of the 2010 census the population was 15,722.

[[Johnny Mandel]]

CATEGORIES: Grammy Award winners, Academy Award winning composers, 1925 births, 2020 deaths, American composers, American conductors, Writers from New York City, Musicians from New York City

John Alfred Mandel (November 23, 1925 – June 29, 2020) was an American composer, conductor and arranger of movie scores and jazz music. He was born in New York City.

Mandel's most famous compositions include "Suicide Is Painless" (theme from the movie and TV series M*A*S*H), "Close Enough for Love", "Emily" and "A Time for Love" (nominated for an Academy Award).  

He wrote many movie scores, including the score of The Sandpiper. The love theme for that movie "The Shadow of Your Smile", which he co-wrote with Paul Francis Webster, won the 1965 Academy Award for Best Original Song and the Grammy Award for Song of the Year in 1966.

Mandel died on June 29, 2020 at his home in Ojai, California at the age of 94.

[[Richard Hooker (author)]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 1997 deaths, Deaths from leukemia, American novelists, American military personnel of the Korean War, American physicians, Writers from New Jersey, Writers from Maine, People from Trenton, New Jersey

Hiester Richard Hornberger Jr. (February 1, 1924 – November 4, 1997) was an American writer and surgeon. He wrote under the pseudonym Richard Hooker. 

Hornberger's best-known work was his novel MASH (1968), based on his dramatic and comedic experiences as a wartime army surgeon doctor during the Korean War (1950–1953). It was used as the source for an award-winning movie movie – M*A*S*H (1970) and the long running television series (1972–1983) of the same name.

Hooker was born in Trenton, New Jersey. He studied at Bowdoin College and at Cornell University. Hooker died on November 4, 1997 in Waterville, Maine from leukemia, aged 73.

[[M*A*S*H (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 comedy movies, 1970 drama movies, 1970s comedy-drama movies, 1970s war movies, American black comedy movies, American war movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Robert Altman, Golden Globe Award winning movies

M*A*S*H is a 1970 American black comedy war movie directed by Robert Altman and written by Ring Lardner Jr.. It is based on Richard Hooker's 1968 novel MASH: A Novel About Three Army Doctors. The movie's score was composed by Johnny Mandel.

The movie is about a unit of medical personnel stationed at a Mobile Army Surgical Hospital (MASH) during the Korean War. It stars Donald Sutherland, Tom Skerritt, and Elliott Gould, with Sally Kellerman, Robert Duvall, René Auberjonois, Gary Burghoff, Roger Bowen, Michael Murphy, and Fred Williamson. 

Although M*A*S*H was based during the Korean War, the movie was set in the Vietnam War. 

It was released on January 25, 1970 to strong positive reviews. The movie has an 86% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, based on 50 reviews. Critic Roger Ebert gave the movie four out of four stars.

The movie went on to receive five Academy Award nominations, including Best Picture, and won for Best Adapted Screenplay. M*A*S*H was selected for preservation in the United States National Film Registry. The Academy Film Archive preserved M*A*S*H in 2000. 

The movie inspired the television series M*A*S*H, which ran from 1972 to 1983. Gary Burghoff, who played Radar O'Reilly, was the only actor who appeared on both movie and television show.

It is also the #56 movie on AFI's 100 Years... 100 Movies list and #7 on AFI's 100 Years... 100 Laughs list.

[[Roger Bowen]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 1996 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, American novelists, Actors from Connecticut, Writers from Connecticut, People from Providence, Rhode Island

Roger Bowen (May 25, 1932 – February 16, 1996) was an American actor and novelist. He was known for his role of Lt. Col. Henry Blake in the 1970 movie MASH. He was born in Providence, Rhode Island.

Bowen died on February 16, 1996 while on vacation in Marathon, Florida from a heart attack, aged 63. The day before, McLean Stevenson who played Henry Blake in the television show, died.

[[Laura Bernal (diplomat)]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, 2020 deaths, Argentine politicians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Argentina, People from Buenos Aires

Laura Bernal (1956 – 26 April 2020) was an Argentine diplomat. She served as Argentina's ambassador to Ireland from 2016 until her sudden death in 2020. She was present in the country for her compatriot Pope Francis's visit to Ireland as part of World Meeting of Families 2018.

Bernal was from Buenos Aires. She died at her Rathmines home on 26 April 2020 and was found post-mortem to have contracted COVID-19. At the request of her sister and due to the COVID-19 pandemic, Bernal's body was not repatriated. Her funeral took place on 15 May at St Michael's parish church in Foxford and she was buried afterwards at nearby Craggagh Cemetery. Foxford is where Admiral William Brown (who founded the Argentine Navy) was born, hence this choice. As well as her sister, Bernal was survived by niblings and a sister-in-law.

[[Bayaz Aliyeva]]

CATEGORIES: 1990 births, Living people, Azerbaijani sportspeople, Volleyball players

Bayaz Aliyeva (born 9 June 1990 in Sumqayit) is an Azerbaijani female volleyball player. She is a member of the Azerbaijan women's national volleyball team. She was part of the Azerbaijani national team at the 2018 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship.

She played for Telekom Baku in 2015–2016, at the 2015–16 CEV Women's Champions League.

[[Taba, Egypt]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Egypt

Taba (طابا ar, ˈtˤɑːbɑ) is a city in Egypt. It is next to the border of Israel on the Gulf of Aqaba. It is next to the Israeli town of Eilat. There is a road border crossing here into Israel. It is Egypt's busiest. It is the furthest north resort of the Red Sea Riviera.

[[Shafagat Alishanova]]

Shafagat Alishanova (born 8 March 1991 in Kemerovo) is an Azerbaijani female volleyball player. She is a member of the Azerbaijan women's national volleyball team. She was part of the Azerbaijani national team at the 2018 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship and 2019 Women's European Volleyball Championship.

She played for Azerrail Baku and E.Leclerc Radomka Radom

[[Iryna Joukova]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 births, Ukrainian volleyball players, Living people, Sportspeople from Kiev

Iryna Joukova (also known as Iryna Zhukova, born 22 November 1974 in Kiev) is a Ukrainian volleyball player.

She participated at the 2001 Women's European Volleyball Championship, 2004-2005 Women's Volleyball Champions League, 2011 Women's World Volleyball Club Championship, and 2012 FIVB Women's Club World Championship.

From 2003 to 2005, she played for Volley Bergamo. She played for VC Zarechye Odintsovo. In 2012 to 2013, she played for Rabita Baku.

[[Assistant referee]]

CATEGORIES: Referees

An assistant referee is a referee that helps the main referee with areas that they cannot see or control. The assistant referee has the power to do things that the main referee cannot do. For example, in Football (soccer), the assistant referee can call offside, determine if a goal was valid based on the ball position, and determine who is in possession if the ball went out of play. However, assistant referees cannot overrule a referee's decision, such as if an assistant believes there was an offside but the referee believes there was not.

[[Ivy Vila Wittingham]]

CATEGORIES: 2001 births, Living people, Cuban volleyball players

Ivy Vila Wittingham (born 22 July 2001) is a Cuban female volleyball player. She is a member of the Cuba women's national volleyball team and played for Camagüey in 2018.

She was part of the Cuban national team at the 2018 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship, and 2019 FIVB Volleyball Women's U20 World Championship.

She was part of the Cuban national team at the 2018 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship.

[[Latisha Morain]]
