[[Portia White]]

CATEGORIES: 1911 births, 1968 deaths, Canadian singers, Cancer deaths in Ontario, Contraltos, Deaths from breast cancer, Entertainers from Nova Scotia

Portia May White (June 24, 1911 – February 13, 1968) was a Canadian contralto. She is known for becoming the first black Canadian concert singer to gain international fame. She trained at the Halifax Conservatory of Music. She also taught young musicians such as Lorne Greene, Dinah Christie, Don Francks, Robert Goulet and Anne Marie Moss. She performed a special command performance for Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip in 1964. Her final public appearance was in Ottawa during July 1967.

White was born in Truro, Nova Scotia. Her mother was a descendant of Black Loyalists in Nova Scotia. Her father, William A. White, was the son of former slaves in Virginia.

On February 13, 1968, White died of breast cancer in Toronto, Ontario. She was 56.

[[Renele Forde]]

CATEGORIES: 1990 births, Living people, Trinidad and Tobago volleyball players

Renele Forde (born 6 August 1990) is a Trinidad and Tobago female volleyball player. She was part of the Trinidad and Tobago women's national volleyball team.

She participated in the 2007 Women's NORCECA Volleyball Championship, 2007 Women's Pan-American Volleyball Cup, 2008 Women's Pan-American Volleyball Cup, 2009 Women's Pan-American Volleyball Cup, 2013 Women's Pan-American Volleyball Cup, 2013 Women's NORCECA Volleyball Championship, 2015 Women's NORCECA Volleyball Championship, 2017 FIVB Volleyball World Grand Prix, and 2018 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship.

She played for University of Central Florida's women's volleyball team and Florida International University's women's volleyball team.

[[Coleshill, Warwickshire]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Warwickshire

Coleshill (ˈ KOH) is a town in Warwickshire, England. It is named after the River Cole, which flows through the town. It is about 10.0 east of Birmingham and about 10.4 northwest of Coventry. In 2011, 6,481 people lived there.

[[Kassam tree frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Frogs

The Kassam tree frog (Litoria multiplica) is a tree frog from Papua New Guinea. It lives in forests and swamps far from the ocean.

Scientists say the tadpoles look different from other Litoria tadpoles.  They have dark black and brown stripes and bright gold spots.

[[Slender tree frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Frogs

The slender tree frog (Litoria adelaidensis) is a tree frog from Australia.  It lives in southwestern Australia.

These frogs can grow to 4.5 cm long.  They are pale brown to bright green in colour.  They have stripes down their sides. Adult frogs live near the coast or inland and stay near bodies of water.

They lay their eggs on underwater plants.  The tadpoles are light in colour with stripes down their sides and can grow to 5.5 cm long.  They have two rows of teeth on their top jaw and three rows of teeth on their lower jaw.

Even though this frog's Latin name comes from the city Adelaide, the frogs do not live in Adelaide.

[[Super NES Classic Edition]]

CATEGORIES: Nintendo video game consoles

The Super NES Classic Edition (also known as SNES Mini) is a dedicated home video game console. It was released in 2017 by Nintendo. It is the successor to the NES Classic Edition and emulates the Super Nintendo Entertainment System (SNES). The console comes with two controllers. The cables of the controllers are 1.4 meter long.

[[Hussein Arnous]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, Living people, Prime Ministers of Syria, Current national leaders

Hussein Arnous (born 1953) is a Syrian politician. He became Prime Minister of Syria on 11 June 2020. He became Prime Minister after President Bashar al-Assad had fired Imad Khamis due to the worsening economic crisis. 

[[Murray Olderman]]

CATEGORIES: American cartoonists, 1922 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Writers from New York City

Murray Olderman (March 27, 1922 – June 10, 2020) was an American sports cartoonist and writer. His art was used by the Pro Football Hall of Fame and hung above the Hall of Fame statues. The Hall of Fame made all of the artwork digital so that visitors to the hall can see them through electronic kiosks. He was born in New York City.

Olderman died on June 10, 2020 in Rancho Mirage, California from a heart attack, aged 98.

[[Burton Natarus]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Chicago City Council members, American political scientists, Writers from Chicago, Writers from Wisconsin, Politicians from Wisconsin, US Democratic Party politicians

Burton F. "Burt" Natarus (November 7, 1933 – June 5, 2020) was an American politician. He was an Alderman of the 42nd Ward of Chicago from 1971 to 2007. Natarus was born in Wausau, Wisconsin. He was a member of the Democratic Party.

Natarus died on June 5, 2020 in Chicago, aged 86.

[[Mel Winkler]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American video game actors, American stage actors, Actors from St. Louis, Missouri

Mel Winkler (October 23, 1941 – June 11, 2020) was an American actor. He was born in St. Louis, Missouri. He was known for his voice role of Aku Aku in Crash Bandicoot. He also voiced Lucius Fox in The New Batman Adventures. He starred as Melvin in the 1991 comedy Doc Hollywood.

Winkler died on June 11, 2020 in Los Angeles, aged 78.

[[Murder by Death]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 comedy movies, 1970s mystery movies, American mystery movies, American comedy movies

Murder by Death is a 1976 American mystery comedy movie directed by Robert Moore and written by Neil Simon. It stars Eileen Brennan, Truman Captone, James Coco, Peter Falk, Peter Sellers, Elsa Lanchester, Alec Guinness, David Niven, Maggie Smith and was distributed by Columbia Pictures.

[[The New Batman Adventures]]

CATEGORIES: 1997 television series debuts, 1999 television series endings, American animated television series, Batman, DC Animated Universe, Superhero television shows

The New Batman Adventures (often shortened as TNBA) is an American superhero animated television series based on the DC Comics superhero Batman. It is a continuation of the 1990s Batman: The Animated Series. It was produced by Warner Bros. Animation and aired on Kids' WB from September 13, 1997 to January 16, 1999.

[[Tim Drake]]

CATEGORIES: DC Comics superheroes, Batman characters, Fictional characters introduced in 1989

Timothy Jackson Drake is a fictional superhero appearing in American comic books published by DC Comics. He is a sidekick of superhero Batman. He was created by Marv Wolfman and Pat Broderick.

He first appeared in Batman #436 (August 1989) as the third character to assume the role of Batman's sidekick Robin. 

The character has been seen in The New Batman Adventures, Young Justice: Invasion, and the video game series Batman: Arkham. In 2011, Tim Drake was ranked 32nd in IGN's Top 100 Comic Book Heroes.

[[Creeper (DC Comics)]]

CATEGORIES: Batman characters

Creeper (Jack Ryder), is a fictional character, a superhero created by Steve Ditko and Don Segall for DC Comics. He is a former talk show host dressed in a wild costume with a green, yellow, and red color scheme. 

He is characterized by super strength, agility, and stamina. He can heal himself quickly and has a painful laughter. 

The Creeper is supposed to be the hero version of Joker.

[[Richard Moll]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2021 deaths, American movie actors, American television actors, American video game actors, American voice actors, Actors from Pasadena, California, Accidental deaths from falls in the United States

Charles Richard Moll (January 13, 1943 – February 5, 2021) was an American actor. He was best known for playing Aristotle Nostradamus "Bull" Shannon, the bailiff on the NBC sitcom Night Court from 1984 to 1992 and as the voice of Harvey Dent/Two-Face in Batman-related shows. 

Moll died on February 5, 2021, in his home in North Bend, Washington, at the age of 78, after suffering a fall.

[[George Dzundza]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American stage actors, German movie actors, German television actors, German voice actors, German stage actors, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Actors from New York City

George Dzundza (ˈ ZUUND; born July 19, 1945) is an American actor. He was born in Rosenheim, Germany. He was an original cast member of the long-running NBC drama Law & Order, playing NYPD Sergeant Max Greevey in the first season. He voiced supervillain the Ventriloquist in Batman: The Animated Series and Perry White in Superman: The Animated Series.

[[The Andromeda Strain (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 science fiction movies, 1971 thriller movies, American science fiction movies, American thriller movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Robert Wise

The Andromeda Strain is a 1971 American science fiction thriller movie directed by Robert Wise and based on the 1969 novel of the same name by Michael Crichton. It stars Arthur Hill, James Olson, David Wayne, Paula Kelly, Kate Reid, George Mitchell and was distributed by Universal Pictures. It was nominated for 2 Academy Awards in 1972.

[[Perfecto Yasay Jr.]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from pneumonia, Deaths from lung cancer, Filipino politicians

Perfecto "Jun" Rivas Yasay Jr. (January 27, 1947 – June 12, 2020) was a Filipino politician. He was Secretary of Foreign Affairs of the Philippines from June 30, 2016 until March 8, 2017. He was a member of the Bangon Pilipinas. He was born in Kidapawan, Philippines.

He was Chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) from 1995 to 2000 and was Bangon Pilipinas Party's vice-presidential candidate in the 2010 Philippine elections, running alongside Eddie Villanueva.

Yasay Jr. died on June 12, 2020 in Manila from pneumonia caused by lung cancer, aged 73.

[[Silent Running]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 science fiction movies, American science fiction movies, Post-apocalyptic movies, Dystopian movies

Silent Runnning is a 1972 American science fiction movie directed by Douglas Trumbull and starring Bruce Dern, Cliff Potts, Ron Rifkin, Jesse Vint. It was distributed by Universal Pictures.

The style of the film is apocalyptic. This is a subgenre of science fiction, science fantasy, dystopian or horror film where the Earth's technological civilization is collapsing or has collapsed.

[[List of presidents of Madagascar]]

CATEGORIES: Presidents of Madagascar

This is a list of presidents of Madagascar, since the creation of the office of President in 1959, during the Malagasy Republic.

[[Marc Ravalomanana]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, Living people, Presidents of Madagascar

Marc Ravalomanana, GCSK (born 12 December 1949) is a Malagasy politician. He was the President of Madagascar from 2002 to 2009.

He resigned following a popular uprising in 2009. 

From 2009 to 2012 Ravalomanana lived in exile in South Africa.

In October 2014 he was arrested after returning to Madagascar, having been sentenced in absentia to lifelong hard labour for abuses of power. After his sentence was lifted and he was freed from house arrest in May 2015.

[[Prime Minister of Madagascar]]

CATEGORIES: Prime Ministers of Madagascar

This is a list of prime ministers of Madagascar, since the creation of the office of Chief Minister in 1828, during the Merina Kingdom.

[[Christian Ntsay]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, Living people, Current national leaders, Prime Ministers of Madagascar

Christian Louis Ntsay (born 27 March 1961) is a Malagasy politician. In June 2018, he became Prime Minister of Madagascar. He was appointed by President Hery Rajaonarimampianina. Ntsay worked for the United Nations.

[[Robert Fisk]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, English journalists, War correspondents, Political commentators, Writers from Kent, Irish writers

Robert Fisk (12 July 1946 – 30 October 2020) an English-Irish writer and journalist. He was a Middle East correspondent from 1976 until his death for many medias. From 1989 until his death, he was a correspondent for The Independent. Fisk was born in Maidstone, Kent.

Fisk studied at Lancaster University and at Trinity College Dublin.

He was a known Arabic speaker, he was the few Western journalists to interview Osama bin Laden. He interviewed him three times between 1993 and 1997.

Fisk died of a stroke on 30 October 2020 at a Dublin, Ireland hospital at the age of 74.

[[The World's Greatest Lover]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 comedy movies, American comedy movies

The World's Greatest Lover is a 1977 American comedy movie directed by Gene Wilder (who also stars) and starring Carol Kane, Dom DeLuise, Danny DeVito, Fritz Feld, Ronny Graham. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[High Anxiety]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 comedy movies, 1977 thriller movies, American comedy movies, American thriller movies, Movies directed by Mel Brooks

High Anxiety is a 1977 American comedy thriller movie directed by Mel Brooks (who also stars) and starring Madeline Kahn, Cloris Leachman, Harvey Korman, Ron Carey, Dick Van Patten, Barry Levinson. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[The Turning Point]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 drama movies, American drama movies, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Herbert Ross

The Turning Point is a 1977 American drama movie directed by Herbert Ross and starring Shirley MacLaine, Anne Bancroft, Tom Skerritt, Leslie Browne, Mikhail Baryshnikov, Martha Scott. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox and was nominated for 11 Academy Awards in 1978.

[[Sheikh Ahidul Islam]]

CATEGORIES: Possibly living people, Bangladeshi people

Sheikh Shahidul Islam

Sheikh Sahidul Islam Politician of Bagerhat District of Bangladesh And elected a member of parliament from Bagerhat-2.

[[Wizards (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 movies, 1970s science fiction movies, 1970s fantasy movies, American animated movies, American science fiction movies, American fantasy movies

Wizards is a 1977 American animated science fiction fantasy movie directed by Ralph Bakshi and starring Bob Holt, Jesse Welles, Richard Romanus, David Proval, Steve Gravers, Mark Hamill. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Phosphorite]]

CATEGORIES: Sedimentary rocks

A phosphorite or phosphate rock is a non-detrital sedimentary rock which contains high amounts of phosphate bearing minerals.

[[The Legend of Hell House]]

CATEGORIES: 1973 horror movies, 1970s fantasy movies, British horror movies, British fantasy movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by John Hough

The Legend of Hell House is a 1973 British fantasy horror movie directed by John Hough and based on the 1971 novel Hell House by Richard Matheson. It stars Pamela Franklin, Roddy McDowall, Clive Revill, Gayle Hunnicutt, Roland Culver and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Snake in the Eagle's Shadow]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 comedy movies, 1970s action movies, Hong Kong movies

Snake in the Eagle's Shadow (蛇形刁手) is a 1978 Hong Kong action comedy movie directed by Yuen Woo-ping and starring Jackie Chan, Hwang Jang-lee, Yuen Siu-tien, Dean Shek, Roy Horan. It was distributed by Seasonal Film Corporation.

[[The Last Image]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 drama movies, Algerian movies, Movies directed by Mohammed Lakhdar-Hamina

The Last Image (الصور الأخير, translit. Al-coura al-akhira, La dernière image) is a 1986 Algerian drama movie directed by Mohammed Lakhdar-Hamina and stars Véronique Jannot, Merwan Lakhdar-Hamina, Michel Boujenah, Jean Bouise, Jean-François Balmer. It was distributed by Cannon Films.

[[To Kill with Intrigue]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 movies, 1970s action movies, Hong Kong movies, South Korean movies

To Kill with Intrigue (劍花煙雨江南) is a 1977 Hong Kong South Korean action movie directed by Lo Wei and starring Jackie Chan, Hsu Feng, George Wang, Yuen Biao.

[[Race for the Yankee Zephyr]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 action movies, 1980s adventure movies, New Zealand movies, Australian movies

Race for the Yankee Zephyr (also known as Treasure of the Yankee Zephyr) is a 1981 New Zealand Australian action adventure movie directed by David Hemmings and starring Ken Wahl, Lesley Ann Warren, George Peppard, Donald Pleasence, Bruno Lawrence, Grant Tilly.

[[Parasnath Yadav]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from bladder cancer, Indian politicians

Parasnath Yadav (12 January 1949 – 12 June 2020) was an Indian Samajwadi Party politician. He was a member of 17th Legislative Assembly of Uttar Pradesh from Malhani (Assembly constituency) in Jaunpur district of Uttar Pradesh. He also was Minister of Rural Engineering Department in Government of Uttar Pradesh. He was born in Jaunpur, Uttar Pradesh.

Yadav died at his home in Jaunpur on 12 June 2020 from bladder cancer, aged 71.

[[Dan Hicks (actor)]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in California, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American stage actors, Actors from Michigan, People from Pontiac, Michigan

Dan Hicks (July 19, 1951 – June 30, 2020) was an American actor. Hicks was best known for starring roles in Evil Dead II, Darkman and Intruder. He starred in many movies directed by Sam Raimi such as Spider-Man 2 and Oz the Great and Powerful. 

Hicks was born in Pontiac, Michigan. 

On June 6, 2020, he was diagnosed with stage-4 cancer. He died from the disease a few weeks later on June 30, 2020 in California, aged 68.

[[Claremont, New Hampshire]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in New Hampshire

Claremont is the only city in Sullivan County, New Hampshire, United States. The population was 13,355 at the 2010 census.

[[Jean Hersholt]]

CATEGORIES: 1873 births, 1943 deaths, Deaths from pancreatic cancer, Cancer deaths in Los Angeles, Danish movie actors, Danish television actors, Danish stage actors, Danish movie directors, Naturalized citizens of the United States, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American radio actors, American movie directors, People from Copenhagen

Jean Pierre Carl Buron (12 July 1873 – 2 June 1943), known professionally as Jean Hersholt, was a Danish-American actor and director. He was best known for starring on the radio series Dr. Christian from 1937 to 1942 and in the movie Heidi (1937). He was born in Copenhagen.

He told The Literary Digest how to pronounce his last name, "In English, her'sholt; in Danish, hairs'hult." 

Hersholt died on 2 June 1943 in Hollywood, California of pancreatic cancer, aged 69.

[[Chronicle of the Years of Fire]]

CATEGORIES: 1975 drama movies, Algerian movies, Movies directed by Mohammed Lakhdar-Hamina

Chronicle of the Years of Fire (Waqāʾiʿu sinīna l-jamri; Chronique des Années de Braise; these names both mean "Chronicle of the Years of Embers") is a 1975 Algerian historical drama movie directed by Mohammed Lakhdar-Hamina (who also stars) and starring Yorgo Voyagis, Hadj Smaine Mohamed Seghir, Lelia Shenna, François Maistre.

[[Rosemary DeCamp]]

CATEGORIES: 1910 births, 2001 deaths, Deaths from pneumonia, Disease-related deaths in California, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American radio actors, Actors from Arizona, People from Prescott, Arizona

Rosemary DeCamp (November 14, 1910 – February 20, 2001) was an American actress. She was born in Prescott, Arizona. Her career lasted from 1937 to 1989.

Her first movie role was in Cheers for Miss Bishop and appeared in many Warner Bros. movies, including Eyes in the Night, Yankee Doodle Dandy playing Nellie Cohan, This Is The Army alongside Ronald Reagan, Rhapsody in Blue, and Nora Prentiss. 

She played the mother of the character played by Sabu Dastagir in Jungle Book.

DeCamp died at her home in Newport Beach, California on February 20, 2001 from pneumonia, aged 90.

[[The Prisoner of Second Avenue]]

CATEGORIES: 1975 comedy movies, American black comedy movies, Movies based on plays, Movies directed by Melvin Frank

The Prisoner of Second Avenue is a 1975 American black comedy movie directed by Melvin Frank and based on the 1971 play of the same name by Neil Simon. It stars Jack Lemmon, Anne Bancroft, Gene Sacks, F. Murray Abraham, Sylvester Stallone and was distributed by Warner Bros..

[[Dorothy Fay]]

CATEGORIES: 1915 births, 2003 deaths, American movie actors, American television actors, American silent movie actors, Actors from Arizona, People from Prescott, Arizona

Dorothy Fay (April 4, 1915 – November 5, 2003) was an American actress. She was known for her appearances in Western movies. She was born in Prescott, Arizona. 

She played a heroine in The Green Archer (1940) and White Eagle (1941), both at Columbia Pictures. 

Fay also made a few small appearances in other genres, such as the crime drama Missing Daughters (1939). She had a small role in The Philadelphia Story, which starred Cary Grant, James Stewart, and Katharine Hepburn. 

She was married to Tex Ritter. She was the mother of John Ritter and paternal grandmother of Jason Ritter and Tyler Ritter.

Fay died on November 5, 2003 in Los Angeles at the age of 88.

[[Tex Ritter]]

CATEGORIES: 1905 births, 1974 deaths, Deaths from aortic dissection, American country singers, American silent movie actors, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, Actors from Texas, Singers from Texas

Woodward Maurice "Tex" Ritter (January 12, 1905 – January 2, 1974) was an American country music singer and actor. He was popular in the mid 1930s into the 1960s.

His son was actor John and his grandchildren include Jason and Tyler, and granddaughter Carly. He is a member of the Country Music Hall of Fame.

In 1936, Ritter moved to Los Angeles. His motion picture debut was in Song of the Gringo (1936). He starred in 12 B-movie Westerns for Grand National, including Headin' for the Rio Grande (1936), and Trouble in Texas (1937) co-starring Rita Hayworth.

Between 1938 and 1945, he starred in around forty "singing cowboy" movies. He made four movies with actress and future wife Dorothy Fay.

Ritter died in Nashville, Tennessee on January 2, 1974 from an aortic dissection, aged 68.

[[Liu Shaoqi]]

CATEGORIES: Presidents of the People's Republic of China, 1898 births, 1969 deaths, Unexplained deaths

Liu Shaoqi (pronounced l; 刘少奇; 24 November 1898spaced ndash12 November 1969) was a Chinese revolutionary, politician, and theorist. 

He was Chairman of the NPC Standing Committee from 1954 to 1959, First Vice Chairman of the Communist Party of China from 1956 to 1966 and Chairman (President) of the People's Republic of China, China's de jure head of state, from 1959 to 1968.

For 15 years, President Liu was the third most powerful man in China, behind only Chairman Mao Zedong and Premier Zhou Enlai. In the early 1960s before the Cultural Revolution, he became a critic of Mao. 

Liu disappeared from public life in 1968 and was called the "commander of China's bourgeoisie headquarters", China's foremost "capitalist-roader", and a traitor to the revolution.

Liu died on 12 November 1969 in Kaifeng, Henan while under torture, aged 70. After his death, the Chinese government later honored him with a state funeral and is now seen as a political hero.

[[The Sunshine Boys]]

CATEGORIES: 1975 comedy movies, American comedy movies, Movies based on plays, MGM movies, Movies directed by Herbert Ross

The Sunshine Boys is a 1975 American comedy movie directed by Herbert Ross and based on the 1972 play of the same name by Neil Simon. It stars George Burns, Walter Matthau, Richard Benjamin, Lee Meredith, F. Murray Abraham, Fritz Feld, Ron Rifkin, Carol Arthur. It was distributed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and was nominated for 4 Oscars and won an Academy Award in 1976.

[[Rosalind Chao]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American stage actors, Actors from California, People from Anaheim, California

Rosalind Chao (born September 23, 1967) is an American actress. 

Chao's best-known roles have been Soon-Lee Klinger in the mid-1980s CBS show AfterMASH, Rose Hsu Jordan in the 1993 movie The Joy Luck Club, Keiko O'Brien on Star Trek: The Next Generation and Star Trek: Deep Space Nine in the 1990s, and Dr. Kim on The O.C. in 2003.

For some time, Chao worked at Disneyland as an international tour guide.

[[Taija Thomas]]

CATEGORIES: 1996 births, Living people, Trinidad and Tobago volleyball players

Taija Thomas (born 24 October 1996) is a Trinidad and Tobago female volleyball player. She was part of the Trinidad and Tobago women's national volleyball team.

She participated in the 2018 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship.

[[Sofia Carson]]

CATEGORIES: 1993 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American pop singers, American dancers, Singers from Florida, Actors from Florida, People from Fort Lauderdale, Florida

Sofía Daccarett Char (born April 10, 1993), known professionally as Sofia Carson, is an American actress and singer. Her first appearance on television was as a guest star on the Disney Channel series Austin & Ally. In 2015, she appeared as Evie, the daughter of the Evil Queen, in the Disney Channel Original Movie Descendants, and later returned to this role in Descendants 2 and Descendants 3. 

[[Darlene Ramdin]]

CATEGORIES: 1989 births, Living people, Trinidad and Tobago volleyball players

Darlene Ramdin (born 5 August 1989) is a Trinidad and Tobago female volleyball player. She was part of the Trinidad and Tobago women's national volleyball team.

She participated in the 2017 FIVB Volleyball World Grand Prix and 2018 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship.

She played for St. John's University's women's volleyball team.

[[Anand Mohan Zutshi Gulzar Dehlvi]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in India, Indian journalists, Indian poets, Indian educators, People from New Delhi

 Anand Mohan Zutshi Gulzar Dehlavi  (Urdu: آنند موھن زتشی گلزار دہلوی; आनंद मोहन जुत्शी गुलजार आनंद मोहन जुत्शी गुलजार देहलवी) (7 July 1926 – 12 June 2020) was an Indian poet, scholar, and journalist. He was honored by Vice President Mohammad Hamid Ansari on his 91st birthday for his works towards Urdu Poetry. He was an editor of the first Urdu science magazine named Science Ki Dunya. He was born in New Delhi. He taught at the University of Delhi for forty years.

Gulzar Dehlvi died on 12 June 2020 in New Delhi from problems caused by COVID-19, aged 93.

[[Kiune Fletcher]]

CATEGORIES: 2002 births, Living people, Trinidad and Tobago volleyball players

Kiune Fletcher (born 14 May 2002) is a Trinidad and Tobago female volleyball player. She was part of the Trinidad and Tobago women's national volleyball team.

She participated in the 2017 FIVB Volleyball World Grand Prix and 2018 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship.

[[David Owen Brooks]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, American serial killers, American rapists, American people convicted of assault, American people convicted of manslaughter, People from Houston, Texas, Criminals from Texas

David Owen Brooks (February 12, 1955 – May 28, 2020) was an American convicted murderer. Working with serial killer Dean Corll, who, along with Elmer Wayne Henley Jr., abducted, raped, tortured, and murdered at least 28 boys and young men in a series of killings from 1970 to 1973 in Houston, Texas. 

The crimes, which became known as the Houston Mass Murders.

Many of the victims had been friends of Brooks and Henley. At the time of their discovery, the Houston Mass Murders were seen as the worst example of serial murder in American history.

In the years since his 1975 conviction, Brooks was repeatedly denied parole (most lately in 2018). He was next eligible for parole in 2028.

Brooks died of COVID-19 on May 28, 2020 in a Galveston, Texas hospital while serving out his life sentence. He was 65.

[[Delicia Pierre]]

CATEGORIES: 1991 births, Living people, Trinidad and Tobago volleyball players

Delicia Pierre (born 11 October 1991) is a Trinidad and Tobago female volleyball player. She was part of the Trinidad and Tobago women's national volleyball team.

She participated in the 2017 FIVB Volleyball World Grand Prix and 2018 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship. 

She played for Bethune-Cookman University's women's volleyball team.

[[Ninth Fort]]

CATEGORIES: Lithuania, Forts

The Ninth Fort (Devintas Fortas) is a stronghold in the northern part of Šilainiai elderate, Kaunas, Lithuania. It is a part of the Kaunas Fortress, which was constructed in the late 19th century. 

During the occupation of Kaunas and the rest of Lithuania by the Soviet Union, the fort was used as a prison and way-station for prisoners being transported to labour camps. 

After the occupation of Lithuania by Nazi Germany, the fort was used as a place of execution for Jews, captured Soviets, and others.

[[Frank Bolle]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2020 deaths, American comics artists, American illustrators

Frank W. Bolle (June 23, 1924 – May 12, 2020) was an American comic-strip artist, comic book artist and illustrator. He was best known as the longtime artist of the newspaper strips Winnie Winkle and The Heart of Juliet Jones. He also drew for comic books Tim Holt and Doctor Solar, Man of the Atom. He was the illustrator for the Boy Scouts of America magazine Boys' Life for 18 years. 

Bolle died May 12, 2020 in Weston, Connecticut at the age of 95.

[[Markus Klaer]]

CATEGORIES: 1968 births, 2020 deaths, German engineers, Politicians from Berlin

Markus Klaer (June 26, 1968 – May 21, 2020) was a German politician and engineer. He was a member of the Christian Democratic Union (CDU). Klaer was in the Abgeordnetenhaus of Berlin, the city's state parliament, from 2011 until 2016. He returned to the Abgeordnetenhaus from August 1, 2019, until his death in May 28, 2020. He was born in Geseke, North Rhine-Westphalia.

Klaer died on May 21, 2020 at the age of 51.

[[Józef Grzesiak (boxer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Polish sportspeople, Olympic bronze medalists, Boxers

Józef Grzesiak (18 February 1941 – 30 May 2020) was a Polish boxer. He was born in Popów, Greater Poland Voivodeship, Poland. He competed for Poland in the 1964 Summer Olympics held in Tokyo, Japan. He finished in third place, winning a bronze medal.

Grzesiak died of dementia-related problems in Warsaw on 30 May 2020, aged 79.

[[Claude Heater]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, Cardiovascular disease deaths in California, American opera singers, American movie actors, Actors from Oakland, California, Singers from Oakland, California

Claude Heater (October 25, 1927 – May 28, 2020) was an American opera singer and actor. He was also known for playing the role of Jesus Christ in the 1959 classic movie Ben-Hur. Heater was born in Oakland, California.

Heater died on May 28, 2020 from heart disease in San Francisco at the age of 92.

[[Laiana Rodrigues]]

CATEGORIES: 1982 births, Living people, Brazilian sitting volleyball players

Laiana Rodrigues (born 8 May 1982) is a Brazilian Paralympic sitting volleyball player. She is part of the Brazil women's national sitting volleyball team. She competed at the 2016 Summer Paralympics, 2015 Parapan American Games, and 2019 Parapan American Games.

[[Simone Turck]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2020 deaths, French stage actors, French theatre directors, People from Toulouse

Simone Turck (1924 – 23 May 2020) was a French actress and theatre director. She starred in French Shakespeare productions of Twelfth Night, King Lear and The Taming of the Shrew. A theatre director, she directed French productions of The Game of Love and Chance, La Dispute, The Barber of Seville and Electra. 

Turck was born in Toulouse. She died in Nice on 23 May 2020, aged 96.

[[Johann Weber (bishop)]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, Austrian Roman Catholics, Bishops

Johann Weber (26 April 1927 – 23 May 2020) was an Austrian Roman Catholic bishop. He was ordained to the priesthood in 1950. He was bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Graz-Seckau, Austria, from 1969 until 2001. Weber was also Chairman of the Episcopal Conference of Austria between 1995 and 1998.

[[Kitbull]]

CATEGORIES: 2019 movies, Pixar short movies, Disney+ movies

Kitbull is a 2019 American animated short movie directed and written by Rosana Sullivan, produced by Pixar Animation Studios, and made by Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures. 

It is the third movie in Pixar's "SparkShorts" program. It is about stray kitten and an abused pit bull, who form an unlikely friendship. The short premiered at El Capitan Theatre on January 18, 2019, before being released on YouTube on February 18, 2019. 

The short was also released on Disney+ on November 12, 2019.

The movie had strong positive reviews. The short was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film at the 92nd Academy Awards.

[[Lava (2014 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2014 animated movies, 2010s musical movies, 2014 romance movies, Pixar short movies, American musical movies, American romance movies

Lava is a 2014 American computer-animated musical romantic short movie, produced by Pixar Animation Studios. It was directed by James Ford Murphy and produced by Andrea Warren.

It premiered at the Hiroshima International Animation Festival on June 14, 2014, and was theatrically released alongside Pixar's Inside Out on June 19, 2015. 

The short is a musical love story that takes place over thousands of years between two volcanoes near Hawaii. It stars Kuana Torres Kahele and Nāpua Greig.

[[Piper (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: Academy Award winning movies, 2016 animated movies, Pixar short movies

Piper is a 2016 computer-animated short movie produced by Pixar Animation Studios. It was written and directed by Alan Barillaro, it was theatrically released alongside Pixar's Finding Dory on June 17, 2016. It won the Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film at the 89th Academy Awards, becoming the first Pixar animated short to win the award since For the Birds in 2002.

The short movie is about a hungry baby sandpiper learning to overcome her fear of water.

[[Bao (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2018 animated movies, Pixar short movies

Bao is a 2018 American computer-animated short movie written and directed by Domee Shi and produced by Pixar Animation Studios. It was released with Incredibles 2 on June 15, 2018. 

The movie is about an aging and lonely Chinese-Canadian mother, suffering from empty nest syndrome, who gets a second chance at motherhood when she makes a steamed bun (baozi) that comes to life. 

The movie won the Oscar for the Best Animated Short Film at the 91st Academy Awards.

[[The Blue Umbrella]]

CATEGORIES: 2013 movies, Pixar short movies

The Blue Umbrella is a 2013 computer-animated short movie produced by Pixar Animation Studios that was released alongside Monsters University. The short is directed by Saschka Unseld of Pixar's technical department. The short uses photorealistic lighting, shading, and compositing.

The movie was about a blue umbrella that falls in love with a red umbrella in the middle of a storm in a busy city. However, because of the story, it makes it hard for the blue umbrella to follow and find the red umbrella. Eventually, the owners of the umbrella find each other and therefore the two umbrellas fall in love.

[[Eppie Wietzes]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Canadian sportspeople, Racecar drivers, Sportspeople from Drenthe

Egbert "Eppie" Wietzes (28 May 1938 – 10 June 2020) was a Dutch-born Canadian racing driver. He was born in Assen, Netherlands. 

Wietzes took part in two Formula One World Championship Grands Prix, debuting on 27 August 1967. He retired on lap 69 with wet electrics and was disqualified for receiving outside assistance. Wietzes also participated in the 1974 Canadian Grand Prix with a rented Brabham BT42 but again retired with a transmission problem.

He was the driver of the first safety car in Formula One, in the 1973 Canadian Grand Prix, taking a Porsche 914 course car on to the track after a crash involving François Cevert and Jody Scheckter.

Wietzes was inducted into Canadian Motorsport Hall of Fame in 1993.

[[François Cevert]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 1973 deaths, Formula One drivers, Sportspeople from Paris

Albert François Cevert Goldenberg (25 February 1944 – 6 October 1973) was a French racing driver. He took part in the Formula One World Championship. He competed in 47 World Championship Grands Prix, achieving one win, 13 podium finishes and 89 career points.

He was killed in a racing competition in Watkins Glen, New York on 6 October 1973, aged 29.

[[Horst's tree frog]]

CATEGORIES: Frogs, Animals of Oceania

Horst's tree frog (Litoria amboinensis) is a tree frog from Papua New Guinea.  People have seen it in the Southern Highlands Province, from 1280 to 1750 metres above sea level.

These frogs can grow to 6.5 cm long.  People have seen them near human-made ponds by the edges of forests.  They make a loud rattling sound with their voices.

[[Capitol Hill Autonomous Zone]]

CATEGORIES: Seattle, Washington, June 2020 events

The Capitol Hill Autonomous Zone (CHAZ) was sometimes called Free Capitol Hill, or Capitol Hill Free Zone (CHFZ), others called it the Capitol Hill Organized Protest (CHOP). Some people called it a country. It was in Seattle, which is a big city in Washington. It was 6 city blocks in size. A city block is a group of buildings with a street next to it. It started on June 8, 2020 because all police left the area.

They wanted the United States of America to lower costs of rent, destroy expensive buildings near cheap buildings, make medicine and hospitals free, make all people who have been seen destroying things while in groups be let out of jail, and to lay off all police officers. Lay off means to make someone stop working.

Some people liked the Capitol Hill Autonomous Zone. Some people did not like the Capitol Hill Autonomous Zone. Donald Trump and Ted Cruz did not like the Capitol Hill Autonomous Zone. The mayor of Seattle Jenny Durkan thinks that it is party, not a real country.

Some people who live in Seattle are suing the city because they say they should move people out of the Capitol Hill Autonomous Zone.

[[Cape Melville tree frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Frogs

The Cape Melville tree frog (Ranoidea andiirrmalin) is a tree frog from Australia.  It lives in the Melville Range mountains on Cape Melville in Queensland.

These frogs live in fields of boulders near rainforests.  They are difficult for people to study because the mountains are hard to climb. As of 2004, they had only been found in four streams.

[[Yucca moth]]

CATEGORIES: Butterflies

Yucca moths are a family of  butterflies (Lepidopera). There are about 80 species, in two subfamilies. Many of them are specific to one or a few species of agave-like plants. The moths live inside the plants. They are an example of co-evolution: many moths evolved with the specific host plant. The host plants sometimes adapted that they need specific moths for pollination.

[[Pâmela Pereira]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 births, Living people, Brazilian sitting volleyball players, Brazilian Paralympic bronze medalists

Pamela Pereira (born 25 April 1988) is a Brazilian Paralympic sitting volleyball player. She is part of the Brazil women's national sitting volleyball team.

She won the bronze medal, Brazil's first in the sport, at the 2016 Summer Paralympic Games in Rio de Janeiro, after defeating the Ukrainian women's national sitting volleyball team by 3 sets to 0, and the silver medal at the 2019 Parapan American Games.

[[Afe­sha Olton-Humphreys]]

CATEGORIES: 1992 births, Living people, Trinidad and Tobago volleyball players

Afesha Olton-Humphreys (born 22 May 1992) is a Trinidad and Tobago female volleyball player. She was part of the Trinidad and Tobago women's national volleyball team.

She participated in the 2017 FIVB Volleyball World Grand Prix and 2018 FIVB Volleyball Women's World Championship.

[[Nurya de Almeida Silva]]

CATEGORIES: 1991 births, Living people, Brazilian sitting volleyball players, Brazilian Paralympic bronze medalists

Nurya de Almeida Silva (born 26 April 1991) is a Brazilian Paralympic sitting volleyball player. She is part of the Brazil women's national sitting volleyball team.

She won the bronze medal, Brazil's first in the sport, at the 2016 Summer Paralympic Games in Rio de Janeiro, after defeating the Ukrainian women's national sitting volleyball team by 3 sets to 0, and the silver medal at the 2019 Parapan American Games.

She plays for VBC Galina Schaan.

[[Janaína Petit Cunha]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 births, Living people, Brazilian sitting volleyball players

Janaína Petit Cunha (born 16 July 1977) is a Brazilian Paralympic sitting volleyball player. She is part of the Brazil women's national sitting volleyball team.

She competed at the 2016 Summer Paralympics.

[[Camila Maria Leiria de Castro]]

CATEGORIES: 1982 births, Living people, Brazilian sitting volleyball players, Brazilian Paralympic bronze medalists

Camila Maria Leiria de Castro (born 8 May 1982) is a Brazilian Paralympic sitting volleyball player. She is part of the Brazil women's national sitting volleyball team.

She won the bronze medal, Brazil's first in the sport, at the 2016 Summer Paralympic Games in Rio de Janeiro, after defeating the Ukrainian women's national sitting volleyball team by 3 sets to 0.

[[Gizele Maria Dias da Costa]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 births, Living people, Brazilian sitting volleyball players, Brazilian Paralympic bronze medalists

Gizele Maria Dias da Costa (born 29 October 1977) is a Brazilian Paralympic sitting volleyball player. She is part of the Brazil women's national sitting volleyball team.

She won the bronze medal, Brazil's first in the sport, at the 2016 Summer Paralympic Games in Rio de Janeiro, after defeating the Ukrainian women's national sitting volleyball team by 3 sets to 0.

[[Edwarda de Oliveira Dias]]

CATEGORIES: 1999 births, Living people, Brazilian sitting volleyball players, Brazilian Paralympic bronze medalists

Edwarda de Oliveira Dias (born 22 April 1999 in Suzano) is a Brazilian Paralympic sitting volleyball player. She is part of the Brazil women's national sitting volleyball team.

She won the bronze medal, Brazil's first in the sport, at the 2016 Summer Paralympic Games in Rio de Janeiro, after defeating the Ukrainian women's national sitting volleyball team by 3 sets to 0.

[[Terrorizers]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 drama movies, Taiwanese movies, Movies directed by Edward Yang

Terrorizers is a 1986 Taiwanese drama movie directed by Edward Yang and starring Cora Miao, Lee Li-chun, Chin Shih-chieh, Yu An-shun, Ku Pao-ming. It was distributed by Central Motion Pictures.

[[Let's Play in the World]]

Let's Play in the World (Juguemos en el mundo) is a 1971 Argentine musical comedy movie directed by María Herminia Avellaneda and starring Rodolfo Machado, Eva Franco, María Elena Walsh, Perla Santalla, Jorge Mayor, Hugo Caprera.

[[Shampoo (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1975 comedy movies, American comedy movies, Movies directed by Hal Ashby

Shampoo is a 1975 American comedy movie directed by Hal Ashby and starring Warren Beatty, Julie Christie, Tony Bill, Lee Grant, Jack Warden, Jay Robinson, Carrie Fisher, Susanna Moore. It was distributed by Columbia Pictures and was nominated for 4 Oscars and won an Academy Award in 1976.

[[Li Ting]]

Li Ting (born 25 October 1989) is a Chinese female sitting volleyball player. She won a silver medal at the 2016 Summer Paralympics.

[[Christina Schwenkel]]

CATEGORIES: American anthropologists, Editors, Living people, Year of birth missing (living people)

Christina Schwenkel is an American anthropologist and historian. She is an associate professor at University of California, Riverside. She is co-editor of Journal of Vietnamese Studies. She won a Berlin Prize.

Her work appeared in Sense.

[[Alison Sherwood]]

CATEGORIES: American journalists, Pulitzer Prize winners, Living people, Year of birth missing (living people)

Alison Sherwood is an American journalist. She won a 2011 Pulitzer Prize for Explanatory Reporting. She works for the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel.

She studied at the University of Missouri. In 2016, she participated in the Journalists in the Community program, sponsored by the Wisconsin Humanities Council.

[[Rebecca Kimitch]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, Year of birth missing (living people), American journalists, Pulitzer Prize winners

Rebecca Kimitch  is an American journalist. She won a 2015 Pulitzer Prize for Local Reporting.

She studied at Northwestern University. She worked for the Daily Breeze, Los Angeles News Group, and Metropolitan Water District of Southern California.

[[Nancy Cleeland]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, Year of birth missing (living people), American journalists, Pulitzer Prize winners

Nancy Cleeland is an American journalist. She won a 2004 Pulitzer Prize for National Reporting. and 2004 George Polk Award. She works for Economic Policy Institute.

She studied at University of Arizona. She worked for the Associated Press and the Los Angeles Times.

[[Abigail Goldman]]

CATEGORIES: American journalists, Pulitzer Prize winners, George Polk Award winners, Living people, Year of birth missing (living people)

Abigail Goldman is an American journalist. She won a 2004 Pulitzer Prize for National Reporting and 2004 George Polk Award. She teaches at University of California, Los Angeles.

She graduated from University of Wisconsin-Madison and Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism. She worked for the Los Angeles Times.

[[Maggie Michael]]

Maggie Michael is an Egyptian journalist based in Cairo. She won a 2019 Pulitzer Prize for International Reporting and 2019 Michael Kelly Award. She covered the civil war in Yemen from 2015 to 2019.

She studied at Northwestern University. She worked for the Baltimore Sun and WBEZ's This American Life.

[[Moscow on the Hudson]]

CATEGORIES: 1984 comedy movies, 1984 drama movies, 1984 romance movies, 1980s romantic comedy movies, 1980s romantic drama movies, American romantic comedy movies, American romantic drama movies, Movies directed by Paul Mazursky

Moscow on the Hudson is a 1984 American romantic comedy drama movie directed by Paul Mazursky and starring Robin Williams, María Conchita Alonso, Cleavant Derricks, Alejandro Rey, Yakov Smirnoff. It was distributed by Columbia Pictures.

[[Rapture (BioShock)]]

CATEGORIES: Video games

Rapture is a fictional city where the BioShock series of video games takes place. The city was built at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean so that no government could find it. Rapture is a city based on the ideas of objectivism, the philosophy that believes everything people do should be based on logic (rather than emotion) and for their own self-interest. 

Rapture was built by a man named Andrew Ryan. Andrew Ryan believed that the governments and religions above the ocean wanted to take away the wealth from people who worked hard for it and to give it to so-called "parasites", people who take away things from people who worked for it. He wanted Rapture to be a place where people could become anything or do anything they wanted if they worked hard for it, a place where science could develop quickly because religions could not enforce morality to slow down or stop scientific research, a place where artists could make any art they wanted because governments could not censor their ideas, a place where rich and powerful people would not be forced to give anything to poor and powerless people.

Due to not having laws that slowed down or stopped scientific research, many intelligent scientists from above the ocean moved to Rapture and made many new discoveries. This allowed Rapture to develop very quickly. The most important discovery is the discovery of ADAM. ADAM is a liquid that comes from sea slugs that can rewrite a person's genetic code. This allows people to have special powers like shooting lighting bolts, shooting fire, and lifting objects without touching them. However, ADAM was also extremely addictive, and if users of ADAM went through long periods of time without it, they would suffer serious health problems and go insane. People who got withdrawals from ADAM would turn into Splicers. Unfortunately, many people in Rapture also became addicted to ADAM, and ADAM became something everyone in Rapture wanted and needed. Since ADAM had such a high demand and low supply, young girls called Little Sisters were raised to collect ADAM from dead Splicers. As Splicers would try to kill Little Sisters to take the ADAM they collected, Big Daddies were created to protect the Little Sisters. Big Daddies would kill anyone who attacked a Little Sister.

However, when the wealth gap between the rich and poor people of Rapture became too wide, Frank Fontaine, also known as Atlas, sold ADAM and made charities to help the poor people of Rapture. Also, since the economy of Rapture is based on laissez-faire captalism (an economy where governments make as little changes to the economy as possible), businesses could sell ADAM to people without any laws stopping it. Since Atlas was giving help and selling ADAM to the poor people of Rapture, they would become loyal to him. Since Atlas was gaining power and tried to control Rapture, Ryan betrayed the values he built Rapture on and became a dictator. Eventually, a civil war in Rapture was fought between people who supported Ryan and people who supported Atlas. This made Rapture a very dangerous place. Many people left Rapture to go back to the surface world. Most of the people who stayed in Rapture became Splicers.

[[Colleen McCain Nelson]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, Year of birth missing (living people), American journalists, Pulitzer Prize winners

Colleen McCain Nelson is an American journalist and editorial writer. She won the 2010 Pulitzer Prize for Editorial Writing. She is editorial page editor of the Kansas City Star.

Nelson grew up in Salina, Kansas. She was editor of the Tripodium newspaper at Salina High School South and won a national award for excellence in feature writing in 1991. She studied at the University of Kansas, where she was editor of The University Daily Kansan. She was a reporter for The Wichita Eagle and Fort Worth Star-Telegram. She was columnist for The Dallas Morning News. She was the White House reporter for The Wall Street Journal.

Nelson's husband, Eric, oversees The Kansas City Star's digital news operations.

[[Angiana tree frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Asia, Frogs

The angiana tree frog (Litoria angiana) is a large tree frog from Papua New Guinea and Indonesia.

Male adult frogs can grow to 5.5 cm long and females can be 8 cm long.  They can be brown or green with a dark stripe on the sides.  There are yellow spots around the stripe.

They live near rivers and in forests.

[[Diana Dadabaeva]]

CATEGORIES: 1991 births, Living people, Uzbekistani water polo players

Diana Dadabaeva (born 29 July 1991) is an Uzbekistani female water polo player. She was a member of the Uzbekistan women's national water polo team. 

She was a part of the team at the 2009 World Aquatics Championships, 2010 Asian Games, 2011 World Aquatics Championships, and 2013 World Aquatics Championships.

She was a part of the team at the 2009 World Aquatics Championships.

[[Daniela Lavorini]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 births, Living people, Italian water polo players

Daniela Lavorini (born 15 August 1976) is a female water polo player from Italy.

She participated at the 1997 Women's European Water Polo Championship, 2003 Women's European Water Polo Championship, and 2009 World Aquatics Championships.

On the club level, she played for Fiorentina Waterpolo.

[[Bicycle-sharing system]]

CATEGORIES: Cycling, Transport infrastructure

A bicycle sharing system is in place all around the world and is very popular. It is an easy way to reduce emissions as bikes are sustainable and safe. You can find these bikes at a dock and return the dock of the same brand. 

These bikes may be free of charge or have a small fee that increases however long the bike is away from a dock.

[[Mary Overlie]]

CATEGORIES: American dancers, American educators, American choreographers, Writers from Montana, 1946 births, 2020 deaths, People from Havre, Montana

Mary Overlie (January 15, 1946 – June 5, 2020) was an American choreographer, dancer, theater artist, professor and author. She was a creator of the Six Viewpoints technique for theater and dance. She was born in Havre, Montana. Overlie was the co-founder of the art institutions such as Danspace Project, the Studies Project, Movement Research, and the Experimental Theater Wing at New York University.

Overlie died on June 5, 2020 at the age of 74.

[[Basen Murmu]]

CATEGORIES: Indian singers, 1987 births, 2020 deaths

Basen Murmu (9 April 1987 – 8 June 2020) was an Indian emerging popular singer in the Santali film and album world. 

Basen Murmu was born in Barhajian village of Bijtala block in Mayurbhanj district of Odisha. His parents were Naran Murmu and Maina Murmu. He was married to Mamta Murmu. Bhagyalakshmi Murmu is his only daughter.

Basen Murmu died at the young age of 33. On 8 June 2020, he suddenly collapsed and was taken to Rairangpur Government Hospital for treatment, where doctors declared him dead.

[[Talat Özkarslı]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Turkish footballers, Turkish football managers

Sefer Talat Özkarslı (21 March 1938 – 10 June 2020), nicknamed Koçero,  was a Turkish football manager and footballer. He played as a defender. Özkarslı was best known for his playing career with Galatasaray from 1961 to 1971. He also played for the national team from 1962 to 1968. He also managed Gaziantepspor. Özkarslı was born in Gaziantep, Turkey.

Özkarslı died on 10 June 2020, aged 82.

[[Marcel Maréchal]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, French movie actors, French television actors, French stage actors, French screenwriters, French movie directors, People from Lyon, French theatre directors

Marcel Maréchal (25 December 1937 – 11 June 2020) was a French actor, writer, and director. He was born in Lyon, France. He was best known for his roles in I as in Icarus (1979), Simple mortel (1991) and Fanfan (1993).

Maréchal died on 11 June 2020 in Paris, aged 82.

[[Dennis O'Neil]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cardiopulmonary arrest, American comics writers, American editors, Writers from St. Louis, Missouri

Dennis J. O'Neil, also known as Denny O'Neil (May 3, 1939 – June 11, 2020) was an American comic book writer and editor. He worked for Marvel Comics and DC Comics from the 1960s through the 1990s. He was a Group Editor for the Batman family of titles until his retirement. O'Neil was born in St. Louis, Missouri.

O'Neil died on June 11, 2020 from cardiopulmonary arrest in Nyack, New York at the age of 81.

[[Matt Poore]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, New Zealand cricketers

Matt Beresford Poore (1 June 1930 – 11 June 2020) was an international New Zealand cricketer. He played 14 Tests for New Zealand in the 1950s. He was born in Christchurch.

Poore died at a retirement home in North Shore, Auckland, on 11 June 2020 at the age of 90.

[[Alan Burgess (cricketer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1920 births, 2021 deaths, New Zealand cricketers, People from Christchurch

Alan Thomas Burgess (1 May 1920 – 5 January 2021) was a New Zealand cricketer who played first-class cricket for Canterbury from 1940 to 1952. He was a tank driver in World War II. He was born in Christchurch. 

In nine matches for Canterbury between 1945-46 and 1951-52 his top score was 42 against Auckland in 1950-51, when he put on 105 for the first wicket with Ray Emery.

Burgess celebrated his 100th birthday in May 2020. He died on 5 January 2021 in Rangiora, New Zealand.

[[Carl Brewer (politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, 2020 deaths, American mayors, Politicians from Wichita, Kansas, US Democratic Party politicians

Carl Brewer (March 8, 1957 – June 12, 2020) was an American Democratic politician. He was the 100th mayor of Wichita, Kansas and was Wichita's first black mayor. He was elected in 2007 and reelected in 2011. He was born in Wichita.

Brewer died on June 12, 2020 in Wichita at the age of 63.

[[Brandon Whipple]]

CATEGORIES: 1982 births, Living people, American mayors, American educators, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from New Hampshire, Politicians from Wichita, Kansas, US Democratic Party politicians

Brandon Whipple (born July 13, 1982) is an American politician and educator. He was elected Mayor of Wichita, Kansas in 2020. He was a Democratic member of the Kansas House of Representatives representing the 96th district.

He was an adjunct professor of American politics at Wichita State University. 

[[Waka Waka (This Time for Africa)]]

CATEGORIES: 2010 songs, Shakira songs

"Waka Waka (This Time for Africa)", called "Waka Waka (Esto es África)" in Spanish, is a song by Colombian singer Shakira, featuring the South African band Freshlyground. It was released on 7 May 2010 by Epic Records as the official song of the 2010 FIFA World Cup, which was held in South Africa. 

It was written, composed, and produced by Shakira and John Hill, "Waka Waka (This Time for Africa)" is a pop song.

It positive reviews from critics, however, it was controversial after mant South Africans expressed disappointment in FIFA's decision to select Shakira to sing the song, arguing that a native artist should performed it.

"Waka Waka (This Time for Africa)" peaked at number one on record charts of fifteen countries worldwide. 

It was the biggest song of 2010 in seven countries, is the seventh bestselling song of all-time in Switzerland, and the tenth in Belgium and France. "Waka Waka (This Time for Africa)" has sold 15 million downloads worldwide, becoming one of the best-selling singles of all time.

[[Arthur Donald Spatt]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from blood cancer, Cancer deaths in New York, American judges, Politicians from New York City

Arthur Donald Spatt (December 13, 1925 – June 12, 2020) was an American politician and judge. Spatt was the United States District Judge of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York from 1989 to 2004. He was born in New York City. Spatt was nominated by President George H. W. Bush.

Spatt died on June 12, 2020 in Commack, New York from blood cancer, aged 94.

[[Commack, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places in New York (state)

Commack (' KOH) is a census designated place (CDP) in the towns of Huntington and Smithtown in Suffolk County, New York, United States, on Long Island. The CDP's population was 36,124 at the 2010 census.

[[Ricky Valance]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from dementia, Welsh singers

Ricky Valance (born David Spencer, 10 April 1936 – 12 June 2020) was a Welsh pop singer. He was best known for the UK number one single "Tell Laura I Love Her", which sold over a million copies in 1960. He was the first male Welsh singer to have a UK number one single hit. Valance was born in Ynysddu, Monmouthshire.

Valance died on 12 June 2020 from dementia-related problems in Spain, aged 84.

[[Sprague Grayden]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 births, Actors from Massachusetts, American movie actors, American stage actors, American television actors, American voice actors, Living people

Sprague Grayden (born July 21, 1980) is an American actress. She played schoolteacher Heather Lisinski in the television drama Jericho, Karen Kawalski in John Doe, first daughter Olivia Taylor in the television thriller 24, and Kristi Rey in the movies Paranormal Activity 2 and 3.

[[Manchester-by-the-Sea, Massachusetts]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Massachusetts

Manchester-by-the-Sea (also known simply as Manchester) is a town on Cape Ann, in Essex County, Massachusetts, United States. The town is known for its beaches. At the 2010 census, the population was 5,136.

[[Essex, Massachusetts]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Massachusetts

Essex is a coastal town in Essex County, Massachusetts, 26 miles (42 km) north of Boston and 13 miles (21 km) southeast of Newburyport. The population was 3,504 at the 2010 census.

[[Cape Ann]]

CATEGORIES: Geography of Massachusetts

Cape Ann is a rocky cape in northeastern Massachusetts, United States on the Atlantic Ocean.  It is about 30 miles northeast of Boston. It is the northern limit of Massachusetts Bay. 

Cape Ann includes the city of Gloucester and the towns of Essex, Manchester-by-the-Sea and Rockport.

It was named after Anne of Denmark.

The Cowboys is a 1972 American western movie directed by Mark Rydell. It is based on the novel of the same name by William Dale Jennings. It stars John Wayne, Roscoe Lee Browne, Slim Pickens, Colleen Dewhurst, and Bruce Dern. It was distributed by	Warner Bros..

[[The Last Polka]]

The Last Polka is a 1985 Canadian mockumentary movie written by John Candy and Eugene Levy (also who stars) and starring Rick Moranis, Catherine O'Hara.

[[Brahmanda Purana]]

CATEGORIES: Hinduism

The ''Brahmanda Purana'' is one of the oldest Puranas. Estimates for the composition of its earliest core vary widely. The early 20th-century Indian scholar Dikshitar dated the Brahmanda to 4th-century BCE. Most later scholarship places this text to be from centuries later, in the 4th- to 6th-century BCE. The text is generally assumed, states Ludo Rocher, to have achieved its current structure about 1000 CE.

The text was often changed after the 10th-century, and new sections probably replaced older ones. The 13th-century Yadava dynasty scholar Hemadri quoted large parts of the then existing Brahmanda Purana, but these parts are not found in currently surviving versions of the same text. This suggests that the 13th-century version of this Purana was different in many respects than extant manuscripts.

The Adhyatma-ramayana, the most important embedded set of chapters in the extant versions of the Purana, is considered to have been composed centuries later, possibly in the 15th-century, and is attributed to Ramananda – the Advaita scholar and the founder of the Ramanandi Sampradaya, the largest monastic group in Hinduism and in Asia in modern times. The Adhyatma-ramayana thus was added to this Purana later, and it is an important document to the Rama-related tradition within Hinduism.

A Javanese Brahmanda palm-leaf manuscript was discovered in Indonesia in the mid-19th century by colonial-era Dutch scholars, along with other Puranas. The Sanskrit originals of these are either lost or yet to be discovered. The Javanese Brahmanda was translated by the Dutch Sanskrit scholar Jan Gonda and compared to Sanskrit texts found in India.

[[The Van (1977 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 comedy movies, 1970s teen movies, American comedy movies, American independent movies

The Van is a 1977 American teen comedy movie directed by Sam Grossman and stars Stuart Getz, Danny DeVito, Deborah White, Harry Moses, Bill Adler. It was distributed by Crown International Pictures.

[[Phil Lester]]

CATEGORIES: 1987 births, Living people, BBC radio presenters, Gay men, LGBT entertainers, Internet celebrities, Writers from Lancashire

Philip Michael Lester (born 30 January 1987) is an English YouTuber and presenter. He is best known for his YouTube channels AmazingPhil, which has over 4 million subscribers, and DanAndPhilGAMES.

Together with friend Daniel Howell, Lester presented Sunday night entertainment show Dan and Phil (radio show) on BBC Radio 1 from January 2013 until August 2014, and from September 2014 to April 2016.

Lester was born in Rawtenstall, Rossendale, Lancashire. He is openly gay.

[[B. Kannan]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, 2020 deaths, Cardiovascular disease deaths in India, Indian cinematographers

Bhimsingh Kannan (10 January 1951 – 13 June 2020) was an Indian cinematographer. He was born in Madras, Tamil Nadu. He was known for his works with director P. Bharathiraja. His best known works were Oru Nadigai Natakam Parkiral (1978), Kadalora Kavithaigal (1986) and Solla Thudikuthu Manasu (1988).

Kannan died on 13 June 2020 from problems caused by heart disease at a hospital in Chennai, Tamil Nadu, aged 69.

[[S. Robson Walton]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, Living people, American billionaires, American lawyers, Businesspeople from Arkansas, Businesspeople from Tulsa, Oklahoma

Samuel Robson "Rob" Walton (born October 28, 1944) is an American businessman. He is the heir to the fortune of Walmart, the world's largest retailer. He is the eldest son of Helen Walton and Sam Walton. He was Chairman of Walmart from 1992 to 2015. 

As of March 2020, Walton had a net worth of $54.1 billion, making him the 10th richest person in the world. He was born in Tulsa, Oklahoma.

[[Jim Walton]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, Living people, American billionaires, Businesspeople from Arkansas

James Carr Walton (born June 7, 1948) is an American businessman. He is the heir to the fortune of Walmart, the world's largest retailer. 

As of March 2020, Walton was the 8th-richest person in the world, with a net worth of US$54.6 billion. He is the youngest son of Sam Walton. Walton was born in Newport, Arkansas.

[[Darya Vassilyeva]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 births, Living people, Kazakhstani water polo players

Darya Vassilyeva (born 14 October 1988) is a Kazakhstani female water polo player. She was part of the Kazakhstani team at the 2011 World Aquatics Championships, and the 2012 Women's Olympic Qualification Tournament.

[[Alice Walton]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, Living people, American philanthropists, American billionaires, Businesspeople from Arkansas

Alice Louise Walton (born October 7, 1949) is an American businesswoman, philanthropist and art collector. She is an heir to the fortune of Walmart Inc. She is the daughter of Walmart founder Sam Walton and Helen Walton, and sister of S. Robson Walton, Jim Walton and the late John T. Walton.

In September 2016, she owned over 11 billion in Walmart shares. As of May 2020, she was ranked as the 9th-richest person in the world and the richest woman, with a net worth of $56 billion.

Walton was born in Newport, Arkansas.

[[Yelena Chebotova]]
