Coppell (k kə) is a city in the northwest corner of Dallas County in the U.S. state of Texas. It is a suburb of Dallas.  The population was 38,659 at the 2010 census.

[[Farmers Branch, Texas]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Texas, Settlements in Dallas County, Texas

Farmers Branch, officially the City of Farmers Branch, is a city in Dallas County, Texas, United States. It is part of the Dallas–Fort Worth metroplex. The population was 28,616 at the 2010 census.

[[Keller, Texas]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Texas, Settlements in Tarrant County, Texas

Keller is a suburban city in Tarrant County, Texas, in the Dallas–Fort Worth metroplex. According to the 2010 census, the city's population is 39,627, making Keller the 74th most populated city in Texas. 

[[Mansfield, Texas]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Texas, Settlements in Tarrant County, Texas

Mansfield is a suburban city in the U.S. state of Texas, and is part of the Dallas-Fort Worth Metroplex area. The city is located mostly in Tarrant county, with small parts in Ellis and Johnson counties. As of the 2010 census, the population was 56,368.

[[Wylie, Texas]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Texas, Settlements in Dallas County, Texas

Wylie is a city and northeastern suburb of Dallas, mainly in Collin County, but now has parts going into neighboring Dallas and Rockwall Counties in the U.S. state of Texas.

[[Seagoville, Texas]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Texas, Settlements in Dallas County, Texas

Seagoville (ˈ SEE) is a city in Dallas County, Texas, United States, and a suburb of Dallas. A small portion of Seagoville goes into Kaufman County. The population was 14,835 at the 2010 census. The city is located along U.S. Highway 175. It is 10 from downtown Mesquite.

[[University Park, Texas]]

University Park is a city in Dallas County, Texas, United States. It is an inner northern suburb of Dallas. The population was 23,068 at the 2010 census. The city is home to Southern Methodist University.

[[Watauga, Texas]]

[[Interstate 2]]

CATEGORIES: Interstate Highways, Geography of Texas

Interstate 2 (I-2) is a partially completed Interstate Highway running through the Lower Rio Grande Valley of South Texas. 

It begins at the intersection of U.S. Highway 83 (US 83) and Business U.S. Highway 83 (Bus. US 83) in Penitas and heads eastward before terminating at I-69E/US 77/US 83 in Harlingen. 

For its entire length, I-2 runs concurrently with US 83. I-2 also parallels Mexican Federal Highway 2 (Fed. 2), another major east–west route that traces the Mexico-U.S. border along the Mexican side of the Rio Grande. 

When completed, the western part will be the city of Laredo.

[[Interstate 11]]

CATEGORIES: Interstate Highways

 

Interstate 11 (I-11) is an Interstate Highway that currently runs for 22.8 on the northwest–southeast part in the U.S. state of Nevada, running concurrently with U.S. Route 93 (US 93) between the Arizona state line and Henderson. 

The freeway is planned to run from Nogales, Arizona, to Reno, Nevada, generally following the current routes of I-19, I-10, US 93 and US 95.

[[Interstate 14]]

CATEGORIES: Interstate Highways

Interstate 14 (I-14), also known as the "14th Amendment Highway", the Gulf Coast Strategic Highway and the Central Texas Corridor, is an Interstate Highway in the U.S. state of Texas that follows U.S. Highway 190 (US 190). 

The highway was named for the 14th Amendment.

In 2005, I-14 was planned to have a western portion at Natchez, Mississippi (later from I-49 near Alexandria, Louisiana), extending east through Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama, before ending at Augusta, Georgia, or North Augusta, South Carolina. 

[[Sonora, Texas]]

Sonora is a city in and the county seat of Sutton County, Texas, United States.  The population was 3,027 at the 2010 census.

North Augusta is a city in Aiken and Edgefield counties in the U.S. state of South Carolina. It is on the north bank of the Savannah River. The population was 21,348 at the 2010 census.

[[Isaiah Scroll]]

The Isaiah Scroll, (also 1Qlsaa; the Great Isaiah Scroll), is one of the Dead Sea Scrolls that were found in Qumran Cave 1. The scroll is written in Hebrew language and contains the entire Book of Isaiah, with small damaged portions. This manuscript is 1000 years older than the oldest Hebrew manuscripts known before the discovery of Dead Sea Scrolls.

[[Kottangal]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Pathanamthitta district

Kottangal is a village in Pathanamthitta district, Kerala state,India.

[[The Killer Meteors]]

The Killer Meteors (Chinese: 風雨雙流星) (or The Killer Meteors, Jackie Chan vs. Wang Yu) is a 1976 Hong Kong Taiwanese action movie directed by Jimmy Wang Yu (who also stars) and Lo Wei. It stars Jackie Chan.

[[The Purple Rose of Cairo]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 comedy movies, 1985 romance movies, 1980s romantic comedy movies, 1980s fantasy movies, American romantic comedy movies, American fantasy movies, Movies directed by Woody Allen

The Purple Rose of Cairo is a 1985 American romantic fantasy comedy movie directed by Woody Allen and starring Mia Farrow, Jeff Dainels, Danny Aiello, John Wood, Edward Herrmann, Deborah Rush, Zoe Caldwell, Milo O'Shea, Dianne Wiest. It was distributed by Orion Pictures and was nominated for an Academy Award in 1986.

[[Steven Bauer]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, Living people, Actors from Miami, Florida, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, People from Havana

Steven Bauer (born Esteban Ernesto Echevarría Samson; December 2, 1956) is a Cuban-born American actor. He is probably best known for his role as Cuban drug lord Manny Ribera in the 1983 crime drama movie Scarface. His work on television includes shows such as ¿Qué Pasa, USA? (1977–1980), Breaking Bad (2011), Better Call Saul (2017; 2020) and Ray Donovan (2013–2020).

Bauer was born in Havana. His family moved to the United States on July 4, 1960. He grew up using the name Steven, an English form of his given name, Esteban. He has been married four times, each ending in divorce. His first wife was actress Melanie Griffith. He has two children.

North Bergen is a township in the northern part of Hudson County, New Jersey, United States. As of the 2010 census, the township had a population of 60,773.

[[Robert Iler]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 births, Living people, Actors from New York City, American movie actors, American television actors, Podcasters, Poker players

In 2019, he started hosting the podcast Pajama Pants alongside The Sopranos co-star Jamie-Lynn Sigler and comedian Kassem G.

[[All of Me (1984 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1984 romance movies, 1984 comedy movies, 1980s romantic comedy movies, 1980s fantasy movies, American romantic comedy movies, American fantasy movies, Movies directed by Carl Reiner, Universal Pictures movies

All of Me is a 1984 American romantic fantasy comedy movie directed by Carl Reiner and based on the unpublished novel Me Too by Edwin Davis. It stars Steve Martin, Madolyn Smith, Victoria Tennant, Lily Tomlin, Richard Libertini, Dana Elcar and was distributed by Universal Pictures.

[[Vince Foster]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 1993 deaths, American lawyers, People from Hope, Arkansas, Suicides by firearm in the United States, Democrats (United States), Conspiracy theories

Vincent Walker Foster Jr. (January 15, 1945 – July 20, 1993) was an American attorney. He served as Deputy White House Counsel for the first six months of President Bill Clinton's presidency until his death in July 1993. He was found dead by gunshot at a federal park in McLean, Virginia, at the age of 45. His death was ruled a suicide by five official governmental investigations. However, there are many conspiracy theories about Foster's death.

Foster was born in Hope, Arkansas. He married Elizabeth Braden in 1968. The couple had three children.

[[The Salzburg Connection]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 thriller movies, American thriller movies, Movies based on books

The Salzburg Connection is a 1972 American thriller movie directed by Lee H. Katzin and based on the 1968 novel of the same name by Helen MacInnes. It stars Barry Newman, Patrick Jordan, Anna Karina, Klaus Maria Brandauer, Karen Jensen, Wolfgang Preiss, Raoul Retzer and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Zuma Beach]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 comedy movies, American comedy movies

Zuma Beach is a 1978 American television comedy movie directed by Lee H. Katzin and starring Suzanne Somers, Steven Keats, Mark Wheeler, Kimberly Beck, Perry Lang, Michael Biehn, Rosanna Arquette, Tayna Roberts, Gary Imhoff, Timothy Hutton. It was distributed by Warner Bros..

[[Booroolong frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Frogs

The booroolong frog (Litoria booroolongensis) is a tree frog from Australia. It lives in New South Wales and Victoria.

Adult frogs are about 5 cm long.  They can be brown or gray or green, with black marks.  Their bellies are white. 

They live in or near streams 200 to 1000 meters above sea level.  They lay eggs in cracks in underwater rocks.  The tadpoles grow in pools or slow-flowing streams.

As of the early 2000s, the booroolong frog was endangered because human beings divided their habitat into small pieces for logging and grazing, because willow trees clogged the streams where they live, and because invasive species of fish ate the tadpoles.

[[Eleanor Stackhouse Atkinson]]

Eleanor Stackhouse Atkinson (1863 – November 4, 1942) was an American author, journalist and teacher.

[[Madeline van Heemstra]]

She graduated from Sydney University.

[[Auston Matthews]]

CATEGORIES: 1997 births, American ice hockey players, Calder Trophy winners, Ice hockey centres, Living people, Sportspeople from California, Toronto Maple Leafs players

Auston Taylour Matthews (born September 17, 1997) is an American professional ice hockey center and alternate captain for the Toronto Maple Leafs of the National Hockey League (NHL).

[[Terence Winter]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, Living people, American movie producers, American television producers, American television writers, Screenwriters from New York City, Writers from Brooklyn

Terence Patrick Winter (born October 2, 1960) is an American screenwriter and producer. He is the creator, writer and executive producer of the HBO series Boardwalk Empire (2010–2014).

Winter is also known as a writer and executive producer for the HBO series The Sopranos, from the show's second to sixth and final season (2000–2007). He wrote the screenplay to Martin Scorsese's The Wolf of Wall Street (2013) for which he was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Adapted Screenplay. He co-created HBO's Vinyl, which ran for one season in 2016.

Winter was born in New York City. He grew up in Marine Park, Brooklyn.

[[M42 motorway]]

CATEGORIES: Motorways in England

The M42 is a motorway in the Midlands of England. It runs northeast from the M5 near Bromsgrove, Worcestershire to near Ashby-de-la-Zouch, Leicestershire. It runs south of the West Midlands conurbation, going through Solihull and Birmingham Airport. Here, it crosses the M6 motorway. It then goes past Coleshill and then past Tamworth, before ending. At the end of the motorway, just south of Ashby-de-la-Zouch, it becomes the A42.

The road was first built in the 1970s, and was built to make a motorway between the East and West Midlands. It is now also used as part of a ring road around Birmingham nicknamed the "Birmingham Box". It is made up of parts of the M5, M6, and M42 motorways.

[[Raj Mohan Vohra]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 deaths, 1932 births, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in India, Indian military people, Generals

Lieutenant General Raj Mohan Vohra, PVSM, MVC (7 May 1932snd14 June 2020) was a General Officer of the Indian Army. He was awarded the Maha Vir Chakra for his leadership in the Battle of Basantar during the Indo-Pakistani War of 1971. He was born in Shimla, Himachal Pradesh.

Vohra died on 14 June 2020 from COVID-19, aged 88.

[[Claude Samuel]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, French journalists, Businesspeople from Paris, French radio personalities, French music critics, Writers from Paris

Claude Samuel (23 June 1931 – 14 June 2020) was a French music critic and radio personality. He was born in Paris.

He worked for many newspapers of the daily press (Paris-Presse, from 1961 to 1970; Le Matin de Paris, from 1977 to 1987), of the weekly press (L’Express in 1959 and 1960; Le Nouveau Candide from 1961 to 1967; Le Point, from 1974 to 1989), the monthly press (Revue Réalités, and discs collection Philips-Réalités from 1957 to 1960) and the music press (Harmonie, Le Panorama de la Musique, Musiques, La Lettre du musicien, Diapason).

Samuel died on 14 June 2020 in Paris, aged 88.

[[Jim Grelle]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, American Olympians, American track and field athletes, Sportspeople from Portland, Oregon

James Edward Grelle (September 30, 1936 – June 13, 2020) was an American middle-distance runner. He had his best achievements in the 1500 m event, finishing eighth at the 1960 Olympics, winning a gold and a silver medal at the Pan American Games in 1963 and 1959. He was born in Portland, Oregon.

Grelle died on June 13, 2020 in Portland, aged 83.

[[Marjorie G. Horning]]

CATEGORIES: 1917 births, 2020 deaths, American biochemists, American centenarians, Female scientists, Scientists from Detroit, Michigan

Marjorie Janice Groothuis Horning (August 23, 1917 – June 11, 2020) was an American biochemist and pharmacologist. 

She was thought to be a leading scientist of chromatography for her work in developing new techniques and applying them to the study of drug metabolism. 

She discovered that drugs and their metabolites can be transferred from a pregnant woman to her developing child, and later through breast milk, from a mother to a baby.  

Horning's work made possible the prevention of birth defects, as doctors began to warn of the dangers of drugs, alcohol, and smoking during pregnancy.

[[Friedrich Stelzner]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 2020 deaths, Czech scientists, German scientists, Czech academics, German academics

Friedrich Stelzner (4 November 1921 – 5 June 2020) was a Czech-born German academic surgeon, scientist and educator. His works focused on gastrointestinal surgery. He was a Professor and Chairman of three university departments and was honored as President of the German Society for Surgery in 1985. 

Stelzner wrote more than 80 books and book chapters to the literature and authored over 450 publications and presentations. Throughout his scientific career, Stelzner investigated questions of anatomy and its impact on surgical methods.

Stelzner was born in Františkovy Lázně, Czechoslovakia. He died on 5 June 2020 at the age of 98.

[[Luce Douady]]

CATEGORIES: 2003 births, 2020 deaths, Accidental deaths from falls, Deaths in sport, French sportspeople, Mountain climbers

Luce Douady (17 November 2003 – 14 June 2020) was a French climber. She became Youth World champion in 2019 and won the bronze medal at senior level at the 2019 IFSC Climbing European Championships.

Douady died at the age of 16, on 14 June 2020 after falling off a path on the way to a cliff near her home town of St. Bernard, Isère, France.

[[Moscow, Pennsylvania]]

CATEGORIES: Boroughs in Pennsylvania

Moscow is a borough in Lackawanna County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 2,026 at the 2010 census. It is located about 9 miles from Scranton and 25 miles from Honesdale.

[[Honesdale, Pennsylvania]]

CATEGORIES: Boroughs in Pennsylvania, County seats in Pennsylvania

Honesdale is a borough in and the county seat of Wayne County, Pennsylvania, United States. The borough's population was 4,480 at the time of the 2010 census.

[[Wayne County, Pennsylvania]]

CATEGORIES: 1790s establishments in Pennsylvania, 1798 establishments in the United States, Pennsylvania counties

Wayne is a sixth-class county in Pennsylvania. The county's population was 52,822 at the time of the 2010 census. The county seat is the Borough of Honesdale. The county was formed from part of Northampton County on March 21, 1798. It was named for the Revolutionary War General Anthony Wayne.

[[Galley]]

CATEGORIES: Ships

A galley is a type of ship. Galleys use rowing to move. The first galleys were using in Ancient Egypt, during the Old Kingdom (c. 2700-2200 BCE).

[[Haroldo Rodas]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic, Economists, People from Guatemala City, Guatemalan politicians

Roger Haroldo Rodas Melgar (May 29, 1946 – June 15, 2020) was a Guatemalan economist and politician. He was Minister of Foreign Affairs in the cabinet of President Álvaro Colom, from January 14, 2008 to January 14, 2012. He was the only minister that was in office for the four-year term. He was born in Guatemala City.

Rodas died of COVID-19 on June 15, 2020 in Guatemala City, aged 74.

[[List of lieutenant governors of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands]]

CATEGORIES: Lieutenant governors of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands

This is a list of lieutenant governors of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands is a political office, almost like an ambassador and Lieutenant-Governor position, that is in charge of Andaman and Nicobar Islands. They are appointed by the President of India.

[[Devendra Kumar Joshi]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, Living people, Indian military people, Lieutenant governors of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands

Admiral  Devendra Kumar Joshi, PVSM, AVSM, YSM, NM, VSM (Retd.) (born 4 July 1954)  is an Indian military official and politician. He is the Lieutenant Governor of Andaman and Nicobar Islands and the Vice Chairman of  Islands Development Agency (IDA).

He was an Admiral in the Indian Navy and was the 21st Chief of Naval Staff of the Indian Navy.

[[Nagendra Nath Jha]]

CATEGORIES: Ambassadors of India, Lieutenant Governors of Puducherry, Lieutenant governors of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, 2020 deaths, 1935 births

Nagendra Nath Jha (5 January 1935 – 15 June 2020) was an Indian diplomat. He was the Indian ambassador to Ireland (1977-1979), to Turkey (1979–1981), to Kuwait (1984-1989), to Yugoslavia (1989-1990) and to Sri Lanka (1990-1993). He was Lieutenant Governor of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands (2001–2004) and Lieutenant Governor of Pondicherry (2004).

Jha died on 15 June 2020, aged 85.

CATEGORIES: Lieutenant Governors of Puducherry

Puducherry (formerly known as "Pondicherry") is a Union Territory of India. Governance and administration of the territory fall directly under federal authority. 

[[Kiran Bedi]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, Living people, Indian writers, Lieutenant Governors of Puducherry

Kiran Bedi (born 9 June 1949) is a retired Indian Police Service officer, social activist, former tennis player and politician. She is the current Lieutenant Governor of Puducherry. She is the first female Indian Police Service (IPS) officer.

[[C. Rangarajan]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, Living people, Indian businesspeople, Governors of Andhra Pradesh, Governors of Odisha, Governors of Tamil Nadu

C. Rangarajan or Chakravarthi Rangarajan (born 1932) is an Indian economist. He was the 19th Governor of the Reserve Bank of India. He is the former Chairman of the Prime Minister's Economic Advisory Council. He was a professor in Ahmedabad University. From 1997 to 2003, he was Governor of Andhra Pradesh.

[[Biswabhusan Harichandan]]

Biswabhusan Harichandan (born 3 August 1934) is an Indian politician. In July 2019, he became the 23rd and current Governor of Andhra Pradesh.

CATEGORIES: Governors of Arunachal Pradesh

The Governor of Arunachal Pradesh is a state head and representative of the President of India in the state of Arunachal Pradesh. The Governor is appointed by the President for a term of 5 years. The current governor is B. D. Mishra.

[[Phagu Chauhan]]

CATEGORIES: Governors of Bihar, 1948 births, Living people

Phagu Chauhan (born 1 January 1948) is an Indian politician. In July 2019, he became the 29th and current Governor of Bihar. He is a former member of 17th Legislative Assembly of Uttar Pradesh from Ghosi, a seat he won from a record six times.

[[Buta Singh]]

CATEGORIES: Governors of Bihar, 1934 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from cerebral hemorrhage

Buta Singh (21 March 1934 – 2 January 2021) was an Indian politician. He was a senior leader of the Indian National Congress. He was the Union Home Minister of India, Governor of Bihar from 2004 to 2006 and was chairman of the National Commission for Scheduled Castes from 2007 to 2010.

Singh died on 2 January 2021 in New Delhi from problems caused by a cerebral haemorrhage, aged 86.

[[B. D. Mishra]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, Living people, Governors of Arunachal Pradesh

Brigadier B. D. Mishra (born 20 July 1939) is an Indian politician and former brigadier of the Indian Army. In October 2017, Governor of Arunachal Pradesh.

[[Jagdish Mukhi]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, Living people, Governors of Assam, Governors of Mizoram, Lieutenant governors of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands

Jagdish Mukhi (born 1 December 1942) is an Indian politician. In October 2017, he became the Governor of Assam. and a member of BJP and RSS.  He also was Lieutenant Governor of the Andaman and Nicorbar Islands from 2016 to 2017. In 2019, he was the Governor of Mizoram.

[[Padmanabha Acharya]]

In 2017, he was Governor of Arunachal Pradesh. From 2014 to 2015, he was Governor of Tripura. From 2014 to 2016, he was Governor of Assam.

[[Anusuiya Uikey]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, Living people, Governors of Chhattisgarh

Anusuiya Uikey (born 10 April 1957) is an Indian politician. She was elected to the Madhya Pradesh Legislative Assembly from Damua constituency in the 1985 Madhya Pradesh Legislative Assembly election as a member of the Indian National Congress. 

She was appointed as Governor of Chhattisgarh on 16 July 2019.

[[Ram Naresh Yadav]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2016 deaths, Governors of Chhattisgarh, Governors of Madhya Pradesh

Ram Naresh Yadav (1 July 1928 – 22 November 2016) was an Indian politician. He was Chief Minister of Uttar Pradesh from 1977 to 1979. He was from Janata Party; later he joined the Congress. He also was Governor of Madhya Pradesh from 26 August 2011 to  7 September 2016.

[[Satya Pal Malik]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, Living people, Governors of Meghalaya, Governors of Goa, Governors of Bihar, Governors of Odisha

Satya Pal Malik (born 24 July 1946) is an Indian politician. In 2020, he became the Governor of Meghalaya. He was the 18th Governor of Goa from 2019 to 2020. From 2018 to 2019, he was Governors of Jammu and Kashmir. From 2017 to 2018, he was Governor of Bihar. 

[[M6 Toll]]

CATEGORIES: Motorways in England

The M6 Toll, also called the Birmingham North Relief Road (BNRR) or Midland Expressway, is a toll motorway in the Midlands. It is used as a way to avoid the traffic on the M6 motorway by Birmingham. It goes from the M6 at Coleshill to the M6 at Wolverhampton. It is a toll road, so drivers have to pay to use it.

It first opened in 2003, and many people do not think it has been a good idea. It was built to lower the amount of traffic on the M6 between Coleshill and Wolverhampton, which is the busiest part. Many people have noted that the traffic has not gone down since it opened. Many people say it is because the road is too expensive to use and many drivers do not want to pay the fee.

Om Prakash Kohli (born 9 August 1935) is an Indian politician. He was the Governor of Gujarat  and a former member of Rajya Sabha. He was president of the Delhi unit of the Bharatiya Janata Party in 1999-2000.

From 8 September 2016 to 19 January 2018, he held the additional charge of the office of Governor of Madhya Pradesh  along with Gujarat.

[[Alan Winde]]

After his party won a majority in the provincial parliament in May 2019, he became the Premier and replaced Helen Zille. Winde held ministerial positions in Zille's provincial cabinet.

Dhanik Lal Mandal (born March 1932) is an Indian politician. He was elected to the Lok Sabha from Jhanjharpur in Bihar, twice in 1977 and 1980. He was the member of Bihar Legislative Assembly (1967–74) and also speaker of Bihar Legislative Assembly, (1967–69).

He was the Governor of Haryana from 1990 to 1995.

Singh died on 21 August 2021 at a hospital in Lucknow, India from sepsis caused by multiple organ failure, aged 89.

[[Lalji Tandon]]

Lalji Tandon (12 April 1935 – 21 July 2020) was an Indian politician. He was the 22nd Governor of Madhya Pradesh from July 2019 to June 2020. He was a member of Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP). He was a protégé of Atal Bihari Vajpayee.

Tandon was hospitalized in June 2020 for a urinary tract infection. He died on 21 July 2020 in Lucknow, aged 85.

[[Nomarussia Bonase]]

CATEGORIES: 1966 births, Human rights activists, South African people

Nomarussia Bonase (born 1966) is a South African human rights activist. In 2017, she won the Anne Klein Women’s Award.

She was a union shop steward. She identified her brother's body after he was killed. She joined Khulumani Support Group after the failure of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission to address rape. She organized workshops and art therapy sessions, after the Marikana massacre.

Roukiata Ouedraogo (born 1979) is a Burkinabé actress and comedian.

She grew up in Fada N'Gourma. She moved to Paris. She was an intern at Cours Florent. She acted in the play, Yennenga, the epic of the Mossé. She appeared in the movie Samba.  She appeared in the show Le Parlement du rire on Canal+.

She speaks both French and Bambara.

[[Andrea Donnellan]]

Andrea Donnellan is a principal investigator at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory. She is an editor of the Earth and Space Science journal. She studies earthquakes using geodetic imaging.

[[Alessandra Sardoni]]

Alessandra Sardoni (born 5 May 1964 in Rome) is an Italian journalist and television presenter. From 2013 to 2014, she was president of the Parliamentary Press Association. In June 2015, she was awarded the Premiolino.

[[Graziella Fumagalli]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 1995 deaths, Italian physicians

Graziella Fumagalli (24 August 1944 in Casatenovo - 22 October 1995 in Merca) was an Italian doctor. She was a Catholic volunteer, killed in Somalia in 1995 at the Anti-tuberculosis Center which she directed.

[[Elisa Biagini]]

CATEGORIES: living people, Poets

Elisa Biagini (born 1970 Florence) is an Italian poet, translator, and professor. Her work won a 2014 Best Translated Book Award.

[[Mila Rodino]]

CATEGORIES: Bulgaria, National anthems

"Mila Rodino" (bg. Мила Родино, pron. ˈrɔdino "MEE-luh RAW-dee-no"; en. 'Dear Motherland') is the national anthem of Bulgaria. It was originally a song written and composed by Bulgarian author and scientist Țvetan Radoslavov Hagi-Dencov (1863–1931) whilst on a mission to fight in the Serbo-Bulgarian War in 1885. It was first adopted in 1964 as the anthem of the People's Republic of Bulgaria with different lyrics (words), then again in 1991 when the communist regime fell.

[[Andrea Tenuta]]

CATEGORIES: Uruguayan entertainers, Actors, Singers, Dancers, 1963 births, Living people

Andrea Tenuta (born 6 January 1963 in Montevideo) is an Uruguayan-Argentina actress, singer, and dancer.

She is the daughter of Uruguayan actors Juan Manuel Tenuta and Adela Gleijer. 

She made her film debut in 1983 with the film The arrangement. In 1985, she worked on the Oscar winning film, The official story. She later appeared in Esperando la carroza. In 2012 she appeared in Holmes & Watson. Madrid Days.

She married José Luis Garci . 

[[John Madigan (politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1966 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in Australia, Deaths from colorectal cancer, Deaths from liver cancer, Independent politicians in Australia, Members of the Australian Senate, People from Ballarat, Politicians from Victoria (Australia)

John Joseph Madigan (21 July 1966 – 16 June 2020) was an Australian blacksmith and politician. He was a member of the Democratic Labour Party (DLP), before resigning from the party and becoming an independent in September 2014. He joined the Country Party in September 2016. He served as a Senator for Victoria from 2011 to 2016.

Madigan was born in Ballarat, Victoria. He was married and had two children.

In December 2018, Madigan announced that he had liver and bowel cancer. He died on 16 June 2020 in palliative care near his home in Hepburn Springs, Victoria. He was 53.

[[Deep South]]

CATEGORIES: American culture, Politics of the United States, Regions of the United States

The term "Deep South" refers to the lower states in the Southern United States. It is also part of the "Bible Belt". The core states of the Deep South are Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, South Carolina and Georgia. North Florida, East Texas and South Tennessee are often included as part of the "Deep South". These states are racially diverse, where African Americans and White Americans form a majority or plurality in many areas. These states are generally socially conservative. They relied heavily on plantation farming with slaves in the pre-Civil War era. Politically they are labelled as "Red States", because the people largely vote for the Republican Party, which is socially conservative and right-wing.  

[[Raoof Haghighi]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, Iranian painters, 1976 births, British painters

Raoof Haghighi is an Iranian-born British artist, known for his portraiture and realism.

[[Reza Abbasi]]

CATEGORIES: 1565 births, 1635 deaths, Persian people, Iranian painters

Reza Abbasi, Riza yi-Abbasi or Reza-e Abbasi, رضا عباسی in Persian, usually Reza Abbasi also Aqa Reza (see below) or Āqā Riżā Kāshānī (no – 1635) was the leading Persian miniaturist of the Isfahan School during the later Safavid period, spending most of his career working for Shah Abbas I. He is considered to be the last great master of the Persian miniature, best known for his single miniatures for muraqqa or albums, especially single figures of beautiful youths.

[[Iman Afsarian]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 births, Living people, Iranian painters, People from Tehran

Iman Afsarian (born 1974, Tehran, Iran) is a realist Iranian painter. He is also the artistic director, editor, author of articles and a notable critic working for the prestigious Iranian quarterly art magazine Herfeh: Honarmand Artist since its first issue in 2003.

[[Aydin Aghdashloo]]

CATEGORIES: Iranian painters, Art critics, Academics, 1940 births, Living people

Aydin Aghdashloo  (آیدین آغداشلو; born October 30, 1940) is an Iranian painter, graphist, writer, film critic. Aghdashloo was decorated with the Chevalier (Knight) award, by the French government for his civil achievements.

[[Bahram Alivandi]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2012 deaths, Iranian painters, Austrian painters

Bahram Alivandi (1928 – 21 May 2012) was an Iranian-born Modern artist living in Vienna, Austria. He is known primarily for his paintings, which typically depict stories from Persian mythology and literature, and express oriental mysticism. He has also produced a number of wall tapestries that, like his works on canvas, demonstrate his own instantly recognisable visual language.

[[Kamrooz Aram]]

CATEGORIES: American artists, 1978 births, Living people, Iranian painters

Kamrooz Aram (born 1978 in Shiraz, Iran) is a contemporary artist whose diverse artistic practice engages the complicated relationship between traditional non-Western art and Western Modernism. Through a variety of forms including painting, collage, drawing and installation, Aram has found the potential for image-making to function critically in its use as a tool for a certain renegotiation of history. He lives and works in Brooklyn, New York.

[[New Brunswick Route 695]]

CATEGORIES: New Brunswick

Route 695 is a local highway located in south central New Brunswick. It begins in the south at Route 124 in Springfield and runs for 35.2, through Cambridge-Narrows, to its northern end in Jemseg at Route 105.

[[Historical definitions of race]]

CATEGORIES: Anthropology, Humans, Race, Ethnic groups

Some scientists spoke of three races of mankind: The Caucasian race living in Europe, North Africa and West Asia, the Mongoloid race living in East Asia, Australia, and the Americas, and the Negroid race living in Africa south of the Sahara. Other scientists had different ideas and spoke of four or five races. These ideas were popular from the late 18th century to the middle of the 20th century. Because these ideas belong to former times, they are called historical definitions of race or historical race concepts.

Today, scientists agree that there is only one human race. Modern genetic research has shown that the idea of three (or four, or five) races was wrong.360

[[Borealis Basin]]

CATEGORIES: Mars

The Borealis Basin, also known as the North Polar Basin is a large depression or basin in the northern hemisphere of Mars. It covers 40% of the planet. Some scientists think the basin formed during the impact of a single, large body (~2% the mass of Mars) with a diameter of about 1,900 km (1,200 miles). However, the basin is not currently called an impact basin by the IAU. The basin is one of the flattest areas in the Solar System. The landing site of the Viking 1 lander is a bay that opens into this basin.

[[Heart of Dragon]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 action movies, 1985 comedy movies, Hong Kong movies, Japanese movies, Movies directed by Sammo Hung

Heart of Dragon (龍的心) is a 1985 Hong Kong Japanese action comedy movie directed by Sammo Hung (who also stars). It stars Jackie Chan, Emily Chu, Mang Hoi, Chin Kar-lok, Yuen Wah, Corey Yuen, Dick Wei featuring Yuen Biao action director and was distributed by Golden Harvest.

[[Of Love and Shadows]]

CATEGORIES: 1994 drama movies, 1994 romance movies, 1990s romantic drama movies, Chilean movies, Argentine movies, American romantic drama movies, Movies set in South America

Of Love and Shadows, also known as De amor y de sombra, is a 1994 Chilean Argentine American romantic drama movie directed by Betty Kaplan and based on the 1984 novel of the same name by Isabel Allende. It stars Antonio Banderas, Jennifer Connelly, Stefania Sandrelli, Patricio Contreras, Jorge Rivera López and was distributed by Miramax Films.

[[Armour of God]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 comedy movies, 1986 action movies, Hong Kong movies, Serbian movies, Movies directed by Jackie Chan

Armour of God (龍兄虎弟) is a 1986 Hong Kong Serbian action comedy movie directed by Jackie Chan (who also stars) and Eric Tsang. It stars Alan Tam, Lola Forner, Rosamund Kwan, Božidar Smiljanić and was distributed by Golden Harvest. It was followed by a 1991 sequel ''Armour of God II: Operator Condor.

[[Cambridge-Narrows]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in New Brunswick

Cambridge-Narrows (2016 pop.: 562) is a Canadian village located in Queens County, New Brunswick.

The village is next to Washedemoak Lake, a widening of the Canaan River, several kilometres upstream of the Saint John River.  Cambridge-Narrows has 3 main highways, Route 695, Route 715, and Route 710

The village is made of two separate settlements on either side of the river, Cambridge and The Narrows, which were merged under one municipal government in 1966.

[[Cambridge Parish, New Brunswick]]

CATEGORIES: New Brunswick

Cambridge Parish is a Canadian parish in Queens County, New Brunswick. It was created from Wickham Parish and Waterborough Parish in 1852, and was named for Prince Adolphus-Frederick, Duke of Cambridge (1774-1850) and uncle of Queen Victoria.

[[Queens County, New Brunswick]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of New Brunswick

Queens County (2016 population 10,472) is located in central New Brunswick, Canada. The county shire town is the village of Gagetown.

[[List of counties of New Brunswick]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of New Brunswick, Lists of counties

This is a list of the counties in the Canadian province of New Brunswick, with population and county seats (known in the province as shire towns).

Before New Brunswick was split from Nova Scotia, it was made up of Cumberland and Sunbury Counties. Counties were at the top of a three-layer local government system. Below each county were parishes (townships), Some, but not all, parishes were then further subdivided into municipalities. The exception to this was the municipality of Saint John which was not in a parish but was a sub-division of Saint John County.

With the New Brunswick Equal Opportunity program in 1966, county councils were shut down.  Counties continue to be used as an organizational unit, along with parishes, for registration of real-estate and its taxation. They figure prominently in residents' sense of place and continue as significant threads in the Province's culture (i.e., most citizens always know which county they are in). They still appear on most maps.

[[Albert County, New Brunswick]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of New Brunswick

Albert County (2016 population 29,158) is a county in southeastern New Brunswick, Canada on Chignecto Bay in the Bay of Fundy. Prior to the ending of county government in 1967, the shire town was Hopewell Cape. The county was created in 1845 from parts of Westmorland County and Saint John County, and named after Prince Albert.

Robin Hood is an English opera in three acts, music by George Alexander Macfarren and libretto by John Oxenford. It was first performed in London, on October 11, 1860.

Val Sullivan is an American rugby union player. She played at the 1991 Women's Rugby World Cup. She played for Florida State University.

[[Tasmanian tree frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Australia, Frogs

The Tasmanian tree frog or Burrow's tree frog (Litoria burrowsae) is a frog from Tasmania.  They live in high grasslands and forests near ponds and dams.

Adult frogs are 6 cm long, green with brown marks.

They lay eggs in groups on underwater plants in still water or water that only moves slowly.  The eggs take 6 days to hatch.

In 2018 and 2019, scientists from the Australian Museum asked people in Tasmania to go outside and record frog calls on their phones using FrogID in a citizen science project.

[[Susan Dawson]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 births, Living people, New Zealand rugby union players, Coaches

Susan Dawson (born 20 January 1971) is a New Zealand rugby union player and coach.

She played at the 2002 Women's Rugby World Cup. She coached for Northland Rugby Union and the Pakistan women's national rugby sevens team.

[[Claire Godwin]]

Claire Godwin is an American rugby union player. She played at the 1991 Women's Rugby World Cup. She played for Florida State University.

[[Bostock v. Clayton County, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 in the United States, June 2020 events, United States Supreme Court cases, United States law

Bostock v. Clayton County, Georgia, 590, was a landmark United States Supreme Court case in which the Court held that Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 protects employees against discrimination because of their sexual orientation or gender identity.

[[Jonesboro, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Georgia (U.S. state), County seats in Georgia

Jonesboro is a city in Clayton County, Georgia, United States. The population was 4,724 as of the 2010 census. The city is the county seat of Clayton County.

[[Murlidhar Chandrakant Bhandare]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, Living people, Governors of Odisha

Murlidhar Chandrakant Bhandare (born 10 December 1928) is an Indian politician. He was a senior Indian National Congress leader from Maharashtra and a former Rajya Sabha member for three terms during 1980–1982, 1982–1988 and 1988–1994. He was appointed Governor of Odisha on 19 August 2007, he was sworn in on 21 August. He left office on 9 March 2013.

[[V. P. Singh Badnore]]

Vijayender Pal Singh Badnore (born 12 May 1948) is an Indian politician. In August 2016, he became the 28th and current Governor of Punjab. He was a member of Rajya Sabha, elected on 17 June 2010. He is a member of the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) political party.

[[Sunith Francis Rodrigues]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, Living people, Governors of Punjab, India, Indian military people, Administrators of Chandigarh

General Sunith Francis Rodrigues, PVSM, VSM (born 19 September 1933) is a retired Indian army officer and politician. He was Chief of the Army Staff of the Indian Army from 1990 to 1993 and Governor of Punjab from 2004 to 2010.

[[Lady Pamela Hicks]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, Living people, British nobility

Lady Pamela Carmen Louise Hicks DCVO (née Mountbatten; born 19 April 1929) is a British aristocrat. She is a relative of the British royal family. 

She is the younger daughter of Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma and  Edwina Ashley. Through her father, Lady Pamela is a first cousin of Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, and a grandniece of the last Empress of Russia, Alexandra Feodorovna. 

She was a bridesmaid and later as a lady-in-waiting to Queen Elizabeth II.

Zhang Danyi is a Chinese water polo player. She played at the 2018 Asian Games and 2019 World Aquatics Championships.

[[Praful Khoda Patel]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, Administrators of Lakshadweep, Administrators of Dadra and Nagar Haveli

Praful Khoda Patel is a former Member of Legislative assembly from Himatnagar constituency in Gujarat for its 12th legislative assembly (2007–12). He also was MoS Home Minister of Gujarat. He has been the Administrator of Daman and Diu and as the Administrator of Dadra and Nagar Haveli.

In December 2020, he became Administrator of Lakshadweep following the death of Dineshwar Sharma.

[[List of administrators of Chandigarh]]

[[List of administrators of Dadra and Nagar Haveli]]

The union territory of Dadra and Nagar Haveli was merged with the nearby territory of Daman and Diu to create the new union territory of Dadra and Nagar Haveli and Daman and Diu on 26 January 2020 and the office of Administrator of Dadra and Nagar Haveli was abolished on that date. 

[[Jagmohan]]

CATEGORIES: 2021 deaths, 1927 births, Governors of Jammu and Kashmir, Lieutenant Governors of Delhi, Governors of Goa, Administrators of Dadra and Nagar Haveli

Jagmohan Malhotra (25 September 1927 – 3 May 2021), known by the mononym Jagmohan, was an Indian politician and member of the Bharatiya Janata Party. He was the Lieutenant Governor of Delhi and Goa, as well as the Governor of Jammu and Kashmir. He was also elected to the Lok Sabha (the lower house of the Indian Parliament) and was the Union Minister for Urban Development and Tourism.

Jagmohan died on 3 May 2021 in New Delhi, India at the age of 93.

[[Dadra and Nagar Haveli and Daman and Diu]]

CATEGORIES: Territories of India

Dadra and Nagar Haveli and Daman and Diu, (DNHDD);  is a union territory in western India. It was created through the merger of the erstwhile union territories of Dadra and Nagar Haveli and Daman and Diu. Plans for the proposed merger were announced by the Government of India in July 2019. The necessary legislation was passed in the Parliament of India in December 2019 and came into effect on 26 January 2020. 

The territory is made up of four separate geographical entities Dadra, Nagar Haveli, Daman and the island of Diu. 

All four areas were part of Portuguese India and came under Indian administration in the mid 20th century.

[[List of administrators of Dadra and Nagar Haveli and Daman and Diu]]

CATEGORIES: State Governors of India

This is a list of Administrators of Dadra and Nagar Haveli and Daman and Diu a union territory of India. The union territory of Dadra and Nagar Haveli and Daman and Diu was created following the merger of the union territories of Dadra and Nagar Haveli and Daman and Diu on 26 January 2020.

[[A38(M) motorway]]

CATEGORIES: Motorways in England, Birmingham

The A38(M), usually called the Aston Expressway, is a short motorway in Birmingham, England. It is about 2 long. It runs from the M6 at Gravelly Hill Interchange into Central Birmingham. It first opened in 1972, and is part of the long A38 road.

The motorway is strange as it has seven lanes with no barrier in the middle. Electronic signs above the motorway tell drivers which lanes they can use with either a green tick or red cross. Motorcycles are banned from the middle lane because drains on the ground can make them crash.

[[Dineshwar Sharma]]

CATEGORIES: Administrators of Lakshadweep, Spies, 2020 deaths, Deaths from lung disease, People from Bihar, 1954 births

Dineshwar Sharma, (23 March 1954 – 4 December 2020) was an Indian politician. He was a Indian Police Service (IPS) officer. He was the chief of the Indian Intelligence Bureau, that is the Director of Intelligence Bureau which is the highest-ranked post in the Indian Police Service (IPS). 

He also was an interlocutor to the government of India for the state of Jammu and Kashmir. In November 2019, he became the 34th Administrator of Lakshadweep.

Sharma died of lung disease on 4 December 2020 at the age of 66.

[[List of administrators of Lakshadweep]]

CATEGORIES: Administrators of Lakshadweep

The Administrator of Lakshadweep is the Head of the Union Territory of Lakshadweep. He is also the Chairman of Lakshadweep Development Corporation (a U.T. Administration public sector undertaking) and SPORTS (Society for Promotion of Recreational Tourism and Sports).

[[Wajahat Habibullah]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, Living people, Administrators of Lakshadweep

Wajahat Habibullah (born 30 September 1945) is an Indian politician. He was the chairperson of the National Commission for Minorities. He was the first Chief Information Commissioner of India. He was an officer of the Indian Administrative Service (IAS) from 1968 until his retirement in August 2005. He also was the Administrator of Lakshadweep from 1987 to 1990.

[[Anil Baijal]]

CATEGORIES: Year of birth missing (living people), Living people, Lieutenant Governors of Delhi

Anil Baijal is a retired Indian Administrative Service officer and politician. In December 2016, he became the 21st Lieutenant Governor of Delhi. He took over office on 31 December 2016 after the sudden resignation of Najeeb Jung.

[[Indian Administrative Service]]

CATEGORIES: Politics of India

The Indian Administrative Service (IAS) is the administrative arm of the All India Services. It is a key job in civil service of India. The IAS is one of the three arms of the All India Services along with the Indian Police Service and the Indian Forest Service.  

Members of these three services serve the Government of India as well as the individual states. 

[[List of lieutenant governors of Delhi]]

CATEGORIES: Lieutenant Governors of Delhi

The Lieutenant Governor of Delhi is the constitutional head of the National Capital Territory of Delhi. The post was first created in September 1966.

The current Lieutenant Governor is Anil Baijal, a former Union Home Secretary. His official residence is in Raj Niwas, Delhi.

[[Sundar Lal Khurana]]

CATEGORIES: Governors of Tamil Nadu, Lieutenant Governors of Puducherry, Lieutenant Governors of Delhi, 1918 births, Living people

Sundar Lal Khurana (born 10 November 1918)  is an Indian politician. He was the Lieutenant Governor of Delhi from 1981 to 1982, Lieutenant Governor of Pondicherry in 1984 and the Governor of Tamil Nadu from 1982 to 1988. He was a member of the Indian Administrative Service (IAS) and was Union Home Secretary.

[[M8 motorway (Scotland)]]

CATEGORIES: Motorways in Scotland

The M8 is a motorway in Scotland. It is very busy, and connects the cities of Glasgow and Edinburgh. It is about 60 long.

[[G. C. Murmu]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, Living people, Lieutenant Governors of Jammu and Kashmir

Girish Chandra Murmu (born 21 November 1959) is an Indian politician. He was the first lieutenant governor of the Union Territory of Jammu and Kashmir. He was a 1985 batch Indian Administrative Service officer of Gujarat. In October 2019, he became the Lieutenant Governor of Jammu and Kashmir.

[[List of lieutenant governors of Jammu and Kashmir]]

The Lieutenant Governor of Jammu and Kashmir is the head of state of the Union territory of Jammu and Kashmir.

[[R. K. Mathur]]

Radha Krishna Mathur (born 25 November 1953) is an Indian IAS officer of Tripura. In October 2019, he became the first Lieutenant Governor of the union territory of Ladakh. He retired as the Chief Information Commissioner of India (CIC) in November 2018.

[[Kalraj Mishra]]

He also was a Cabinet Minister of Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises. He was a member of Parliament from Deoria constituency in Uttar Pradesh from 2014 to 2019.

[[Banwarilal Purohit]]

Banwarilal Purohit (born 16 April 1939) is an Indian politician. He is the current and 21st Governor of Tamil Nadu since October 2017. He was appointed as Governor of Assam State by President of India on 17 August 2016.

He was a Member of Parliament from the Nagpur (Lok Sabha constituency) three times, twice as an Indian National Congress member, once as a BJP member.

[[M9 motorway (Scotland)]]

CATEGORIES: Motorways in Scotland

The M9 is a motorway in Scotland. It goes from Edinburgh to Dunblane. It is 33 long.

[[List of governors of Tamil Nadu]]

CATEGORIES: Governors of Tamil Nadu

The Governor of the State of Tamil Nadu is the constitutional head of the Indian state of Tamil Nadu. Like all states, the governor is nominated by the President of India.

[[P. S. Ramamohan Rao]]

CATEGORIES: Governors of Tamil Nadu, 1934 births, Living people

P. S. Ramamohan Rao (born 31 July 1934) is an Indian politician. He was the Governor of Tamil Nadu from 18 January 2002 to 4 November 2004. He became a member of the Indian Police Service in October 1956. He is a retired Director General of Police of Andhra Pradesh. 

He was awarded the Indian Police Medal in 1974 and the President's Police Medal in 1982.

[[Fathima Beevi]]

CATEGORIES: Indian judges, Governors of Tamil Nadu, 1927 births, Living people

M. Fathima Beevi (born 30 April 1927) is an Indian lawyer and politician. She was a Judge of the Supreme Court of India. In 1989, she became the first female judge to be a part of the Supreme Court of India,

She was a member of the National Human Rights Commission and later as the Governor of the Indian state of Tamil Nadu from 1997 to 2001.

[[M60 motorway]]

CATEGORIES: Motorways in England, Manchester

The M60, also called the Manchester Ring Motorway or the Manchester Outer Ring Road, is a motorway. It is a ring road around Manchester, England, as well as other towns nearby. The M60 is about 36 long. The M60 was created in 2000 by using old parts of the M62, M66, and all of the M63.

[[Tamilisai Soundararajan]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, Living people, Governors of Telangana

Dr. Tamilisai Soundararajan (born 2 June 1961) is an Indian doctor and politician. She is the 2nd and current Governor of Telangana since September 2019. She was a member of the Bharatiya Janata Party until September 2019.

[[List of governors of Telangana]]

CATEGORIES: Governors of Telangana

The Governor of Telangana is the nominal head and representative of the President of India in the state of Telangana. The Governor is appointed by the President for a term of 5 years.

Since 8 September 2019, Dr. Tamilisai Soundararajan is the Governor of Telangana.

[[E. S. L. Narasimhan]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, Living people, Governors of Chhattisgarh, Governors of Andhra Pradesh, Governors of Telangana

Ekkadu Srinivasan Lakshmi Narasimhan (born 1945) is an Indian politician. He was the 1st Governor of Telangana from 2014 to 2019. He also was Governor of Andhra Pradesh from December 2009 to July 2019 and Governor of Chhattisgarh from January 2007 to December 2009. 

He was the Director of the Intelligence Bureau from February 2005 to December 2006. 

Narasimhan was Governor for 12 years making him the longest-serving Governor in India.

[[M62 motorway]]

CATEGORIES: Motorways in England

The M62 is a motorway in Northern England. It connects Liverpool and Manchester with Leeds and Hull. It is about 107 long. Around seven miles of the motorway is shared with the M60.

[[Frosty (frozen dairy dessert)]]

CATEGORIES: Ice cream

The Frosty is the signature frozen dessert of Wendy's restaurants. The Frosty's original light chocolate flavor (a mix of chocolate and vanilla), was at first the only flavor offered. Wendy's founder Dave Thomas thought that a pure chocolate flavor would overwhelm the taste of the restaurant's hamburgers. In August 2006, a vanilla flavor was introduced after repeated consumer requests.

[[Ramesh Bais]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, Living people, Governors of Tripura

Ramesh Bais (born 2 August 1947) is an Indian politician. In July 2019, he became the 18th and current Governor of Tripura. He is a member of the Bharatiya Janata Party. He was a Union Minister of State (Independent charge) for Environment and Forests in Atal Bihari Vajpayee's government from 1999. He was elected to the Lok Sabha from Raipur.

[[D. Y. Patil]]

Dnyandeo Yashwantrao Patil (born 22 October 1935) is an Indian politician. He was Governor of Bihar state in eastern India from 29 May 2012 to 26 November 2014. He was a leader of the Indian National Congress from Maharashtra state. He was appointed as the Governor of West Bengal (additional charge). 

[[Siddheshwar Prasad]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, Governors of Tripura, Living people

Professor Siddheshwar Prasad (born 19 January 1929) is an Indian politician. He is a member of the Indian National Congress. He was elected to the Lok Sabha, lower house of the Parliament of India from the Nalanda Constituency of Bihar in 1962, 1967 and 1971. He was the Governor of Tripura from June 1995 to June 2000.

[[Anandiben Patel]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, 1941 births, Governors of Uttar Pradesh, Governors of Madhya Pradesh, Governors of Chhattisgarh, Bharatiya Janata Party politicians

Anandiben Patel  (born 21 November 1941) is an Indian politician. She was the former Chief Minister of Gujarat. She was the first female chief minister of the state. She was a member of the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) since 1987. She was the Cabinet Minister for Education from 2002 to 2007.

In 19 January 2018, she became the Governor of Madhya Pradesh replacing Om Prakash Kohli who was holding additional charge since September 2016.

In July 2020, she became Governor of Madhya Pradesh again.

[[Baby Rani Maurya]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, Living people, Governors of Uttarakhand

Baby Rani Maurya (born 15 August 1956) is an Indian politician. She is the seventh Governor of Uttarakhand since 26 August 2018. She started her political career with the Bharatiya Janata Party in the early 1990s. She was the first woman mayor of Agra from 1995 to 2000. From 2002 until 2005, she was on the National Commission for Women.

Jagdeep Dhankhar (born 18 May 1951) is an Indian politician. In July 2019, he became the Governor of West Bengal. He is a member of the Bharatiya Janata Party.

[[List of governors of West Bengal]]

CATEGORIES: Governors of West Bengal

The Governor of West Bengal is a nominal head and representative of the President of India in the state of West Bengal. He is the Head of State of West Bengal. The governor is appointed by the president for a term of five years. 

Jagdeep Dhankhar became the governor of West Bengal on 30 July 2019.

[[M. K. Narayanan]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, Living people, Governors of West Bengal

Mayankote Kelath Narayanan (born 10 March 1934) is an Indian politician. He was National Security Adviser of India from 2005 to 2010. Subsequently he served as Governor of West Bengal from 2010 to 2014.  From 2010 to 2014, he was the Governor of West Bengal.

[[John Hannah (actor)]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 births, Living people, Scottish movie actors, Scottish television actors, Scottish stage actors, Scottish voice actors

John David Hannah (born 23 April 1962) is a Scottish actor. He is known for his roles in Four Weddings and a Funeral (1994), Sliding Doors (1998) and The Mummy trilogy (1999–2008).

[[Kathryn Hach-Darrow]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 2020 deaths, American philanthropists, Businesspeople from Missouri

Kathryn "Kitty" Hach-Darrow (October 20, 1922 – June 4, 2020) was an American businesswoman. She co-founded the Hach Chemical Company in 1947 with her first husband Clifford C. Hach (pronounced hɑ:k). She was CEO of the Hach company.

Hach-Darrow was also the first woman director of the American Water Works Association, an international non-profit working for better water quality.  She was known for her philanthropic work.

[[Bucklin, Missouri]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Missouri

Bucklin is a city in Linn County, Missouri, United States. The population was 467 at the 2010 census.

[[Linneus, Missouri]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Missouri, County seats in Missouri

Linneus is a small city in Linn County, Missouri, United States. The population was 278 at the 2010 census. It is the county seat of Linn County.

[[Loveland, Colorado]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Colorado

Loveland is the Home Rule Municipality in Larimer County, Colorado, United States. Loveland is situated 46 north of the Colorado State Capitol in Denver and is the 14th most populous city in Colorado. As of the 2010 census the population of Loveland was 66,859. 

[[Duilio Arigoni]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Swiss chemists, Wolf Prize winners

Duilio Arigoni (December 6, 1928 – June 10, 2020) was a Swiss chemist. He was an Emeritus Professor at ETH Zurich. He worked on the biosynthetic pathways of many organic natural substances.

He was also a visiting professor at Harvard University and Cambridge University. He has worked as a professor at ETH Zurich for over fifty years.

Arigoni died on June 10, 2020 at the age of 91.

[[Giulio Giorello]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, People from Milan, Italian philosophers, Italian mathematicians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Italy

Giulio Giorello (ˈdʒuːljo dʒoˈrɛllo; 14 May 1945 – 15 June 2020) was an Italian philosopher, mathematician, and epistemologist. He was born in Milan. He taught physics and natural sciences at the University of Pavia, University of Catania, University of Insubria and the University of Milan.

He was also President of SILFS (Italian Society of Logic and Philosophy of Science).

Giorello died in Milan on 15 June 2020 from COVID-19, aged 75.

[[Marinho (footballer, born 1957)]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from pancreatitis, Deaths from prostate cancer, Brazilian footballers, Brazilian Olympians

Mário José dos Reis Emiliano (23 May 1957 – 15 June 2020), commonly known as Marinho, was a Brazilian professional footballer and assistant manager, He played for Bangu. He played as a right winger. He competed in the men's tournament at the 1976 Summer Olympics. He was born in Belo Horizonte, Brazil.

Marinho died on 15 June 2020 in Belo Horizonte from pancreatitis caused by prostate cancer, aged 63.

[[Anton Schlembach]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Italian Roman Catholics, Bishops

Anton Schlembach (7 February 1932 – 15 June 2020) was an Italian Roman Catholic official. He was the 95th Bishop of Speyer from 1985 to 2007.

On 25 August 1983 Pope John Paul II named him the successor to bishop Friedrich Wetter. He became the bishop on 16 October 1983 in the Speyer cathedral. Pope Benedict XVI agreed to his retirement, effective 10 February 2007.

Schlembach died 15 June 2020, aged 88.

[[Mike McCormick (pitcher)]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from Parkinson's disease, National League All-Stars, New York Giants (NL) players, San Francisco Giants players, Baltimore Orioles players, Texas Rangers players, New York Yankees players, Kansas City Royals players, Baseball players from California, People from Pasadena, California

Michael Francis McCormick (September 29, 1938 – June 13, 2020) was an American baseball pitcher who played 16 seasons in Major League Baseball (MLB). He played for the New York and San Francisco Giants, Baltimore Orioles, Washington Senators, New York Yankees and Kansas City Royals from 1956 to 1971. He batted and threw left-handed and served primarily as a starting pitcher.

McCormick died on June 13, 2020 in Cornelius, North Carolina from Parkinson's disease, aged 81.

[[Mohammad Asghar]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Welsh politicians

Mohammad Asghar (30 September 1945 – 16 June 2020) known as Oscar, was a Welsh politician.  He was a member of the Welsh Conservative Party, and of the Welsh Labour Party, and Plaid Cymru. He was elected to the Welsh Assembly in 2007 as a member of Plaid Cymru on the list for South Wales East. 

He is best known for being the first ethnic minority and Muslim Member of the Senedd, and being the first Assembly Member who was a member of a political party to defect to another party.

Asghar died on 16 June 2020 after being rushed to hospital in Newport, Wales earlier in the day, aged 74.

[[Fred Jarvis]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2020 deaths, British activists, Trade unionists

Frederick Frank Jarvis CBE (8 September 1924 – 16 June 2020) was a British trade union leader. He was President of the National Union of Students (NUS) from 1952 to 1954 and General Secretary of the National Union of Teachers (NUT) from 1975 to 1989.  

Jarvis was President of the Trades Union Congress in 1987. 

[[Harriet Jacobs]]

CATEGORIES: 1813 births, 1897 deaths, American abolitionists, African American writers, American autobiographers, Writers from North Carolina, Writers from New York, Slaves

Harriet Jacobs (February 11, 1813 – March 7, 1897) was an African American in the 19th century. She was born as a slave in North Carolina, but learned to read and escaped to the North in the 1842.

When she was still a girl, her master wanted to start a sexual relationship with her. She refused and entered into a relationship with Samuel Tredwell Sawyer. Sawyer was a lawyer and had some power to protect her. He became the father of her two children, Joseph and Louisa Matilda. Still, the law gave a master absolute power over a slave. Jacobs's master wanted to sell her children away from her. In 1835, she decided to hide in a small room in her grandmother's house. That room was so small that she could not stand up. She had to stay there for seven years. Because she could neither stand nor walk, she was suffering from leg problems for many years afterwards. In 1842, she was finally able to escape to Philadelphia by boat. From Philadelphia, she went to New York where she found work as a nanny for the children of Nathaniel Parker Willis. Also her brother John S. Jacobs and her children were able to escape from slavery.

While she was still working as nanny for the Willis children during the day, at night she wrote down her experiences. In January 1861, her experiences were finally published as a book called Incidents in the Life of Slave Girl, written by herself. After the American Civil War had started in April 1861, she went to Alexandria, Virginia. There she helped black people who had just escaped from slavery. She spent her last years in Washington, D.C. where she lived together with her daughter.

After the Civil War, the slaves were set free. The people of the United States lost interest in slavery and forgot Jacobs and her book. But in the second half of the 20th century, people began to show new interest in the history of slavery. Professor Jean Fagan Yellin did a lot of research work and wrote the book Harriet Jacobs. A Life. The Remarkable Adventures of the Woman who Wrote Incidents in the Life of a Slave Girl. Today, people call Jacobs's book an "American classic", meaning that it is one of the most important books written in the United States of America. 

[[Anastassia Zoubkova]]

CATEGORIES: Russian water polo players, Living people, Year of birth missing (living people)

Anastassia Zoubkova is a Russian water polo player. She was part of the Russian women's national water polo team. She participated at the 2003 World Aquatics Championships and 2004 Summer Olympics.
